And then, suddenly he turned around, and started to walk up to the middle of the kitchen again, towards the table, and where Mr. Smith moments ago was laying on the floor. “Uh, Mr. Smith?”, Tommy asked, while stepping closer to the kitchen table. “Mr. Smith!?”, Tommy yelled louder, “Did you go to the bathroom or something?”. While Tommy came closer, his view glanced a tiny little remaining ant on the white kitchen floor and he started to smile. “Yo Mr. Smith, there's one ant left in your kitchen, but don't worry, I'll take care of that pest.”

It all went so fast, that Mr. Smith couldn't even start to scream. The last thing he saw was the dirty sole of Tommy's right converse shoes, and then, nothing. His eyes shut, Mr. Smith suddenly noticed that he still had some kind of consciousness, was he alive? He tried to open, slowly, very slowly, his eyes and... what he saw sent a shock through his mind.

In front of him sat two teenage boys, two teenage boys he got to know earlier under the names of Mason and Tony. “Nooo...”, Mr. Smith silently screamed again. What he experienced moments before, the horror in his kitchen with Tommy, that was the nightmare, and he, he was still the size of half an ant in that flat with those three unknown teenagers. But what, where was he. Mr. Smith tried to move his right arm so he could scratch his head, but, nothing. His arm didn't move. Mr. Smith tried the same with his left arm... nothing, “What the...”, while trying to look to his left, Mr. Smith failed to do so too. But he was able to move his eyes just so far to the left, that he could see what was holding back his arm, and then he moved his eyes to the right, and then he started to scream.

Poor Mr. Smith just now realized, that he wasn't dead. That his nightmare wasn't far from over, and what happened to him. The careless step of Pete in the kitchen just moments ago didn't kill Mr. Smith. Actually Murphy's Law kicked in, again, and let one unlucky tiny little ant got stuck in the remains of a wad of gum. And now, Mr. Smith had no chance of escaping. His arms, his legs and even his head were glued deep into the gum. Forced to watch the two teenagers in front of him, all he could do now was listening to the sounds of the TV and the three boys, where one of them was having a wad of gum under his sneakers with a tiny little ant stuck in it.
111112222112112.title: Bryan remains stuck in the sticky wad of gum

choices: The broom.
The glue traps.
11111222211212.content:
Pete lead the way into the kitchen, intent on retrieving his drink. Mason wandered after, coming to a halt next to the doorway with an thoughtful expression as he scanned the discoloured linoleum flooring. Countless tiny ants scattered in fear at the arrival of these two gargantuan beings, including one unusual "bug" that froze in shock.

"Dude, they're everywhere. Shit...." Mason stated flatly. He had been in and out of the kitchen numerous times during the day, never looking at the floor long enough to notice the tiny creatures foraging for food. He frowned as he noticed how filthy the floor was. "This is gross."

Meanwhile, Pete lumbered across the floor, only half-listening to his roommate. His soda rested on the counter next to the dated refrigerator. After retrieving it, he sauntered back to Mason. "Yep, pretty damn messy." He idly sipped his frothing soda pop. "You should clean it up before it gets worse." Pete hinted, always glad to push chores off to someone else.

Pete gave an unconcerned grunt before lumbering back to the living room. The sound of the television called to him, and he was growing bored. He didn't notice the many ants he smashed under his sneakers as he left.

Mason scratched the back of his head. Like his buddies, Mason contributed to the current mess, adopting an "out of sight, out of mind" attitude. Unlike his buddies, he was grossed out by messes when finally confronted with them. His room was the tidiest out of the three, but only by a slight margin. Better late than never, he thought.

It was all just an inconvenience to him. Not appreciating just how huge and powerful he was to such minute creatures, Mason approached the pantry. The aged sliding door opened easily for him, presenting a view of the sparsely stocked pantry. A few cans of soup, boxes of cereal, a broom, and a few other household supplies sat before him.

Tapping his foot idly, he inspected a can of Raid, which proved to be empty. Next to it sat a box of glue traps that the landlord had left a few months ago, and a plastic-handled broom leaned against the wall. A small gnat peskily buzzed around his face as he considered.

A loud explosion from the television show caught his attention, and he looked back with annoyance at his two roommates sitting visibly in the next room. "Lazy bastards..." He muttered, and reached for...
11111222211212.title: Chores

choices: Continue sweeping
Do it later
111112222112121.content:
Broom in-hand, Mason turned around to give the kitchen floor another cursory scan.

From his perspective, he could see gross crumbs, dirt, and clods of mud on the floor. Tiny moving specks mingled in the filth. "Uh, yuck!" Mason scowled. Stepping forward he prepared to begin sweeping, bent on doing at least some good to the filthy apartment the three teenagers lived in.

Mason lifted his sneaker up, revealing the crunched remains of a pretzel. "Dammitt, Tony!" He glared at his seated buddy in the next room. Tony had spilled the bag of salty snacks a few weeks ago, and made a point of telling them that he cleaned all the pretzels up.

Starting with the crushed pretzel, Mason began sweeping.

---

"Oh, Dear God! No!" Bryan screamed at the sight of the humongous broom-wielding teenager.

Gigantic skate shoes large as mountains crashed heavily as the teen stepped away from the pantry. Like viewing a disaster movie, Bryan saw fleeing ants disappear under the giant sneakers. A sickening crunch shuddered through the tiny man's very bones.

"DAMMITT!" He managed to discern from the uproarious thunder that was the titan's voice.

The giant inspected what remained of the pretzel casually. His planet-sized face scowling with annoyance only made his towering visage more frightening.

"I need to get out of here before this blundering fool sweeps me up!" Bryan looked to and fro in desperate haste. His heart sank, realizing he was in the middle of the expansive floor, trapped. Trapped. The word seemed to echo through his mind.

Sudden movement ahead brought him back. The titanic youth was on the move, violently sweeping destruction in massive swatches with his deadly broom. Ants and crumbs alike were swept up in the thick bristles and deposited in a pile of dirt or mangled within the hard bristles. Any that didn't get caught by the gigantic broom were carelessly crushed by the enormous shifting skate shoes.

Another loud boom emitted from the behemoth teen's huge mouth. The words were indiscernible to tiny Bryan, who felt as if he had been caught in the apocalypse. Ants skittered around him in fearful frenzy. Following their example, the bug-sized man sped away from the oblivious giant, squealing and waving his arms.

"Shit!" Bryan face-planted in the dried remains of a flattened ant. "Wake up! Just wake up! It has to be a nightmare!" He cried.

As if to bolster Bryan's hysteria, the huge broom whipped by, scooping tiny ants and smashed crumbs into its dust-filled bristles. The tiny man cried out in shock and ran in the opposite direction. He was completely helpless. A broom larger than a small town thundered across the floor, piloted by a gargantuan teenager with little regard for anything tiny. Suddenly he was encompassed by a large shadow.

With enough force to throw Bryan back, landed one of the monstrous sneakers. The huge guy stood idle, glancing at his smart phone that vibrated in his pocket. Bryan only had eyes for the looming skate shoe. Unlike the other giant's footwear, this pair was less trashed, though still well-used from its tattered stitching and grime-covered sole.

"DCSHOECOUSA" Bryan mouthed the large brand name that was pressed into the hard rubber. An enormous DC logo was plastered on the suede of the sneaker, in splashes of white and camo, and towering many stories high. The black suede was discoloured with dirt, and he could see clumps of mud jammed in the thick lugs of tread. His stomach turned at the site of an ant, half-crushed, struggling vainly against the unfathomable weight pressing upon it.

Having survived this long, the tiny man needed to act before he was ended.

---

Chuckling at the clever picture his skater friend shared, Mason had halted his sweeping and stood with his phone in-hand. He was completely oblivious to the diminutive drama unfolding at his feet.

Smiling, the skateboarder looked away from his phone and frowned suddenly. "Ugh. This is fucking lame." Cursed the once-determined Mason. A whole six minutes had passed.

Halfway done, the swept floor looked better already. It was a lighter shade, closer to the original cream colour from so many years before. The unswept floor looked a sorry sight still, more so when compared. Mason hated cleaning. It was the main task assigned to him at work by his asshole boss.

Uncaring of anything at his large feet, Mason leaned against the nearby counter and propped his foot so the sole showed.

Scanning the room blankly, he decided to...
111112222112121.title: Broom Apocalypse

choices: Bryan has landed in the box!
Bryan is on top of Mason's shoe!
1111122221121211.content:
Mason sighed, there was no point in starting something if he wasn't gonna finish it!

"I sure as hell won't be the sucker to do this next time!" Mason vowed to the empty room. He scanned the kitchen floor, noting the patches he had missed. After pocketing his phone, he snatched the beat up broom and started sweeping haphazardly.

As he continued sweeping Mason noticed that in spite of his progress, there were numerous spots where the grime stubbornly remained in place. He brought the broom to the nearest such spot, and tried to use the bristles to remove it. He could feel the broom stick to the floor as he pushed it.

Mason let out a growl of annoyance. Someone had spilled who knew what and when it had dried, the sticky spill collected all sorts of refuse from the floor. Still glaring at the spill, he could see a couple of ants stuck in it. Sneering with disgust Mason lifted his shoe over the bugs. Utterly apathetic to their extended entrapment in the spill, Mason dropped his shoe down. He felt his shoe stick to the floor, more concerned with that minor annoyance than his callous extermination of the ants. Pulling his shoe free, Mason didn't give the ants a second thought, instead wondering what was on the TV.

Unwilling to miss more than he had to by mopping, Mason decided he had done the best he could with just sweeping. Snatching up the dust pan, he began sweeping up the pile of dirt and crumbs.

---

Bryan didn't wait to take advantage of the suddenly immobile giant. He immediately fled towards the looming counter as it was the only feasible shelter in any direction. A number of ants it seemed ad the same idea, and though they showed no interest in the tiny man, Bryan still made an effort to steer clear of the frightfully large insects.

A thunderous roar of disdain sounded from above. An ever curious man (as a scientist should be!) Bryan couldn't help but turn back to see what was going on, unconsciously slowing his pace as he continued to flee.

The mountain sized teen towered over the scene, his brow furrowed in annoyance. His eyes were grazing the floor, though his focus was more in the middle of the room rather than where Bryan currently was. Without warning, the cruise liner of a shoe lifted and swung towards Bryan with unsettling ease. Bryan screamed, picking up his pace again as the shoe landed on it's toe, the sole soaring above like a sheer cliff.

Bryan halts as he can't help but stare in stupor. Above him, the many crevices twisted together to form the company's logo in the dark tread. Crammed into seemingly every crevice was one type or another of debris. Near the toe were the pulverized, white crumbs of the pretzel so easily crushed. Higher where the arch of the foot would be, Bryan could see a disgusting dark mass that had been compacted tightly into the crevice. In a couple places he could see some surviving ants, hopelessly trapped in the grimy tread. They struggled fruitlessly, too simple to know of their inevitable end underneath the shoe of the oblivious giant.

A gusting sigh brings Bryan's attention up to the giant's face again. His expression is now one of defeat.

"He'll never be able to understand just how monstrous he is. He is so far removed from the world at his feet" Bryan thinks to himself. "And I've made myself a part of that world! One where I am among specks easily disposed of, often simply be being unnoticed!"

Bryan's heart skips a beat at the last thought. His entire time in the teenagers' apartment had been hell due to their lack of attention paid to the ground underfoot. Any attempts at contact had been complete failures, and part of Bryan had accepted these behemoths would do far more harm than good for him.

The towering shoe whisks away, landing on the floor with a resounding thud. The gigantic young man has resumed sweeping! Bryan had wasted precious time to escape deep in thought, and he remained out in the open!

He screams, resuming fleeing towards the base of the counter. The broom crashes down at random, it's rough bristles scraping the ground as it plows across the floor. As he is running, a small part of Bryan can't help but be baffled that a simple household chore had become a terrifying nightmare for him.

Having not been swept away, Bryan feels hopeful he will reach the counter unscathed. At precisely that moment, the broom slams down in front of him, eliciting an embarrassingly high pitched scream from the tiny man as he abruptly halts.The bristles bend under the pressure from the behemoth, but seem stuck to the floor. After a few seconds the broom lifts away, like a moving forest. Bryan can see ahead of him, amidst random crumbs and dust, a few ants appear to be trapped, struggling ineffectually to move.

He had been headed straight for that death trap! Ironically he had been saved by the broom wielding giant. He lets out a laugh, suddenly appreciative of the massive teen. Maybe he wasn't so monstrous!

BOOM Where there had been a group of defenseless bugs, there was now an island sized shoe firmly planted. Bryan stared in shock at the wall of rubber and suede that was starting to fray. A loud smack echoed across the expanse of the floor as the shoe ripped away. Bryan can see bits of grime raining down from the exposed sole. Even more disturbing is the brief view of ants, ripped in half between the sticky floor and filthy shoe sole.

Unconcerned with the tiny lives extinguished by his callous actions, the gigantic teen drops his foot to the ground behind Bryan. He wasn't even given an opportunity to further ponder the unknown power held by the enormous young man. Because before he could react a filthy, flat object descended from the sky. It was a dust pan, coated in a layer of grime and as expected, dust.

Bryan only understood the danger he was in a mere second before the bristles of the broom slammed into him.

---

Mason swept up the majority of the mess onto the dust pan, not bothering with the unavoidable line of minuscule dust. He fails to notice the tiny speck amongst the crumbs, dirt, and twisted hairs. He takes a couple steps towards the overflowing trash can. Deciding he would make it work, Mason dumps the dust pan. A swoosh followed by clattering as the dust settles amongst the trash signals success, though he misses the bit of dust that gently rains onto his shoe. Mason returns the broom and dustpan to the pantry, sliding the door shut once more.

Satisfied with a job well done, Mason pounds out of the room, unaware as ever of the helpless ants snuffed out by his careless steps.
1111122221121211.title: Swept Up in the Moment

choices: Bryan finds the formula!
Still nothing, but Bryan keeps digging
11111222211212111.content:
Bryan let out a whoop that was combination of fear and elation, as he slid forward uncontrollably. Though a harrowing experience, he couldn't deny the feeling that he was on some giant slide. He reached the end of the dust pan and hurtled into a free fall. All around him, massive debris rained downwards. Looking down revealed mountains of disgusting garbage, the nauseating smell threatening to overwhelm the tiny man. In spite of this Bryan is thrilled.

He is falling directly into the opened top of his crumpled box! Hitting the cardboard wall roughly elicits a grunt of pain from Bryan as he starts rolling down the incline towards the floor. He lands in a heap, on top of the dumped dust that had collected in the box. Looking up reveals the face of the behemoth as he leans away, disappearing beyond Bryan's sight. Quaking steps fade in both sound and intensity, signaling the giant's departure.

A feeling of calmness settles over Bryan, this ordeal would soon be over! He takes a deep breath that devolves into a coughing fit caused by the combination of stench and dust surrounding him. Upon regaining his breath, Bryan stands, looking around his warehouse like box. The thing sits at an angle so that the floor stretches upwards. The walls are buckled and deformed from when Mason had effortlessly ripped it open. The handkerchief is spread over the far corner, hanging over the top and out into the trash. His various supplies are half buried in the dust that had accompanied Bryan into the box.

He huffs in disappointment upon realizing the antidote is not on the surface. But Bryan remains hopeful, knowing he is so incredibly close to it, all he had to do was dig!
11111222211212111.title: Landing in the box

111112222112121111.content:
Tony, Mason, and Pete stare wordlessly at the screen from their seats. For the last hour they had been completely engrossed by a marathon of a mutual favorite show. On the table next to his recliner, Tony's hand rests on the final bite of his sandwich he had yet to finish off. He doesn't notice the stray ant that was exploring the hill of food. Pinching it between his fingers, Tony brings it to his open mouth.

A loud crash from the kitchen gets all three boys to jump, Mason literally out of his chair. "What the fuck was that?" Pete asks his voice tinged with confusion and fear. Tony shrugs, staring at the doorway that leads to the out of sight kitchen. Mason shrugs "Hell if I know bu-"

A thud sounds from the kitchen, followed by gasping breaths. "The fuck?" Tony breathes, closing the recliner and standing up, sandwich still in hand. He stomps towards the doorway, hunching his shoulders in preparation for whatever, or whomever, was in the kitchen. Mason and Pete follow just behind him.

Rounding the corner brings him a sight he would never forget. A pale, older man tiptoeing around the kitchen, avoiding the ants, mumbling apologies as he stares intently at the floor. In addition to that he is stark naked, and looks disheveled as though he had just survived in a forest.

"DUDE?!" Tony bellows, unable to react any other way. Mason sputters in confusion, and Pete hits the ground laughing hysterically. The man looks up at them in surprise, before his features twist into anger.

"YOU!!" he shouts pointing a finger, before jumping from the kitchen onto the carpet beyond the doorway. Tony stumbles backward away from the stranger, bumping into Mason who is still babbling incoherently.

"YOU MONSTERS EACH ALMOST FUCKING KILLED ME!!" the man shouted furiously. Tony doesn't respond, though his face clearly communicates his complete confusion.

The man let out a humorless laugh, "You don't even know!" he snapped, his voice quieter but still aggressive. "I was just a fucking bug in your kitchen, and you all tried to kill me!" he paused to breathe "Hell you didn't even have to try! Your careless steps were enough without any effort on your part!"

"Huh?!" Tony exclaims. Behind him Mason has grown quiet, and Pete is wheezing from his continued laughter.

"You guys are monsters!" the man growls. "Torturing and killing tiny bugs just because you're bigger and you can. Maybe even worse is that you're killing them just because you can't be bothered to see what's underneath your oversized feet!"

Tony stares at the man, unable to respond to his rant. Feeling the food in his hand, the one thing that made sense, Tony brings it to his mouth. If he was eating, then he didn't have to respond to the psycho in front of him.

As he pushes past his lips, the man lets out a disappointed howl. "Oh you eat them too!" he said, throwing his hands in the air. Tony chews and swallows his food. "What?!" he asks, his mouth gaping in confusion.

"It's not enough that you're annihilating them with your feet, you have to eat them too?!" the man shouts. "I can't do this, I need to leave!" he says taking a step forward. Tony tries to step backward, while Mason goes into defense mode behind him. The resulting collision, sends them both sprawling onto the floor.

The man scans the living room, "I'm taking this" he states bluntly, snatching up a threadbare blanket form the sofa and wrapping it around his naked form. Pete, who's laughter had subdued, descends into a fit of giggles. This was absolutely ridiculous.

"Good day, I hope I never see you monsters again!" the man said haughtily, before marching to the front door, wrenching it open, and loudly slamming it shut behind him.

The boys are left in shocked silence, aside from the sounds of the forgotten TV shows, and Pete's subsiding snickering.

"Should we call the police?" Mason finally asks. Tony is still sitting on the floor, frozen in shock.

Shaking his head, he faces Mason. "And tell them what? Some naked fag appeared in our kitchen, yelled at us and stole our blanket?" Mason's response was an incredulous shrug, while Pete literally started rolling on the floor laughing.

Tony felt a tickle on his hand, and noticed a single, brave ant crawling over it.

"Augh, fucking bugs!" he snapped, shaking it off and smashing it with his palm.
111112222112121111.title: Success!!!

choices: The ants take an interest in Bryan
Time to take out the trash
111112222112121112.content:
As if he were running against a clock, the search for his antidote continued with increasing impatience.

"It has to be here!" Bryan spat, pushing and digging through mounds of dust and dirt.

It seemed futile - so close, yet still impossible as the antidote remained lost to him. Grunting, Bryan moved on to another sections of seemingly endless dust dunes. He dug through the silty grime, uncovering large hunks of dried food, and unidentifiable wads of sticky gunk. Any calmness he felt before seemed to be quickly draining, as the tiny man felt desperation replacing it.

He slid over crumbled structure of paper half-buried in dark dust and resumed searching. Far off, Bryan could hear the dull roar of television accompanied by an occasional thunderous voice. Those damn teenagers remained completely oblivious to Bryan and his bug-sized plight. Frowning, he allowed these fuming thoughts to stoke his search, but in his fervor failed to notice the dusty soil beneath him shifting.

Suddenly, Bryan snapped from his jaded digging with a screech. "What the?" The ground beneath him shifted, and not a moment to soon Bryan rolled away just as two jagged mandibles rose out of the dust like a sea monster from the ocean.

"Holy Christ!" Bryan screamed again, backing up to distance himself from the angry bug.

The ant remained half-buried, thrashing a head large enough to crush Bryan like a kitten. With violent determination, the ant pulled itself out of the deposited dirt, clashing and clacking. The shrunken man gasped, realizing the large creature was missing two legs and appeared painfully twisted as it trundled away.

He realized many more ants were slowly excavating themselves from the devastation. Some that had already freed themselves were either attempting to escape, or searching the dusty dunes for others. It seemed reminiscent of the aftermath of a bomb. Ashen ruin all around, and the injured survivors pulling themselves free of the wreckage; it almost made the bug-sized man sympathetic for the unfortunate bugs.

But, he knew such thoughts were better left alone. Somewhere in this mess was his formula - a tiny bottle, no bigger than his palm, and hopelessly mixed with thousands of pounds worth of dirt and dust from the giant's floor.

He had to find it - before it was too late!
111112222112121112.title: Still nothing, but Bryan keeps digging

choices: Before any of the guys had woken up
After they had all left
1111122221122.content:
For over an hour, teeny Bryan Smith stood perfectly still underneath the colossal appliance. He was in shock at all he had just experienced. Some how he had escaped being crushed by the titanic BMX biker.

Besides occasional roaring laughter, or a deep shout from the living room, everything was still. His legs ached. Pangs of soreness rang through his body from all the sudden exercise he had been put through. Bryan had never bothered to keep himself in shape, it never seemed important until now.

Skittering shapes could be seen in the distance all over. The ants were returning now that the huge young residents had left. Some ants seemed to be inspecting their lost brethren. Spotting the floor, and especially visible near the fridge were the flattened splotches of these unlucky ants. It was unreal to him that all this death was nothing to the gigantic guys, only an ant infestation. The huge teenagers had no idea how destructive and cruel they were.

Bryan settled near a large metal column that supported the massive appliance. The powerful hum the fridge produced felt almost comforting.

He decided to rest, falling into a deep slumber.

-----

Mason had been the first to retire to bed at half past 12 am. He always fell asleep first.

Once the program ended, Pete yawned loudly, giving a dramatic stretch. "I'm going to bed." He proclaimed flatly and left.

Flicking through the channels with an idle expression, Tony stuck it out longer. He scratched his arm, not noticing the tiny ant that was sent flying by his fingers.

Nothing interesting appeared to him from the flickering screen. Clicking the device off, the young guy stood up, sweeping sandwich crumbs off his shirt. He stopped before the archway leading to the kitchen, his eyes blurry with sleep.

He considered grabbing something else to eat, desiring more fold solely from boredom. Tony didn't noticed a group of ants that hurriedly sped moving their purloined cheerio after seeing the gargantuan Tony stomp into view.

Yawning lazily, he decided against it and lumbered off to his room, his steps rattling the tiny inhabitants. Tony had no inkling that his minor decision spared the insignificant lives of many ants.

-----

All three teens fell fast asleep, allowing the shrunken scientist to get some needed rest. He awoke the next morning....
1111122221122.title: All quiet on the kitchen floor

choices: Escape!
Recover the antidote!
11111222211221.content:
With a jolt, Bryan returned to consciousness. He had been dreaming that none of this had ever happened, that his entire ordeal with the shrinking formula was just a dream itself...

The rumbling hum generated by the gargantuan appliance help set in the cruel reality. He was still smaller than an ant, resting under a refrigerator in a strange home occupied by unknown giants. Bryan covered his face with his hands, stifling a pathetic cry. It all seemed so hopeless. Looking up again, the huge expanse of kitchen floor only disheartened him further.

His make-shift resting spot didn't offer any consolation to the tiny man. Many years of collected dust now coated him, along with a foul scent that seemed to seep from the humming darkness above. He couldn't even find any edible food particles. Only some boulders, many larger than he was, and half a Cheerio that sported a mossy texture, were all that resided under the fridge. Further back into the darkness, what looked like a dead beetle sat like some forgotten memorial.

Bryan listened for any signs of the dangerous occupants. He proceeded out into the open floor with timid steps, his hands wringing nervously and his stomach feeling quite empty.

On the opposite end of the expansive space, a digital clock rested high on the wall. Bright red numbers read 6:58 AM, in the dimly lit room. The tiny scientist felt better knowing that the titanic teenagers would probably be asleep for many more hours. "It is now or never... I can't waste any time." He breathed, not thoroughly sure what his course of action would be.

"I should try and find a way out of this place..." Was his first thought, thinking back to how huge and oblivious the teenagers were. The layout of this apartment was unknown to him, and precious time would be wasted in exploring it. Looking up, he noted the lofty counter tops. "There is no way I could climb that height" He noted to himself. Trying to gain their attention from the floor was just suicidal. Hopelessness began to set in as he remained undecided.

Then his gaze drifted to the trash receptacle on the other side of the kitchen. It rested in the corner, at the end of the counter, looking filthy. This wasn't important to him. The crumpled remains of his cardboard haven caught his attention, resting precariously on the crest of a mountain of trash.

"The antidote!" Bryan had completely forgotten about the carefully formulated serum. This presented itself as a very possible salvation, since the trash bin itself was only half the height of the looming counters. New hope burning inside him, Mr. Smith began the long trek.

His progress was naturally slow, due to his size and restless sleep. Around him, the floor slowly began to re-populate with ants, ever ready to risk their lives for food. Bryan passed many dozens of flattened ants, pressed into almost unrecognizable splotches by the careless giants. He tried to turn his head away from the dried remains, but they seemed to be everywhere he looked. Bryan reflected grimly how close he had come to the same fate.

Nearing the end of the kitchen, he found himself an equal distance from the trash bin and the doorway leading out. The digital clock proclaimed the time as 8:49 am, so Bryan's time was wearing thin.

Should he try and escape, or attempt to recover his antidote?
11111222211221.title: Early bird

choices: To investigate the vending machine
Down the hall, towards the stairs
111112222112211.content:
This decision was possibly the most important he would ever make.

Ridiculous, he thought. He was bent on choosing between climbing a gigantic trashcan, or fleeing an apartment. Bryan pulled at his hair in frustration. Dirt and refuse had turned his usually groomed hair into a greasy mess. He wanted nothing more than to wake up in his bed, safe and normal, and destroy all of his research on this accursed formula.

Looking back up he noted the clock. "I've got to get moving!" He urged himself.

The mere thought of encountering one of the three giants that occupied this apartment made Bryan tremble. He had far too many close calls, and his luck surely wouldn't last forever. He also didn't see himself scaling the sheer side of the humongous trashcan to retrieve an antidote that may not even be there.

"That's it. I'm going to run..." He bit his lip. "What other choice is there? These blundering behemoths are far too dangerous!"

With that, tiny Bryan Smith sprinted towards the vast doorway leading out of the dingy kitchen. It took nearly 30 minutes, but he finally crossed the threshold of linoleum to carpet. Like the sticky linoleum, the carpet was a horrifying sight itself, displaying all signs of misuse and age. Stains, dried spills, and food smashed into the fibers made the floor a revolting display.

"Dear God, how can they live like this?"

Bryan set his sights on the front door. It was fortunately not far off, resting on the immediate wall to his left.

Sounds of footsteps, and rushing water alerted the tiny man that his time was short. At any moment an enormous teenager would come stomping out and cut his journey short. With this thought, he crossed the final stretch to the base of the massive door. The huge fixture towered a dizzying height, causing Bryan to marvel at the sheer size and power it would take to open. A thick weatherstrip lined the base of the door, worn and crumbling from age.

Approaching it slowly, he scanned for a possible gap or tear. At his size, the smallest split in the material might offer him passage. Lady Luck seemed to be smiling on him, as he discovered a spacious tear in the weatherstripping under the door that allowed him easy exit.

"That is probably how all the ants are getting in." He noted with an eye roll.

The hallway outside the teenager's apartment was like a whole new world. The air smelled less stale. No wandering aromas of dried food or sweat assaulted his nose. Dusty linoleum covered the floor, speckled with clods of mud and boulder sized pebbles all over.

He was no closer to salvation, but hope bubbled in his tiny heart nonetheless. "Now I just need a plan!"

Bryan turned his gaze, scanning for a destination.

To his left, the hall ended suddenly with a window, and a vending machine pressed against the adjacent wall. To his right, the hall stretched on and on. Other doors leading to apartments unknown lined the hall ending in what looked like a staircase.

Bristling himself, the bug-sized man went...
111112222112211.title: Change of scenery

choices: Investigate the strange box
Something happens
1111122221122111.content:
Now that he was safely out of the nightmarish apartment, Bryan decided that some investigating was in order.

Even the most mundane objects were awe inspiring at his reduced size. Bryan had experienced his fair share of dangerously large people, but he had hardly been given a chance to explore the world from an insect's view. The vending machine, already a looming monument from afar, looking quite interesting. His grumbling stomach also led him to hope there might even be some crumbs of food to eat.

Shaking off the last of his fears, the tiny scientist trotted towards the humongous machine. Not even halfway there, he noticed a loud looping hum emanating from the appliance. It seemed to resonate through his entire body in almost a lullaby melody.

"Damn..." He looked up in wonderment. Displayed beverages and candies sat in display upon the glass covered shelves. "The food and liquid in there alone is enough to end world hunger and thirst!"

Thoughts of this nature had helped spur his ambitions in developing the shrinking formula. He fancied himself winning a few dozen prizes and being praised as a paragon of humanity after unveiling the miraculous formula. These thoughts made him smile, but truthfully, Bryan had far more selfish desires at heart when creating his shrinking solution. These desires turned out to be far more dangerous as a reality, as evidenced by his life threatening experiences not even a day ago.

Unseen to the regular person, the underside of the vending machine was a sight to behold. Tangles of dust, hair, and dirt had collected under the machine in large amounts, all visible enough by the sparse light filtering in. Bryan quickly forgot these when he spotted a group of large crumbs.

"At least I won't be hungry when I go to get rescued!"

He had almost forgotten just how impossible it would be to find rescue at his size. Tearing a morsel free from a crumb larger than he was, he looked it over thoughtfully.

"Looks like graham cracker," He sniffed it. "Smells like it..." Timidly biting into the chunk, he chewed slowly. "Not too bad!"

Other oddities were strewn under the huge machine; Crinkled wrappers, a couple bottlecaps, and a pool of strange smelling liquid dripping from the vending machine itself. He noticed he wasn't alone either. Large beetles, or at least what he thought were beetles, seemed to favour the hospitable space. He noted a couple of dead ants laying near a box that sat just under the vending machine. A hole was poked into the side of the box, allowing entry.

Finishing his stale chunk o' crumb, he decides....
1111122221122111.title: The Vending Machine

choices: Is interrupted when somebody approaches
Finds the box to be an insect trap!
11111222211221111.content:
Bryan craned his head towards the box with an inquisitive expression,

"I wonder what that could be..."

The box looked sizable enough, easily large as a suburban home. Darkness made any writing or illustrations on the packaging unintelligible to the already near-sighted man. Bryan continued his leering squints, noting any possible dangers--something he had been forced to become quite adept at.

"Looks safe enough, can't hurt to check it out." He convinced himself.

The underside of the utterly massive vending machine cast a great shadow over the landscape, creating an almost segregated world for the tiny man. Low, yet strong, the machine released an electronic hum that was almost soothing to tiny Bryan.

Nearing the large box, Bryan was startled by a loud commotion from down the hall. He saw the distant form of a person exiting their apartment and heading towards the staircase at the other end of the hall. Returning to his investigation, he passed two dead ants, cringing at their grisly greasy bodies, and stopped before the gaping hole punched into the side of the box. Large clumps of dust spotted the dark interior, as well as stray crumbs.

It also smelled. "...some kind of chemical scent" Bryan noted with a wrinkled face.

Preparing to enter, Bryan...
11111222211221111.title: Tiny curiosity

choices: Tiny man falls asleep, but someone arrives to check the box
Tiny man falls asleep before he can escape the box
111112222112211112.content:
Something nagged at his brain, warning him to keep his distance. At the same time, what harm could a little peek inside do?

The strong chemical odor intensified once he pushed through the gaping hole in the house-sized box. The chemical smell irritated his eyes and throat. As he plunged ahead, deeper into the spacious interior, he noticed the crumpled heaps of insects where they had fallen and...

He kicked at a dead ant. It was dead, but he didn't see any injuries. Farther into the box, he found a small, dark beetle, on its back, six stiff legs in the air.

"I wonder what..." the tiny began when his vision went blurry and he almost fell. He grabbed one of the spiky beetle legs to balance himself. His head was spinning. The cloying chemical scent began to seem overwhelming.

And then it snapped into place.

The chemical scent... it must be a subtle, slow-acting toxin.

"I've got to get out of here," the shrunken scientist said.

He turned, but the torn entrance into the box wavered in front of him. He staggered a few feet, but then he sank down to his knees. "Got...to...keep...moving..."

But the chemical began to overwhelm him, robbing him of mobility.
111112222112211112.title: Trap

choices: The giant janitor looks closer, noticing one survivor in the trap
The giant janitor decides to dispose of the trap
Bryan decides his own fate
1111122221122111121.content:
The air felt thick as soup, slowing Bryan's progress towards the exit as if he were wading through water. He blinked. Light filtered in, becoming dimmer as each moment ticked on.

"No...dammit...no..." He gurbled, lips and tongue feeling heavy. "...just gotta...gotta...get..."

Suddenly, Bryan was on his knees. He couldn't figure out how or when, but then his head lurched as if he had fallen asleep momentarily. Alarm spread through his mind like wildfire, yet his body felt numb and heavier than lead. He needed to escape. The exit was right there...or was it?

He couldn't see it anymore. Everything was dark and whatever he could discern seemed hazy, like a gauzy filter from an old movie had been put over his vision. "Sh-shi-....shhhhiiiiiittt....." He said. Barely a murmur, but using the last bit of cognitive strength before he flopped forward.

Completely blank dreams overtook him. Nothing, like a surgical sleep before waking what felt like mere moments later.

This wasn't that, Bryan realized as everything shuddered with the force of a distant bomb. Sticky, congealed vomit had pooled around his head, jellifying both hair and skin to the oily surface beneath. Bryan extracted himself with a groan. His body felt immobile -- filled with sand and sorer than any after-gym experience had ever left him. Another earthquake rattled beneath, shortly followed by a distant boom. It made Bryan think a building had collapsed. Was World War III happening? He gasped, but looked around again, peering through a roughly hewn portal that looked out upon a massive world. Something moved out there...a person?

He had shrunken! And....and....the poison! This strange space -- smelly, oily, and dark -- was that fucking bug motel he blundered into before collapsing. Bryan gasped again, pulling himself up. That thing outside wasn't a person; but an ant!

The earthquake returned once more just then, rattling Bryan who had just begun shambling for the exit. Instead, the tiny man watched as something too big to comprehend rushed across the visible terrain outside. Redwood sized stalks of black, rough and matted, swept over debris and ant leaving only microbial bits behind. Bryan screamed, confused. What was happening? What was that?

Again it returned, rushing past with hurricane force and thundering noise before leaving. Then the endless world darkened, reminding him how a huge cloud might shadow the earth. Unlike those peaceful memories, this cloud fell with such concussive result that Bryan was thrown to the ground, squishing into the cold vomit. Colossal mass of dirty, scuffed black rubber filled the view outside the box. Deep noise emanated, the vast dirt-stained surface shifted with intimidating effect that made Bryan feel thankful for his cardboard haven, no matter the poison. More noise filled the air with roaring notes of deep-toned squelching that caused the shrunken man's skin to goose pimple. It lifted and was gone, followed moments later by a deep quaking crash.

He held his breath, never considering the absurdity of it as he felt consecutive quakes. Outside, the vast landscape was riddled with chunks of dirt and chalky boulders once more, left behind by that enormous mass.

What was going on? Bryan's genius mind felt cloudy, intoxicated by whatever normally benign poison was contained within this horrid trap. Nothing made sense. This all felt like some weird dream still. He had been lucky to have survived it, but he needed to get out before it got worse.

Before any action could be taken, it returned. Bryan braced himself with a terrified yelp, roughly jarred as the incomprehensible mass crashed landed outside. The muffled sounds of it returned as well, groaning and compressing like some vast industrial structure against gravity. Bryan felt a burst of foolish bravery hit him, compelling him to rush outside and face it. It struck first.

They appeared like vast heavenly pillars...no...towers belonging to some mythic god. It hit Bryan like a brick of ice, rushing with memories of everything that happened before. The tribulations he had experienced at the hand of those giants. "Oh, god. Giants..." Was all he could muster as he realized the enormous towers were fingers. Huge fucking fingers; and headed straight for him! Most left his vision as they neared, thudding against the ground sluggishly, like massive monuments collapsing. Contact resulted in one tiny man being flung inside as the entirety of the gigantic bug motel was pulled from beneath the vending machine and lifted into the heavens.

It was like some adrenaline junkie's wet dream: rough swaying, rocking motions accompanying intense G-force and wind that combined induced extreme vertigo. Some kind of vast, sheer enormity rushed past, dark material and stitching barely discernible. All the tiny, terrified scientist could do was serenade the heavenly rapture with a scream that was anything but angelic. Ghastly, blood-curdling terror. All of which went silent as something new encompassed his view outside.

The ride subsided, his teeny stomach swaying thankfully inside and vertigo subsiding, allowing Bryan to gaze out at the eye of God looking right at him.

"Oh-oh my...God!" He tried to stand, but instead dry heaved. The floor rocked and swayed roughly, making it hard for him, but the stubborn man gazed out.

It was beautiful and yet existentially terrifying at the same time. He felt like it was consuming him, dissolving his very being like the fool Icarus who drifted too far from the mortal realm. Dark black waters seemed to swell, bits of what seemed like significant chunks of dust and debris tainting it, swirling around as the entire mass pulsed and contracted. Beyond this darkness was a vivid paradise of warm hazel and greenish tides. Bryan couldn't even look upon it wholly. It was a literal ocean. Suddenly, a low, almost watery, rushing sound interrupted and the vast eye was overtaken by a wave of towering trees followed by oily, bumpy flesh. It impacted a similar mass with a muffled thud and violently retracted, washing back over the watery ocean and out of sight. Bryan just screamed, tepidly moving forward as he vocally vied for rescue.

It seemed sacrilegious even to the normally agnostic Bryan, like an affront to God. Was he looking at God?

By all rights, it seemed only God could be this imposing and powerful, and in agreement to that thought, this god began rattling the bug motel with cruel impunity. Bryan screamed, impacting a larger deceased denizen of the bug motel before he flung towards the entrance, barely locking fingers against the rough side to avoid falling. The vast space outside gusted happily to greet him. Humid, smelly winds rushing through his thin legs while Bryan gaped downwards. He could see dark, ragged towers stretching down to huge filthy black work boots. Vertigo shot through like a fiery harpoon. The boots were planted like mountains over the grimy linoleum floor. A tiny black ant could be seen veering past the toe of the right boot, reminding Bryan that the floor below was much more a vast landscape than it appeared.

A fucking god dressed in utility pants and work boots. Who was he? Some kind of maintenance worker? Did this guy even graduate highschool? All he had done was pick up a cheap bug motel; nothing more. Holding Bryan's tiny, seemingly insignificant, yet still-human life like some celestial creator and arbiter; and the big guy had no fucking idea.

It had only been mere seconds, yet it was enough to put Bryan into an existential crisis.

Bryan pulled himself back in. His breath quick and short, following the rhythm of his heart and his mind a flurry. The massive bug motel swayed again, jolting Bryan from his thoughts as the unfathomably huge man stirred the bug trap again and peered inside. Had he noticed Bryan? He couldn't even see this behemoth's face, much less comprehend him or his enormity. Was contact possible?

"Oh, please! Please, help me!"
1111122221122111121.title: The Janitorial God

1111122221122111122.content:
The air seemed to become thicker than soup. Bryan's vision blurred and his head pulsated.

"Ugh... almost... there..." Still on his knees, he was barely afforded the ability to reach his arm out and grasp pitifully towards the exit. "...Damn...it...."

His whole body seemed to act against him; refusing to move at his command. The space seemed to be growing dimmer - the exit vanishing with it - and Bryan muttled a faint squeak. His eyes closed and his head sagged heavily as he slumped over, unconscious.

Bryan was as helpless as the insects the trap was intended for. He lay there, twitching and turning a ghastly green while the toxins took their toll upon his weak body.

The entrance of another hapless victim, who thrashed and grunted violently upon realizing the danger, failed to wake tiny Bryan. His suffering didn't last long--ending a short time later when his twitching ceased and after all he had been through: he fell still.

---

To any normal human being, the tiny palm-sized box looked no more threatening than a stick of gum. In fact, the colourful design splayed across all sides of the box read, "Non-toxic! Safe for use around pets and children!" This of course was true for anyone but a bug-sized man; who had less resistance to the poison than some insects.

Sam, the apartment building's very own janitor and maintenance guy, appeared a few hours later. His uniform consisted of dark coveralls, gloves, work boots, and a backwards cap.

By far, he wasn't the most thorough (or hard-working) guy. Evidenced by the buildings faulty electricity, scuffed floors, and creaking stairs. The insect problem, now plaguing most of the tenants, was all but ignored by him--who instead placed a few traps, sprayed some Raid, and told the tenants to do the same.

With his tool belt, supplies, and a trashbin, Sam had been cleaning along the hallway for almost an hour before he reached the vending machine. He brought his broom around the edge of the humming machine. Bits of dust and crumbs swept out, including unsuspecting ants that were scattered on the floor near the janitor's heavy boots. Boredom and routine made his mind numb while working, and Sam swept it all into a loose pile. He was just finishing when he noticed the small shape of the box beneath the vending machine.

"'Bout time I checked these things," He said, crouching down to retrieve it. "Let's see how many it caught..."

He had poked the hole through the cardboard himself, using a screwdriver. Bringing it up to his scruffy face, he squinted at it with a frown, unable to peer through the tiny hole to see inside. Instead, he brought it up to his ear and gave it a little shake.

"Sounds like I got a few in there!"

The small box was easily smashed in his hand. Crunching into an unrecognizable clump, effectively obliterating the deceased occupants. Oblivious and uncaring, Sam tossed it into the wheeled trashbin and returned to his cleaning, mentally noting the need to place another one later.
1111122221122111122.title: Laid to Rest

choices: Bryan attempts to be seen
Something falls under the vending machine
11111222211221112.content:
Heavy rhythmic pounding alerted Bryan, who turned to watch from beneath the humongous vending machine.

Huge feet clad in dirty white socks stomped towards the machine. Bryan steadied himself from the powerful vibrations as the feet neared. They came to a halt before the machine facing it.

Instinctive fear took hold of the tiny man. Fear that had been learned from his life threatening encounters with giants. He gawked at the gigantic socked feet; Shifting slightly, the toes raising up and down, one slightly visible through a worn spot. Frayed denim covered the towering legs, but past the tops of his feet, Bryan could see no more of the mysterious giant.

A loud sigh sounded from above. Noises that indicated the enormous man was working the machine could he heard.

Bryan couldn't get himself to move. All his blissful curiosity had melted away, leaving him a petrified man no larger than an insect. He wanted rescue, but the thought of running out there was too much.

Two ants scurried past one of the massive feet, tiny as specks in comparison. He envied their foolhardy courage as they went on their way, unnoticed by the busy giant.

"I can't just stay under here! He can help me, I just need to be discovered." He told himself, though not believably.

Peering out from under the safety offered by the vending machine, Bryan gazed upwards. If he was to run out and risk his life, he wanted to know who he would be encountering.

Squinting at the dial pad on the machine, the gigantic man noticed nothing on the floor below. He had short dark brown hair with the same dark colour stubble covering his jaw. A white t-shirt with some band logo covered his torso, and he wore wrinkled jeans. His mouth opened into a gaping yawn as he clumsily punched in a code for the machine.

It looked as though he had just gotten out of bed, pulled on some jeans and left his apartment without even putting shoes on. He looked far older than the callous teens from before though.

"It is still early..." This guy didn't seem likely to notice him in such a groggy state.

Still watching the huge titan, Bryan debated what he should do next.
11111222211221112.title: A possible saviour?

choices: Bryan attempts to get the man's attention.
Bryan hitches a ride via socked foot.
111112222112211121.content:
Bryan considered his options. He would never get help by just staying under this vending machine. Sure, there was a lot of food here, so he'd have some sustenance, but that would only last so long, and who knows how many bugs were living under here.

Bryan decided to leave the cover of the vending machine, and began running towards the impossibly huge man standing before the snack-dispensing skyscraper. The enormous socked feet of the giant guy were planted in front of the minuscule scientist. He ran and ran until he was near the smallest toe, concealed by what seemed like extremely thick cotton.

Bryan stared straight up, and instantly felt like he was standing at the bottom of the Empire State Building. He was reminded of why he had decided to make the shrinking formula in the first place; for perspectives like this one. It was so entirely fascinating. Everything looked so different, and despite being so vulnerable, it was a sight to behold.

Then, though, Bryan did realize just how vulnerable he was, standing directly in front of a huge foot. He knew that he needed to act, and he needed to act quickly, in order to ensure his preservation and eventual restoration to his original height.

There we two choices he foresaw. One, he could try his best to get the giant's attention before he left the dirt-covered hallway. It seemed unlikely, seeing as the giant man was preoccupied with getting his early morning snack. But, Bryan thought maybe punching the toe in front of him might illicit a response.

The other choice was to hitch a ride on the socked foot. The cotton provided many hand holds, so Bryan would have no difficulty in holding on. Then, the giant would carry him to his apartment, where Bryan could formulate a more secure plan for getting the guy's attention. The only con to this option was that he would lose his guarantee of food under the vending machine...but it did provide a longer window of getting the guy's attention than the next few seconds he would be standing here.

Bryan pondered, the time for making the choice quickly running out.
111112222112211121.title: Bryan attempts to be seen

choices: Lucky stomp!
Unlucky stomp!
1111122221122111211.content:
Bryan pinched his nose, grunting with disgust.

"God almighty, the smell..." He felt saturated by the stink just standing near the huge socked feet. It seemed as though the socks hadn't been cleaned for days, evidenced by dirt stains and sweat.

Loud clanking that resounded through the ground alerted the tiny man. He watched a huge hair covered arm, thick with decent muscle, retrieve an enormous bottle of orange juice. There looked to be enough frothy orange liquid in there to fill an ocean.

Bryan feared for a moment that his chance had gone, and the giant would leave. This proved otherwise, as the giant container of juice was set nearby on the ground as the titanic man began browsing for more edible goods. Looking back to the humongous socked foot before him, Bryan considered.

It was unimaginable in size. Easily larger than any battle ship, or commercial ship, the size was positively daunting. Gigantic toes concealed by sock shifted idly, curling and lifting at random. The ground trembled as the other foot lifted, shifting slightly in position as the huge stranger browsed. Despite threading that provided large enough gaps for the minuscule man to climb with, Bryan felt it would be pure folly to try scaling it.

He looked over at a sizable hole in the thick material, exposing an entire toe almost. "I could get his attention right here and now," Bryan considered, mapping out a plan. "He would have to feel me if I touched his bare toe!"

Gulping nervously with his plan in-mind, Bryan approached the massive toe. The white sock has been worn down, the threads breaking enough to allow his middle toe to be visible. Such a tear would of bothered tiny Bryan to no end in his own socks, but this gigantic man didn't seem to care. This apathy was an opening for potential rescue.

----

Chris let out another gaping yawn, his eyes blurry with grogginess.

His girlfriend had nudged him awake that morning. Insistent nudges coupled with whines of, "I'm hungry", "Go get something", finally found result. The 25 year old rose from the bed, yawning and scratching. Rumbles in his midsection agreed with his girlfriend. He pulled on a t-shirt and his jeans and left their apartment. Despite being almost noon, Chris planned on sleeping in late today with his girlfriend. He worked late last night and such a rest was well earned.

Lumbering out the front door, he headed towards the vending machine at the end of the hall. His filthy socks slapped the linoleum floor heavily, picking up more dirt on his large sole.

He had tapped in a three-digit code, buying himself a bottle of orange juice. That suited him just fine, but his girl asked for one of the pricier drinks. A single dollar remained in his wallet, that he stared blankly at still half-asleep.

Up to that point, he had no thought or regard of anything at his feet. Something as small as an ant would be nearly invisible to him, as well as insignificant. Slight tickling sensations bothered his right foot, which he shifted without thought. Moments later it persisted, prompting Chris to glance downwards in annoyance.

He pulled his foot back a bit, wiggling the offending toe that peeked from a tear in his sock. Chris grumbled with annoyance. Ignoring it, he reached into his pocked, feeling for the change he put in there a couple days ago.

Suddenly, the sensation returned. "What the hell?" Chris muttered in a deep, groggy voice. His bleary gaze returned to the floor.

A tiny, barely noticeable speck scuttled away from his shifting foot. He glared at it, realizing it was a stupid ant. Without much thought, he raised the harassed foot over the pesky bug.
1111122221122111211.title: Insistent bug

11111222211221112111.content:
"WHAT THE HELL?" Roared a groggy voice above.

Bryan back away in alarm as the unfathomably huge sock lifted suddenly.

All his experiences in the den of huge teenagers suddenly returned to him. "Oh God, no!" He looked up at the mammoth foot hovering above.

The word "HANES" was visible in large red stitching directly above. Dirt and crumbs covered the moist sole. Bryan saw a single ant, smashed almost beyond recognition on the ball of the foot. He shrieked for mercy, incredulous at his own stupidity.

Without remorse, the enormous foot descended. Bryan's last thought was one of disgust at the hideous smell given off the gigantic man's feet.

-----

"Damn, this place is infested..." Grumbled the bleary-eyed man, his dirty socked-foot raised.

His foot came down with a heavy thump! Dragging his foot back, he frowned at the sight of two other ants scurrying under the vending machine. Chris was anything but squeamish. His foot shifted, preparing to erase these newcomers in the same fashion. They vanished into the thin gap provided by the machine, safe from harm.

Chris stifled a strong yawn and returned his attention to more important matters. He studied the selection of quick snacks offered by the vending machine, trying to decide what his girlfriend would want.

"Tea. Maya would want tea..." Chris mumbled. Sliding the change pulled from his jeans, he clumsily punched the code in. The plastic container shifted and dropped into the chute loudly. Chris grabbed it and smiled at the container of green tea. "Perfect."

Ready to return, he blindly reached down for his orange juice. Instead he knocked the juice over, cracking the cheaply-made bottle cap. Cussing, he quickly grabbed it before more than a thumb-sized puddle could be lost. Both containers in hand (one dripping) the young guy stomped back to his apartment. Maya stood in the kitchen, nightgown covered with a robe, cooking eggs. She cooed happily at the sight of the tea and pecked him on the cheek.

Chris grinned, seating himself on the couch and propping his feet on the table. Filthy socks with soles coated in dirt, lint, and a few mashed ants were conformed around his size 12 feet. He sighed, resting his head back and taking in the smell of cooking eggs.

The ant he flattened never entering his mind again as he relaxed.
11111222211221112111.title: Infested

choices: To wait for the giant to leave
Something else
11111222211221112112.content:
Bryan had been insistent on getting the attention he deserved.

His tiny hands scraped and scratched at the monolithic toe before him. A loud rumble from above shook him.

"WHAT THE HELL?" The groggy voice roared from high above.

The tiny man squeaked. Memories of eerily similar experiences came to him. "God, wait I am not a bug! Wait!"

Unfazed by his diminutive cries, the enormous socked foot lifted suddenly. Bryan's eyes went wide with terror at such a sight. He saw crushed crumbs, splotches of dirt and even an utterly flattened ant on the ball of the sock. In red stitching, the brand name "HANES" stood out on the filthy sole. Staring dumbly, the shrunken man shook himself into action and bolted with flailing arms.

Looming above, the huge toes stretched idly and the foot descended.

----

"Aw, fu-... Shit!" Chris was groggy and rather unbalanced, causing his body to stumble and knock into his juice.

Quickly steadying himself, the young guy groaned at his fallen orange juice. The lid, cheaply made in China, had cracked and precious swallows of his beverage leaked onto the dirty floor. He bent and picked up the bottle. Gazing at it sadly through bleary eyes, he noted that a good quarter had spilled.

Cussing softly, he glanced back to the ground. The pesky ant was gone, fleeing like the lucky bastard that it was.

He had half a mind to grope for it under the large machine, but figured that would be a little silly. "Stupid ant..." Chris muttered scornfully. He turned his gaze back to the snack items scratching himself idly.

A bottle of green tea caught his gaze. "Tea. Maya likes tea..." He yawned, attempting to stifle it but failing. With the extra change he discovered, Chris purchased the expensive drink with a jump due to the loud clang when the drink dropped into the chute. "Perfect..." Sighed the young guy, holding both his juice and his girlfriend's tea in-hand.

Unknown to Chris, the "stupid ant" watched in fear from under the vending machine.

Bryan decides...

No! Bryan decides against it
111112222112211121121.content:
"What the hell was I thinking running out there?" The tiny scientist mumbled to himself harshly.

The man stood close, huge and terrifying. A rank stench drifted from his monster-sized feet clad in dingy socks. One of the gigantic socked feet shifted, sending a noticeable shudder through the floor. Bryan couldn't believe he survived. He was so tiny, and the young man was so impossibly huge.

"I have survived worse," Bryan said. "I should of known better..." He felt hopeless. Telling himself to not try for help was more than disheartening. Tears welled in his eyes. Bryan sniffled and wiped them away.

He looked back to the humongous man, who seemed to be more than a little groggy. Despite his incredibly close call, Bryan felt a twinge of excitement looking at the massive human being. More scandalous thoughts began to enter his mind as he leered at the giant man's form, taking in his muscled arms covered in dark hair, and his dangerously large feet.

The man raised a hand to his mouth, stifling a monstrous yawn. Bryan gawked slack-jawed. With slow, but smooth motions the giant shifted and stomped away. His huge feet raising and slamming down with powerful concussions. Glimpses of his filthy sock soles were given, reminding Bryan of his close call. He would of been flattened underneath the humongous foot, and the gigantic owner--thoughtless to just how huge and dangerous he was--would of been none the wiser that Bryan was anything but a pesky bug.

Bryan felt a pang of regret when the gargantuan guy lumbered back to his apartment, vanishing from view with a slam of the door.

Far back out into the open floor, Bryan noticed a clumpy lake of spilled juice. "What a callous slob... He just left it there for somebody else to clean!"

Then his stomach gurgled. The orange pulp alone would be as large as he was. It would more then suffice as a meal, and then some. The shrunken scientist was not alone in his observations; scuttling ants began to approach the juice pool already.

Wringing his hands, Bryan considered. Should he go for it?
111112222112211121121.title: Stay hidden

choices: Bryan chooses one of the doors
Bryan continues down the corridor
1111122221122111211212.content:
Biting into his lip, the shrunken scientist tore his gaze from the tempting lake of spilled juice.

"No, no! I can eat all I want when I am rescued. I don't have time for this!" He scolded his grumbling stomach.

Since this whole misadventure began, Bryan found himself speaking his thoughts aloud more often than not. This, coupled with his frequent bouts of hysteria, made him concerned for his mental well-being.

"I really need to get help..." He began, but stopped realizing he spoke out loud again.

A hefty crash sounded from a distance, alerting tiny Bryan. He peered out into the spacious hallway, spotting the source of the calamity. A single giant appeared from one of the doorways, lumbering with a powerful, sluggish gait. With a grunt, the titan pulled a bicycle through the door behind him and slid a backpack over his shoulders before stomping down the hall.

Bryan watched - looking the young titan over as he moved. He looked familiar. The tiny man watched the enormous shoes lift and slam into the ground heavily every step. With a jolt, he realized this was the same frightening giant from before that attempted to extinguish Bryan under his huge dirty sneaker. This time, the gigantic youth was heading away, taking his large and dangerous feet with him.

Bryan let out a sigh, relieved when the giant vanished at the end of the hall. He knew one thing: There was no way he was going back there!

After all, he appeared to be stranded in an apartment complex. There had to be dozens of potential liberators that didn't include the careless teenagers. All he had to do was make himself known as anything but an insect.

The mere thought conjured memories of his numerous close-calls. His body tensed in response, as well as ached.

So far, all Bryan's attempts had resulted in disastrous failure. Worse than disastrous, in fact, all nearly resulting in the poor man's demise! They would of murdered him and not even known it!

"Next time will be different... I am a human being," Bryan stated, trying to build himself up. "A genius! This break-through is too valuable to die with me!"

Once more, he was shouting out loud and welling up with emotion. Instead of calming himself, an errant ant came bustling by and knocked the tiny man over as it passed. Bryan yelped, fearing his end had come in the form of a lowly ant.

The hulking bug thought differently and continued without remorse, leaving the self-important man behind.

"Damn bugs!"

That said, Bryan bolted upright and began running. He made incredibly small progress, but eventually put some distance from the looming vending machine towards the doors.
1111122221122111211212.title: Food can wait

Bryan falls off!
1111122221122111212.content:
Bryan covered his nose, suddenly realizing the assaulting stench that emanated from the cotton-clad mountain before him.

"Holy Christ! That is damn near poisonous!" The tiny man squinted and puckered his face, waggling a hand uselessly.

He had been so preoccupied with the intimidating view, that the putrid odor had gone unnoticed. Now that he smelt it though, there seemed to be little else to breathe.

"BETTER GRAB SOME TEA..."

Bryan clutched over his ears with a squeak. The thunderous voice seemed to boom against the ground with such power, that his whole body rattled. High above, the giant punched the dial pad with a building-sized finger. His planetary face showing an expression of grogginess and boredom. Completely above noticing some as tiny as Bryan, the monolithic man jabbed one last number before planting his meaty thumb over the "enter" key.

Loud clunks, clanks, and a final thud made Bryan jump. He realized his window of opportunity was closing - fast! The giant would retrieve his tremendous beverage and leave... without Bryan! One last look above, Bryan turned his attention to the living mass of cotton looming before him.

Thick woven strands spanned the massive surface, creating treacherous ravines between each weave. Across this filthy surface jutted many loose strands, most within easy reach. Higher up, many spots looked threadbare and allowed the bug-man to see the enormous shifting toes hidden beneath.

"I can't believe I am going to... Oh, dear! Here goes nothing!"

Steeled for this next adventure, Bryan leaped and latched onto a loose thread. He quickly scrambled against the woven surface, pulling himself higher and higher. Barely a minute went by, giving the tiny man only a slightly better position on the mountainous small toe. Bryan looked above and saw the giant man's tanned, hairy arm reaching overhead, loudly pulling a tower of iced tea from the machine depository.

Then began the ride of his previously sheltered life.

"Shiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiit!" He dug his thin arms into the threading, closing his eyes tight.

THOOM.

If he had ever been passenger on a falling meteor, Bryan could be certain this was far worse. The impact of the colossal foot was tremendous. Such force, that if he had been any lower on the toe, his tiny body would of shattered. Blood seeped from his mouth - indicating that he had, in fact, cracked some teeth.

THOOOOM.

The other foot had landed. With it a shuddering vibration rattled through the foot he was riding before it too lifted once more.

His eyes burning from the intense G-forces and smell, Bryan held on for dear life.

---

Vending machine drinks in-hand, Chris turns and slowly plods down the hall to his apartment door.

He takes for granted just how effortless the journey is. To him, a mere 14 feet down the corridor, and he crossed it leisurely. It was something Chris did daily - almost mindlessly as he pounded heavily over each square of linoleum. Never once did his thoughts stray to bugs, or for that matter, shrunken scientists and other insignificant creatures. Chris only had thoughts of his breakfast and chugging down his machine-bought beverage with his girlfriend, Maya.

Other residents exited their doors, some greeting Chris while others minded their business. He gave a groggy acknowledgement to one neighbour dressed in jogging gear who waved back before vanishing down the stairs.

Approaching the door, Chris idly begins searching his pocket for keys. "Yeah... left it open... right." He mumbled, shaking his head. Two misguided ants vanished beneath his socked foot, completely unnoticed by him.

Chris turned the knob and entered, greeted by the sing-song of Maya's voice.

watch some TV

Bryan was about to move out into the open when ear-splitting clanks filled the air. He instinctively put his arms over his head, screaming in terror. A moment later he stops screaming. After some hesitation he slowly checks his surroundings to find nothing has changed.

"Of course, it was the vending machine!" he laughs nervously to himself. Deciding he has delayed too long, Bryan forces himself to move towards the gigantic socked feet in front of him. He takes only one step before something crashes down from above.

Chris leans down and pulls a bag of cookies from the machine. It wasn't exactly breakfast , but somehow it seemed his closest choice.

"I should've bought milk last night," he sighs to himself. He scratches his thick hair as he scans the machine. Unsure what to get his girlfriend, he opens his bag of cookies.

"Tea! Maya would want some tea." he grunts to himself. Clumsy from sleep, as he reaches for his money, his cookies slip from his hand. They hit the floor with a light smack.

"Damn it!" Chris groans, leaning down. A couple cookies had fallen out of the bag and Chris sweeps them back into the bag with his palm.

Standing back up he puts the money into the machine, hits the code, and retrieves the tea. "Treasures" in hand Chris slowly plods down the hall to his door.

Still a few feet away, it flies open with a bang. Maya sprints out, pulling her hoodie over her head.

"Maya wha-"

"Gotta go sweetie, they need me to cover a shift!" she says quickly. She notices the tea in his hand.

"Aw, you're so sweet!" She coos, snatching the bottle. "Love ya, byyye!" she sings as she bolts down the stairs.

"Bye!" Chris calls after her. Though disappointed Maya had left, he couldn't help but smile. She just did that to him.

Chris strolls through the open door, swinging it shut behind him. Pausing in the living room he reaches into the bag, grasping a mini cookie and pops it into his mouth. Munching on it Chris decides to...

Chris pinches another cookie between his fingers and brings it to his lips. As he opens his mouth, he stops. Suddenly the cookies did not sound good at all. Chris looks at the cookie, frowns, and drops it back into the bag.

"Fuck this. I'm going back to sleep!" he grunts. Tossing the bag of cookies onto the kitchen counter, Chris heads straight for his bedroom, and drops heavily onto his mattress.

Bryan in seconds concluded there was no way out of the bag. That was pretty clear due to the impossibly high, smooth aluminum colored walls. Not that it mattered either way. Because at the same time Bryan had concluded that he was hopelessly stuck in some frosting between the Oreo.

When he had tried to venture out for help, the Oreo had slammed into him from above. Though not hurt, he was immobile.

"Oh why?" Bryan whined. It was not a specific question but rather a why to everything that had led him to this exact point.

His analytical mind quickly decided that self-pity would get him nowhere. He took in his surroundings. Other Oreos were piled around him. A layer of dust on his cookie and two others was clearly visible to the tiny man. It had been swept from the floor when the giant had retrieved his snack.

A loud crinkling from above got Bryan's heart pumping. Long fingers reached through the opening and grasped one of the dust covered cookies. "Oh ew no!" Bryan shouted. Through the hole he could see the giant's face. He stared at something else and never looked at the cookie before effortlessly popping it into his mouth.

Bryan can't suppress a cringe as a crunch sounds from the titan's mouth. He panics and tries to find a way to free himself, but simply has no options.

Another crinkling signals the return of the fingers. They surround Bryan.

"NO!" he screams as the fingers close on his cookie. He struggles fruitlessly as he is lifted. As he stops in front of the lips Bryan holds still. He doesn't even breathe.

The thick lips, surrounded by some morning stubble, slowly part. Light floods the interior, glinting off sharp, white teeth and the strands of saliva between them. Beyond that the tongue stretches into the darkness of the throat, its surface smeared with soggy Oreo crumbs. Bryan can also clearly see a clump of dust from the floor, stuck to the tongue.

"PLEASE NO!" he screams, breaking his silence. As if in response, the gargantuan jaws snap shut, and the giant turns his eyes to the cookie.

"Yes!" Bryan cheers, staring into the pond-like eye. He can't even see himself in the reflection of the cookie in the eye.

A falling sensation is his only warning before he finds himself back in the bag of cookies.

"FUCK THIS! I'M GOING BACK TO SLEEP!" thunders the giant. Bryan shakes his head as he realizes he hadn't been seen.

He screams as the entire bag lurches violently, as everything seems to hover for a split second. A jarring impact sends him flying free across the bag, screaming the whole time.
.
He lays still for a moment, mentally checking himself for injuries. Deciding he is okay, he slowly stands.

The bag is on its side, the cookies spilling out the opening.

"I'm free!" Bryan shouts giddily as he bolts out of the bag. Eventually he emerges onto the countertop where he...

choices: The giant enters the room suddenly, looking for his phone!
Bryan waits for his opportunity
11111222211221112211.content:
Looking around presented Bryan with a layout not dissimilar with the teenager's apartment. But, instead of a wall separating the living room and kitchen, only an island countertop tiled in off-white ceramic, separated the two spaces.

It was on this island that the shrunken scientist found himself. "It's big enough to fit the entire city!" Bryan remarked, padding around as he gawked at the new surroundings.

There was something strangely exciting about exploring some complete stranger's home - while they were home - without their knowledge. Bryan looked from the monumental bag of cookies, carelessly strewn over a massive area by the callous giant, to the kitchen. It was honestly not much to look at - cream coloured cabinets; boring appliances; and the usual condiments or supplies tucked away. Craning his neck, Bryan looked at the tubular mass of light that lit the room, emitting a low humming noise.

His other vista concerned the living room. A simple blue couch, old-looking arm chair, and plain, but tasteful decorations made the room what it was. Bryan assumed the presence of a woman besides the man because of this, since he doubted such a oblivious oaf could ever think to decorate anything but an empty plate with food.

"These people at least seem to keep a tidy enough place - unlike those goddamn kids! I just need to find some place they can see me!" Bryan said thoughtfully.

He began investigating the empty landscape of field-sized tiles. Before he got far, he stopped with a gasp and narrowed his eyes. "Fucking hell! Ants!" Sure enough, on the horizon Bryan could clearly see black shapes skittering across the massive counter like himself. There were only a few, but the tiny man figured these were just scouts and more would follow in their wake. "I need to make sure I don't get confused with those fuckers... Not again! There has to be..." Then his little eyes settled upon something set upon the counter like a massive rectangular stadium in the distance.

Bryan yipped as he approached - it was perfect! A cellphone left upon the counter with the screen facing up. The idea immediately formed in his mind: all he needed to do was climb up, sit himself upon the enormous screen, and wait for the behemoth owner to spot him upon such a conspicuous surface.

Thoroughly decided, he swished happily towards the cellphones side. It was of the smartphone variety; thin and sleek; but loomed over twice his height.
