Eyelashes akin to redwood trees framed dark hazel eyes set beneath a tangle of dark hair canopied by an immeasurably huge hat. The rest of the exterminator's face was hidden beneath a mass of fibrous plastic making up his disposable safety mask. Huge muffled blasts of deep, humid breath could be heard as the enormous man breathed. Bryan trembled, filled with fear once more as he tried in vain to comprehend, much less relate, to this titan of a man. He couldn't even tell if the giant had an expression.

It didn't matter. Despite the tiny man's hope, the huge man looked at the ground but not at the minuscule human upon it. To him, Bryan realized, he was invisible. Another speck. Too tiny for something so fucking huger to discern out of all the skittering ants.

The hulking titan scanned the ground, glossing over the skittering insects, utterly incapable of understanding the utter terror his presence caused. Bryan stood again, his lame arm tucked like an injured wing and tried in vain to follow the giant's gaze. A rumbling sensation warned him moments before an enormous hand appeared overhead, thick edificial fingers poised, thumb-out. With a dull thud, the huge digit impacted the once imposing crack in the foundation, now reduced to a mere sliver in comparison. Scraping sluggishly, the crack was completely filled with a matte gray caulk, completely sealing it from the insects inside and out. Bryan kept his pace, gasping and pained as he tried to make some meaningful contact with the giant exterminator before it was too late.

With ease, Bryan watched the thick digit pull away, leaving a greasy, dirty fingerprint embedded in the caulk. "No! Wait! Wait!" He yelled, running for it as if it alone were capable of understanding him.

Chunks of grimy left-over caulk debris fell free from the digit, sprinkling noisily as Bryan ran himself against the calloused mass of ridged flesh. And against all odds, it worked. Halting momentarily before raising directly above the speck of a man. Bryan staggered back, gaping up at the literal mountain of thumb just above him. Bits of dust, dried caulk, and debris lined the rough surface. He realized his mistake.

Like a meteor crashing down to Earth, the thick digit fell downwards with leisurely speed and abruptly smashed Bryan and thousands of pounds of earth into itself. The crushing sensation was immeasurable. Such power that Bryan couldn't even begin to fathom, seemingly beyond that of even biblical description. He felt pain, but the strange temperature most. The harsh, ridged skin was warm. And the moist earth below was cold, but quickly warming. Then suddenly, everything lifted and it was over.

Bryan went upwards for a moment as well before falling many feet back to the ground. Chunky debris fell around him. Pain shot over his body, mostly from his already damaged arm, and his head throbbed, but overall he had been spared due to the softness of the ground.

"F-fu-uck..." He said, barely able to breath.

Loud disturbance showed the humongous man had already moved on and was back to his full towering height. Bryan realized fully that contact was not only impossible, but suicidal. The guy effectively pulverized Bryan just because he dared to make even the most insignificant contact. Genius Bryan Smith was literally nothing to this behemoth of a man.

There was no chance of rescue. Not now, at least. And it wasn't over.
1111212121112.title: Fell upon the tiny man!

11112121212.content:
His eyes felt like they had melted. Everything in his vision was a hellish shade of red. In the haze, he saw the space between floor and underside of door that represented his salvation.

He was on hands and knees now, every painful breath failing to pull need oxygen into his scorched lungs. The crevice, more of an expanse, between door and floor meant survival, but he was failing.

He needed some rest. Just close his eyes...

The exterminator watched as the tiny bug stopped crawling and curled into a tight ball right on the floor, the chemicals going to work on its frail form. It was the oddest damn little bug, smaller than most of the pests he eradicated on a daily basis, as well as pale and simply unusual.

Before the giant man's professional curiosity advanced, the shrunken scientist's eyes fluttered open. The giant, squinting, was staring down at him.

His bruised brain screamed escape, and he rolled over and tried to continue crawling.

"You are one stubborn little cuss, but I reckon this will take care of you."

"No," came an unheard whimper as shadow enclosed the source of the sound.

The man raised his boot and, in the most tried and true method, lowered it squarely onto the pest before it could resume its attempt at evasion.

"Never fails," he said, and ground the sole of the work boot across the floor.

He spoke from experience. Over the years, his boots had probably eliminated lots of assorted pests and, now, one somewhat unrecognized but soon lamented scientist.
11112121212.title: Exterminator means to block bug's escape

1111212122.content:
Shrunken Mr. Smith dared to let his hopes soar when the gigantic exterminator answered Tommy's question.

"THIS STUFF WON'T HARM ANYTHING BUT BUGS," the huge man told Mr. Smith's teenaged neighbor. "SHOULD BE FINE FOR YOU TO COME BACK IN A COUPLE OF HOURS."

Reassured, Tommy headed toward the back door, forcing his bug-sized neighbor to scurry out of the path of the teenager's enormous shoes. After barely dodging one of the sneakers, the little man squeaked in terror.

"Tommy!" He cried. "Don't step on me! Look for me!"

Of course, Tommy had other things on his mind, first and foremost being to get to the post office with Mr. Smith's important package.

The little man watched helplessly as the teenaged titan left, the package clutched in one of his huge hands.

"Oh no!" Mr. Smith groaned. "Please don't leave me with…"

A sudden boom blasted him as the exterminator's boots stomped across the floor. The little man hoped the scary giant meant to leave the room, but as he turned he saw the giant seemed determined to head in his direction.

A second later, he realized he had been seen.

Carlos kept his eyes fastened on the tiny, pale creature near the back door. He figured some pest had scurried into the house during the teenager's departure.

"BIG MISTAKE, LITTLE BUG," he said.

Routinely, mechanically, he decided to get rid of the bug the old-fashioned way. He raised his boot and moved it into position over the pest.

"No! Wait!" The shrunken scientist screamed. He simply needed to evade the giant and wait for Tommy's return.

Unfortunately, it wasn't in the cards.

The boot slammed down, the impact of it slamming into the tiles drowning out the pitiful crunch of the destroyed "bug."

A couple of hours later, right on schedule, Tommy returned, bringing one of his friends with him.

They entered through the back door, and Tommy's sneaker slapped down on the splattered remains of his shrunken employer. After watering a few plants, Tommy and Joe made themselves comfortable in Mr. Smith's living room.

When Tommy propped his feet on the coffee table, he saw something drop out of the treads of his sneakers. On closer inspection, it looked like the mangled remains of some strange bug. He tossed Joe the remote and instructed him to find a game.

In the meantime, he went to the kitchen, fetched a paper towel and returned to deal with the icky mess on the coffee table. After he swiped the mess into the towel, he crumpled it and carried it to the trash bin in the kitchen.

"Remind me," he told Joe as he returned to the living room. "I need to take out the trash and put it at the curb before we leave."

Mr. Smith hadn't told him to worry about the trash, but Tommy knew that the trash collectors came every three days. He was happy to put forth some extra effort on Mr. Smith's behalf.

He did wonder where his neighbor had gone on his trip, but he was sure he would hear all about it when he eventually returned home.
1111212122.title: Routine stomp

choices: Basement Life
Someone comes to the basement
111122.content:
The tiny man was still trying to get back on his feet when the giant stomped swiftly toward his spot on the kitchen floor. The blur of the onrushing work boots added motivation to the shrunken scientist's efforts, but he simply wasn't quick enough to avoid the oncoming boots.

One of Diego's boots stomped down. For tiny Bryan, the sound of thunder was followed by a sickening, squishy sound. The boot lifted off the floor as the giant opened the door to the basement. Everything looked tilted and crazy as the shrunken man struggled to comprehend what had just happened.

Diego's enormous boot had dropped right on top of him, but he wasn't dead. Instead, he found himself lodged deep into the fresh mud trapped in the tread beneath the boot. The exterminator had stepped in the mud on the short walk from the curb to Mr. Smith's front door.

The tiny man wanted to be thankful for his evasion of a grisly fate, but it was hard to feel appreciative as Diego stomped down the flight of steps leading into the dusty, darkened basement. Piles of cardboard boxes were stored along one wall. A weight bench (a holdover from one of Mr. Smith's short-lived phases to get in better shape) stood in the center of the room. Tucked under the flight of stairs with its set of six steps was the skyscraper-like water heater. Bare concrete floors and cobwebs in corners and crannies completed the atmosphere of the forlorn basement where Mr. Smith rarely visited.

Diego, however, knew that many insect problems began in the basement. As he stomped around the concrete floors, a chunk of mud dropped from the tread of his boots. Diego poked the nozzle of his canister of insecticide into a few likely nooks and crannies, spraying the lethal liquid in liberal doses, never noticing as a tiny, pale form squirmed out of the chunk of mud and crawled over the bare floors.

"THAT SHOULD JUST ABOUT DO IT DOWN HERE," Diego said.

The bug-sized man realized the true horror of his situation. The giant human was about to leave the basement, which would leave the shrunken scientist marooned a world away from help.

The naked little man screamed as he ran the impossible distance toward the staircase. "Wait! Don't leave me here!"

Once again, the giant moved with a swiftness that left the bug-sized man at a complete loss. In no time, Diego ascended the stairs, never realizing what he had left behind on the basement floor.
111122.title: Marooned

choices: Shelter
Food/Water
1111221.content:
The tiny man reached the bottom step on the towering flight of stairs that led out of the alien-looking basement into the gigantic but familiar surroundings of his home.

He stopped, numb from shock, as he realized he could never hope to scale even one of the steep steps, let alone the entire flight of stairs.

"I'm trapped," he said aloud, his tiny voice swallowed by the immensity of the basement.

Not only trapped, he had no supplies, no tools, not even any clothes. He felt it might have been better if the giant had simply crushed him unknowingly beneath his boots.

The naked little man wandered across the vast plain of cold, gray concrete. He passed beneath the colossal weight bench, which looked liked the size of some mysterious ancient monument. Its true purpose was certainly beyond him now. He saw a set of little-used barbells in the distance, and marveled that he had once been capable of holding them in one hand.

He told himself that someone would come looking for him.

"Dammit," he cried, realizing how delusional such thoughts were. No one would ever think to look for a tiny man lost in his own basement.

In a month, Diego or someone else from the extermination service might, possibly, return to the basement.

The surroundings looked sterile and barren. No food, no water. Well, he thought, his exile might be short-lived without those crucial necessities. He wouldn't be able to hold out an entire month and, even if he did, what hope did he have of contacting a giant? He had already tried and failed miserably.

As bleak as his future looked, he pushed himself. He made a list of goals. First, he needed shelter and, perhaps, some sort of clothing. Then, he would make an effort to scavenge for food and water.

The distant horizon of stacked cardboard boxes held potential. With little other choice, he trudged toward the cardboard cityscape.
1111221.title: Basement Life

choices: The bar's wrapped has been opened
The bar's still sealed in its wrapper
11112212.content:
Two enormous windows high up on the concrete walls of the basement admitted the only light into the basement. The windows might have provided a route of escape from the basement if they hadn't been positioned hundreds of feet up a vertical cliff.

No, ascending to either of the two windows was as unlikely as was ascent up the colossal flight of stairs. The tiny man, however, was thankful for the windows. Not only did they provide light, they allowed him to keep track of the passage of days.

So far, he had spent two nights in the basement, huddled in his lodging that was nothing more than a space between the stacks of enormous cardboard boxes along one wall. During the fitful sleep between light and darkness, he often dreamed of gigantic teenagers and the destruction they could bring to helpless insects.

He had awoken not too long ago to his third morning in the basement when diffused light shone through the windows and cast everything in the basement in a dull gray.

He slept on a scrap of paper that at least didn't require him to bed down on the hard, cold concrete. His scrounging around the basement had not found anything that could serve as even modest clothing, so he continued to go about naked as he explored the seemingly endless basement.

His attempts to find food and water had proved as futile as the one to find clothing, until yesterday. A slow leak from the towering water heater crammed into a space beneath the stairs had formed a pool of water on the concrete floor. The little man, who might have been concerned about a leak in his water heater had he been normal size, rejoiced at the discovery as he drank from the pool of stale water by dipping his hands into it. Lacking any means to collect the water, however, he was now obliged to make the long trek from the cardboard boxes to the water heater every day just to quench his thirst.

The long trek took him past the long-forgotten exercise bench, and on this day he noticed something. He saw it atop a folded towel that he must have left behind on the floor beneath the bench the last time he had made use of the exercise bench.

The red, gold and brown foil gleamed in the dull light, but he would have recognized it even without the large letters that spelled out "ENERGY BAR."

His empty stomach rumbled at the thought of the oatmeal and chocolate bar, which looked big enough to provide him an inexhaustible supply of food, or at least enough food to hold out until someone came to the basement.

He found plenty of knotty handholds in the fabric of the towel and quickly climbed onto the vast, white surface of the towel and ran toward the discarded energy bar.
11112212.title: Resources

choices: The next day...
One month later...
111122121.content:
It had taken him three days from the time he had first been exiled to his own basement, but after he stuffed himself on crumbs scraped from the walls of the humongous energy bar, the tiny scientist rejoiced that his food problems looked solved.

"I could eat off this thing for years!" He said aloud in an excited squeak that was quickly swallowed by the vast basement.

He wished that he had a way to move the colossal snack food from the towel beneath his massive exercise bench, but there was no way that he could hope to budge it at his current ant-sized height.

"That's OK," he said. At least he wasn't facing a slow death by starvation.

"I'm just lucky I had already unwrapped it," he said aloud. He stared at the red, gold and brown foil that gleamed in the dim light of the basement. He knew without any doubt he would never have been able to tear his way through the foil wrapper. He was simply so damn small that even a thin layer of foil could defeat him.

He tried to remember the day when, at his normal size, he had gone to the basement, taken a bite of the energy bar and then forgotten it when he left. He tried, but he could not recall how long ago that had been.

But, he could still remedy his exile. He could get back to his proper size. "Tommy, or someone, will come looking for me..." he said, trying to deny the improbability of that hope.

"When I do get back to normal, I will never, ever use the formula again," he vowed. "It's too dangerous."

He grabbed up a few handfuls of the oatmeal/chocolate crumbs for the long trek back to the cityscape formed by the irregular stack of large cardboard boxes. He was tempted to spend the night here. The towel provided a soft, comfortable surface, but he was also exposed and vulnerable. Once the basement was again plunged into darkness, he preferred to be tucked away in his cranny "apartment" wedged into a crack between two of the massive cardboard containers.

On the long journey back across the concrete plain, he entertained himself with visions of the enormous exterminator. Seeing that massive human being from an insect's point of view had been an altering experience. He had never felt so helpless in his entire life than when that enormous boot had come down on top of him.

That should have been the tragic end to his experiment, but instead of crushing him, some mud squished into the boot tread had saved him.

Of course, that had also been the cause of his banishment from his own home when he fell out of the tread and was left behind when the exterminator left the basement.

He felt his dick harden, fueled by the memory of Diego's powerful form. The organ bobbed between his legs as he walked across the basement floor. He paused as he neared the lowest step in the staircase leading upstairs to freedom.

Facing the stairs, mesmerized by how each step loomed steeper and steeper, wordlessly emphasizing how far removed he had become from the rest of his known universe, he grunted and groaned as he jerked himself to a quick climax.

This was his life, reduced to the basic instincts... thirst, sex, hunger... he could still satisfy those needs.

His intellect, which had brought him here, played very little role in his daily life now. When he did entertain schemes to escape the basement, they always ended in frustration as the impossibility of any attempt loomed large in his mind.

Before continuing on his journey, he visited the nearby pool below the slowly leaking water heater for one last drink of the day. Fortified as far as his needs went, he continued his way toward the boxes, arriving at his destination as the sun outside began to rob the basement of even dim light for another night.


He settled onto the scrap of paper, and almost as soon as his eyes closed, he sank into a deep sleep. His exhausting daily treks across the basement desert left him with little energy for dreams.
111122121.title: Basic needs

choices: Venture through the hole
Find another means of escape
1111221211.content:
Restless dreams plagued tiny Bryan Smith as he slept.

An enormous work boot raised overhead, the thick tread filled with many crushed bodies of himself. He belted out a shrill screech as it crashed down. Bryan woke with cold sweat speckling his face and arms as he rubbed his eyes with shaking hands.

"A dream," He breathed. "Just a horrible dream..."

Unfortunately, he found it wasn't a dream. He was still in his basement, under a scrap of paper, smaller than a grain of rice. It was a nightmare come true.

Shy rays of light shown through the dust covered window high up the cement wall. Bryan surveyed the enormous space lain before him. He couldn't imagine that he was ever able to stride across this room in a few steps. It had always seemed too small, which is why he never put his make-shift lab down here. Now it seemed impossibly spacious, enough to fit an entire world on the expansive cement floor.

Leaving his tiny paper haven, Bryan ventured out. "Damn, how the hell will I get out of here?"

Far in the distance sat the creaky wooden stairs leading up into the kitchen. Memories from the previous day told him that it would be foolish to even attempt scaling the mountainous steps--steps that the massive exterminator climbed easily after carelessly depositing tiny Bryan from the mud-filled tread of his boots.

Thoughts of the enormous man stirred Bryan. He shook his head, scolding himself. "I need to do something productive." With that notion, he began exploring.

The world that was his basement proved to be filled with fantastic curiosities. Forgotten documents lay in piles, some scattered about, unused chairs sat against a wall, their ornately carved legs towering high up, and an old gramophone given to him by his grandparents rested near the piled boxes. A single record lay flat on the ground from when he last investigated the antique. Bryan was able to seat himself in the dirt-filled grooves of the Depression era record.

All the while, Bryan saw terrifying sights as well. Cobwebs, which he kept away from like the plague, and a cluster of ants that scuttled around busily, searching for food.

"The exterminator didn't even spray down here..." Bryan noted with an annoyed look. Turning towards his home in-between the humongous boxes, he began walking.

The thought only then struck him. "Ants!" He shouted. "The ants had to get in somehow!" Spinning around, he looked to the ants that ignored his squeaking shouts.

His eyes squinted. Farther down the wall, following a trail of the invasive pests was a thin crack in the aged cement of the wall. Elation welled inside the tiny man's body, causing him to leap with excitement. A plan began to form in his mind, a plan that made him feel hopeful for the first time since he shrunk.

Presumably, this break in the foundation would lead him either outside, or preferably somewhere in his house. He could then concentrate on returning himself to normal and ending this nightmare before it turned deadly.

This also meant engaging with the fearsome looking ants head-on. A though which sent shivers down the minuscule man's spine.

Bryan decides...
1111221211.title: New day, new prospects

choices: Somewhere outside
Inside
11112212111.content:
Another chill went down Bryan's spine as he watched the hulking ants with narrowed eyes.

He hated bugs. Any bug; ants, beetles, flis, and especially spiders. He had always hated the contemptible creatures, not even liking them for what benefit they did provide the world. At the current size of a speck, the tiny scientist had every excuse to fear the huge beasts.

They easily out-sized a small automobile--jagged legs made them seem even larger--and antennae resembling large pipes swung around furiously while the insect foraged. Bryan grumbled, continuing to stare at the swirling trail of ants that stretched from the crack in the wall to a point behind a nearby box. He would have to brave them if he wanted to leave the lonely prison that was his basement.

"I might as well be dead if I stay trapped here," The tiny man remarked. "Besides, nobody is even looking for me. Why should anyone come down here to find me?"

He thought of his beloved neighbor Tommy, who had probably come and gone the day before, unaware of Mr. Smith's plight.

The small man took a deep breath, pushed all thoughts out of his mind, and set towards the distant crack. It took nearly an hour to reach it, the distance he crossed only about 8 feet to the normal person. As Bryan traveled, he warily avoided the ants, preferring to keep a distance. His heart nearly stopped when a stray ant confronted him. Bryan pealed in terror, reeling backwards as the huge insect inspected him with rope-like antennae. It left abruptly with a loud disgruntled clack from its mandibles.

"They aren't even interested in me..."

Bryan realized this as he walked closer. The busy insects didn't offer him any attention as they raced along in either direction. He dared a nervous smile. "Perhaps this will be easier than I thought!"

It was then that he approached the hole. Standing over 10 feet tall, and many feet wide, the crack in his foundation offered an easy entrance for the invasive ants. It also offered the bug-sized man an easy escape.

With no idea where he may end up, Bryan Smith entered the pitch darkness. His tiny form was seemingly swallowed by the inky black as he descended.

Shouldering past numerous careless ants, Bryan eventually emerged....
11112212111.title: Escape is the best option!

choices: Something happens
He sees a house in the distance
111122121111.content:
Glaring sunlight flooded Bryan's vision when he emerged from the hole.

Scuttling away from the cavernous hole, he took a deep breath. Traversing the pitch blackness was possibly the bravest, and potentially most foolish, thing he had ever done. More than once did he think he would be lost in the cavernous tunnels. Such thoughts plagued him, making his flight through all the more desperate.

Other things frightened him ever more though. Ungodly sounds; Rasping hisses, skittering feet, and ghastly clicks. He was convinced at one point, after hitting a dead end of soft dirt that something had been following him.

"I'm just glad to have that over with!" He said with intense relief.

The next step was upon him now. He was outside, as he suspected the tunnel would lead. The tiny man found himself sitting upon a rugged land of loose, dry dirt, like some kind of arid planet. Towering plants with majestic leaves larger than a garage drooped above. It looked like nothing short of an alien world to tiny Bryan, complete with buzzing beasts of epic proportions soaring overhead.

He began wandering around, looking for possible landmarks to pinpoint his location. "This is amazing..." Bryan gawked at what was nothing more than a common milk thistle, but now blown up to impressive scale.

Passing many similar sights, he passed through shady clusters of grass, under huge overhanging rocks and twigs in wonderment. It was hard to believe this had all been insignificant to him before. This prehistoric setting was no more than some neglected weeds in a backyard.

Thirst and hunger began to gnaw at him. In his excitement, he had failed to feed or drink from the meager sources in his basement.

"Where am I?" He complained. "Perhaps this wasn't a good idea..."

His regrets were interrupted suddenly.
111122121111.title: Somewhere outside

choices: He wanders aimlessly
Bryan encounters something
1111221211111.content:
Bryan was broken from his pessimistic state when a loud rustling began behind him. He turned just in time to see a monstrous shape leap from a nearby cluster of tall grass.

"Bloody hell!" He squeaked. The tiny man flung himself back just as the giant shape descended with a dull crash.

Breathing heavily, Bryan gawked at the monster-sized insect. "A grasshopper!" It might have been one to the normal eye, yet to teeny Bryan Smith it looked like some monster insect from outer space.

The grasshopper hunkered down before him. It presented a sight both terrifying and wondrous for the shrunken scientist. Larger than a passenger bus, every detail of the beastly bug stood out: huge crystalline eyes, long, thin, powerful legs, greasy exoskeleton covered with hideous hairs, and sharp mandibles that gnawed at the air. It made flitting movements, the many faceted eyes reflecting the light in a dazzling display as the head twitched.

It seemed completely unaware of tiny Bryan as it sat there. As if preparing to conduct a symphony, the grasshopper raised its legs and brought them together.

"Graaahhhh!" Bryan shuttered his ears in an attempt to shield off the cacophony of noise.

He writhed in the dirt, crying and shouting for mercy while the careless grasshopper played both legs together like an out-of-tune fiddle. Just as Bryan was convinced his head would explode, the shrill noise ceased.

He released his ears with a sigh. "Thank God...!" A high ringing still thrummed in his skull. He glowered at the large insect that sat dumbly before him. "Fuck you! I hate bugs!"

With that, he groped for a stone, as the dirt around him was strewn with them. Plucking a sizable one, he hurled it at the idle grasshopper with furious strength. The pebble arched pitifully but made contact with the creature's bulbous eyeball, leaving a noticeable dent.

Quick as lightning, the grasshopper reacted with a frightened cry and blasted off with two powerful legs in a fury of dirt.

The bug-sized man watched the grasshopper vanish into the distant horizon. He let out a grateful sigh. The whole ordeal left him feeling a deal more distressed than before, despite his slight victory over the much larger insect. He figured himself lucky that his first contact outside had been as harmless as the grasshopper.

Bryan rubbed his temples, then turned to resume his slow exploration of this humongous and unknown land.
1111221211111.title: Grasshopper serenade

choices: Spending the night
Somebody approaches
11112212111111.content:
After what felt like hours of aimless wandering, Bryan's legs felt like liquid.

The world at his extremely reduced size was nothing short of amazing, but Bryan could hardly appreciate the wonders in his current state. He was stranded. He needed help--a task that would already be nigh impossible, as evidenced by his encounter with the gigantic exterminator--and he did not want to spend the night out here. The thought of what might prowl the wilderness under the cloak of darkness made Bryan's skin crawl.

"There has to be something out here," He whined. "Where did that damn tunnel take me?"

He persisted his wandering despite pains from his out-of-shape legs.

Plants, or more specifically, weeds, towered over the land at every turn. Huge bristling milk thistles, fanciful dandelions, and alien-like ragweeds. He felt like an explorer than landed on a new planet filled with wondrous flora and formations. Pebbles and boulders, usually no larger than his thumb, ranged in sizes from a couple feet in height to larger than a house. It was becoming harder to believe that this entire space was likely nothing more than somebody's unremarkable backyard.

"Definitely not my yard! I could never get flowers to grow!" The tiny man remarked as he passed underneath a forest of many coloured daisies. It felt as if he had stepped into Wonderland.

One object of particular interest was an enormous quarter that he happened upon. The gigantic bit of change lay at an angle, half-buried like an ancient monument. He studied the gigantic metal coin, feeling the ridges and noting that he was of comparable height with the thickness of the coin. He felt incredulous at his own stupidity. "Why the hell did I make myself so small?"

Thirst and hunger began to weaken him. "I can't wander forever," Bryan wheezed. "This was a big mistake..."
11112212111111.title: Tiny wanderings

choices: Tries to eat Bryan!
Is more interested in a juicy bug!
11112212111112.content:
Trundling at such a slow pace, Bryan began to feel his morale wane.

High above the sun shone at a new angle: in the mid-afternoon position. The realization that daytime was slowly coming to an end sent a shudder through the shrunken man's body. Above all, Bryan did NOT want to be lost out here in the dark.

No; he had to keep moving - to find either his own home or some kind of shelter.

"God! There doesn't seem to be anything out here!"

Stumbling over another dale of packed dirt, Bryan slumped against a boulder and groaned. He had never trained himself for such exertions. Barely passing any gym classes in high school and never bothering to exercise anything but his brain. Bryan simply wasn't made for this kind of situation.

He had been through a lot, and if straining himself to keep walking was the next step... then be damned, he was going to do it!

Pushing himself off the rock, he steeled himself and prepared to continue. Before his first step, his whole body froze when an enormous shadow coated the land.

"Shit!" He bellowed and dove down the dirt incline.

Just then a tower of hard orange scales and sharp talons crashed down, covering the hill Bryan had rested on almost entirely.

On his back and exposed on the hard, packed dirt, Bryan gazed up in awe. The humongous feathered creature looked nothing short of monstrous. Two thick legs loomed upwards, stretching many stories high to support the giant body of blue and black feathers. Moving with surprisingly quick motions, the bird's head bobbed and rotated to survey the ground before it.

Bryan was beside himself with panic. He would have soiled himself had his stomach had any contents to release.

Towering above the immediate area, the bird resembled a skyscraper of fantastical design set upon towering stilts. It scanned the ground and shifted a bulging black eye to peer down at Bryan. He stared into the seed-shaped mass, unable to detect any emotion or reason within the glinting darkness.

"No! Not like this!" He shuffled back, still on his rear. "Fuck, I can't die like this!"

The bird responded by opening a beak larger than his garage and released an earsplitting roar. Bryan attempted to match it, but fell into terrified sobbing and whimpers.

Suddenly, the bird...
11112212111112.title: Birdzilla

choices: Bryan enters the home
Bryan enters the home but meets misfortune
1111221211112.content:
As he walked, Bryan hung his head in dejection. He stepped, stumbled, and nearly tripped many times over the rugged terrain. The tiny man was anything but suited for this type of adventure.

His throat began to bother him also; scratching with dehydration. In his excitement to escape his cellar, Bryan had failed to provide himself with ample food or water. The continued scorching from the magnified sun caused him further anguish as he plodded along.

"Where am I?" He complained. Sighing deep, Bryan rubbed his scalp. "Perhaps this wasn't a good idea..."

Upset and afraid, Bryan looked around. Common plants and weeds grew around, seperated by large patches of rocky, dry dirt. He felt as if he had wandered onto the set of a 1950s space movie; everything looked so unbelievable.

Suddenly, something caught his eye. Visible just through the looming fronds of a daisy, the tiny scientist spotted a structure. He immediately began sprinting towards it. Clumsily, Bryan leaped over large twigs and boulder-sized pebbles - slowing briefly to scamper over a low hanging leaf. Then he saw it.

"A house!" He couldn't help shrieking with joy. The sight of a house - albeit far off in the distance and of humongous proportions - felt like nothing short of a miracle for the tiny man. "I'm saved!"

Not even stopping to think if he knew the home owners, Bryan began a hastened journey towards the humongous suburban home. As he traveled, his brilliant mind went over all the things he had experienced: the disastrous meeting with Tommy. The traumatizing encounter with the huge workboot; which left him stranded in his own basement. Now, his current situation.

Smiling despite these thoughts, Bryan tried to keep positive. "I could write a bestselling book on this!" The thought was amusing to him, allowing him to briefly chuckle. The task at-hand called for his attention though, and Bryan slowed to a walk to gaze up at the nearing house. "Just gotta get rescued first... Yep."

The one-story home would appear to any normal viewer as nothing but a modest suburban abode. Tinier than an ant, Bryan looked at it differently. He gazed at the dizzying height of it - it seemed unlikely that anything but humongous gods of old could reside in such a dwelling. A window coated in shadow towered far above. Bryan squinted at it, craning his neck in an attempt to view the inside.

Only then did he begin to wonder about the owners. Bryan would be putting his very life into their unknown hands. He felt the hope bubbling inside him dampen. The house was unrecognizable from this perspective. Plus, Bryan was never neighbourly: seldom bothering to leave his home to introduce himself to any of them. Could he trust complete strangers to find him? These doubts further justified by memories of the near-fatal encounter with the gigantic exterminator.

"God... What choice do I have? I can't very well stay out here for an entire night!" Bryan had heard many disturbing sounds produced by unknown insects while he traveled. Interactions with a monster-sized bug terrified him beyond measure.

The cement foundation loomed ahead. Fissures, cracks, and dirt covered the worn surface. Presumably, it would be a simple matter to enter the home through any of them.
1111221211112.title: Getting somewhere

choices: The spider is distracted by a larger insect caught in the web
Somebody is home
11112212111122.content:
Studying the ominous caves set before him, the tiny man looked them over.

Of the nearest, a long crack, stretching high up the cement foundation, sat partially buried in dirt. Dried leaves of fantastic size were collected around it. He noted no movement from the inky depths. Further down, another cave sat. Bryan immediately decided against this option, viewing many ants filtering in and out of it.

"Damn things are everywhere..."

Turning to other fissures, he saw that they all appeared in similar states: infested, or unappetizing. Nervously, he decided upon the half-buried one nearest him and made his way into the darkness.

"Don't panic... You've done this before... Just keep moving," Bryan padded through the darkness, his already battered feet contacting sharp stone and dirt as he progressed. He felt himself enter into a large space. It was still pitch black, but he could smell plaster and musty electrical cords.

Light suddenly assaulted him, beaming from a long stretch where the baseboard had lifted off the floor with age.

"That wasn't so hard!" Bryan giddily scuttled towards the light, no longer caring about his surroundings. "I'm free! Free!"

"I'm fre-"

Entering into the light, Bryan's excited flight was abruptly halted. Long gleaming cords, sticky and moist stretched all about him. He had managed to swing his right arm right into one of them; effectively trapping it.

He was just out from under the giant baseboard and able to view the immense world of hardwood floor stretching out before him. Yet, no matter his struggles he could not free himself. He looked up, realizing this entire corner was coated in the treacherous webbing. A ladder of webs gracefully stretched upwards, ending at a hole in the wall. Marring any possible beauty the intricate web may offer, were many dozen corpses: ants made up the bulk, while a single gnat, and a small beetle were bundled nearby.

Nestled in the webby roost above, a spider peered out to investigate the latest catch.

Bryan gawked at it, and screamed in horror. The giant arachnid would easily dwarf any vehicle and looked far more fearsome than any mammal he knew of.

"HEEEELP!"

His cries seemed pitiful as they were instantly absorbed by the enormous space before him. A few ants skittered nearby, consciously keeping away from the dastardly trap set by the spider. They passed by without giving Bryan, or his screeches, any notice. Despite himself, Bryan reached out with his free arm and flailed it pleadingly. His imploring gesturing had no effect on the dull insects, and he resigned himself back to trying to tear himself free.

---

Cautious and alert, the spider proceeded slowly toward the struggling prey. Living as an uninvited guest in a suburban home, the tiny arachnid knew to venture out only when the coast was clear.

Squeaking and wiggling, the soft prey continued to attempt escape; all in vain. It was likely no more than a snack, but would nourish the hungry spider nonetheless.
11112212111122.title: Silken Hell

choices: Bryan manages to escape
Bryan still can't escape
111122121111221.content:
Bryan pulled, he wretched, and nearly dislocated his shoulder - it was hopeless. The thick strand of glistening silk held to him like super glue.

"Oh my God, I don't want to die!"

All around him were various insects that probably thought the same thing. Only for the architect of this sinister trap to creep down and extinguish their puny lives. Now it seemed Bryan would meet the same fate.

Despite his dehydration, the tiny man felt tears begin to drip down his dirty cheeks. It was almost laughable. A brilliant man such as himself would meet his end at the gnashing mandibles of some common arachnid. A spider that - under normal circumstances - could be crushed beneath a quarter. At his size, this spider looked like it could take down King Kong, much less a quarter.

Bryan let out a hysterical laugh and tasted salt as his own tears trickled into his mouth.

He brushed them away with his free arm and resumed his struggles.

---

Meanwhile, the large house spider crept past some past victims. Each step upon its webby home was done with tender, masterful grace. It kept all eight eyes on the latest catch.

This prey was curious. The spider - with what limited mental abilities it possessed - could not seem to recognize what it was. Tiny, thin, soft, and pink. It struggled erratically and produced strange, fluctuating shrieks that bothered the hungry spider.

Interesting as it was, the spider didn't pause to consider any of these thoughts and proceeded down the last stretch of webbing.

---

"Not...." Bryan grunted dryly. "...NOT like this! I deserve better than this!"

The tiny scientist halted his pathetic struggles when he noticed the gigantic spider nearing him. Eight golf balls of glinting black glass bored down on him from atop the horrible monster's carapace. Bryan welcomed the nearing predator with a terrific scream. It paused mid-step, one long leg poised and stared at the shrunken man.

Bryan was taken aback by the reaction. Then the idea struck him and he inhaled a deep breath. If the gigantic beast was disturbed by his cries, then Bryan would give him one to remember - he wasn't going down without a fight!

Hisssssssssssss

The sound made Bryan jolt and spew all his breath out uselessly. The spider seemed captivated by the noise, no longer interested in the tiny man. With a clanking thud, emerged a truck-sized ladybug from underneath the baseboards gap. It came trundling out, hissing and clacking with an air of confusion. Not a moment later, the dumb beast wandered clumsily - right into a delicate net of shimmering silk.

Bryan gasped as all hell broke loose. The bulky beetle let out a throaty cry and began to thrash hysterically, pulling and twisting itself into more sticky strands.

As if Christmas had just dawned, the giant spider turned away from Bryan and scuttled towards the bigger and better prey. The web trembled from the beetles struggles - many sticky cords glued to the vividly red and black shell.

Chortling at his own luck, the trapped scientist turned away. He had no wish to watch the grotesque spider silence the confused ladybug. He also knew he needed to take advantage of this distraction.
111122121111221.title: Bigger and better

choices: Bryan heads further into the living room
Bryan heads for the kitchen
1111221211112211.content:
Caught like an animal, tiny Bryan Smith fought for his life. He twisted, he wiggled, and he thrashed against the silken bindings - but, to no avail.

Pausing, he glanced over at his fellow captive and gasped. The blundering beetle was in far more dire straits than himself; coated in a drape of loose, but strong webs and being actively molested by the terrifying spider. Fear flushed through his tiny body like ice, threatening to paralyze him.

His resolve proved stronger. "No! I don't want to die!" The declaration sounded pathetic, but managed to fill the shrunken man with courage. "I'm....going....to....ESCAPE!"

It was as if somebody had pressed a button marked "release". The cords of silken steel twisted and broke, freeing his arms and legs in a clumsy tumble to the ground. Bryan immediately jumped up with a squeak and began running blindly, arms and head flailing wildly.

"I'm free! I'm free! Freeeee!"

At the size of a poppy seed, the shrunken scientist's glee was nothing but silence to the massive room, but to him, he was leaping and shouting with relief.

All worries and woe of his journey seemed miles away. He slowed his pace, halted his celebrating, and sucked in well-needed mouthfuls of air. If anything, Bryan could publish one damn good adventure story from this. Imagining himself seated behind a table and signing copies of his book brought a smile to his tear stricken face.

But, the reality of his situation remained and the tiny man frowned as he took in his enormous surroundings with wide eyes.

He stood in the corner of a rectangular room filled with the usual furnishings found in a living room. Dated planks of wood coated the walls in a horrendous example of paneling. Bryan twisted his lips, rotating his head in order to appreciate more of the worldspace. Like a mountain of drab blue, towered a hulking beast of a couch. It faced an enormous television resting upon a cabinet that looked more like towering skyscrapers constructed of oak than simple shelves full of DVDs and electronics. Beyond the mountainous couch was a doorway leading into what appeared to be a small foyer. Light was allowed into the space from a row of windows upon the furthest wall.

To his left, Bryan was given another worldspace. This one was of white cabinetry and tile flooring: a kitchen, he realized. It looked just as humble as the living room, despite the grand scale of it all.

"Doesn't look like the inside of any of my neighbour's houses..." He said, beginning to wander with small steps. "How far did that damn ant nest take me? I'm not even in my own neighbourhood!"

All over the landscape of huge wooden flooring, the tiny man saw bits of grit and dirt strewn at random. It looked filthy to him, but he figured it must be completely unnoticeable to the regular person. He glared back at the corner of the room with the treacherous spider web. It seemed so small in comparison to the huge baseboard. Bryan followed the wall up, squinting at photographs hung impossibly high above. Whoever owned the place seemed to be out or indisposed. The pictures were impossible to make out, and he gave up with a grunt before continuing his rather aimless wandering.

Movement caught his gaze and he looked towards the looming portal into the kitchen. Two agile ants scurried over the transition in flooring, vanishing from sight into the distant kitchen.

"I'm not alone in my exploring!" Bryan smirked. He watched another, no more than a skittering shape at this distance, as it sped through the spider's webbing and towards the kitchen. "Little fuckers, breaking into houses witho-..." The tiny man trailed off, feeling goosebumps prickle his skin at the realization of his own predicament.

He had broken in to this house. Here he was padding along the living room floor of some stranger's home he didn't even know. By all regards, size and all, Bryan was an invading insect!

Shaking himself, the tiny man revoked that thought. He was a brilliant scientist - not some filthy insect! It wasn't his fault he had been thrown in such a mess because circumstances beyond his control. He needed to stop thinking and get rescued! Or, at the very least, find something to quench his hunger and thirst!
1111221211112211.title: Bryan manages to escape

choices: The gigantic house pet arrives
Bryan makes a tasty appetizer!
1111221211112212.content:
Thrashing produced no viable results, leaving the tiny man in a state of dread and desperation.

"Oh no, I can't get unstuck!" He cried, still pulling before suddenly turning paler than chalk.

About a dozen feet away, Bryan witnessed the end of his fellow prisoner's life. The huge spider fell upon it, unfazed by the large creature's struggles and mercilessly petrified it with but a single bite.

"Shit!"

He locked gaze with the pitiable eyes of the ladybug. Frozen in a seemingly expressive state of confused terror, it made him sick. Bryan slumped his head away, unable to watch the hideous spider any longer as it went to work on the fresh prey.

This couldn't be his fate. Paralyzed cruelly by a thoughtless, instinct-driven arachnid of industrial size, and drained like a child's juice box? It was too horrible a fate to even think, much less believe could happen to him! Yet, it was all he could do - unable to break free, despite the unintended sacrifice offered by the ladybug. He was next on the ghastly spider's menu.

Crying, Bryan felt thoroughly sorry for himself until...
1111221211112212.title: Unable to break free

choices: Two security men from EDL labs!
Two exterminators!
1111221212.content:
Bryan returned to the base of the staircase often. Amidst all the dust bunnies and dirt, he would gape at the enormity of what once was a regular staircase. Now, each step loomed higher than an office building, an impossible height to Bryan.

Days went by, each one melting into the other. Bryan would wake up in his cozy abode fashioned from a shred of paper. It was quite a bit larger than he was, and offered a respite from the frighteningly massive basement. He would then spend the better part of the day traversing the massive expanse of concrete flooring to reach water and food. The trek was positively draining, and he would often collapse into sleep upon returning to his paper scrap.

His intelligent mind had all but given up with theories on how to escape. A broom leaning against the side of the mountainous steps seemed his best option. The bug-sized man spent hours trying to scale the pillar-like bristles to no result. Unlike any common insect, Bryan was no more equipped for climbing than he was for flying.

With no way of telling time, much less the date, Bryan had no idea how much time had really passed.

As if to add a cherry on top, Bryan discovered that his mega-sized power bar had been discovered by ants. The busy insects covered the abandoned energy food, crawling over it, and carrying large chunks away. The bug-sized man didn't even try to reclaim it, as the ants were larger and far more numerous than he would ever be. Deigo's noxious repellents didn't last very long it seemed.

The loss of a food supply hung grimly over the shrunken man. Fortunately, he had squirreled away a sizable supply of crumbs over the days, but they would only last him so long.

"Damnitt to hell!" He screeched vainly and stamped his feet.

More than often he found himself talking, yelling, and muttering to himself as of late. Before he would relish his alone time at home, and at work. Now, he wanted nothing more than for somebody to talk to.

"For that matter, somebody to come looking for me!" He cawed out loud as he returned to his safe haven between the towering boxes.

With that thought, he lay himself down to sleep on the large paper scrap. Sleep came quickly as always, and he even dreamed that he was able to return to normal size and all his family, friends, co-workers, and even Tommy, were happy to see him.

He wretched back to consciousness to the a distant thumping. His vision was blurry from sleep as he squinted his eyes over the expanse of concrete to look at the stairs. What was that noise?

A loud slam rumbled from above, and Bryan heard heavy footsteps and deep voices.

"Somebody is there!" He realized. It didn't even bother him slightly that somebody had entered his house, his only thought was the possibility of rescue.

He had just appeared from his cardboard haven when the sound of a door opening and thunderous footsteps were heard coming from the stairs.

Bryan's mood changed for the worst as he realized the intruders were...
1111221212.title: Times marches on!

choices: Brent puts out some ant traps
Brent sees something tiny
11112212122.content:
Diego checked off the Smith residence on his notepad and turned to his younger assistant, Brent, with instructions.

“This is a follow-up visit from one I did a few weeks ago,” the large, well-built Latino man told his assistant. “You take the basement, and do a good job. I didn’t spend much time down there during the last visit.”

“Sure thing, boss,” Brent said. A pleasant young man, Brent was still a probationary trainee for Diego’s exterminating service. But, he had impressed his boss by doing a thorough, effective job.

Like his boss, Brent looked good in the gray uniform with the company logo. An inch shy of the six-foot mark, he wasn’t as tall as Diego. He opened the door to the basement and felt for a switch. Finding it, he flipped on the lights, immediately providing some bright illumination for the dim, shadowy basement. In size 12 work boots, Brent stomped down the flight of stairs carrying all the tools of his trade.

For the tiny man, the sight of a huge man in a gray uniform, a canister of insecticide draped onto his muscular body with a shoulder strap, petrified him. He stood in the shadow of the row of cardboard boxes. He had wished for so long that someone would come to the basement. Now, he simply wanted them to go away.

But, as he stared up in terror, he realized it wasn't the same exterminator. In addition, he heard the clomp of more distant footsteps as an unseen second giant stomped around upstairs.

Once in the basement, Brent made a cursory inspection, which soon revealed an ant-covered energy bar on a towel beneath an exercise bench.

“Well, that’s a sure way to attract pests,” Brent said as he reached for the chocolate bar. Picking it up in one hand, he looked for a place to dispose of it.

The whole time, his actions were observed with increasing horror by the tiny basement occupant. Even claimed by the ants, the energy bar had represented his only food source. He didn’t want to consider the consequences of being left without food in the bleak basement.

He sprinted across the concrete plain, desperate now to make contact. He waved his arms and tried to shout for help.

“Don’t take that,” he screamed. “I need that.”

Brent, seeing the row of boxes stacked along one wall, figured he might find a place to get rid of the bar in that direction. He began stomping across the concrete floor, unaware of the shrunken man running headlong toward him.
11112212122.title: Double Trouble

choices: Moving the boxes!
Going to spray elsewhere
111122121222.content:
Brent stood before the row of cardboard crates and boxes.

Five waist high stacks made up the row, and they were pushed well against the far corner of the basement. He shrugged off the heavy chemical container and set it down to take a look around the boxes.

No trash receptacle of any shape or form stood out to him, so he set the rancid energy bar on a box which disrupted a plume of dust. The entire row was coated in a thick layer of dust and littered with dozens of dead moths. A few small moths wafted through the dusty air near him, and were easily swatted down.

"Looks like there might be a moth infestation." The young probee remarked. He crushed the wiggling moths under his boot and turned back to the box..

Lifting a cardboard flap, more dead moths were revealed as well as a tiny spider that darted away to escape his huge hand. Dark recesses lay between each box, giving insects and spiders perfect places to hide and breed. The exterminator clicked a small LED light on and peered through one of the small gaps. Dust-covered cobwebs coated the tight space like tiny clothing lines.

"Gonna have to move these to spray back there" Brent said to himself.

He scratched his neck thoughtfully. The entire basement would need thorough spraying, along with traps to catch any remaining insects. Most infestations tended to start in the basement, and this one seemed no exception. Brent liked to be more than thorough, not only out of pride, but because any input from a satisfied home owner was good for his job.

Grunting, he turned to retrieve the energy bar and head back up stairs.

As he reached for it, he happened to glance downwards. Well-trained vision allowed the youthful exterminator to spot the tiny scurrying speck. It was headed for a gap in between the boxes furthest from Brent.

"Little bastard!" He exclaimed loudly and quickly covered the distance with two strides.

Aware of the danger, the insect jerked quickly into the cover between the two boxes. A space barely large enough for Brent to stick his thumb into.

Annoyed, Brent kicked the toe of his work boot against the gap, causing the ant to flee further into the darkness. He didn't consider for a second how the terrified bug felt and just how monstrous he looked to the such tiny creatures.

Flicking his flashlight on again, he crouched and directed the powerful beam into the gap.

Squinting, he made a quick inspection. A crumpled scrap of paper, likely another food wrapper, and little crumbs mixed with dirt lay around it. He didn't see any ants, but previous trade experience told him this was another attractant. He would have to retrieve the wrapper before spraying chemicals.

With a heavy sigh, he leaned back and pressed his hand into the gap.

----

Even in his state of desperation, Bryan knew when he was facing folly.

The humongous guy dominated the seemingly spacious basement with his bulky form. A pair of work boots carelessly stomped around on the grainy cement floor. Ants that had seemed so fierce before were flattened under the gigantic boots without notice.

Without even looking at the ground, the oblivious exterminator turned and stomped towards the boxes. Bryan halted his flailing procession as a dark brown boot, larger than a cruise ship, slammed down near him. The powerful concussion threw the tiny scientist to the ground.

"I've got to get out of here!" He shrieked. How did he think approaching the titan was a good idea?

Rescue was his utmost desire, but he knew a close encounter with one of those massive boots was a guaranteed death. The bug-sized man decided that he best return to safety and concoct an actual plan for rescue.

Bryan ran with terrific ferocity towards the gaping crevice created by the two mountain-like boxes. Memories flashed through his mind of his previous encounter with the other exterminator a month before. Despite his desperation for rescue, Bryan knew at his incredibly minute size, he would have no more luck contacting the enormous man than the ants did.

Thunderous rumbles could be heard as the giant muttered to himself. The huge man sat the impressive tank of poison on the ground, and began inspecting the boxes furthest from Bryan. With wide eyes, the minuscule scientist watched the exterminator swat foolhardy moths out of the air and grind them out under his frightening work boots. Closing his eye tightly, he continued running and tried to adopt an "out of sight, out of mind" attitude.

His heart beat lividly inside his chest and his lungs threatened to burst as he slowed to a walk. Yawning large as the Grand Canyon was the sheltering safety between the boxes just ahead.

"LITTLE BASTARD!" The sudden thunderous roar caused him to look back in horror.

Terror filled him once again, causing Bryan to run faster than he thought possible. Violent tremors followed the tiny man, causing him to leap dramatically in an attempt to secure his shelter in the gap. He skidded on the ground, and turned to see the humongous exterminator's massive form dominating his view. The giant work boots stood very close.

Suddenly, the mountain of scuffed leather lifted and rushed towards tiny Bryan, slamming into the cardboard edges with shuddering result. The terrified man squealed in horror, pulling himself up and running frantically for cover. He settled behind the flimsy scrap of paper, shaking violently from such a tremendous close call.

"Oh crap!" He cried. "What the hell is he doing?!"

The titanic boot lifted away, landing with a dull boom farther away. From his bug-sized view, the boots were mountains of rough, worn dark brown leather with powerful heavy lugged soles. He swallowed weakly at the sight, paralyzed at the thought of ending up beneath one. Like a glacier, the boot began shifting, causing a calamity of vibrations and noise.

Bryan looked up, realizing the huge man was crouching down to get a closer look. He felt an elation of hope, despite his fear (and urine-soaked pants).

"Please! I'm not a bug!" Bryan waved his thin arms and prepared to reveal himself again.

A loud 'click' and a bright light burst to life. It was like a spotlight the size of an intersection and instantly caused tiny Bryan to reel back, covering his eyes. His head throbbed and tears streamed down his face. Bryan could see the harsh white beam scanning the area, searching. He truly felt like prey being hunted. A tiny bug hiding from an incredibly huge and powerful predator.

The shrunken man had been so excited at the prospect of being rescued, he had underestimated his size and the exterminator's size. It would be nothing short of a miracle for him to be noticed at his size. Especially to somebody that denotes anything tiny to an "ant".

As if things couldn't get worse for the tiny man, they did. Huge building-sized fingers probed the tiny space with thunderous result. The hand was covered in a glove made of thick suede, giving it an even more alien like and monstrous appearance. At his miniscule size, Bryan would be instantly mashed by the smallest of movements made by the huge hand. With amazing power, the invading fingers expanded the small gap by pushing the heavy boxes apart.

"Stop!" He yelled. "Just leave me alone!"

He watched in horror as the gigantic digits carelessly decimated what had been Bryan's home. His hard-earned cache of crumbs were instantly dusted and ruined. Bryan was forced to retreat further back, watching his paper shelter get flattened and roughly pulled out by the huge hand.

Lifting it to his face, the enormous man examined the small crumpled scrap.

"JUST A PIECE OF PAPER" He noted loudly, looking dejected as if he expected something else. Without delay, he crushed the paper in his hand and dropped it back on the floor.

Bryan watched this with dread. Everything he had made and known in his time being trapped down here was just instantly destroyed without care by this giant. He wanted nothing more than to be left alone, and never to see another human again.

Just then the exterminator began to move, he was...
111122121222.title: A Thorough Inspection

choices: The situation worsens!
Bryan searches for alternative food sources
111122122.content:
The surface of the enormous towel was difficult for Bryan to trek across. The thick white stalks of fabric seemed to mimic a meadow. A meadow with knotted, tangled cotton and not soft grass.

Nearing his destination, Bryan took in the sight of the energy bar. "Oh, no..." His eyes widened while his blood ran cold. "No, no, no!"

Bryan had never considered the possibility that the energy bar would still be sealed within the protective foil wrapping. Stumbling, he sped around the gargantuan bar. It took him almost 10 minutes to completely inspect each end of it - and the result was unanimous.

"Sealed tight!" Bryan cried out. "Damnitt!"

Hungry and afraid, Bryan devolved into a state of panic. He lunged towards the side of the looming snack and racked his thin arms against the thick, reflective surface. The effort made no discernible impact on the foil wrapping. In fact, it didn't even budge. Not only was he tiny; he was incredibly weak.

The tiny man sighed and settled himself into the plush surface offered by the humongous towel.

"What the hell do I do now?"
111122122.title: Sealed tight

choices: He sees a giant spider descending from the web
A large bug stampedes from the shadows and knocks him into the web
1111221222.content:
Bryan Smith, shrunken through his own folly to the size of an insect, realizes that he may very well starve within reach of an almost inexhaustible food source.

Once again, he flails his fists against the unyielding foil wrapping that secured the nutritious energy bar. There's no possible way out of the basement. He finally sinks back to his knees on the white, knotty surface. It's so unfair. He feels really small and helpless now, all ego obliterated by the fact he cannot even manage the wrapping of a candy bar at this size.

After a long pout, he gets back onto his feet. Maybe there are other sources of food in the basement. The room looks huge, more like a sprawling metropolis than a dank storage area below his house.

"I just need to make a thorough search," he says aloud to help him focus his thoughts.

After some wandering through the changed realm that is his basement, he finds something in a dark corner tucked behind some building-sized boxes. A thin film of sickening green has spread across the concrete in the eternal shade. From it, ghostly pale mushrooms have sprouted on spindly stalks. A few of the tiny fungi are taller than him, but there are dozens of them.

Unless sauteed with a juicy steak, he's never been much of a mushroom fan. As he steps closer, his feet squish in the pale, green slick. How does he even know they're edible? They could be highly toxic. If he gets hungry enough, perhaps death by poison mushroom might be preferable to starvation. He hasn't reached that point, so he leaves the shaded canyon and continues his search.

Later, exploring beneath an old desk chair consigned to the basement, he finds a cobweb. The silk cords are anchored against one of the chair's four wooden legs, stretching across the space of a few inches to attach to the concrete wall.

He clearly saw the sticky silk threads and had no intention of stumbling into the trap. His focus was on the many trapped insects held fast in the web. Hadn't he read that insects are a great source of protein...

Ugggh. He groaned at the thought of extracting one of the plump gnats from the web and dining on it. Up close, they looks so bizarre with all those legs, the gossamer wings and spiky appendages. Not at all appetizing....

Besides, there was the challenge of getting them out of the web. This meal would require some work, unlike the stationary mushrooms just standing in rows for the taking.

While in a contemplative state, he looks down and sees a gleam on the floor. Looking closer, he finds a tiny shard of glass that he picks up in one hand. With this crude cutting edge, he could saw through each silken cable if he does need to extract the trapped insects.

Then, inspiration strikes. With this bit of broken glass, he could saw through the foil wrapper on the energy bar. He feels a surge of excitement until...
1111221222.title: Bryan searches for alternative food sources

choices: Bryan is caught!
Bryan gets up and flees
11112212221.content:
Smiling at his discovery, Bryan gripped the shard of glass in his hands with determination.

It was gross - possibly unsanitary in more than a few ways - but, Bryan needed sustenance if he wanted to survive. And, this bundled dinner of dead gnat was as good as any meal.

Two tentative steps forward and the bug-sized man suddenly froze, gasping.

The intricate construction of webbing created a sort of quasi-cathedral between the chair leg and the concrete wall. Many bundled insects adorned arching strands of glimmering silk, hanging like macabre chandeliers at almost every turn. This was not what halted the shrunken man. Higher up, against the looming surface of pitted concrete, were situated many pockets of silk: almost like hotel rooms built into a mountain side.

From such a pocket, Bryan watched one jagged leg at a time poke through, allowing a spider of monstrous scale to pull itself through. It was like something crafted from the depths of Hell itself. Not only larger than a car, but coated in fine, greasy hairs across a hardened body of black and brown exoskeleton. His whole body became trembling ice when the collection of gibbous eyes looked right at him.

Forgetting his surge of excitement, the tiny man squealed and about-faced. He immediately tripped, falling over and dropping his scavenged weapon.
11112212221.title: Monstrous Spider

111122122211.content:
"Shit!" Bryan belted in a voice brought on by sheer desperation. He attempted to right himself, clumsy in his haste. "My hands...Christ almighty!"

His palms had been savagely shredded by his makeshift weapon allowing warm bursts of blood to coat the ground. Unaccustomed to pain, Bryan lay prone in a fit of gasping terror. An hourglass seemed to dangle playfully over the writhing scientist. Each granule of sand representing his time to escape certain doom clinking away with nauseating speed.

Bloodied hands slipping over the saturated cement, Bryan's right suddenly made contact with the dangerous shard of glass. His fingers clumsily wrapped around it and he brandished it before him.

"Heh!" The spark of determination re-igniting in his eyes as he grunted out his second wind. It mapped itself out in his mind instantaneously: wield the shard of glass like Excalibur, twist around and skewer the vile spider like the dragon of yore. "I...refuse...to...die...!"

But, Fate was a bitch and Fate's finger a fickle bitch at that.

Before Bryan could enact his resurgence of will, he heard a tremendous cascade of movement followed by a looming presence from behind. Uncaring of any cardboard speech the injured man had been speaking, the huge spider fell upon him and buried two enormous fangs deep in Bryan's exposed back. Moments of sheer pain followed and Bryan heralded every second with a howling aria of high-pitched shrieks that would never be heard by another human. The spider, stone-cold and opaque-eyed, lifted the tiny, squirming man from the ground and allowed him to dangle as intricate muscles viciously pumped liters and liters of toxins into the shrunken man.

As per usual, the spider began the task of prepping a meager, but nourishing meal. It lavished the catch no more than any other. Bryan was just another bug foolish enough to blunder within reach. It held no concept of how horrific or cruel the process would be for this strange pink victim. Meanwhile, Bryan felt the pain ebb away until nothing of his extremities could be felt or moved. A double-edged blade: he was spared any further signals of physical torment reaching his brain while his vision continued to work. He would witness every second of his nightmarish end.

His thoughts zipped through his head slower than the last. Slowing, slowing, slowing until only a few could be coherently understood to him.

Why.....This has to be a dream.....Fuck my shitting luck with a stick.....but, I discovered the impossible....

Last but not least, Bryan's mind pictured himself enjoying a day at the beach with his favourite nephew and neighbour. Himself falling to eternal rest upon the golden sands.
111122122211.title: Nightmarish End

choices: Bryan struggles to survive
Bryan has unexpected visitors
111122122212.content:
"Oh, shit! Shit, shit, shit!" His cursing came out ragged and breathless. "Fuck! Not a spider...not a goddamned giant spider!"

He stumbled, picking himself up in the process and bolted forward. Only then did he remember his weapon that lay dangerously close to the descending monster.

Bryan looked back, feeling as if he would turn to salt if he did, and squeaked. The huge arachnid touched down, gracefully landing on all eight legs like some hideous dancer and stepping over his forlorn weapon.

"Fuck that!"

Forsaking the rare tool, he bolted as fast as his tiny - and comically thin - legs would allow him. Running, and running, and continuing to run until his limbs threatened to cave in from exhaustion.

Only then did he dare glance back, hoping beyond hope that he wasn't going to see that fucking spider.

And, he didn't. The coast was clear; the massive chair looming surprisingly far against the towering wall that housed the godless arachnid. Bryan nearly deflated as he flopped upon the cold ground with a sigh.

It was like his nightmares come true - a spider, bigger than his damn car, crawling after him with bulging eyes. And, just the memory of those eyes made Bryan shudder. He held back tears, merely thankful the entire ordeal was over. Never would he go there again - not as long as he lived.

That damned spider could keep the glass shard for all he cared!

Standing back up, Bryan needed to gather his bearings and figure out a new plan.
111122122212.title: Fleeing

choices: Bryan attempts to escape
Bryan meets the spider
11112212222.content:
Looking from his newly acquired blade of glass to the hanging bundles above, Bryan considers this option.

"People eat insects all the time... I mean, it can't be THAT bad!" The tiny man reasoned while squinting at one bundled gnat closest to him.

Stepping nearer to the glittering strands, he looked up at it. His foot nearly brushed a large pile of webbing. Thankful for his lithe build and nimble step, Bryan managed to avoid other strands and bits of sticky silk as he neared the captured gnat.

The entire structure of webs was nothing short of a marvel. The bug-sized man found himself gazing around, slack-jawed with curiosity. Never before had any biologist investigated the intricacy of these arachnid homes with such first-person detail. Dozens - no, hundreds of the silken strands stretched around and overhead. Some glimmered dully in the meager light of the basement, while others sagged heavily from collections of dust and dirt.

"Yes, very remarkable, but I need to concentrate!" Bryan shook his head and turned his attention back to the hopeful source of food. "Just a couple more feet..."

Suddenly, he froze. A scratching, gnawing sound had pierced the relative silence, sending a sharp chill down his tiny spine. "What the hell...?" Again, he heard it, so much louder that he almost dropped his precious weapon in surprise. It was behind him!

Bryan turned, his eyes wide and his hands already sweating. He immediately qourked in terror. An insect - if it could be called that - skittered from the shadows and began a furious rampage directed at tiny Bryan. Only a tiny beetle to the normal human: this beetle looked nothing short of a tank of heavy plate with glinting eyes and clashing mandibles.

It was upon him more quickly that he anticipated. Many quick legs allowed the hulking beast to move quickly and with tremendous force. Bryan stepped back, feeling his legs squish into a slimy strand of silk, effectively trapping him.

"Oh, fuck me!" Then the beetle crashed through the webbing that separated them and hurled itself into Bryan.

Bryan's thin, diminutive form was flung backwards violently. He felt himself collide with the bundled gnat and break through many ropes of spider silk. Abruptly, he came to a stop seemingly mid-air. His entire body was covered in scraps of sticky silk, while he backside was held suspended by it.

The powerful collision had his brain in a whirl. His vision threatening to go black into unconsciousness. Bryan shook his head into awareness and groaned painfully.

His groan was met with a hissing response, which made the tiny man jolt. More than ten feet before him lay the enraged beetle that caused this. It clacked and thrashed lightly, before sinking to the ground with a final hiss. Bryan stared in both shock and disbelief, unable to remove his eyes from the horrific insect that assaulted him. Atop the bulky bug's small head, the shrunken man noticed a dull object that jutted from a bulbous eye.

"The glass shard!" The beetle, driven by instinct, failed to notice the pointed shred of glass wielded by the tiny prey. It had pierced through the beetle's head with ease upon impact.

This was fine and dandy - yet Bryan had now been forced into a worse predicament. He was hopelessly trapped!
11112212222.title: Instinct driven

choices: Pulled it free!
Something happens!
111122122221.content:
"Uuurgh! Gah!" The tiny man's voice squeaked while he thrashed and shook himself.

It was hopeless - his feeble attempts only managing to tire him and make himself feel foolish. He wondered if his comical attempts amused any insects that might be watching. It was this thought that made him freeze.

"Oh God!" He cried out. Realization of the web's true purpose now dawning upon him.

Bryan fell still; Only turning his head back and forth. Besides the now dead beetle and a few dangling victims, Bryan saw no signs of the webs architect. He allowed himself a few minutes to relax before continuing his escape.

He was suspended many feet above the ground like a puppet. Half a dozen sticky strands fused to both his backside and right leg, allowing only his other leg and both arms any effectual movement. Beneath him lay a bundled gnat - the very one he contemplated consuming. It's size rivaled that of a small sedan and it was almost within the tiny man's flailing grasp.

"If I could reach it, I might be able to pull myself off..." Bryan clenched his teeth and attempted to grab the nearest appendage.

It seemed hopeless, when he had another spark of inspiration.

Bryan slowly began to shift his weight: forward, then backward. He did this increasingly until his momentum was enough that he nearly brushed against the fallen gnat's leg.

SNAP!

"Aaaaahhhhcck!" Bryan squealed.

The sticky webbing that supported his minuscule frame snapped from the unusual exertion applied by the tiny man's movement. Bryan found himself swinging forward - still held by two strands of silk - and face-first into the deceased beetle's carcass. It was like colliding with a plate glass window - a window coated in grease and sharp bumps.

Using his hands, Bryan steadied himself. As he did so, he released a yelp of joy.

Within realistic reach of his thin arm, protruded his make-shift glass shard weapon sticking proudly from the beetle's bulging eye.

"Finally, Lady Luck shines on me for once!"

Bryan reached for the shard and...
111122122221.title: Lady Luck

choices: Find a way to bandage his hands
Look for help!
1111221222211.content:
Wrapping both of his hands around the shard of glass, the tiny man pulled with a scream. In his excitement, he failed to realize removing the jagged glass would cost him severely.

"Fuck! My hands! Fucking fucker!" He squealed, pulling his hands back to see both torn and soaked in blood. He clambered awkwardly against the enormous beetle, his body dangling against the knobby shell. One hand bumped against the surface and pain screamed through his whole body. Blood from the long cuts wept steadily, seeping down his thin arms and dripping to the ground below.

The glass shard remained adamantly stuck, uncaring and unmoved by his attempt. Bryan clenched his teeth, trying hard to keep back tears. He needed that damn blade of glass - no matter the cost!

"Grrrrraaaaaaaaaagh!" Flinging himself in a state of pure adrenaline and desperation, he gripped the cruel shard once more and pulled.

It shifted, biting into his hands with seemingly hungry malice, and suddenly sliding free.

"Motherfucking...! Oh, god... Yes!" He cried through the pain.

Careful to not drop it, he twisted his silken bindings and began jabbing and cutting at them with the shard. Each effort was a test in strength for Bryan. Jolts of blinding pain shot through him each time - each more painful than before. Yet, somehow, he prevailed and found himself falling the distance to the dusty floor below.
