He rolled into a fetal position. The bloodied glass clinking next to him, gleaming with his life's blood like a satisfied predator. Bryan moaned, looking his shredded palms over and grinding his teeth. The cuts were deep and needed nothing short of many stitches to stem the bleeding. Bryan felt woozy just looking, so he pressed them against his sides.

"I need to find help, right now... dammitt!"

All worries of starvation and dehydration seemed utterly minuscule now. Bryan had only managed to blunder himself into a far greater peril. It seemed Fate, God, or whatever the hell was out there just wanted him to suffer more and more before finally succumbing to death. He would be nothing but a tiny dot on his basement floor; dead, bloodied, and completely unseen. The police would probably crush him underfoot without ever knowing!

Hugging himself, Bryan stood and decided to...
1111221222211.title: Freedom at a cost

choices: A jumping spider spies him from its perch on the kitchen light fixture
A housefly buzzes his head
11113.content:
Although he had used the formula on earlier testing occasions, he was still left in awe after going from his normal height of 5'10" to the measly size of a mere quarter of an inch.

Bryan retrieved his pre-shrunk clothes and pulled them on. He still had at least a half-hour before Tommy would arrive to take the package (and its tiny passenger) to the post office.

The tiny man marveled at the vast landscape of the flat tabletop. The polished wood beneath his feet stretched out for what looked like miles. His gaze focused on the building-sized package placed in the center of his kitchen table. Nearby, he saw the twin towers represented by a pair of glass salt and pepper shakers.

"I might as well get inside the package," Bryan said aloud, only to feel his voice swallowed by the immensity of the room.

As he started the trek across the tabletop, he got the uncanny feeling that he was being watched...
11113.title: Household pests

choices: landed several inches behind him
landed between him and the box
111131.content:
The tiny arachnid would have, before Bryan took the shrinking formula, been no bigger than the scientist's thumbnail.

Now, in comparison to the bug-sized man, the spider was as big as an African lion, and even more terrifying.

The predator, unlike some spiders that just hang out in their webs until something stumbles into their grasp, lived in active lifestyle. With excellent vision, due to four complex pairs of eyes, the jumping spider tracks its prey.

When it spied likely prey scurrying on the tabletop, the spider leaped from the light fixture attached to the ceiling over the kitchen table. Plunging confidently toward that distant surface, the spider had the benefit of being able to attach a cable of silk that it could use later to retract itself back to its hiding place.

Tiny Bryan had covered half the distance over the table toward his shipping crate when he looked toward the ceiling, which his brain kept insisting represented the sky.

To his surprise, he saw something falling toward him. His confused brain interpreted the falling creature as a skydiver.

Then, as the plunging creature continued its descent, Bryan made out more details, including an an oblong body bigger than his shrunken form and eight spindly legs.

"Oh fuck!" Bryan screamed and bolted as fast as he could toward the box.

The spider landed softly on the huge kitchen table, several inches from the tiny man.

The predator had no way of knowing that the prey had been alerted to its approach, but as soon as it felt its eight feet on the solid surface, the arachnid pivoted and focused its eight eyes.

It's excellent vision instantly detected the prey, which was on the move.

Bryan, realizing that he had reduced himself to no more than helpless prey, looked around to locate where the spider had landed.

He saw that the spider had...
111131.title: Predator/Prey

choices: The spider grabs Mr. Smith
Spider AND Mr. Smith are trapped together in the box
1111311.content:
The jumping spider landed precisely where it wanted, and immediately all eight legs kicked into gear as the lion-sized arachnid scrambled across the tabletop, closing the gap between it and its vulnerable prey.

The little man had started running before the airborne spider reached the wooden surface of the table and scurried over the three-inch gap between it and him.

His goal was to reach the safety of the box. He could seal the box from inside, denying the spider access.

The contest, however, would be determined by whether bug-sized Mr. Smith's two legs were faster than the spider's eight.

The spider also had one other advantage, as its name of jumping spider implied. As its prey pulled out of reach and seemed close to ducking inside the box, the spider's brain sent signals for its legs to prepare for a powerful, well-aimed leap.

"Yes," Mr. Smith gasped as he arrived at the narrow entrance into the box.... just as the spider's leap flung its horrendous body toward him.
1111311.title: Pursuit and evasion

choices: Tommy enters
Somebody else enters
11113111.content:
Just reaching the rough tear that led into the safety of the humongous box, Bryan glanced back.

A comically pitched squeal let loose at the sight of the hideous spider lunging at him like a wildcat. Bryan turned to rush through the entrance and hide himself in the safe confines of the box. He stumbled through, all together too quickly and far too clumsy, and fell over a jagged tear in the cardboard landing flat on his face.

"Gahh... Shit... My nose...!" He gurgled as blood wept over his face. Bryan struggled to raise himself. "Need to... Get... Safety... Just a litt-..."

Suddenly he heard pounding from behind and something grabbed him. "Nooooooo!!!" Blood from his injured nose intruded his mouth as he yelled, causing him to choke on it. He was dragged roughly back, feeling something wet and gooey cover his legs. Bryan's heart felt as if it would burst from his chest at the rate it was going. He struggled vainly. This was easily the most terrifying turn of events possible.

The terror really began when he was wretched into the air and made to face the horrific creature. Not more than 3 feet away was the array of eight glinting eyes that stared mercilessly at him. They looked like bulbous plums larger than his hands and seemed to pulsate randomly. Underneath Bryan saw the gnashing mandibles capable of grinding his tiny, pink form into a shapeless paste. The tiny man yelped and wiggled violently, his broken nose continuing to spurt blood.

The spider frothed hungrily at him. His struggles seemed only to excite the beastly arachnid. "This can't be happening... Oh, God. Somebody, HELP!"

Bryan was convinced of his doom when a loud crash shook both he and the large spider.
11113111.title: Snatched!

choices: Tommy spots the spider on the counter
Tommy spots the package and money on the counter
111131111.content:
Bryan's thin, frightened voice rang out with despair.

"Oh, God! Somebody, HELP!"

As if an answer from God himself, the humongous backdoor flung open with tremendous force.

Dripping a mix of blood, tears, and mucus, Bryan turned his gaze towards the distrubance. Clutching the tiny man with strong mandibles, the spider steadied itself against the explosive gale produced by the opened door. Bryan felt the monstrous arachnid become rigid, gazing hatefully towards the newcomer.

"MR. SMITH?" What Bryan might mistake for the boom of thunder was, in fact, his neighbour Tommy. "HELLO? ANYBODY HOME!?"

Bryan could only gawk. The sight was nothing short of awesome - and his large arachnid captor seemed in agreement. Both of them, barely larger than a penny upon Bryan's kitchen counter, watched Tommy walk around the kitchen. Each movement the colossal teenager made was accompanied shortly by a quaking boom. Tommy lumbered past the counter - his pace was enormous, yet seemingly slowed and sluggish.

The behemoth passed into the living room, out of sight. Bryan could still feel slight vibrations, as well as detect Tommy's thunderous voice calling for him.

"Tommy! I am here!" Bryan attempted to respond, thrashing his tiny form against the iron-grip of the spider. "Toooommmmy!"

Suddenly, the gigantic youth appeared in the doorway. Bryan froze once more, captured again by the sheer majesty of his enormous neighbour. A look of confusion dominated the titan's planet-sized face. Tommy proceeded into the room, looking around and scratching his neck. His enormous gait shaking both Bryan and his captor. The shrunken man looked helplessly at the gigantic youth towering before him.

"Help me! Please, help me! You have to-..."

"HE MUST OF LEFT ALREADY." Tommy unknowingly interrupted, standing huge and tall over the countertop.

Bryan felt his eyes become misty once more, as desperation threatened to take hold. Tommy right next to him, why didn't he see him?

"WHAT'S THAT?"

Tommy's massive form broke into movement suddenly.
111131111.title: Tommy Enters

choices: Crush the spider
Sweep the spider off the table and onto the floor
1111311112.content:
Tommy's massive form continued to advance into the kitchen.

"He must of left already," the teenager said after making his way into Mr. Smith's home without encountering any sign of the owner. Of course, that wasn't too surprising. His neighbor had told him he wouldn't be home.

Tommy's sudden movement sent the spider, clutching tightly its captured meal, scurrying for cover. The dark, furry arachnid used its eight legs to quickly travel the few inches to hide between the towers of glass and stainless steel represented by the salt and pepper shakers on the tabletop.

"What's that?" The teenager wondered.

Tommy's attention missed the tiny, fleeing spider. His eyes had fastened on the promised package and payment waiting for him on the table, just as Mr. Smith had told him it would be.

"Good ol' dependable Mr. Smith," the teenager said as he scooped the package from the table in one hand. He then grabbed the money Mr. Smith had left him, an unthinkable amount for a task as menial as mailing something for him.

Tommy held the box to his ear, shaking it. "Wonder what's so important?"

Each time the bug-sized scientist squirmed, the spider's strong mandibles tightened their grip on him. He knew the spider would soon use its venomous fangs to finish him off.

"Tommy!" He could still scream, although his voice was getting hoarse. "Please, save me. Down here! Oh please look for me!"

His screams, desperate as they were, went unheard by the massive teenaged titan.

The shrunken owner of the home realized that if Tommy left with the package, his only means of returning to normal size would go with him.

Not that it mattered much if he became a light snack for the awful spider.

The spider remained nervous. The teenager's movements kept the creature uncertain. It want only one thing, which was a dark recess to hide while enjoying its meal.

Decision reached, it scurried into the open, using its multiple eyes to look for a place to finish off its prey in peace. Impatience, however, exposed it to a teenager's sharp eyes.

"What the…." Tommy said when he saw the spider crawling swiftly across the tabletop.

The teenager acted mostly from reflex, using the cardboard package in his hand to...
1111311112.title: Tommy's His Only Hope

11113111121.content:
Still held firmly in the mandible of the awful spider, tiny Bryan gazed up at the mammoth teenager. Tommy's skin looked even more pale in contrast to the black, sleeveless T-shirt he wore. His long, dark hair cascaded like waves over the cliff of his forehead.

The spider's alert senses caused it to twitch nervously. The tiny man, captured in its grasp, tried to squirm free. The spider renewed its grasp, which might as well have been bands of steel holding him in place. He screamed in anguish. "Tommy! Down here! Look down here!"

Tommy did look, but all the teenager's big, dark eyes saw was the unexpected and unwelcome presence of a tiny, furry spider crawling on Mr. Smith's tabletop.

"What the..." Tommy said in surprise. "Ugh, I hate spiders."

He used the carton held in his right hand as the most immediate means for dealing with the little pest before it could escape into hiding.

Mr. Smith saw the teenager's hand lifted over him, enormous fingers curled on the side of the building-sized mailing carton as the teenager lowered it toward the table. Unable to see beyond the colossal hand and the package, he was spared the grimace of distaste on the teenager's normally attractive face.

"No!" The shrunken scientist screamed as he recognized what was about to happen. "Tommy, don't!"

The tiny spider, plunged into darkness, froze to ascertain the surprise development.

The package, used as an improvisational means of pest control, landed with a loud, explosive BOOM! Spider and tiny human exploded in a gory mess.

Tommy lifted the package and surveyed the aftermath, easily locating the pulverized remains of the spider, including a few mangled limbs that still twitched ever so slightly. He also saw another tiny crushed form.

"Hehe," the teenager laughed. "Gross. Looks like I took out two little pests."

The second tiny bug had been so thoroughly crushed that very little recognizable evidence remained. Tommy did see one pale, tiny, thin limb. He thought it oddly funny that it almost looked like a human arm.

"Well, world's a better place without bugs, especially the weird ones," he remarked before leaving, package in hand, to complete the mailing arrangements as he had been instructed by Mr. Smith.
11113111121.title: Hand of Destruction

choices: Stomp
Notices the tiny creature doesn't quite look like a spider
11113111122.content:
The tiny scientist looked at Tommy in a whole new light now that he had shrunken himself to the size of an insect. His teenaged neighbor now looked like a powerful god.

In that vein, the shrunken man prayed the god would notice and, hopefully, save him from his own folly.

At any moment, the horrible spider, having already captured its helpless prey, would finish him off. The tiny man struggled again, remorseful that he had ever invented the shrinking formula. He couldn't believe he was about to become a meal for a creature he could have once crushed with a single fingertip.

"Tommy! Please!" He screamed again. "Down here… save me from the spider!"

The tiny man, still held firmly in the arachnid's clutches, saw Tommy's enormous face as it turned and glanced downward.

Downward toward the spider.

"Yes!" Mr. Smith rejoiced. "Here I am!"

"WHAT THE…" Tommy said loudly.

He swept the tabletop with the package Mr. Smith had instructed him to mail. In one powerful motion, he brushed the spider off the table.

Well, the spider and one very tiny man, who fell screaming toward the floor. The action, however, had forced the spider to release its grip on its prey.

Shrunken scientist and spider hit the floor a considerable distance from each other. Before Mr. Smith could celebrate his rescue, however, another danger became immediately apparent.

Tommy scanned the floor, searching for the spider. He figured the least he could do would be to remove the eight-legged pest from his neighbor's house.

Knowing that the creature was pathetically small, his eyes were alert for any sign of the tiny creature.

He chuckled when his eyes detected a scurrying motion that, surprisingly, was running toward him instead of trying to escape.

Tommy shrugged. The dumb spider was just making his job easier.

He raised a sneaker...
11113111122.title: Pest Eradication

choices: Tommy forgets the other odd bug
Tommy looks for the other odd bug
111131111221.content:
"Ha!" Tommy said excitedly. "There you are."

Had the teenager seen him? Recognized him?

"Tommy, yes!" The tiny man cried, so confident he was about to be rescued. "It's me..."

"Stupid bug," Tommy said, carefully aiming his raised sneaker for maximum impact when he brought it down.

"No!" The shrunken scientist came to a halt within the twilight region of shadow beneath the massive sneaker. "Don't step on me! Don't!"

At that moment, the spider scurried back into the scene, attracted to the shadowy darkness that had appeared thanks to a teenager's huge shoe. The terrified tiny man abandoned language and screeched in pure terror as they eight-legged monstrosity rushed toward him. It couldn't be! The monster was back and bearing down on him. He saw the fangs and multiple eyes in the creature's nightmarish face.

"What the...." A distracted Tommy said, adjusting his aim and bringing the paused shoe down on the phobic-enhancing arachnid with a loud boom and a feeble, squelching crush.

A wave of nausea overcame the shrunken man. The huge shoe lifted, making the ferocity of his nausea increase as he gazed on the mangled spider smashed into the tread of the sneaker. The scene blurred and the tiny man fainted.
111131111221.title: Stomping Time

choices: House is now empty
Finds Tommy taking a nap on the sofa
1111311112211.content:
His sudden and zealous urge to demolish and destroy satisfied with the obliteration of the spider, Tommy almost instantly forgot about the other odd bug that he had seen before the interloping spider infiltrated the scene.

For tiny Mr. Smith, that's a mixed blessing. The teenager's enormous shoes step near his body, unconscious and limp after the faint, but spare him the fate of the arachnid. When he leaves the room, he leaves the tiny man unnoticed and without aid.

A short while later, his next-door neighbor stirs, only to find his skull aching. He holds his head in his hands as he forces himself into a crouched position on the floor. His eyes snap open as he remembers the last thing before the fade to black...

A shoe... Tommy's gigantic sneaker ... slamming down with the force of a god's hammer, absolutely destroying the fearsome predator of insects.

Now, the house is still and silent.

Staggering onto his feet, the shrunken scientist wondered if Tommy had left. "He can't be gone," the tiny man moaned. "He's my only hope for getting back to normal size."

Despite the pain afflicting his skull, the tiny man forced himself to look for the teenager.
1111311112211.title: Tommy forgets the other odd bug

choices: Try to climb and reach Tommy
Wait for the teenaged giant to wake
11113111122112.content:
He felt a sobering splash of fear as he looked back on his he had nearly come to ruin, all because of an ordinary teenager's good-intentioned blundering.

As the tiny man explored the immediate vicinity, he remembered Tommy's shoe raised far above him, ready to crash down and destroy the spider. He knew that he owed Tommy a huge favor for unknowingly saving him from the awful spider's clutches, but it also reminded the scientist just how small he had become. Anyone looking at him now was almost sure to mistake him for an insect.

Thanks to Tommy's quite effective eradication of the arachnid, Mr. Smith now knew with crystal clarity how the teenager dealt with tiny pests. He swallowed hard. "I've got to be careful," he said aloud in the overwhelming stillness of his giant home.

It was the fact that everything was so still and quite that he heard the strange sound. He almost mistook it for a storm rumbling somewhere out of sight beyond the horizon, but then he realized he was inside his own home. "It can't be an approaching storm," he said, turning to face the direction of the loud, rumbling noise. He stared toward the monolithic doorway that served as an awesome divide between the realm of the kitchen and the expanse of the living room beyond it.

Having recovered most of his strength, the shrunken scientist sprinted across the floor in the direction of the doorway. The sound grew louder and was frustratingly familiar. "What is it?" Mr. Smith kept asking himself.

Standing on the floor beneath the heavenly arch of the enormous doorway, the shrunken scientist peered across the landscape. His eyes fixed on a distant sofa, looking like a bizarre mountainscape. Draped over the upholstered slopes of the mountainous piece of furniture, he saw an awesome sight and instantly recognized the source of the noise.

"It's Tommy!" He shouted aloud. "He didn't leave!"

True enough, his next-door neighbor was still present in the house, but he had sprawled on Mr. Smith's sofa for a quick nap. The thunderous rumbles turned out to be Tommy's snoring.

"But I need his help," he uttered as he pondered how he could possibly wake such a slumbering titan.

He crossed the threshold into the living room kingdom, realizing he still had quite an expanse to travel. He kept his eyes on Tommy's distant form. The teenager, really just some scrawny kid in jeans, T-shirt and a pair of sneakers, was now an unbelievable enormity hard for the scientist to comprehend at his new status as a bug-sized human.

As he made the tiring trek across the living room floor, he tried to develop a strategy. Once he reached the sofa, what should he do then?
11113111122112.title: Approaching Storm

choices: Tommy flicks the bug off his chest
Tommy swats the bug with his hand
111131111221121.content:
The tiny scientist, now smaller than the smallest of bug, raced across the floor, motivated by the unexpected second chance at seeking assistance in ending his dilemma from Tommy, his next-door teenaged neighbor.

The skinny youth had sacked out on Mr. Smith's sofa for a quick nap. Normally, the shrunken man would have decried this lack of motivation on Tommy's part, but it now provided an unexpected reprieve.

Tommy had placed the shipping package on the coffee table near the sofa. Mr. Smith saw the building-sized cardboard container overhanging the edge of the table — so close, yet so far!

He checked, but saw no way of scaling the table. The four supporting legs, looking like the support columns for some mega-structure, provided no means of ascent for the bug-sized man.

The upholstery of the sofa, however, provided plenty of tiny handholds in the loops and folds of the fabric. The tiny scientist convinced himself he could scale the sofa and reach the teenager's sleeping form, which now looked much more impressive and scary from the shrunken man's reduced perspective.

Quite some time later, he achieved the first goal in his plan. He reached the cushions that supported Tommy's resting form. Now, he simply needed to make contact with the teenaged titan.

"Tommy!" Mr. Smith screamed. "Wake up! Please, wake up!"

When his tiny, high-pitched cries yielded no results, he knew he needed a better plan. He examined the enormous swath of cotton fabric spanning Tommy's torso. Could he climb the teenager's T-shirt?

A short while later, successfully having made a climb onto Tommy's chest, the bug-sized man turned and faced Tommy's enormous head and face. The teenager's eyes remained closed, and his breathing sounded even more thunderous at this close proximity.

"Tommy!" Mr. Smith shouted. "Help!"

Tommy's eyes fluttered as he woke, slowly at first.

The bug-sized scientist felt the teenager's giant body start to shift.

"Whoa!" The little man screamed, running toward the huge face. "Tommy! Here! Help me!"

As he woke, Tommy heard an irritating drone, sort of like the buzz of an insect. Still groggy from his nap, he squinted his eyes and saw the source of the sound — a tiny bug crawling across the front of his shirt.

With a yawn, he complained, "Awww, fuck! Not another damn bug!"

Mr. Smith heard and panicked. "No! No!" He shouted again. "It's me! I've shrunk... you've got to help me!"

Tommy lifted his right hand. "I can't believe Mr. Smith lets these little pests run free in his house."

His shouts of no avail, he abandoned attempts to communicate and turned to flee.

Tommy's raised hand cast a dark shadow, quickly outpacing the bug-sized scientist.
111131111221121.title: Try to climb and reach Tommy

choices: Tommy wants to help, but he's only a teenager
Tommy is more curious than helpful
111131111222.content:
When he looked back on the moment, Tommy couldn't say what stopped him from stomping the scurrying bug. He usually didn't hesitate to stomp such tiny pests.

Fortunately, he took a second look. For one thing, the "bug" stood on two legs. The bug raised a familiar face toward him and squeaked at him.

In the silence of the empty room, he could just make out the tiny pleas if he concentrated.

"Tommy! Don't step on me! Don't! Please!" The shrunken scientist pleaded for his life, uncertain if his gigantic teenaged neighbor had recognized him or was on the verge of stomping a bug.

"Oh fuck!" Tommy gasped, erasing any doubt. "It's really you, Mr. Smith. What happened?"

He felt so relieved that he let himself sink to his knees as he blurted out an incoherent story that was lost as his tiny squeaks went unheard as Tommy looked around the room. The teenager stepped away, his sneakers causing tremors to move through the floorboards. As he returned, the shrunken scientist saw Tommy held a skyscraper-sized glass in one of his hands.

"Let's get you off the floor," the teenager said in, Bryan felt, a helpful voice.

That didn't keep him from cringing as a huge hand dropped toward him.
111131111222.title: Something odd

111131112.content:
The spider froze suddenly. Bryan would of thought it was nothing more than a statue if not for the terrible pulsating eyes.

The calamity of noise, coupled with a terrific gale of wind accompanied the opening of Bryan's now colossal backdoor. Held tight in the spider's clutches, he turned his head to view the new arrival.

"HEY, BRYAN! YOU HOME?" Exploded a deep, booming voice that sounded more god-like thunder than human speech.

Forgetting all about his plight, Bryan stared dumbly at the impossibly huge being the loomed in his doorway. It took him a moment to even recognize who it was.

"Mike!" He gasped. "Thank God! Mike!"

Relief washed over him at this fortunate realization. Mike was Bryan's next door neighbor and known as the "go-to guy" in the neighborhood because of his friendly nature and mechanical know-how. He was dressed casually; t-shirt, jeans, and a navy-blue cap over his cropped hair. Bryan could usually rely on the guy for anything, often more than Tommy who was known for occasionally slacking off. The spider continued to stay frozen, but Bryan felt anything but fear.

Unfortunately, there was one problem: Bryan was tiny.

Mike looked nothing short of colossus. His already tall, built form was now blown to impossible size, causing him to appear like some mythic titan of old. Slamming the door behind him, Mike lumbered towards the counter where Bryan was held by the large spider. Heaving vibrations accompanied each movement the enormous man made, along with dull booming that reminded Bryan of distant bombs going off.

"Holy shit, he's huge!" Said the shrunken man. "Hey! Mike! Down here! He-..."

"BRYAN!" Humongous Mike rudely interrupted without noticing any diminutive cries. "BROUGHT YOUR DVD BACK" Mike came to a halt before the counter, planet-sized face gazing around the kitchen and his gigantic hand holding a massive DVD case.

Bryan suddenly felt fear. Fear of his trust and friendly neighbor who was now towering over him unlike any mountain Bryan had ever seen. Thinking himself prepared and ready, the shrunken scientist had never anticipated any of his current situations. He never considered being confronted by any insects, nor had he ever planned on encountering a human at his diminished size--especially a Navy man like Mike.

Bryan did dream of it though. Secretly, the thought both thrilled and frightened him. Now, he found it mostly frightened him.

"Miiiiike! Help me!" Bryan shouted up at his huge neighbor. Wiggling, Bryan batted his thin arms against the stubborn spider. "I need to get Mike to notice me, if I can just..."

Powerful vibrations rattled Bryan when Mike suddenly moved again. The bug-sized man gaped up at him again, remarking on his thick muscles visible through his shirt that jolted slightly with every step the huge man took. As if in slow motion, Mike stomped towards the living room door and thundered his neighbor's name again. Bryan screamed vainly from his spot on the counter, which Mike heard none of. His gigantic form turned back to the counter, large feet thudding heavy, looming over it once again.

"GUESS I'LL JUST LEAVE IT HERE."

The giant hand laid the massive DVD case down on the counter top, covering many city blocks worth of space. Bryan cried in terror, fearing that he may be crushed beneath it. "No! I'm here, right here! Heeeelp!"

Suddenly, it happened.

"WHAT THE...?" Bryan felt a shiver go down his spine when Mike gazed directly at him. "A BUG."

Bryan had a bad feeling. "The spider! Help me! Get rid of the spider!" He demanded in a shrill wail.

His giant face showed no signs of recognition as Mike raised his hand, thumb poised, as if in response to Bryan's diminutive plea. The spider, stubborn and foolish, was convinced that standing perfectly still would make it invisible to the colossal human, but Bryan was not so foolish. The huge digit lowered quickly. Its immense size blotted out the owner, leaving Bryan a view of the huge fleshy surface covered in dirt-filled ridges.

The tiny scientist belted out one last plea for help before the massive thumb pressed down upon both human and arachnid.

---

"Hey, Bryan! You home?" Mike called out to his neighbor's empty kitchen.

He held Bryan's copy of "Dirty Work", a comedy that Mike had been wanting to see for years and Bryan had been nice enough to lend it to him.

"His car was in the driveway..." He told himself as he stepped inside and closed the door. Mike had been over to his neighbor's house so often that he felt not qualms about entering without invitation. Bryan had nicely told him to visit whenever he felt like it. His wife, Ella, had him mowing the lawn most of the morning. Mike jumped at the chance to return the DVD to Bryan and maybe have a chat with him. Bryan was nice, but oddly never seemed to be doing anything important.

Mike remained ignorant of how his presence affected one teeny speck held captive by a small spider on the counter before him. He stopped next to the counter and looked around, confused.

"Bryan!" He bellowed. "Brought your DVD back!"

Nothing but a very faint squeaking noise returned his summons. Ignoring the minor noise, he called into the living room with no result.

"He must of gone out or something..." He thought, still looking around the kitchen as if his missing neighbor would pop from the woodwork. Turning to the counter again, he muttered. "Guess I'll just leave it here."

Mike set the plastic case down on the counter, paying a cursory glance to a small package already sitting there. His eyes then settled on a small black shape near the box. "What the...?"

"A bug." More specifically, a spider, but Mike never bothered much for any insect. Tiny and thoughtless, and notably, invasive. Just the other day, Mike had dealt with an ant hill that seemed to periodically appear on his front lawn.

Not squeamish in the least, Mike brought his large thumb down flat on the stagnant bug, barely feeling it crunch under the calloused skin. He smiled at the mashed remains, thinking how Bryan freaked out over the single beetle that appeared when he was at Mike's cook-out a few months back. He figured it was the least he could do for his neighbor.

"I'll give him a call later" Mike said, wiping his thumb off on his jeans and left the house.

He whistled as he strode across the lawn heading for his own, oblivious to anything that ended up under his larger sneakers, and stopping suddenly when a kid approached up Bryan's walkway. The teenager looked like he was in a hurry as he rushed to the back door, paying Mike no attention. He shrugged, and returned to his own home

Ella called out to Mike, asking him to wipe his feet and announcing lunch, all thoughts of Bryan Smith were instantly forgotten.
111131112.title: Good natured

choices: Zack returns and is upset to open a box containing a spider
Tiny Mr. Smith feels the box just before Zack arrives
11113112.content:
The fearsome predator's leap carried it forward with a bit too much momentum. Crashing into the little man's body, the spider pushed the screaming shrunken scientist deeper into the box that he had carefully prepared for transport to his nephew.

In the dark interior of the box, the tiny man scrambled into the fabric folds of the gigantic handkerchief stuffed into the box, burrowing as deep as he could to hide from the spider.

The spider, taking time to adjust its hunting strategy, could detect the tiny man's faint movements. The box represented strange terrain, however, and the creature's pre-wired instincts were cancelled by undue caution.

And then, everything changed.

Tommy arrived right on schedule, saw the tiny box on the table and scooped it into his hand.

Spider and shrunken man were jostled inside the box as Mr. Smith's huge neighbor gripped the small package, causing the cardboard walls to smash inward slightly from his tight grip.

Mr. Smith wanted to scream for Tommy to stop, but he dared not make a sound. He tried to burrow deeper into the handkerchief, in anticipation of the package being mailed, as well as to try to avoid any encounters with his fellow occupant in the warehouse-sized cardboard carton.

The spider, thoroughly distressed by the unpredictable movements, found its own crevice in the cotton folds and stayed put. It could patiently ride out this storm.

Tommy followed his instructions well. Less than 24 hours after he dropped the package at the post office, it arrived at the dormitory of Mr. Smith's nephew.

After so many hours of unceasing movement, the stillness when the package arrived at its destination conveyed information to both the tiny man and the spider.

For the horrible predator, the stillness translated as an opportunity to emerge from hiding and explore.

For the tiny man, he knew he had succeeded. Soon, he would be reunited with his nephew and he could reverse the folly of his plan. He imagined that he and Zack could share a few laughs about the adventure.

While the shrunken man felt excitement at his arrival at the college dorms, the spider felt only one thing: hunger. As it began to navigate the complicated folds and tunnels formed by the crumpled handkerchief, tiny Mr. Smith heard the raspy noise of its legs on the cotton fabric.

Suddenly, waiting in the box for Zack didn't seem like such a great idea. "I've got to get out of here before that monster finds me!"
11113112.title: Trapped together

choices: Still in the box!
On the floor!
111131121.content:
Bobbing his head rhythmically to the heavy music piped though his earbuds, Zack tossed his backpack down and slammed the dorm room door shut.

"What did he send me this time?!" The college student gushed, holding the package to his face and giving it a shake.

Zack had been pleasantly surprised by Steven, the front desk clerk, when he entered into the dorm building's lobby. Steven presented him with a delivery addressed to Zack from his favourite uncle Bryan. Never fail, Uncle Bryan sent Zack a gift for any occasion, often than not for no reason at all.

"Feels light," Zack strode across the room towards his desk. "Probably a gift card!" He grabbed for something to open it with on the desk.

Plucking a screw driver from the pencil jar, Zack set the small package onto the desk. While excited for the gift, he couldn't help but think of his Uncle's promised arrival in the flesh. Bryan seemed to think that gifts were all his nephew wanted, often never bothering to visit more than once or twice a year. These thoughts caused him to frown slightly, his readied arm drooping.

"Maybe he'll call at least..." Zack muttered with a nod. Readying the tool, he broke the sealing tape and began working the cardboard flaps open.

His enthusiastic reveal fell completely flat upon pulling back the flaps.

"Huh?" His eyebrows raised curiously at the contents. Nothing more than what looked like a plain handkerchief. "Is this some kind of joke?"

Zack pulled the airy scrap of fabric out for inspection. Turning it over, he unfolded it. "Is that-..." A dark shape appeared from a crease in the cloth causing Zack to wretch his hand back. "Bloody shit! A Spider!"

"Fucking hell! Where'd it go?" The swatch of cloth fluttered to the ground, spider and all, landing between his feet. Zack scowled, spying the dazed arachnid as it scuttled into the open carpet. Without hesitation, he lifted his foot and stomped the gross creature before it could react.

He dragged his sneaker back, grinding the spider against the abrasive carpet and sighed.

"What the fuck was that about?" He said quietly, reaching for the small package again. "Does Uncle Bryan think that crap is funny?"

The answer seemed plain. The box and the handkerchief appeared empty, leaving a cruel joke as the only conclusion. Zack grunted, tossing the box back onto his desk and furiously punching his Uncle's phone number into his cellphone (another gift from Bryan!). His annoyance was only fed by the seemingly cheeky voice of his Uncle's answering service.

Confused and frustrated, Zack stood before his desk and redialed. He failed to notice one pale little speck that lay...
111131121.title: Bad joke?

choices: Tiny Bryan runs beneath his nephew's desk
Zack notices another bug loose in his dorm
1111311212.content:
Bryan Smith wanted to kick himself. He had come all this way, endured so much, and at the moment of truth, he had panicked.

"What's wrong with me?" He whined aloud.

He recalled the anticipation that had built as his nephew had methodically torn apart the shipping carton that had transported his shrunken uncle halfway across the country.

Sealing tape made a loud, tearing noise as Zack tore it free from the cardboard flaps as he opened the package.

The sight of his enormous nephew, now some unbelievable titan, was what had prompted the tiny man's untimely failure of nerve.

It has been a costly mistake.

While the tiny uncle cowered in the folds of a gigantic handkerchief, his disappointed nephew tried to make sense of opening up an apparently empty package.

"IS THIS SOME KIND OF JOKE," Zack muttered as he stared into the box. He reached in and pulled out the handkerchief, unwittingly bring along his shrunken uncle, as well as one unexpected passenger.

"BLOODY SHIT! A SPIDER!"

In shock, he recoiled in fright, dropping the handkerchief and the box.

It all happened so incredibly quickly. The shrunken scientist tumbled onto a dirty dorm floor as his nephew raged about the shock of finding a live spider in the box.

"FUCKING HELL!" Zack roared. "WHERE DID IT GO?"

Still stunned, the tiny man looked up to see his nephew's enormous sneaker raised high overhead.

"Zack! No!" He screamed. "Don't step on me!"

At the same time, the tiny man saw the buffalo-sized arachnid scuttling across the floor.

His nephew's shoe stomped down with a resounding thud. As his terrified uncle watched, Zack dragged his sneaker back, grinding the spider against the abrasive carpet.

The titan sighed loudly, wondering aloud why the fuck his uncle would send him a live spider.

He was totally unaware of the bug-sized form cowering on the floor. With sickening clarity Mr. Smith had recognized his peril after his nephew so violently and destructively destroyed the spider.

"Oh my god! He could crush me like a bug!"

Gone were thoughts of a giddy reunion with his huge nephew. Instead, the tiny man ran blindly, intent on finding a hiding place until he could think of a safe way to approach Zack.
1111311212.title: On Zack's floor

choices: Zack missed
Zack's aim is true
11113112122.content:
Zack pulled out his phone and dialed his uncle's number, determined to express his irritation.

He waited impatiently as the rings sounded, remaining utterly unaware that the box had contained one other tiny occupant, now stranded on the floor of his dorm room.

When the call went to his uncle's voice mail, Zack's tone made plain his frustration.

"Uncle B, what the hell you doing mailing my a fucking spider?" The college student said. "You know how I hate bugs."

Actually, it was one of the college student's attitudes that had gone largely unremarked by his uncle, who was always too wrapped up in his own world to notice some of Zack's day-to-day quirks.

It was an inattentiveness that could now get him killed. The bug-sized man had already witnessed his nephew's shoe stomped down with a resounding thud on the stowaway arachnid that had caused Bryan Smith's plans to unravel.

As his terrified uncle watched, Zack dragged his sneaker back, grinding the spider against the abrasive carpet.

"Zack!" The tiny man shouted, desperation outweighing preservation. "Down here! Look! Please!"

The titan ended the call with a loud sigh. "Just call me back when you get this," he finished his recorded message to his uncle.

He was putting the phone back into his pocket when he glanced at the floor, his eyes detecting a puny form dating across the floor near his right sneaker.

"What is it with bugs now?" Zack grumbled in a rumbling, gruff tone of exasperation.

At least it didn't look as big and alarming as the damn spider, and he had deal with that frightful surprise quite adequately.

He raised his shoe, prepared to remove another pathetic pest from his immediate vicinity.

This wasn't how his reunion with his huge nephew was supposed to go.

"Zack! No!" The shrunken scientist screamed in sudden terror. "It's me! Not a bug!"

The sneaker slammed down with a dull thud that stirred an explosion of dust and debris.
11113112122.title: Another bug

choices: Time's wasting. Finish off the bug
Zack hears something odd
111131121221.content:
Zack slammed his sneaker down, trying to adjust for the bug's last-second veering toward the left.


The concussive blast from the explosion knocked the bug-sized man off the floor and into the air, as his body twisted for the best landing possible, all things considered. He felt like a combat soldier in a battle zone as bombs were falling, only these missiles were his nephew's sneakers stomping down on the dorm room floor with enough shock-and-awe force to rattle the tiny man's brain.

On his way toward the impact with the floor, the only thought in his head concerned the fact that his nephew, who had just tried to stomp him like a bug, had missed!

Zack had missed, and the shrunken scientist lived to try again to communicate with his skyscraper-sized nephew.

He fell on his back, knocking the breath from his lungs. As he groaned and tried to get onto his feet, Zack was already lifting his other foot, realizing almost instantly that he had missed the target.

His mind screamed "run" but his body refused to respond. Even as his brain sent out urgent messages to his sluggish body, the shrunken man gazed up at his nephew, transformed into a monstrous entity of almost immeasurable strength and power.

"Zack!" He screamed so loudly his throat hurt. "It's me! Your uncle!"

Even as the tiny man tried to crawl, he found himself darkened by a descending shadow.
111131121221.title: Zack missed

choices: The dorm building front desk
The desk in Zack's dorm room
111131122.content:
Bryan felt himself paralyzed by fear.

Here he was trapped in a maze of folds made up from a giant crumpled handkerchief with a spider of monstrous proportions. It was like a nightmare. His ears pricked up at the sound of skittering legs nearby.

"I've got to do something!" Bryan thought to himself with a gasp.

Sweat collected at his brow as he strained to determine what direction he entered from. The spider would undoubtedly pinpoint his location as soon as he made his move, so he had to make it count.

With agility that surprised even him, Bryan scuttled up the sloping cotton landscape. His hands thankfully finding a grip in the pitch darkness of the box. Lugging himself over a crest, he prepared to continue when in his haste, his footing slipped sending him sliding down the steep fold of fabric.

A sound of many legs on cardboard gave the tiny man a shot of adrenaline. He quickly recovered from his tumble, blindly tripping forward.

Light made itself known as he passed another fold. It seemed as if the spider was right upon him as he threw his trembling form through the tear and into the heavenly light. Bryan didn't stop there, he hurriedly picked himself up and ran as fast as his thin legs would permit. Ahead of him lay a large object that he wasted no time in taking cover behind.

For tiny Bryan, he felt like a helpless animal being pursued by an unstoppable predator. Gulping nervously, he timidly peeked from his cover.

Nothing appeared through the ominous portal that was just a minuscule tear in the large shipping box. The shrunken man breathed a sigh of relief. He was safe.

"Now I just need to find Zack." He looked around in an attempt to figure out just where he was. Excitement about his breakthrough surprise he had planned began to return, overshadowing the frightening encounter he just escaped from.

The world around him was unimaginably enormous. Bryan backed away from the object he had taken cover behind, squinting curiously at what appeared to be writing pressed into it.

"MIRADO 174-No.2" Read the letters in a font larger than he was. He could only gape at the enormous object that in reality was just a regular pencil.

Suddenly feeling very small and insecure, Bryan realized his location was...
111131122.title: Safe for now

choices: Zack enters the dorm building
Two giant guys enter
1111311221.content:
The tiny man surveyed his surroundings. A giant redwood tree toppled onto its side could not have looked any bigger than the enormous pencil in front of him.

"Where the hell is Zack?" The tiny man wondered aloud as he began to assemble the clues to his location.

A monolithic door filled the horizon. Two large panes of glass allowed soft rays of sunlight to illuminate the otherwise gloomy surroundings. The bug-sized scientist stood on a desk of sorts, but there was no computer or any other signs of any of the items usually found on a college student's desk.

Other than the carton, the desktop was bare of most items. Toward the center of the expanse, a wide plateau of blue rose from the wooden surface. The tiny man made his way toward it.

After a brief journey, he reached the blue plateau, but a 20-foot cliff seemed to block him as he made his way around the edge of the object. Frustration began to replace his excitement about what seemed to be the arrival at his destination.

The package might have been delivered, and he might be safe from that awful spider, but he didn't seem any closer to his nephew. Then he saw the huge cylinder that leaned against an edge of the blue plateau.

"A pen!" He exclaimed.

He ran to the huge object, which leaned it a convenient angle to allow him to climb it like a bridge. In little time, he had ascended and was greeted by some other massive letters scrawled hurriedly into the blue surface.

VISITORS PLEASE SIGN IN!

He read the message, and everything clicked into place.

He wasn't in his nephew's dorm room. Someone had delivered the carton to the dorm, but left it on the sign-in table in the entrance hall into the dorm building.

Of course, eventually Zack would arrive and claim the package.

Then he felt a splash of fear. Yes, Zack would arrive, see the package, take it and leave him stranded and tiny.

"I've got to get back inside," the tiny man realized.

He turned and ran back toward the pen, definitely alarmed at finding himself so tiny and separated from his only means of uniting with his nephew.


He knew the spider still lurked in the dark interior of the shipping carton. He would just have to evade the predator a little longer.

He had reached the desktop and started across the vast plain toward the towering cardboard crate when the front door to the dorm building opened.
1111311221.title: The dorm building front desk

choices: Zack leaves with the (empty!) box in tow
Zack sees more tiny movement
11113112211.content:
Bryan stopped dead in his tracks. Hideous and large the persistent spider peered out from the safety of the cardboard crate.

The spider cautiously poked a long, pointed leg out, as if to test the stability of the ground. More legs appeared from the dark gap, and Bryan felt the eight-eyed beast return his stares.

Seeing the spider in the light again reminded the shrunken man just how horrifying it truly was. He backed away, his knees threatening to buckle, his body trembling with fear. Bryan had forgotten all about the opening of the front door, but heavy vibrating reminded him.

"SWEET!" Thundered a familiar voice. "THE PACKAGE!"

The surface of the desk shuddered heavily as the humongous student approached. Bryan chose to ignore the emerging spider, turning to gape at his nephew who approached with booming steps. "He-... He's freaking enormous!" Squeaked the reduced scientist.

Zack was in fact more than just "enormous." To bug-sized Bryan, his nephew's size was near unfathomable as it towered over the desk surface. Bryan continued his dumb-struck stare, looking up towards his nephew's moon-sized face, currently showing an expression of excitement. Minute details of his gigantic nephew's appearance stood out immediately to him: light stubble coated his jaw like an alien forest. Zack's godly physique looked more impressive than ever as it filled out his grey university hoodie. Bryan could even see a cut, barely an inch long, under his nephew's chin.

Bryan had never expected his first encounter to be such a wonder.

Unaware of his tiny slack-jawed audience, Zack reached a huge arm over the desk towards the small package. The spell of awe broke too late for Bryan as he realized his folly. "Wait Zack! I'm supposed to be in there! Wait for me!"

Huge building-like fingers wrapped around the box and lifted it off the desk with remarkable ease. Zack failed to notice the tiny tear or the small spider that made a quick descent from the moving box via silk strand. It landed with a thump, all eight eyes locked onto the tiny man.

Sensing his danger, Bryan looked at the monstrous arachnid in horror. His fearful screeching of the spider's quick approach was suddenly interrupted.

---

Zack smiled looking at his own address written on the box in his Uncle's clean writing. Lack-luster in weight, Zack's mind still raced with thoughts of what might be inside.

He had been notified by Bryan of the packages existence. Ever since he was a small child, Zack had been showered with girfts from his Uncle. All of them containing something of great value more often than not. The car his Uncle Bryan had purchased him recently was good evidence of that.

Quick movement caught the college student's notice. He squinted at the desk. "Gross, a spider!"

Heavily laden backpack in one arm, Zack raised the cardboard box with his other hand. The small arachnid halted its flight, sensing Zack's intent, and suddenly reversed direction.

"Got'cha!" Zack slammed the box down with a hard thwack and a twist. He lifted it to inspect the remains. "What the-... Where did it go?"

The clever spider hurriedly fled back towards the pile of other boxes, vanishing from sight. Zack grunted, resisting the temptation of pursuit. It was just a dumb tiny spider after all.

Plus, he wanted to see what his uncle sent him!
11113112211.title: Zack enters the dorm building

choices: To the floor
On the desk
111131122112.content:
Zack bit his lip as he prepared to leave. He liked receiving gifts from his Uncle Bryan, but he still would prefer if he had made an appearance in the flesh.

Sighing, Zack had no idea his wishes had actually come true as he turned to leave.

"Huh...?" On the open space of the desk moved yet another creature. This one smaller, and rather strange looking. Zack shrugged. He might as well take care of this one at least.

Re-adjusting his heavy backpack, he raised the package over the wiggling speck with his other hand. "You won't get away, you little bugger!"

His arm had just begun its descent when a voice from behind the desk surprised him.

"Yo, Z-Man! What's happenin'?" Greeted Steven, the front desk clerk, who appeared from a doorway behind the desk and sauntered over.

Hesitating, Zack stared blankly for a moment before replying. "Hey man," He replied. "Was just crushing this ant here."

Steven raised his dark brows and peered down at the desk. The little pale ant seemed to be attempting escape, which Steven responded to with a sweep of his hand that sent the tiny insect flying. Zack looked shocked at that, glancing around for where it landed.

"No worries, bud. Just a tiny bug." Steven remarked in his casual tone. "Live and let live, I always say." He didn't pay attention to where his hand sent the bug, nor did he care that much.

Zack suddenly felt sheepish at his behaviour. It was just a stupid, tiny bug.

Steven was a fellow student, though a year above him in both age and classes. He was regarded as a likable and easy-going guy, always getting to know everyone in the building and conjuring nick-names for them at moment's notice. He landed the desk job a few months ago, gladly accepting pay and points for an easy position that required him to sit back and relax.

"You got your box? Awesome. Can ya give a quick signature right here?" He presented a clipboard to Zack, who scrawled his name down. "Sweet. You're good to go dude."

Having forgotten the two tiny creatures, Zack grinned at his buddy and hurried off with box in-hand, oblivious to his bug-sized uncle he left behind.

---

Bryan on the other hand had been swept...
111131122112.title: Live and Let Live

choices: Get Steven's attention
Undertake an epic trek to Zack's dorm
1111311221121.content:
Never had the sound of his nephew's voice sounded so unwelcome and terrifying to his uncle.

In the aftermath of the fearsome reunion, Zack's horrifying words still echoed in the shrunken man's brain.

"You won't get away, you little bugger!" Zack had promised as he prepared to use the cardboard shipping carton to pulverize the tiny bug on the desk.

The untimely arrival of another giant had rescued the shrunken scientist only to land him in a possibly more vulnerable position on the grimy floor of the colossal entryway into the dormitory.

Now, in hiding from their fearsome feet, the little man replayed the unfortunate chain of events.

Ironically, it had started with a titan's friendly greeting that had given the shrunken man cause to rejoice when it seemed to cause his nephew to pause in his action of lowering the building-sized carton on top of his tiny uncle.

"Just crushing this ant..." Zack had answered.


Zack lifted the carton away, and for a brief instant, the bug-sized man was given an unobstructed view of both titans. In that moment, they were not fellow humans. They looked liked destructive gods, and the tiny man's nerve failed. He ran blindly.

"Live and let live, I always say," Steven said, swiping his hand across the desktop to catch the bug up in a clean sweep. Almost as soon as he had done so, he forgot about the tiny bug.

Neither of the titans noticed when the tiny man fell hard onto the floor. The tiny man's shock at surviving the fall gave way to paralyzing fear when one of his nephews shoes slammed down only inches from him.

"Oh god," the tiny scientist cried. "Zack, watch out. Please, don't step on me."

He fought through a haze of pain to get to his feet and flee deeper beneath the monumental desk.

He heard the two titans continue to converse in thunderous tones.

The giant that had swept him onto the floor asked Zack for a signature. Once he got it, he told Zack he was good to go.

Zack, the cardboard container still clutched in one hand, hurried toward the stairs, eager to get to his room and open the surprise from his uncle.

"Please, don't go," Bryan screamed in vain.

He felt his fear settle in the pit of his stomach as he realized that both his nephew and the antidote within the box were now effectively beyond his reach.

"I've got to think of a Plan B," he said, trying to stay calm and rational.
1111311221121.title: Dorm floor

choices: Bryan's journey continues
Bryan's journey is interrupted!
11113112211212.content:
Pressed against the cold surface of but one of many metal towers that supported the desk, Bryan bit his lip.

"Shit...! I've got to catch up to Zack!" The recent memory of Zack's attempt to crush him already seemed like a distant dream. Inside him, Bryan knew Zack would be his saviour! "He's the reason I did this, and he'll recognize me!"

Thoroughly convinced, Bryan glanced around one last time before bolting.

He briefly caught sight of two enormous sneakers lifting off the floor and out of sight. A distant crash signaled their landing upon the desktop high above. The giant's face was unviewable, and his identity still unknown, yet Bryan knew this giant was at fault for the botched surprise intended for Zack.

With a frown, he briefly focused all blame on the oblivious giant.

Returning his attention, Bryan kept his pace and scoped the terrain ahead. The "terrain", as he painfully realized, was an utter wasteland of filthy floor. It stretched seemingly forever in every direction, ending with different vistas in each direction. Each one made up of objects normally uninteresting to the tiny scientist, but now blown up to proportions that made them otherworldly.

One such option was the hallway Zack went down. It stretched onward, looking close to something plucked from a surrealist painting. To his right, Bryan was presented with a distant wall of towering glass. Bright beams of light filtered in past potted plants and mountainous furniture positioned against it. Two huge doors were the focal point: looming like the gates to a dimension of titans and gods. This was all more evident by the huge shapes that lumbered sluggishly outdoors, barely recognizable as mere college students.

He met no opposition to his goal. Bryan kept along, running and circumventing the occasional deposit of dirt or mud. His mind completely on reaching Zack and ending this mishap - Bryan never even thought how impossible his journey was...
11113112211212.title: An epic trek

choices: Bryan hides beneath the desks
Bryan tries to find Zack
111131122112121.content:
Unappreciated by him, the tiny man's desperate journey continued with little incident. He was able to continue a decent pace, ultimately crossing the span of the lobby within half an hour.

He approached the base of a wall, trying to take in the tremendous size. Alone, the moulding was taller than most office buildings, coated in a layer of dirty scuffs from years of student activity.

"Almost..." The shrunken man heaved, clutching his strained chest. "...to... uurgh... Zack!"

Bryan dared a look behind. His progress was admirable, as the distance he crossed was nothing short of many miles. Now in his view, the giant that swept him off leaned back in a chair, his feet propped against the desk. Like most his age, the huge young man was focused dumbly on his smart phone; poking and prodding it with seemingly empty eyes.

Deciding he would deal with the foolish youth after, Bryan returned to his trekking.

The hallway his nephew had stomped down was nothing but a short entrance that led into a much larger room. It contained a multitude of tables, lined orderly in rows flanking a wall of windows. Only a few students occupied the small study space, sitting idly out of the tiny man's view.

Bryan quickly passed through the passage, before gasping at his next worldspace.

"I'm so small!" Was his only thought, looking out into the huge span of floor occupied by towering tables and chairs.

He cussed softly. From here, the room led out into different corridors - all of which looked identical. Bryan realized with a shiver that he had absolutely no idea which passage to take! A stepped mountain was evident farther in the distance, barely recognizable as stairs.

"Zack might even be upstairs... I can't remember!"

Bryan clutched himself like a forlorn child. The ground trembled lightly, distant crashes tensing his tiny body.

In the distance, he watched a huge student pound up the stairs with a large pack over his shoulders. The behemoth easily scaled each immense step without effort, vanishing from sight quickly.

"What do I do?!" Bryan suddenly felt unsure. His whole plan revealed itself for what it was: foolish! He was lost!
111131122112121.title: Lost!

choices: To climb out of the crevice
To remain hidden
1111311221121211.content:
Hearing loud noise and more vibrations from behind, Bryan jolted and sped towards the nearest table for cover.

The towers of wood and metal offering a spacious but seemingly secure space to hide. Underneath the table, dust bunnies, dirt, pebbles, and fallen scraps dominated the landscape. Bryan passed a pencil that easily surpassed any city-street he had ever seen.

He retreated to the monumental leg of a chair, pressing himself against it. The ground trembled, signaling the entrance of new giants who stomped past without regard to anything in their path. Each monumental step slamming against the floor, easily crushing various particles that would have been obstacles to tiny Bryan.

"Oh God! What have I gotten myself into?" He screamed. Just then, two enormous sneakers headed his way, the giant owner dropping his backpack against the tabletop above. "No!"

Bryan cried out when the pillar of metal he clutched was wretched away. He was flung with shocking force, hurling many dozens of feet before landing roughly. Next to him, the ground dipped suddenly as it gave way to an electrical outlet inset into the floor.

A deafening screech rang across the floor, causing Bryan to clutch his ears as the titanic student easily maneuvers the mountainous chair. The giant's sneakers thud heavily against the floor as they shift allowing their gigantic owner to settle into the chair. The enormous piece of furniture groans in protest under the huge student's weight, creaking loudly with every movement.

Lain on his side, Bryan cowers with shaking limbs. Staring up a tower of thickly-haired legs which meet a pair of dark shorts and red t-shirt that stretches further upward to the dark underside of the table, obscuring the unknown giant's face. Distant sounds of commotion thunder from above as the giant unloads his backpack.

Still staring up with disbelief, Bryan is unprepared when an intense aroma invades his nostrils. It reeked of something both earthy and sweaty; rubber, dirt, and god-awful odor. He wipes tears away as he identifies the source: one of the giant student's filthy sneakers. Heavily abused, the low-top Vans sneaker towers dangerously close. Bryan is afforded a front row view of the footwear. Every smudge of dirt, deposit of grime, and dark stain of grass are plain against the off-white wall of rubber.

Bryan sneers with disgust, his face red with humiliation. Rising above the stained sole is a surface of soiled dark canvas sporting fraying rope-like stitching that ends with a pillar of sock that wraps around a thick leg coated with thick forests of dark hairs. The huge shoe shifts suddenly, shaking the ground as it drags backwards.

Without allowing the tiny man a moment of preparation, Bryan screams as the ground darkens. From above, looms the monumental shape of an enormous hand. The fingers, longer than office buildings and powerful enough to reduce a city to dust, clutch a huge object with large metal teeth.

"Please, don't hurt me!" Bryan shrieks. His first assumption that him and only him are the center around which everything rotates. "Eek!"

He throws himself to the ground, wrapping himself defensively. The ground lurches with an impressive crash as the giant shoves the huge plug into the outlet. Bryan peeks from his vain defense to watch the gigantic fingers press the towers of metal into the plastic slots. They inset with a dull boom, causing Bryan to squeak and scamper away as the massive fingers lift away.

Suddenly, there is a thunder from above. Bryan gazes upwards dumbly, gawking as he deciphers the godly speech.

"Huh?" He babbles with confusion. Something along the lines of "Fucking" and "Ant".

With a peal of protest, the tiny man flings into action - waving his arms and screaming for help against this mistake. "I'm NOT an ant! Heeeelp! I am a man!"

Disregarding his cries, the gigantic hand looms into view; the huge index poised above the tiny speck of a man. The ridged finger tip is coated in grime and dirt that fill each groove of skin. Bryan is offered only a moment to react as it descends towards his location. He leaps to his side, falling into a groove between the floor and a wall of hard plastic just as everything turns dark and the ground lurches.

Above him, the thick pillar of flesh lifts off, shifting to present the unseen owner with the crushed victim. Bryan hold his breath, shaking with fear. He hears a deep grunt and screams when the huge dirt-filled digit returns and crashes into the ground again, attempting to flatten him.

Bryan merely wept tears of terror, sputtering incoherent pleas to the uncaring digit of destruction above. It lifted away once more, raining bits of dirt. Light basked the tiny man who gasped out mouthfuls of air.

"Oh, God... Oh... God..." He remained wedged in the incredibly small space. Trembling, all his senses remained peaked as he waited for something worse - but nothing happened. "Is it over?"

Bryan decides...
1111311221121211.title: Giant student

choices: Bryan is trapped in the treads!
Bryan is left shaken, but unscathed
1111311221121212.content:
The room was beyond huge from the minute perspective Bryan commanded. Chairs loomed with dizzying stature against massive tables that seemed large enough to hold the entirety of a city.

It was overwhelming to say the least. "I need to find Zack!" He said with breathless determination.

Such thoughts of salvation from his beloved nephew were all he could focus on to keep himself from panicking. Sun shone in from a distant wall of windows lining the opposite side on the room. Bryan looked away from the harsh light and tables, instead focusing upon the stars and doorways leading out. Zack could reside down any of them. Even with a destination in mind, the trek would be nothing short of Olympic.

"Oh God, oh man," Bryan whined, coming to halt in order to stare desolately at the distant visages. "I-I-I can't remember!"

If only he could just ask the front desk clerk, he joked internally. That oversized moron was what put him here in the first place! Bryan could only scoff angrily, not even wanting to glance backwards at the reclining giant.

It turns out that was the least of his problems. Bryan started when the ground suddenly vibrated. Then again. Shortly after, it began shuddering enough to send him reeling.

---

Creaking with usual fervor, Steven glanced up at the front door. A tall, ripped, guy passed through the doors, clearly having returned from a game of basketball. Sun reflected off sweat coating his blondish hair and limbs as he nodded towards Steven.

"Wassup Steve-o?" He said with a friendly grin, stepping into the lobby. Glancing up, Steven grinned. "Yo Matty!" He replied cheerfully without moving.

"Anything for me today?" Matt asked as he crossed the lobby. He paused briefly, watching Steven relinquish his phone to lean over and glace at the few boxes nestled on the desk. Unbeknownst to either of them, a tiny spider hid among the looming containers, hissing at the giant face peering above. "Nah dude, nada de nada," Steven shook his head, leaning back again.

"Alright man, see ya around," Matt replied as he continued towards the common room, headed for his dorm.

---

"Huh?" The tiny man reacted. Panic overwhelmed him, and quite roughly, his body was thrown to the floor by the now violent earthquakes. "Oh no!"

Squealing in a vain attempt to halt the approaching behemoth that now towered above his ability to see. Far ahead, but only a mere step away to the titan, crash landed a high-top sneaker big enough to flatten a stadium and then some. Huge glistening globules of sweat fell from above at random, breaking against the ground with loud splashes. Bryan abandoned his cries and devolved into wordless screams. Confusion, terror, disbelief, and a distinctly warm sensation in his pants fueled his panic. He lay on his back, bruised and frozen as he stared at the immense basketball sneaker, watching it creak and groan as the leather and rubber mountain adjusted to the giant's unimaginable weight.

Another drop of sweat larger than himself plummeted from the heavens, exploding nearby and dousing Bryan with warm liquid. As his vision cleared, he screamed again. Blurred by distance that was now quickly shortening, the other high-top soared overhead. Bryan remained frozen long enough to realize his doom when the massive rubber sole blocked out both sky and light.

His instincts kicked in full-throttle. The tiny man ran: running faster than he thought he was capable of, and not a moment too soon. The ground seemed to lurched from under his feet accompanied by a power wall of displaced air when the immense sneaker crash landed.

"Fuuuuuu-...guuurckkkaaaahh!" Bryan flew forward, his head throbbing as if a bomb had just gone off. The worn wall of rubber looked stained and rough like the side of some tall building. Loudly, sounding like a great beast was entrapped, groans and creaks rumbled from the sneaker. It lifted away with sluggish grace, seemingly impossible due to such unfathomable size, but still with ease of such massive power. Bryan was nearly deafened by a thunderous squeak from the cracked rubber. It pulled away from the floor, lifting from it to reveal the complicated tread pattern packed and lined with dirt and boulders from the court and campus. Darkened gunk entrapped the remains of both pulverized and twitching ants that were larger than Bryan but utterly insignificant against the deep grooves of rubber around them.

The giant student continued his step, slamming his mammoth high-top far ahead with a jolting crash. The other followed, soaring like an alien battleship built to completely decimate the planet, blasting the air apart as it moved with little effort. Then it landed far away with a distant crash and duller quake.

Snapping from his frozen gawking, Bryan booked it. He ran -- despite himself -- in the wake of the god-like student, not in pursuit, but hoping to find Zack and a safe haven from gigantic feet.

Legs like skyscrapers out of fiction carried the oblivious basketball player far ahead. Each step of his worn sneakers sending duller and duller vibrations, much to the shrunken man's relief. But then Bryan gasped, slowing his pitiful gait and feeling his already traumatized heart beat harder. From a distant doorway entered another behemoth, dressed not in the athletic clothing of the first student, but in casual clothes that did nothing to downplay his rivaling stature and obvious athleticism.

"Christ on a pogo-stick! Fuck!" Bryan cursed, as the sweat-soaked giant thundered a greeting, raised a thick arm and slammed his massive palm against the new giant's in a high-five of cataclysmic proportions, sending angry waves of meteor-sized sweat crashing to the floor. Like any scrappy young guys would do, but this seemed ridiculous to the speck-sized scientist. It looked more like two gods greeting, then one passing off the job of stomping hapless scientists to his buddy.

The other giant grinned, nodding at his buddy and then the two passed: one leaving for the stairs, the other headed straight for Bryan who gawked at the massive white AF1s.

Not wanting to try fate again, Bryan began hoofing it away from the approaching student. His screams were nothing but gasping whispers at this point, all his breath long since exhausted. He ran. A flight filled with wild screaming, all but fruitless as the gargantuan student was upon him quickly. An enormous shadow was all the warning Bryan had that his time ran out, and suddenly he was bathed in darkness. A momentary look upwards was all he had to see the landscape of descending white rubber, discoloured and worn, and completely unfeeling to his minuscule life.

Right in-between canyonesque rings of tread, it stomped down over Bryan.
1111311221121212.title: Danger, Bryan Smith, Danger!

choices: The giant sits down in a desk chair
The giant notices the tiny ant again
1111311221122.content:
Bryan lay in a pile of sore, bruised limbs. He moaned softly.

Overwhelming his pain was the realization of what had just occurred. His life had been saved by his giant nephew, Zack, who wasted no time in chasing the hideous spider away. That had been fine and dandy, until...

"He thought I was a bug." It had hit Bryan like a load of bricks. The same box had been lifted overhead, poised to destroy him. The same box that brought him here.

As if an oblivious nephew of humongous scale wasn't enough, another behemoth of equal size hunkered over from behind. Bryan just ran at that point, pure adrenaline fueling his flight. Then a monstrous hand slammed down, throwing Bryan's tiny form into a violent flight with a simple brush.

Here he lay, seemingly safe but still hopelessly away from the box that contained the antidote. He pulled himself up, straining to listen to their thunderous conversation.

"LIVE AND LET LIVE, I ALWAYS SAY." The deep, rumbling voice of Zack's buddy roared from afar. His head throbbed as they continued their booming speech.

"SWEET," He discerned. "YOU'RE GOOD TO GO DUDE." Bryan lit up at that despite his rough tumble.

He looked over to Zack's humongous form. The giant raised a hand in farewell and grinned. "No! Don't go, Zack! Don't leave without me! Please, just look! Zack!" Without any sign of hearing the tiny man's cries, Zack turned and stomped away, vanishing from sight in a few steps.

Bryan was in tears. "Waaaaaait!" How could his plan have gone awry? He had planned everything so carefully. "That damn spider...!" The minute man screeched and stamped his feet causing spears of pain in his battered legs. A heavy pounding brought him out of his self-pitying thoughts, and Bryan suddenly remembered the other titanic guy.

Zack had left, unknowingly leaving his shrunken uncle at the mercy of this new giant.

The few visit Bryan had made to the campus had allowed him to meet a multitude of Zack's school-mates. Gazing up, from his position at the base of a cup filled with pencils, Bryan studied the huge youth. His face had a friendly look to it; ear length black hair poked out from beneath a frayed black and white cap with a skate logo on it. Unlike Zack, he sported a chin strip of dark facial hair and trimmed, yet un-shaven, cheeks. Another logo featuring a black skull over the words "ZERO" stood out on his white t-shirt. Bryan did seem to recognize the giant young man, but failed to recall his name as he studied the impossibly massive human.

The enormous youth turned his head from side to side, scanning the room only visible from his lofty perspective. A giant hand large as many city blocks rested on the edge of the desk, idly tapping the surface with powerful motions. The sheer power from such a simple action was unbelievable. Friendly and easy-going he might appear to somebody of normal stature, he looked just the opposite to one as tiny as Bryan. What the giant took for a "helpful" sweep of the hand, could just as easily resulted in Bryan's death.

While true, these observations weren't getting him anywhere. "I need to do something..." The tiny man considered, never taking his eyes off the idle giant. "If I can get his attention, he can help me reach Tommy!"

Suddenly, the huge stranger moved.
1111311221122.title: On the desk

choices: Climb down to the floor and find Zack
Try to contact this guy at the desk
11113112211221.content:
Steven sighed as he sat down into the desk chair. After Zack had headed upstairs, he had been left completely alone in the lobby of the large dorm. Warm sunlight streaming through the large windows reflected off the white floors, giving the room a cheery glow.

Steven began picking through the other packages that had been delivered while he had been away from the desk. He mentally noted the names so he could deliver the boxes to the guys as they came through the lobby. As he lifted the last box, a spider scurried across the desk. Steven, not the least bit afraid, smiled. "No, no little guy, not up here!" he muttered. Acting on his "live and let live" policy, Steven brought his hand towards the fleeing bug and flicked it away.

Finished with the packages, Steven fished his phone out of his pocket. Leaning back he propped his sneakers onto the desk to get more comfortable. Not seeing any messages, he opened a game to keep himself occupied.

Unknown to him, the spider he believed he had spared, lay in a crumpled heap in the middle of the lobby. It fought to find cover despite two mangled legs.

A creak from the front door got Steven's attention. A ripped guy walked through the door, clearly having returned from a game of basketball. Sun reflected off his sweat as he nodded towards Steven. "Wassup Steve-o?" he said as he stepped forward. "Sup Matty!" Steven replied cheerfully without moving.

"Anything for me today?" he asked as he crossed the lobby. As Steven shook his head in reply, Matt's sneaker landed squarely on top of the struggling spider. "Alright man, see ya around," Matt replied as he headed towards the stairs. In his wake was a smear on the floor, unnoticed by Matt. Steven, in spite of his good intentions, had gotten the spider crushed. Unaware of this, Steven refocused on his game in the once more empty lobby.

---

The giant let out a gusting sigh as he dropped into the chair behind him. Even sitting down he towered far above the desk. In spite of the warm glow that filled the room and made the young man look even friendlier, Bryan couldn't shake the paralyzing fear of his predicament.

Bryan watched in awe as the giant easily shifted through the building-sized packages. When the last one lifted, something shot out from underneath it. The spider from earlier was fleeing its compromised hideout. And it was headed straight for Bryan. "Oh dear God no!" Bryan wailed in panic.

"NO, NO LITTLE GUY, NOT UP HERE!" the giant thundered from above. Out of nowhere a set of thick fingers appeared and with a simple flick the spider was gone. Bryan sighed in relief, thankful to the giant for getting rid of the spider. That is until a thought struck him.

This behemoth had no understanding of the power he had in his simple motions. He my have believed that he was "living and letting live" but as Bryan already knew that spider was probably in a world of pain. Not that Bryan was concerned for the monstrous spider. However getting this giant's attention wouldn't be his only obstacle. Being recognized as more than a bug would keep him from being carelessly flicked away or swept aside once more.

A thud rocked the desk, shaking Bryan from his thoughts. He jumped backwards with a yelp. Just in front of him were a pair of sneakers, one crossed over the other. Bryan was unable to tear his gaze away from the titanic shoes. They had a brownish waffle tread that was packed with dirt and pebbles. Bryan could also see what looked to be a couple of ants smashed into the worn tread.
