"So much for live and let live!" Bryan scoffed. Beyond the shoes, the behemoth laid back in the chair. Unaware of his tiny audience, his mammoth face remained focused solely on his cell phone.

A creak at the door got Bryan to spin around. In walked an Adonis, dressed in basketball attire. Roaring to the guy at the desk, his pounding footsteps shook the desk as he approached. Bryan unintentionally stepped backwards as the giant neared. He suddenly stopped and turned abruptly towards the stairs Zack had disappeared up.

"ALRIGHT MAN, SEE YA AROUND!" he thundered as he left. Bryan watched him leave, ignoring the titan still at the desk who didn't move as he returned to his game.

"Zack is in this building, I should just find his dorm!" Bryan reasoned. "Of course if I got this guy's help, that would make finding Zack much easier..." Bryan stood still for a moment. He then decided to...
11113112211221.title: Simple motions

choices: Tommy spots a bug
Tommy recognized tiny Mr. Smith
1111312.content:
The surprisingly graceful descent allowed the spider to touch down on the tabletop with all eight legs poised to travel.

To the shock of its tiny intended prey, the fearsome arachnid's landing took place at a spot almost halfway between the tiny scientist and the shipping carton.

He suddenly halted in his headlong race toward the security that had been represented by the shipping carton. While he still debated a new plan of action, the spider scurried toward him, having fastened it eight eyes on his bug-sized body.

Tiny Mr. Smith screamed at the shockingly swift advance by the horrid-looking creature. He raced in a diagonal lining, hoping to keep distance between them and also make his way back toward the all-important shipping carton.

Into this life-or-death struggle, Tommy arrived, more or less on schedule, humming cheerfully a tune that had been stuck in his head for the past several hours.

Closing the door behind him, the teenager walked toward the kitchen table, spying a small cardboard box in the exact location Mr. Smith had told him to expect it.

The breeze that followed Tommy's opening of the back door rushed across the surface of the table. With eight legs, the spider resisted the sudden surge of air that slammed into the shrunken man and sent him sprawling toward massive metal and glass towers in the center of the table.

When the sudden hurricane suddenly ceased with the closing of the back door, the battered little man saw his gigantic teenaged neighbor walking toward the table.

"Tommy!" Mr. Smith screamed. "It's me! On the table!"

Suddenly, Tommy stopped and looked down with a twisted sneer on his colossal features. "Gross! Freakin' spider!"

He found what he needed by turning and grabbing yesterday's newspaper from Mr. Smith's kitchen counter. He rolled the newspaper into a tube and wielded it into the air.

The impact as he slammed the newspaper down on the itty-bitty spider rocked the table. The unseen little scientist was knocked off his feet in the shadow of the salt shaker. Before he could get his legs back under him, Tommy scooped the package off the tabletop in one huge hand.

"No! Wait, please!" The shrunken scientist screamed. "Not yet."

He dashed away from the strange towers of glass and gleaming stainless steel, mindless that Tommy was still holding the newspaper in his other hand, having already demonstrated a lethal tendency to strike first and ask questions later...
1111312.title: Right on Schedule

choices: Tommy treats the bug as he did the spider
Tommy notices something a little off about the bug
11113121.content:
Tommy, having scooped the small package off his neighbor's kitchen table, lifted the box to his ear and gave it a couple of shakes. Not hearing anything to give him a clue to its contents, he shrugged.

He hadn't mentioned anything, but he had been curious about why Mr. Smith was willing to pay him so well to simply deliver a package to the post office and mail it. With that kind of cash at stake, however, he had remained silent to keep from jinxing such an unexpected opportunity.

Now impatient to get the task done, he placed the rolled up newspaper back on the kitchen table and then started for the backdoor to his neighbor's home when his ears detected a faint squeak, one so feeble it was almost beyond his ability to detect.

The odd, squeaking noise delayed his departure, and caused him to turn and gaze around the room. He didn't see anything, at first, so after a cursory glance he turned again. Then, he heard the squeaky noise again.

"WHAT THE HELL?" Tommy said aloud in mild irritation. He continued hearing the teeny, irritating squeaks and scanned the room for the source. He tilted his head, trying to pinpoint from which direction the sound was originating.

When he took a few steps closer to the table, the squeaks grew more insistent.

From near a set of gleaming stainless steel and glass salt and pepper shakers, Tommy saw a tiny bug scurry into the open space of the table, close to the spot where he had swatted the disgusting spider.

"WHAT'S WITH THE BUG PROBLEM?" The teenager said aloud as he stretched his huge body over the table as he reached for the rolled-up newspaper for a second time.

He had only taken his eyes off the bug for that brief instant, but he lost track of its location. Finally, from the corner of his eye, he saw the itty-bitty bug running back for cover near Mr. Smith's salt and pepper shakers.

Tommy put the package down on the table. "NOT SO FAST," he said.

With one hand, he lifted the pepper shaker and transferred it to the other side of the table. Repeating the process with the salt shaker, he left the tiny, pale bug completely exposed, no hiding places remaining.

The pitiful squeaking noises returned at that point.

"OH, JUST SHUT UP," Tommy complained as he lifted the newspaper over the vulnerable insect.
11113121.title: Tiny irritating noise

choices: The End
Not Yet
111131211.content:
The tiny scientist felt his desperation rising dramatically after Tommy lifted the shipping carton from the tabletop.

He watched the teenaged titan lift the cardboard package to the side of his massive head. The giant shook the package, seeming to listen for a clue as to its contents.

In dismay, tiny Mr. Smith imagined what it would have been like if, as planned, he had been inside the package when the monstrous teenager shook the package so violently.

While the little man watched in mute awe, the massive teenager stretched out his enormous arm over the table and placed the rolled-up newspaper on the vast surface.

Tommy turned and headed toward the door.

"No! You can't go!" His shrunken neighbor screamed in panicked protest. Tommy might have dealt with the immediate peril from the now crushed arachnid, but Mr. Smith knew he was doomed to remain bug-sized without Tommy's help.

He bolted from cover, still screaming for Tommy to see him.

His pleas didn't go unheard.

"WHAT'S WITH THE BUG PROBLEM?" The teenager said in a loud voice.

Detecting the presence of another tiny pest, Tommy stretched his huge body over the table and retrieved the rolled-up newspaper.

Watching with increasing terror, tiny Mr. Smith fled back toward the twin towers of his own expensive silver and crystal salt and pepper shakers. "He's going to swat me like a bug," the tiny man realized too late.

Newspaper now in hand, Tommy scanned the table for the almost invisible bug and saw it dashing for cover near his neighbor's fancy salt and pepper shakers.

Tommy put the package down on the table. "NOT SO FAST," he said, whacking the rolled-up newspaper against his free palm.

His tiny, misidentified neighbor hid between the gleaming towers, but then screamed when Tommy reached with his free and hand and lifted one of the towers. Repeating the process with the salt shaker, Tommy left the tiny bug completely exposed.

He watched as the little bug appeared to wave its thin front limbs at him. The massive teenager detected the pitiful squeaking noises again.

"OH, JUST SHUT UP," Tommy grumbled and raised the newspaper over the vulnerable bug.

"No!" Mr. Smith shrieked in outraged. "It's..."

SPLAT!
111131211.title: Just another bug

1111312111.content:
Tommy raised Mr. Smith's rolled-up newspaper over the tiny bug and slammed it down.

Until the last instant, the desperate little man continue to cry for help. The shrunken scientist's shocked screams cut off abruptly following a deafening thunderclap.

The paper slapped against the tabletop with a resounding WHAP!

The teenager then retrieved the package he had promised to mail for Mr. Smith. Before he left, however, he lifted the newspaper and peeked at the crushed remains of the tiny pest.

The smashed insect was smeared across one of the front page headlines, which caused the teenager to chuckle at the irony.

"Guess you made front page news," Tommy remarked.

He then dropped the newspaper into the kitchen trashcan before leaving Mr. Smith's home with the all-important package.

For such a neat, organized man, Mr. Smith sure had a bug problem. The teenager smiled and decided when he next saw his neighbor he would boast about reducing the number of insect pests in Mr. Smith's kitchen.
1111312111.title: The End

choices: Tiny man runs left
Tiny man runs right
1111312112.content:
Fortunately for Mr. Smith, the teenager's aim was off just enough for the newspaper to miss him by mere inches.

Unfortunately, the concussion generated by the slap from the rolled-up newspaper blew the tiny man into the air and right off the table.

He landed hard on the distant floor, but learned another valuable lesson in the process. His tiny size meant that long drops and falls would not automatically kill him.

While he celebrated that bit of good news, however, his teenage neighbor's sneaker stomped down almost on the spot he had landed.

A fall from his kitchen table might not kill him, but one stomp from Tommy's huge sneaker would do the job quite nicely.

"No!" The terrified little man screamed as he tensed, ready for the other foot to drop.

As for Tommy, he hadn't even bothered to check to see if he had swatted the bug or not. He hadn't a clue that his tiny neighbor was now helpless and in peril at his very feet.

Mr. Smith kept producing a steady stream of screams for help, but his teeny voice was far, far too reduced to be heard by his gigantic neighbor.

Tommy, since he had the package to mail, didn't see any point in wasting any more time in his neighbor's house. He walked toward the door, unaware of the fact tiny Mr. Smith was dangerously close to his feet.
1111312112.title: Not Yet

choices: Tommy returns after the trip to the post office
Tommy and a friend return after the trip to the post office
11113121121.content:
His titanic neighbor pivoted his body, positioning himself to walk out the back door. The tiny scientist reacted in blind panic, knowing that Tommy's action would leave him stranded the size of a bug in his own home.

He had trouble reconciling the sight of the huge titan with his normal associations of Tommy as just an ordinary, somewhat scrawny teenager. Now, he looked like a destructive monster.

Despite the earlier close call, the tiny man ran foolishly toward the teenager's colossal footwear. He kept screaming, but his teeny voice was far, far too reduced to reach the ears of the mega-sized teenager from next door.

Tommy had already tried to swat him like a bug, and now he might effortlessly stomp him like one without ever realizing it.

Tommy started toward the door, and Mr. Smith raced toward him just as the teenager lifted his foot for the first step.

The warning shadow caused the bug-sized man to halt his advance. "Oh fu-"

The stomp cut off the tiny man's shout. When the shoe lifted off the floor again, it left behind a bug-sized man writhing in agony.

Through his pain, Mr. Smith saw the teenager leave. The monolithic door opened and closed.

He was alone, and in hell.

The stomp hadn't been a direct one. That would have pulverized him. Instead, he had merely been dealt a glancing blow, barely caught by the front of the huge shoe.

It has been more than enough, however, to mangle his right leg. When he tried to stand, he could not and fell back with a strangled cry.

The full horror closed in on him. Tommy was gone with the package, which contained his antidote. Without it, he was trapped, bug-sized, and now he was injured, as well.

He tried to crawl away from the back door, but the effort was too much. His body refused, and he slid into an unconscious state that allowed him to forget the pain.

Until...
11113121121.title: Accident

choices: Hope realized
Peril imminent
111131211212.content:
In the dream, he rested in the back yard on a warm summer afternoon.

Tommy kept bringing him cold drinks... tea, water, even a bottle of beer from the icy fridge.

"I really should work on the antidote," the professor told his teenaged helper.

"No, you just rest," Tommy said. "I will take care of everything."

The scientist leaned back and sighed. He really liked Tommy's helpful nature. Sure, in many ways he was still a kid, but he acted more mature than his age indicated.

"You're a great kid," Mr. Smith told Tommy as he sipped the glass of lemonade his neighbor had delivered.

Suddenly, a clap of thunder on the horizon disturbed him. He heard the noise again, and the idyllic scene faded as he returned to the pain of consciousness.

"SO, WE CAN HANG HERE THIS WEEKEND?" A loud, boisterous male voice asked.

"SURE. MR. SMITH WON'T MIND," Tommy informed his best friend.

Tommy led the way as he and Joe entered the kitchen. He had ran into Joe on the way back from the post office after mailing Mr. Smith's important package.

Tommy's first steps sailed over the tiny bug on the floor near the massive doorway. Each time his shoes made contract with the floor, the shock of impact sent out rumbling tremors.

The little man, jolted back to consciousness, felt the searing pain in his injured leg. He didn't have time to cry out, however.

Another set of massive shoes crashed down on either side of him.

POUND! POUND!

The mammoth Airwalks rent the stillness with their awesome crashes as the giant teenager stepped inside the kitchen. The shoes covered the space of a football field!

"Oh no," the little man whimpered, sure that he was about to be stomped like a bug.

It wasn't fair. He needed to get the attention of the two teenaged giants, but he could not even get onto his feet with the leg injured earlier when Tommy had missed stomping him flat by only a fraction.

The stomp hadn't been a direct one. That would have pulverized him. Instead, he had merely been dealt a glancing blow, barely caught by the front of the huge shoe.

Now, he wondered if it might not have been mercifully quicker to have simply been squished under Tommy's sneaker.

The full horror of his situation overwhelmed him. His antidote was gone, on its way to his nephew in California. Without access to the antidote, he was trapped, smaller than most bugs.

And now, he had been seriously injured.

"I'LL SHOW YOU THE REST OF THE HOUSE," Tommy told his friend.

"COOL!"

Joe's marched away, his massive Airwalks thudding on the floor with each step.

Tiny Bryan watched them with both dread and relief. He tried to crawl as best he could, but being unable to walk severely hindered his progress. He needed something he could utilize as a crutch.

He saw something interesting on the underside of the monolithic wooden door.

Splinters. Tiny shafts of wood that were gradually being shaved away from the door. Several of them were too massive for him to handle. He kept searching and found one that looked right.

To reach it, he had to stand, trying to support all of his weight on his good leg. He almost toppled forward, but he managed to grab the rough splinter. His hands held tightly to it as he struggled to tear it free from the rest of the massive wooden door. He produced fresh gashes in his hands, but that was a small price to pay.

Finally, he achieved his goal. Once torn free, he used the splinter to support himself and keep weight off the injured leg. He could move, although not very fast.

He made his way out of the kitchen and toward the living room and the giant teenagers. They were his last hope, and his biggest peril.
111131211212.title: Perseverance

choices: Tommy faints
Tommy picks him up
111131212.content:
Tommy meant to swat the irritating insect and be done with the problem, but as he raised up Mr. Smith's newspaper, the teenager noticed something.

The little bug was still squeaking… but that wasn't what caused the teenager to pause.

"Is this crazy bug wearing clothes?" Tommy said aloud.

Mr. Smith, who had thought he had reached the end of the line when Tommy raised the enormous newspaper to swat him, heard the words and felt his heart begin to race.

"Yes, it's me!" The tiny man shouted.

He forced himself to remain motionless as the teenager leaned in closer for a better look...
111131212.title: Tommy notices something a little off about the bug

choices: Tommy mails the package and heads home
Tommy mails the package and decides he should visit EDL Labs
1111312122.content:
"SHIT! WHAT HAPPENED TO YOU, MR. SMITH?" Tommy exclaimed in an excited voice that forced the little man to his knees.

Nothing had prepared the shrunken scientist for how loud and painful his teenaged neighbor voice would sound to his tiny ears.

"YOU ALL RIGHT?" Tommy asked when he saw the tiny man's pained reaction.

"Tommy, stop talking," the speck-sized man shouted.

Tommy heard the faint squeaks, but again failed to detect any actual words on the little man's part.

His dark eyes studied the little man, dressed in a set of tiny clothes. His neighbor looked the same as always, sort of geeky and awkward, just much, much smaller. Tommy knew Mr. Smith worked as a professor. He could only speculate that some sort of experiment had gone terribly wrong.

"DON'T YOU WORRY, MR. SMITH!" Tommy promised loudly, causing the tiny man to moan in pain again as the teenager's thunderous words uttered in such close proximity increased his agony.

When the teenager stopped talking, the tiny man tried again. "Tommy, I just need the package! It has the antidote!"

The teenager was scanning the room, confusing the tiny professor. But Tommy found what he needed. He left the table, but he soon returned with a small glass canister collected from Mr. Smith's cabinet.

"What the hell does he mean to do with that?" The tiny man asked.

"Better get in here," Tommy said. "I'll take you home with me, but first I will mail that package. I remember how important you said it was!"

The panicked man backed away in shock. "No! Leave the package! It has the antidote I need...."

The little man stopped talking and screamed when Tommy reached down and without any ceremony simply plucked him off the tabletop between two massive fingertips.

"Ahhh, you'll crush me," the tiny many shrieked as the massive digits held him in a crushing grip.

Fortunately, the pinch with the fingertips lasted only long enough to drop the tiny man into the deep glass container that Tommy immediately lifted to his face.

"YOU SHOULD BE SAFE IN THERE, DUDE."

At least the thick glass blocked the painful force of the teenager's loud voice, but it also effectively muffled tiny Mr. Smith's desperate squeaks.

After he had protectively placed his shrunken neighbor in the glass canister, Tommy found the package and the payment his neighbor had left him.

As he pocketed the money and left the house with the cardboard box and a tiny glass bottle, Tommy felt good that he was helping out his neighbor. He didn't have a clue to what had shrunken Mr. Smith, but he could explore that once he had performed the vital task of making sure his neighbor's package got into the mail.

Mr. Smith pounded on the glass walls of his prison until he ran out of strength. In horror he realized that Tommy was on his way to the post office to mail the antidote to the shrinking formula halfway across the country and there was nothing he could do to stop him.
1111312122.title: Tommy's Good Intentions

choices: Family cat
Family dog
11113121221.content:
Mr. Smith felt sick to his stomach, and not just from the way every step Tommy took tossed him about like a cork on the waves. He felt sick to realize that Tommy's helpful actions had been the worst possible action the teenager could have taken.

The antidote that could have restored him was now on its way cross country to his nephew. He had been a helpless, mute observer as the gigantic teenager made the trip to the post office and handed the package over to a giant postal clerk. Mr. Smith felt like crying as he realized how horribly wrong things had gone.

"I just have to get Tommy to listen to me," he said, changing plans to keep pace with the developments outside of his control. "He can reach Zack and tell him it is vital that he bring the package and the antidote here."

He realizes that he is placing a lot of faith in a teenager. With a shake of his head, he realizes that he has very little choice.

The trip from post office and back to Tommy's home is mercifully brief. When Tommy arrives home, he makes a beeline for his room, locking the door behind him before he removes the small glass container and places it on the desk in front of him. He is somewhat relieved to see that Mr. Smith still seems all right.

He gets a goofy grin on his face as he stares through the glass at his bug-sized neighbor.

"I guess it is a good thing I looked closer back at your place, huh Mr. Smith? I came really close to swatting you. But I thought you were a bug, and well, look at you. Could you blame me?"

Mr. Smith stares in horror as Tommy nonchalantly recounts how he almost swatted him like an insect! In response, he tries to gesture at the lid of the container. "Let me out!" He yells, even knowing his words can't be understood by the titan.

Nevertheless, Tommy gets the right idea. A moment later, the tiny man is unceremoniously dumped out of the jar and onto the desktop. The teenager doesn't even seem to comprehend how harrowing it is for the shrunken scientist to simply be dumped onto the desk.

Finally dusting himself off, he stands and looks around. He has never seen the teenager's room. It seems fairly typical. There are some posters of some skateboard celebrities on the walls. His desk is crowded with a computer, keyboard and mouse, as well as enormously oversized objects such as pens, pencils and a bright green notepad.

"Tommy, it's scary being this tiny," I yell at him through hands cupped around my mouth. "Do you understand me?"

I see Tommy tilt his head toward me, but then he shakes his entire upper body, and I feel the result in the tremors beneath my feet. "Sorry, little man. I just can't hear you. You're just so tiny!"

That is when Mr. Smith gets what he believes is a brilliant idea. He runs over to the colossal keyboard and looks up at Tommy. Then he points at the keyboard, and then points at Tommy.

The giant teenager leans over him, and then a light bulb seems to go off. "Good idea, Mr. Smith." His huge hands hover over the keys.

Mr. Smith backs up so he can get a view of the keyboard. He patiently waits for Tommy's finger to hover over the right key. Using the trusty "hunt and peck" method, a semblance of a message begins to take shape on the mega-sized computer screen.

"U mailed antidote. I can't get big. Contact nephew."

"Oh no!" Tommy is remorseful when he realizes what he has done, but also a little defensive.

"How could I know that?" He asked.

Mr. Smith tried to wave his arms to let Tommy know that there are no hard feelings. "Just keep typing!" He yells up as he waits for the teenager to get back to the task at hand.

After a painfully long process of some trial and error, he manages to convey Zack's phone number to Tommy. He watches, thrilled, as Tommy takes out his phone and begins to dial the number on the screen in front of him.

But, he reaches a pre-recorded greeting welcoming him to leave a message. But, when he tries to do so, he gets another message informing him that Zack's voicemail box is full. Then, with a click, the call ends and he must look down in confusion at the tiny, expectant man.

"Sorry, Mr. Smith. Your nephew needs to clean out his voicemail box."

Mr. Smith felt his spirits sink at this other unexpected setback. But, they can always try again later...

"I can always try him again later," he said. A loud rumbling startled the little man, but Tommy just laughed. "I think I could use a snack. Want me to bring you back something?"

Mr. Smith realized the loud gurgling noise had simply been the protests of the teenager's empty stomach.

Of course, Tommy doesn't really wait for a reply. Only after the giant teenager has left the room does Mr. Smith realize that Tommy has also just left him alone and exposed on the desktop.

"That's very irresponsible of him," Mr. Smith grumbles. But, he just went to get a snack...he should be back soon.

But, when he heard a strange noise, he realized it wasn't the teenager returning. Instead, it was the...
11113121221.title: Tommy mails the package and heads home

choices: Mr. Smith must try to regain Tommy's attention
Tommy's careless steps
111131212211.content:
Tiny Bryan Smith began to suspect that being in the hands of a teenager wasn't, all things considered, the best place to be.

Tommy tended to blunder his way through life, and so far that has been very costly for Mr. Smith. The teenager, without consulting him, had mailed the package with the only available antidote halfway across the country to Mr. Smith's nephew.

Now, unless they could contact the nephew, Mr. Smith remained stranded at the shockingly small size of a mere quarter-inch tall. Bug size… speck size.

"I've just got to get through to Tommy," the little man said. "Let him know how vulnerable I am at…"

Mr. Smith's monologue came to an abrupt end when the tiny man heard the blood-freezing sound of a huge feline's friendly meow as it bounded from the floor onto Tommy's bed.

Under ordinary circumstances, the domestic house cat wouldn't have posed a threat. But, the feline now looked like Cat-Zilla.

"Tommy!" Mr. Smith began screaming for assistance at once. "Help me!"

Unfortunately, his tiny, weak cries only attracted the curious cat, which leapt from the bed to the desktop to search for the source of the sound.

Mr. Smith looked for a secure place to hide, noticed the towering container of metallic mesh that held some of Tommy's enormous pens and pencils. At the size of a mere bug, he easily passed through the mesh grille.

And not a moment too soon. The cat had spied a glimmer of movement and proceeded to bat the pencil container with its paw. As a result, the feline sent the container tumbling over the edge of the bed just as Tommy returned to the room.

"No!" The giant teenager screamed. "Get out of her, stupid cat!"

The cat disappeared from the room with a screech and blur of fur.

The teenager hadn't noticed the cat knocking the container of pencils off the desk, so he ran carelessly into the room, not bothering to watch his step.

On the floor, a dazed Mr. Smith crawled from the debris field of the pencils and pens as he watched Tommy's huge sneakers bearing down on him.

The distraught teenager, finding no sign of his tiny neighbor on the desktop, came to the shocking, and erroneous, conclusion that the cat had eaten the bug-sized scientist.

"Oh, gross," Tommy said. "What a way to go!"
111131212211.title: The curious cat

choices: Hide and think of a plan
Try to get Tommy's attention... again!
1111312122112.content:
From a floor strewn with pencils and pens the size of felled hardwood trees, bug-sized Bryan Smith gazed up in awe at his teenaged neighbor.

"Tommy! Thank god!" The little man exclaimed before the teenager's loud words silenced him.

"Gross! What a way to go," Tommy said aloud, experiencing some guilt that the family cat had simply eaten his shrunken neighbor.

Or so he thought.

Listening to the titanic teenager, Mr. Smith realized the danger of the mistaken assumption. "No! I'm still here!"

Suddenly, Tommy took a step back and something collapsed with a loud, splintering crunch beneath his shoe. He look down and saw he had crushed an ink pen. Noticing the overturned container, he cursed.

"Damn cat. Must've knocked them over while it was after poor Mr. Smith."

As for poor Mr. Smith, he stood horrified as he saw the shattered plastic fragments of the pen destroyed by one careless step. "Oh no!"

Tommy moved again, kneeling to gather the scattered pens and pencils.

The tiny man had fled in abject terror when he saw Tommy's enormous form coming down toward him. From his much more puny perspective, the ordinary skinny teenager looked like a fearsome behemoth.

And, no longer even attempting to use sensible precautions, Tommy was more dangerous than ever.
1111312122112.title: Careless, Destructive Teenager

choices: A dropped pencil rolled beneath the desk
He sees glowing eyes in the shadows
11113121221121.content:
The crushed ink pen had produced a wrenching roar as the plastic cylinder splintered into jagged shards of rough plastic. For the tiny man, the destruction of the pen sounded like a demolition crew ripping into an abandoned building.

He was terrified into action, running blindly, navigating his way around more of the fallen pencils and pens. He looked over his shoulder and saw Tommy stretching a hand toward the floor. A shadowy recess opened ahead of him. The tiny man raced toward the shelter just as a gigantic hand dropped from the heavens and seized a couple of pencils.

The shrunken scientist stood, panting heavily, in the dusty recess beneath Tommy's desk. He took stock of the situation, realizing he was probably safer here than out there.

Tommy, thinking that he had been eaten by the cat, wasn't likely to use the precautions necessary to make Mr. Smith feel safe about approaching him.

"I'll just have to wait until the coast is clear," he said, taking another deep breath. "Then I can try again to get his attention."

He was ready to settle down and wait until...
11113121221121.title: Go Into Hiding

Sore. Really sore.
111131212211211.content:
Tommy had almost cleaned up the mess of spilled pens and pencils, putting the writing utensils back into a container on his desk. He saw another pencil, reached down to pluck it from the floor. He still felt bad that his own cat had eaten his shrunken neighbor, but he also told himself it wasn't his fault.

"How could I know the cat was in the house?" Tommy reasoned. "Besides, I didn't shrink him."

If he had been more attentive to the task at hand, he might not have dropped the pencil. The yellow pencil dropped to the floor with some minor clatter and immediately started rolling, disappearing beneath the desk.

From his hide-out under the desk, the tiny man had listened to the giant teenager muttering to himself about the supposed fate of the unfortunate scientist.

"No," Mr. Smith thought to himself. "The cat didn't eat me."

He considered rushing out of hiding and attempting again to capture Tommy's attention, but before he could do so, a huge yellow log dropped from the heavens, making a loud crash as it impacted the floor and started rolling toward him.

"Oh shit!" Mr. Smith had time to exclaim before he tried to race out of the path of the enormous pencil bearing down on him. A foot caught on a small imperfection in the floor, sending the tiny man sprawling just as the huge pencil caught up with him. The mammoth pencil heavily rolled over the tiny man.
111131212211211.title: Dropped Pencil

11113121221122.content:
The jagged plastic shards and puddles of ink scattered across the floor represented a debris field of obstacles for the tiny man to manage as he ran toward the enormous teenager, who mistakenly had accepted that the family cat had snacked on the shrunken scientist.

"I'm alive!" Mr. Smith shouted and waved his hands over his head as he made a headlong dash toward Tommy's right sneaker. "Down here! The cat didn't eat me!"

"What a fucking mess," Tommy grumbled as he surveyed the consequences of one careless step.

Not that long ago, Mr. Smith had viewed his teenaged neighbor as a potential savior, but then the teenager had done some fairly typical teenager things, such as mailing off the antidote to Mr. Smith's nephew, leaving the scientist stranded at his current bug size.

The titan's footsteps caused massive quakes that knocked the bug-sized man off his feet. Before he could recover, the shrunken man saw a huge plastic brush and dust pan held aloft in Tommy's massive hands.

With quick precision, the teenager swept up the remnants of the ink pen, never realizing that his quick, casual motions with the brush has also collected one tiny man.

Mr. Smith continued to scream for help as Tommy carried the ruined pieces of the pen toward a waste basket. He dumped the contents into the basket.

Tiny Mr. Smith hit the bottom of the plastic receptacle ahead of the plastic debris, which then rained down around him.

He tried to roll to one side after he gazed skyward and saw one particular nasty-looking jagged piece of plastic hurtling down like a missile.

The sharp point skewered the bug-sized scientist quite neatly, if not painlessly. In fact, the plastic shard nearly cut the tiny man in half.

If there was a good point to his miserable end, it was he didn't suffer long at all. He managed to look skyward once more, seeing Tommy's massive face staring down into the colossal waste basket as his vision failed.

In the days that followed, more trash was added to the receptacle until, at week's end, the full bag of garbage was carried to the curb by the very same careless teenager that had so utterly extinguished his next-door neighbor's very existence.

A cat rubbed against Tommy's leg as he left the bag of trash for the garbage collectors. He gave the feline a funny look, and still felt a little haunted by the fact his own cat had eaten poor Mr. Smith.

As the fly, which was his equal in size, hovered in front of him, the tiny man got a close look at the alien creature. It looked particularly hideous with its drooping feeding tube dangling from a head crowned with faceted eyes.

Its primary wings, beating 200 to 300 times a second, let the winged bug zip around the tiny man, making a shrill noise the entire time.

He tried to slap at the attacked, but now that he was on a roughly equal footing with the insect, "shooing" away a fly was no longer an option open to him.

Suddenly, the insect used two spiky limbs to grasp at the tiny man's shirt. With a furious buzzing, the fly managed to lift him off the table.

The tiny shrunken scientist screamed as he found himself airborne and carried in an erratic path around his own enormous kitchen.
111132.title: Attack of the fly

choices: Tommy's arrival had scared the fly off
Tiny Bryan's approach had startled the fly into departing
1111321.content:
At first, the tiny scientist struggled to get free of the fly's grasp, but then thought better of his attempt.

If those spiky limbs let go of him, the drop to the distant floor looked to be a long one. As the winged bug veered around the colossal kitchen, the shrunken man found himself hoping desperately that the fly wouldn't let him go.

The fly buzzed toward a wide glass pane and began beating itself against the kitchen window. Of course, every impact rattled the insect's tiny captive as well.

Suddenly, the fly made a sharp turn, flying away from the window and entering a spiral dive. Tiny Mr. Smith saw the fly's destination and tried to scream. "No!" The bug-sized man shouted. "Not the damn trash can!"

Sure enough, the fly landed amid heaps of garbage inside Mr. Smith's kitchen trash can. Fast-food wrappers, old banana peels and coffee grounds competed for space inside the plastic-lined walls of the steep trash container.

When the fly landed, it released its hold on the tiny scientist. Given no warning, he skidded face first into a field strewn with old coffee grounds. When he picked himself up, he saw the fly found the blackened banana peel more interesting.

As the tiny scientist gazed around his prison, he came to the awful realization that getting out of the trash can posed a bigger challenge than getting into it.

Suddenly, the fly buzzed away and flew out of the enormous plastic container.

Tommy closes the door behind him before fly can escape

At first, the shrunken scientist fought to get free of the fly's grasp, but after a look down at the distant floor he realized the peril of making the winged insect drop him from such a height.

If those spiky limbs released their grasp on the collar of his tiny shirt, the drop to the distant floor looked to be a very long one. The speck-sized man cursed his bad luck when the fly veered around the colossal kitchen. All he could do at this point was hope the insect would make a landing before dropping him.

The insect buzzed toward a wide glass pane and began beating itself against the transparent obstacle. Of course, every impact jarred the insect's tiny captive as well.

Suddenly, the fly made a sharp turn, flying away from the window and out of the kitchen. The little man screamed as the fly zipped past gigantic furniture and flew below the enormous light fixture descending from the ceiling in the living room.

A strong breeze caused the insect to beat its wings faster to compensate. That's when the tiny scientist saw his teenaged neighbor standing in the open doorway.

"Oh my god!" Mr. Smith screamed. "He's huge."

Tommy closed the front door and walked across the room. The fly's tiny captive watched in awe every move the titan made.

Suddenly, the fly buzzed around Tommy's head. Mr. Smith saw the teenager's huge ears and then was carried across the forest of brown hairs atop Tommy's head. In the next instant, the fly buzzed right in front of Tommy's enormous and handsome face.

Mr. Smith, from only inches away, marveled at the titanic teenager's large eyes, the steep slope of his nose and the wide, full lips. Based on the stubble, the teenager looked in need of a shave.

The bug of a man tried to wave."Tommy! It's me! Help!"

"No! Don't!" Mr. Smith cried. "You'll crush me!"

Fortunately, the fly soared higher and Tommy continued his trek toward the kitchen. When the fly's flight path leveled off, the tiny man watched the enormous teenager pick up the small package from the table.

"No! I'm not in there yet!" He tried to shout at the oblivious giant.

Tommy, having obtained the package and the money, decided to exit through the kitchen's back door. He opened the door again just as the fly made another dive toward the titan's head.

Hearing the irritating buzz, the teenager swatted again and missed again.

Then, the shrunken man saw another danger. The fly headed toward the open door, ready to escape into the great outdoors.

"No!" The little man screamed...

11113221.content:
No amusement park thrill ride could possibly match the pure adrenaline-pumping excitement of Mr. Smith's wild ride in the clutches of a common House Fly. After the winged insect had grasped his shirt collar and launched itself into flight, there was nothing the shrunken scientist could do, even when his next-door neighbor (and possible savior) showed up.

To his credit, Tommy followed Mr. Smith's instructions with precision. The tiny man got to watch from close to his kitchen ceiling as the gigantic teenager lifted the small package from the table. Next, in one graceful move, the teenager stuffed the payment for the chore into his pocket.

The tiny man endured a couple of too-close brushes with the teenager's colossal hand when the fly carried him too near the towering titan. He survived being almost swatted only to face another ominous prospect.

The fly sensed the change in its surroundings when the teenager opened the back door and zipped toward the open entry, hoping to soar into the indescribably vast back yard.

The tiny man kicked, squirmed and screamed, mindful only of preventing the fly from exiting the dubious security of his home. Everything around him might be scaled to colossal size, but the shrunken man favored his prospect more inside his huge home rather than the immense outdoors.

Once again, the tiny man, now reduced to a size of no significance even to a little fly, found himself in tantalizing proximity with Tommy. Despite his scary enormousness, the teenager represented the unlucky scientist's best hope of regaining normal size.

"Tommy! Help!" He screamed as the fly zipped past the teenager's epic features. Tommy's enormous eyes darted back and forth as he tracked the path of the irritating flying pest.

"No," the tiny man cried again as he saw Tommy's onrushing hand, this time accompanied by a blast of curse words for the pesky insect.

The bug-sized scientist knew he had to get back inside his home. His mind raced with all the over-sized perils he faced at the pathetic stature of a quarter-inch tall.

Frustrated at missing yet again, Tommy would have rushed to his car to continue with his task if he hadn't seen something of interest on a patio table.

"NOW YOU'LL BE SORRY," Tommy said as he lifted the plastic flyswatter from the table. He placed Mr. Smith's package on the table and then listened, trying to detect the buzzy noise generated by the fly's wings.

In the meantime, the fly hovered on the other side of the patio table. Tiring from the effort of carrying extra weight, the insect looked for a place to land on the surface of the patio table.

"No! You can't!" Mr. Smith screamed in desperation. "You'll crush me!"
11113221.title: Outside with the fly... and Tommy

111132211.content:
The fly hovered and circled around the patio table, unperturbed by the feeble efforts to win freedom being made by the tiny man held in the clutches of its spindly legs.

As the winged insect veered and careened through the air, the tiny man kept losing track of his titanic neighbor. On occasion, he spotted Tommy and the raised plastic fly-swatter and tried to shout a warning to the teenager.

"Don't do it! You'll kill me!" The tiny man screamed to the oblivious teenager, who patiently followed the fly's meandering movements.

To the shrunken man's dismay, the fly zoomed in for a landing near the center of the oval patio table. As they landed, the fly released the tiny man, who tumbled across the tabletop. To his credit, the tiny man hit the surface with the immediate plan of putting space between himself and the fly. He raced across the surface of the acrylic patio table as fast as his tiny legs could carry him.

He heard Tommy's gloating voice behind him as he ran. "A-HA!" Tommy cried out as he swiped at the winged insect with the borrowed fly-swatter. The red plastic mesh slammed down hard on the table, reducing the fly to a gruesome mess.

The tiny man had succeeded in putting enough distance between himself and the insect, but he felt the rush of air when Tommy swatted the fly. The hurricane-force wind bowled him over. On his back, he looked upward as Tommy lifted the red fly-swatter off the table. He held the destructive weapon, fashioned from little more than a plastic mesh attached to a thick plastic handle, in one of his huge hands.

The sight of the titan unnerved the little man. He turned left and right, looking for a place to hide. He saw a giant terra-cotta tower rising from the table's surface. A huge green plant bigger than a tree rose from the top of the tower. The gigantic potted plant offered the only available shelter on the table, but it looked very distant.

He took a deep breath, got to his feet and sprinted toward the towering object. If he had waited a few more seconds, Tommy would have already turned and headed back into the house. As it was, he caught sight of something tiny scurrying across the table.

"HEY…ANOTHER ONE," Tommy said in a loud voice, aiming the fly-swatter again.

The tiny scientist pushed himself faster, but looked over his shoulder. He saw the titan raise his muscular arm to make an effective swat with the lethal weapon. Concentrating too much on the huge teenager, he stumbled and crashed. He scrambled onto his back just in time to see Tommy position the fly-swatter over him.

"Tommy!" He screamed. "Wait! It's…."

The loud WHAP from the plastic mesh against the tabletop sounded satisfactorily in Tommy's ears.

"Gross!" He exclaimed, lifting the fly-swatter and seeing the splattered remains of the unidentified bug. He stepped across the deck and looked into a small storage cabinet, finding what he needed.

He sprayed the tabletop with a cleaning fluid and used a paper towel to wipe up the remains of both the fly and the other little bug. He wadded up the paper towel and tossed it into the backyard brick barbecue pit. The next time his neighbor had a barbecue, the soiled paper towel could help fuel the fire.

Then, he retrieved the package he had promised to mail and headed to the post office.
111132211.title: Hard landing

choices: Zapped
Fly drops him
111132212.content:
Tommy held the package he had been instructed to mail for his neighbor in one hand while he wielded a huge red flyswatter with his other hand. His eyes darted back and forth as he tried to track the erratic flight of the irritating fly.

All he saw was a dark little bug with wings that produced an aggravating buzz and defied his earlier swatting attempts. He didn't look closely enough to see the tiny man in the insect's clutches, nor did he detect the faint squeaks for help that emanated from his shrunken next-door neighbor.

The insect veered away from the colossal teenager and buzzed past a building-sized structure hanging from the overhang of the deck. A metal grill enclosed a huge lamp that glowed pale blue.

Only for a brief instant did the tiny man celebrate the move away from his titanic neighbor. Still held in the iron grasp of the insect's spindly limbs, the shrunken scientist renewed his struggle to escape when he recognized the structure as the bug zapper he had installed to eradicate mosquitoes and other pesky insects that intruded onto the backyard living space.

At almost that same instance, Tommy's expression changed to one dominated by a gloating smile as he noticed that the curious fly had begin circling closer and closer to the outdoor bug zapper. Oblivious to the life and death struggle right under his nose, the giant teenager lowering the flyswatter and watched as the tiny fly spiraled closer and closer to its doom.

When the tiny scientist detected that the fly's circling pattern kept moving closer and closer to the giant bug zapper, he realized that the voltage in the device was more than enough to fry the bug and his tiny form. He smelled a strange odor of ozone as they got closer to the zapper.

"Tommy!" The tiny man screamed as loudly as he could. "Help me!"
111132212.title: Big Bug Zapper

choices: Fried!
Shocked but alive
1111322121.content:
The insect, oblivious to the danger, circled closer to the deadly bug-zapper. The blue glow produced by the device worked to attract the insect closer. At the same time, the fly's tiny unwilling passenger recalled hanging the bug-zapper a few weeks ago after a particularly unpleasant evening battling backyard bugs.

Now that he had shrunken to a size smaller than some of those same pests, the research scientist repented his action. "Tommy! Please, you have to see me!" The shrunken man screamed from the clutches of the fly. "Help me!"

Tommy, hearing only the droning buzz produced by the fly's wings, looked on with gloating interest as he realized that the pesky bug was moving closer to its doom.

With the fly drawing closer, tiny Mr. Smith smelled the ozone and heard the humming from the energy produced by the zapper's batteries. More desperately, he struggled to free himself, deciding at last that even a plunge to the distant ground might be preferable to death by electrocution. Even this last effort proved futile, his meager strength no match to the fly's iron grasp.

As Tommy watched, the fly hovered in front of the zapper's metal grill. The insect tried to maneuver through the network of metal bars when there was a loud ZAP!
1111322121.title: Zapped!!!

11113221211.content:
Tommy watched idly as the buzzing fly hovered closer and closer to the zapper's metal grill. He knew how the devices worked and expected at any second to detect the zap and pop when the pesky insect made contact.

The fly veered off, prolonging the suspense. As the bug flew near his ear, Tommy heard something else, a shrill sound almost masked by the buzzing of the insect's wings.

Something that almost sounded like "help me!"

He laughed, remembering a similar line from some old black-and-white sci-fi movie.

As the fly flew toward the giant teenager's head, Mr. Smith began screaming again, realizing this could be his final chance.

"Tommy! Help me!" The shrunken man screamed at his colossal neighbor. "Help me!"

In response, Tommy raised one hand lazily and brushed the insect away. For tiny Mr. Smith, the advancing hand looked enormous and he screamed wordlessly as the teenager succeeded in driving the fly back toward the huge metal zapper.

"No!" The tiny man screamed again. He had invented a shrink formula, dammit! He was supposed to be famous.

The insect crossed the fatal barrier.

"Noooohhh!"

ZAAP!

The teenager heard the implosive noise as the intense electric jolt disrupted the tiny creature, splattering its remains all over the back porch.

"Cool!" Tommy intoned in a dull voice.

It was funny, too, because when the insect flew closer to the zapper, he again heard the "help me" noise and, he could have sworn, he also heard the tiny bug call his name.

He laughed again and shook his head. It was impossible, but it was a cute fantasy.
11113221211.title: Fried!

choices: Tommy pours a flood onto the geranium
Drop off the leaf and hide at the base of the huge flower
11113221212.content:
Tommy watched with gruesome fascination as the fly buzzed too close to the zapper's electric grid and was disintegrated by a powerful discharge.

The former-fly fragments rained down from the hanging zapper, littering the patio bricks and a couple of potted plants.

"Gross!" Tommy exclaimed to himself.

Of course, not knowing to look for anything out of the ordinary, he had failed to notice the pale, tiny form that plunged from the zapper and dropped onto the leafy foliage of a flowering geranium.

A few moments later, as the tiny scientist regained consciousness, he smelled burning hair and realized that contact with the zapper had scorched his hair. Some patches of his scalp were actually smoking, but he quickly patted out the smoldering hairs with his hands.

He felt really strange, and not just because he was still a mere quarter-of-an-inch tall. The fly had taken the brunt of the electric zap, but he had suffered enough of a shock to leave him quite shaken.

"Where am I?" The tiny man wondered.

He looked... and screamed.

Tommy was looming over him. He took a deep, cleansing breath when he realized the titan wasn't about to stomp him.

In fact, as he took a closer look around him, he found he was lying on a wide, flat green leaf, one of many on the trunk-like stem of the houseplant he had potted with his own hands only a couple of weeks ago.

"I survived!" He realized.

Then he saw the charred chunks of fly that had been splattered against him. In disgust, he wiped them away as best he could.

He realized he was the size of a bug, sitting on the leaf of a geranium.

That didn't sound too bad until he saw the huge watering can in Tommy's hands and remembered he had asked the teenager to also water his plants during his absence.
11113221212.title: Shocking

choices: Mr. Smith leap onto Tommy's curly hair
Mr. Smith gets mired in a bog of waterlogged potting soil
111132212121.content:
The tiny man watched with mounting fear as his enormous teenaged neighbor approached, a white plastic watering can bigger than the Taj Mahal held in one of his huge hands.

Stranded on the wide geranium leaf, the tiny man started screaming Tommy's name, pleading for the giant teenager to take notice of him.

Instead, Tommy tilted the spout of the watering can and unleashed a mighty torrent of water that crashed down onto the geranium, which was somewhat wilted from the mid-day sun.

The roaring waterfall crashed into the tiny man and swept him off the leaf. The force of the water carried the speck-sized scientist to the swath of potting soil held in the building-sized pot. Chunks of the soil went flying, dispersed by the awesome force of the water.

Tommy went about his chore in a hasty, unplanned manner. After giving the geranium a thorough soaking, he moved on to one of the neighboring plants.

He took no notice of the shrunken, spluttering man pushing himself to his feet at the massive trunk-like stem of the geranium.

Tiny Mr. Smith's clothes were drenched with water and splattered with mud. He continued to cough water out of his lungs as he tried to focus on the ongoing actions of his giant neighbor. Tommy, who had always been the scrawny, next-door kid to Mr. Smith, now looked like some unbelievable titan from ancient lore.

"And he tried to swat me like a bug!" The tiny man squeaked as the indignity surfaced in his mind as he recalled his wild flight with the pesky fly.

"Now he's tried to drown me," he added as he watched Tommy continue to douse other plants with water.

Each attempt to get the teen titan to notice him ended in bleak defeat.

"I've got to do something to get his attention," the little man said with an edge of frantic desperation in his voice. "He's my only chance of getting back to normal."

He saw Tommy finish up and place the mammoth watering can on a patio table. The titan turned toward the back door, obviously intent on going back inside.

"Not without me!" Mr. Smith exclaimed and ran toward the edge of the pot.

Fortune must have smiled on him, because as the colossal teenager drew closer, he stopped and bent to one knee in front of the potted geranium.

He had only stopped to lace up one of his shoes, but it gave the bug-sized man a heaven-sent opportunity.
111132212121.title: Deluge

choices: Mr. Smith fails to grab hold and falls
The horse twitches its tail even more violently
1111322122.content:
Suddenly, the fly veered away from the bug zapper, quickly leaving Tommy's huge form in the distance.

Tiny Mr. Smith celebrated only for a moment before he realized the fly was heading out of the yard and toward the street. The gigantic surroundings looked a blur as the fly sped through the air. The shrunken scientist struggled to free himself from the winged insect before he was carried too far from his home. If he was transported too far astray, he might never get back.

He heard a strange sound as the fly buzzed through the air, forcing him along for the ride. He heard loud, heavy CLOP, CLOP sounds.

A moment later, he saw the fly heading toward an enormous horse trotting down the street. Astride the horse was one of the community police officers assigned to patrol on horseback.

The fly buzzed the huge officer's head and shoulders. The tiny scientist tried to avail himself of the opportunity of help from an official authority.

"Help me!" He screamed. "On the fly! Please, just look! I need heellllpppp!!!"

He screamed as the fly veered sharply again. The officer had brought the horse to a stop at the side of the street directly in front of Mr. Smith's colossal home. While the huge animal was stationary, the fly buzzed around the rear of the horse. The animal's constant twitching kept its huge tail in constant motion. The shaggy strands of hair hung down at the horse's rear, but twitched every time the fly buzzed too close.

"What the hell is this stupid bug going?" The little man wondered.

Suddenly, the fly landed on the hairy tail while releasing its grip on its shrunken passenger. To keep from falling, the bug-sized man grabbed for a rope-thick strand of horsehair.
1111322122.title: Fly Veers Away

choices: Tommy wants to feed the horse
The cop dismounts to demonstrate proper feeding techniques
11113221222.content:
"Oh, I love horses," Tommy said, walking toward the street to greet the cop on his patrol.

"His name's Duke," the officer told the interested teenager.

"Can I touch him?" Tommy asked.

Although it was really against regulations, the officer could not see any harm. He nodded, and Tommy came close enough to touch the animal's shaggy mane. Then he began to walk around the animal, checking it out from all side.

"They're really big and powerful this close," Tommy said.

He needn't have made the statement for his tiny, unseen neighbor's benefit. Every twitch of the horse's tail threatened to dislodge the tiny man from his desperate grip on a strand of hair in the horse's well-combed tail.

As Tommy got closer, the horse whipped its tail back and forth. Suddenly, on one of the upswings, a tiny man lost his grip and went flying…

When he landed, he was still lost in a forest of fibers. Hairs, he determined, but not the long strands of horsehair in the tail of the patrol cop's mount.

He had landed on Tommy's head!

He grabbed for a hair to secure himself, but he didn't have an interval of security as Tommy continue moving, speaking with the cop.

Every move the teenager made threatened to cause the shrunken scientist to lose his grip.

"Tommy!" He screamed. "Help! It's Mr. Smith… I'm on your head."

Of course, his tiny screams went unheard by the huge teenager and even more huge cop.

"Would you like to feed him?" The cop asked Tommy.
11113221222.title: A twitch of the tail

choices: Gobbled with the oats
Licked up
111132212221.content:
"Sure," Tommy answer, his expression changing into one of a big grin.

The officer, by now an expert at this sort of procedure, brought out a food bag. "We'll put some of his favorite oats in this, and you can hold it while he eats."

"Cool!" Tommy exclaimed. He looked down into the bag, never noticing that as he did so, a bug-sized man fell from his forehead and landed deep in the fabric bag.

Before the shrunken scientist could repeat calls for help, the office introduced a couple of handfuls of oats into what he thought an empty bag. "There, you give him those, and you've got a friend for life."

Tiny Mr. Smith felt the bag sway, and felt himself caught up in an avalanche of grain. "Tommy, please," he screamed. "Get me out of here!"

He horse buried its face in the bag, gobbling the oats in a greedy manner. To finish off this snack, it licked the interior of the bag with its long tongue.

"This is great," Tommy said as he stroked the powerful horse's mane.
111132212221.title: Tommy feeds the horse

choices: Bryan dislodges before duke finishes!
Duke finishes the oats, and Bryan is still stuck! Silver lining?
The tiny man falls just after Duke swallows the last mouthful!
1111322122211.content:
Rest assured, Bryan is alive, even if he doesn’t immediately realize it.

Oat grains twice his size cascaded around him as the officer casually dropped the handfuls into the bag. Bryan rode the wave of oats and displaced air up to the top of it, but that only made the view above all the worse.

The horse’s colossal muzzle descended, blocking out most of the sun. The lips and teeth parted, giving the tiny scientist a front seat view of his destination. A dark, cavernous maw, already dripping with saliva and pulsing as it readied for a treat.

“HEEEELLLPP!” He shrieked, fighting to get to the edge of the bag. If he could reach it, perhaps he could climb up, or at least get out of the horse’s way. His cries were hindered by his size, the burlap feed bag, and the conversation of tommy and the officer. Not even Duke heard him.

The horse’s lips plunged deep into the oats just after Bryan made it to the edge. They shook and rose up as the horse moved the mouthful around, slowly chewing it to a paste before gulping it down. Bryan clung for dear life to the bag.

It didn’t take much to dislodge him, however. Duke exhaled through his nose, those two black holes directly above Bryan. Winds strong enough to put a twister to shame assaulted him. Again he screamed as he swirled about with oats dust, circling the horse’s mouth. He claimed and reached out for anything he could grip, but to no avail. When again the jaws opened, he air current swept the man inside, slamming him into an upper molar, or between two of them. His legs and torso squelched into a bit of stick oats paste from the previous bite, currently packed into the molars. He was able to see below at the mouthful just before the mouth closed.

Wet, deafening noises filled the air as the horse chewed, first on one side, then on Bryan’s. Some giant wet thing, presumably the tongue, hit the scientist hard, forcing him up to his stomach in between the teeth. The horse gave a powerful swallow and opened wide for another bite.
1111322122211.title: Gobbled with the oats

choices: Mr. Smith ends up inside the horse's mouth
Mr. Smith falls off the horse's tongue
1111322122212.content:
The tiny scientist grabbed fistfuls of burlap fibers as he sought to prevent being gobbled with the oats as the hungry horse fed from a food bag.

He heard his teenaged neighbor's voice outside the dimly-lit confines of the enormous feed bag.

"THIS IS GREAT," Tommy said.

The situation was far from great, from tiny Mr. Smith's perspective, but he relaxed as most of the oats disappeared. The horse seemed finished with its meal, and he hadn't been eaten by the huge animal.

As Tommy lowered his hand, however, he brushed his fingers against the burlap feed bag, which had the unfortunate consequence of knocking the tiny man to the bottom of the bag.

At that moment, the horse took one last lick with a long, wet tongue, collecting the last few oats in addition to one speck-sized man.

"No!" The tiny man cried as he stuck to the horse's tongue as the cop removed the feed bag.

Things kept spiraling out of control as the horse withdrew its tongue into its mouth.
1111322122212.title: Licked up

choices: Cop and horse return a few hours later
Last journey
11113221222121.content:
Happy Birthday


"Nooooh!" Mr. Smith screamed at the animal drew its enormous tongue back into its mouth with the last of the oats and a little something extra it had managed to lick from the walls of the feedbag.

"Tommy!" The shrunken man shrieked. "Help. Get me out of here!"

He avoided the massive blocks of the animal's huge teeth, which grinded most of the oats between them. After having compacted the oats, the massive animal's tongue began pushing the last of its feed to the back of its mouth, toward the throat and esophagus. The tiny man tried to retain his place on the surface of the tongue, but he found himself part of a tide of barely chewed oats that were being pushed into position for one big gulp.

"I should really get going," the cop told Tommy. "We're both on duty, after all."

"Yeah, sure," Tommy said. "She's just a magnificent animal."

"You got that right," the cop said.

Neither of them heard the teeny cries from the speck of a man trapped inside the horse's mouth. The shrieks got louder, but still not loud enough for them to detect, as the tiny man slid down the animal's deep throat into its stomach.

There, the tiny man realized exactly where his genius had landed him...
11113221222121.title: Swallowed

111132212221211.content:
He tried to think of one last tactic to use to defeat this latest setback, but he had depleted his resource of ideas. Being swallowed by the giant cop's horse, now finding himself stuck in its stomach, the tiny man could rail all he wanted against the unkindness of fate.

For all the good it would do him…

He laughed in a panicky manner. "This can't really be how it ends?" He said aloud in disbelief. "Swallowed by a damn horse!"

Around him, he heard loud, churning noises as activity increased in the equine stomach.

"I just wanted to surprise my nephew," the shrunken scientist shouted.

How could he have ever predicted such an unfortunate chain of events would lead him here?

He began to feel sleepy, but he tried to shake it off. "A plan… I just need a plan," he kept telling himself. When he hit another deadened, he screamed. "Help! Help me! Someone get me out of here!"

A few hours later, Tommy was in his backyard when he heard the loud clomping of hooves coming from the street. He walked over to the fence and saw the cop and horse in his neighbor's driveway. He exited through the gate and was soon standing in Mr. Smith's driveway.

The horse huffed and seemed to recognize him.

"Could we get a bucket of water?" The cop asked. "It's been a hot day."

"Oh, sure," Tommy agreed. He found a bucket in Mr. Smith's garage and filled it at the outdoor spigot. Many a time he had hooked a hose to the same spigot when Mr. Smith hired him to wash his car.

He soon filled the bucket and offered it to the horse. He chatted a moment with the cop while the horse drank. The horse soon drained the bucket.

"Thanks," the cop said. "We should be on our way."

However, before they left the driveway, the horse lifted its tail and left a "gift" in Mr. Smith's driveway.

"Sorry about that," the cop said and motivated the horse to move back onto the street.

"Never mind," Tommy said, but as he stared down at the mess he realized he should probably clean it up. He had agreed to watch after Mr. Smith's place, and his neighbor was always good for some cash when Tommy was available for the odd job.

He hooked up Mr. Smith's hose and then used the spray from the hose to clean away the horse apples left behind by the cop's horse, never imagining in a million years that he was also erasing the last remnants of Mr. Smith as he washed everything to the curb and down a storm drain to eventually wind up in the sewer system.

He didn't know it yet, but he would miss Mr. Smith.

Well, at least he would miss all the easy cash. He finished spraying off the driveway pavement and then returned to his house to find something to do.
111132212221211.title: Cop and horse return a few hours later

choices: Tommy does...
Duke, the horse does...
11113221222122.content:
The tiny scientist falls off of the horse's tongue and falls onto the ground. He looks up and sees that he's surrounded by a pair of hooves, a pair of cop boots and a pair of sneakers. He gulps as he thinks about what to do next.

Bryan looks around to see if there's a safe way out of this, one false move and he's as good as dead.

He hears Tommy and the cop's booming voices as Tommy talks about where he is.

"I'M NOT SURE WHERE HE IS?" Tommy tells the cop "I JUST HOPE HE'S NOT IN ANY TROUBLE."

"WELL IF HE'S STILL MISSING AFTER 48 HOURS, I'LL FILE A REPORT ON HIM" the cop says reassuring Tommy.

"OKAY SIR" Tommy says to the cop with a small smile.

Bryan figured to crawl out of the way, but he was spotted "DAMN, I HATE BUGS" said the cop and Tommy at the same time.

Bryan can hear the stomping of the cop's boots and Tommy's sneakers and the heavy clopping if the horses hooves behind him.

The cop mounts Duke and the two walk towards Bryan.
11113221222122.title: Mr. Smith falls off the horse's tongue

choices: An unfitting end for Bryan
Bryan is spared
111132212221222.content:
"Alright kid, keep out of trouble." said the cop with a wave as he departed.

Tommy grinned at the officer and horse alike and returned the friendly wave. He loved horses. Living in the suburbs meant Tommy almost never saw them, so this was a fun experience to meet Duke.

The cop tugged Duke's bridle, ready to finish up his leisurely patrol and get some lunch. His mind had already purged thoughts of the simple bug both he and Tommy jeered at moments before and he unknowingly maneuvered the large horse directly at the diminutive creature. Tommy watched the majestic beast clip, clop down the street.

"That looks like a fun job," he wondered aloud, smiling.

With a blissful shrug, Tommy handled the package earnestly and resumed his journey to the post office.

---

Bryan Smith found this encounter quite different from his youthful neighbour. Not that he liked horses, much less nature in general. He was a scientist, after all, and preferred bending nature to his will.

Yet, the speck of a man would have preferred to be hog-tied to the back of the horse instead of directly in the enormous beast's path.

"Holy crap! No, I am right here! HELP!"

Both of the towering entities approaching alarmingly fast failed to register Bryan's cries of alarm. The ground literally jolted beneath the tiny man's feet with every cosmic impact of the horse's mammoth hooves. To make matters worse, Bryan was isolated in a rocky wasteland of asphalt: huge boulders, crevices, and debris lay around him. He had no idea which direction was his home or where Tommy went!

CLOMP.

One gigantic hoof lifted in the distance, soaring high and covering enormous distance before impacting the earth with immeasurable power. Terrified, Bryan shrieked at it just as another hoof raised far to his right.

"What do I do? This isn't fair! What do I do!" His only option, he figured, was to run. Run blindly. Bryan did just that: he scrambled over a boulder and prepared the sprint when the sky darkened just moments before a thundering impact. Boulders both small and large were thrown like confetti by the huge force created by the appendage.

Above him, seemingly so big it was the sky itself, loomed the horse. The planetary being was forested in dark brown hair with towering stretches of dirty white coating the ankles. It resembled something out of myth. As if this great beast was the world itself and not just a simple animal. At his size, Bryan could easily establish a populated settlement of many thousands across the stomach alone. Looking at the nearest tower of leg, he could see tiny creatures - fleas or mites, he figured - leaping from their host to be lost upon the asphalt earth below. He felt so tiny against this filthy, dumb beast. Bryan's gaze shot to another tower of flesh and hair as it lifted, headed in his direction.

"Fuck."

It covered insurmountable distance in mere moments and began descending right on the ant-sized man.

"Fuck!"

He could see all sorts of matter a police horse might collect during the day, packed tightly in worn crevices and pulverized beyond recognition with each clomping step. Mud, dirt, grass, and other crap (literally and figuratively). Bryan wasn't sure if he recognised scattered chunks and bits that might have been alive at one point. It revolted and frightened him. In those slight moments, he even discerned a maker's mark forged into the hard steel shoe. Strange that the last thing he would read were huge letters, barely half-inch normally, detailing the brand and gauge of a horseshoe.

Despite himself, Bryan felt numb to this fate. He gawked upwards: Tiny, insignificant, and helpless. What could he even do?
111132212221222.title: Duke

1111322122212221.content:
Without any hesitation Duke slammed his hoof down on the tiny ant man. Bryan felt his bones crunch as it met the cold horseshoe. The cop didn't even notice or care that his horse just killed a tiny man. The cop continued walking away, Bryan's remains joined the dirt and grime on Duke's horseshoe. The horse neighed as if he was victorious, the cop pet his horse. Bryan's fate was swiftly decided by the giant equine, unfortunately he was just a mere bug to the giant stallion.

Back at the station the cop finally noticed the remaining remains of the tiny scientist "well that bug should've gotten out of your way, eh Duke?" The cop chuckled as Duke nickered, the cop cleaned off Duke's horseshoe. "Now, let's put you with the other horses" the cop smiled, he tossed the tissue containing Bryan's remains into the trash. The cop remains oblivious that his trusted horse crushed a tiny human out of existence. The cop put Duke away and went back to work he wondered why his horse was so happy, maybe it's because he gave Bryan an unfitting end.
1111322122212221.title: An unfitting end for Bryan

choices: Duke heads back to the stables.
Bryan manages to free himself!
Duke steps on a rock. bad luck for Bryan
1111322122212222.content:
The tiny scientist could do little more than watch, so he did. He froze in place and closed his eyes as duke the police horse’s colossal hoof descended down on him. As the shadow darkened, a thought crossed his mind: maybe shrinking himself was NOT a good plan after all. Why had that not occurred to him before? Regardless, it was too late to dwell on that now.

In a final act of acceptance to his fate, Bryan reopened his eyes and looked up at the hoof, which was only inches from his puny frame, at which point a new thought entered his head: oh… fuck… and the hoof slammed down onto him with a resonant CLOMP.

The tiny man blinked and found himself decidedly not dead. Or maybe he was. Was he? If he was, was this the afterlife? Why did the afterlife smell overpoweringly of bubblegum? While questions were surging through his mind, Bryan was suddenly lifted dizzyingly fast, and literally; it made him dizzy and his ears popped. Whatever lifted him up flicked back and moved forward, giving the scientist a good view of the Duke’s titanic underbelly and manhood. Bryan began to descend again, and he realized what happened. “HELP MEEE!” he screamed, to anyone or anything that could possibly hear him. But no one could. No one hears the plea of a bug stuck to a piece of gum under a horse’s hoof.

Duke’s hoof slammed down again, forcing the diminutive Bryan a little deeper into the gum. When he was again exposed to the light of day, he managed to catch a brief view of tommy walking back into his house. There was no point in yelling now. His only salvation would come from his own effort to escape before he got too far away.

Duke’s progress was fast, despite his casual pace. Bryan fought against the bonds of the gum, only to have his attempts at freedom undone at the end of the horse’s step. On a positive note, and Bryan was surprised that he could even think of one at the moment, but had the horse not been wearing a shoe, he would most definitely have been killed.
1111322122212222.title: Police (horse) escort

choices: Bryan’s had enough of horses. Get out of the stable!
too much thinking! Just sit down and take a breather.
Duke shifts his weight! Get out of the way!
11113221222122221.content:
The officer patrolled the neighborhood for another hour before leading Duke back to the stables. He had enjoyed the ride, but he knew too much walking on the asphalt could be bad for Dukes hooves.

The police stables stood a few hundred feet from the station itself, only slightly off the main road. They shared a parking lot, and the horse and rider walked through it to enter the shade of the Stable. The officer dismounted barely five feet into the building and quickly unsaddled Duke, leaving only his bridle as he led him into his stall. Most of the other horses, roughly ten or so, had already returned and were absently eating the hay from the corner of their respective stalls. With an affectionate pat on the flank, the officer walked out to return to his duties.

Bryan was in a figurative hell of sound and motion. He lost track of time and had only the near deafening CLOMPS of hoof on road to tell he was still conscious. Light and dark and light again, given a clear view of duke’s underbelly over and over. The gum had somewhat hardened, but in that time he had freed his arms to the shoulder. The only reason he wouldn’t need traction after this ordeal was the shock absorption of the gum cushioning him, but hat wasn’t helping as much now. His voice was hoarse from screaming for help every time he saw light.

Then, suddenly, the hard asphalt was replaced by slightly less hard packed dirt. “What the Hell?” He muttered. Then, also suddenly, the equine behemoth stopped walking. That took a moment to register, as he had almost grown used to the motion. He fought all the harder to free himself, bending around to pry at the sticky substance and get his leg free. He was sent into a mild panic when he heard the whinnying and grunting of other horses around him. He must be all the way back at the stable! That was early two miles from his home! He groaned and kept fighting his bonds. However, before any meaningful progress could be made, He was moving again. Four more steps of the hoof he was attached to later and the horse stopped again. Bryan found himself face to face with A stick as thick as his torso. As he looked, the floor seemed to be almost made of them. He didn’t take too long to consider it and finally managed to get his leg free. It hung limp as he worked on his other one, scraping away the gum and throwing it away as best he could.
