11121.content:
The first part of the shrunken man’s journey through the mail was nothing if not eventful. Tiny Mr. Smith was repeatedly shaken about; he was surrounded by the noise of machinery, human voices and the thud of other letters and packages landing nearby. It was alarming at first, and Mr. Smith feared that at any moment his fragile sanctuary might be carelessly dropped or the sides crushed in, reducing him to a tiny, unrecognizable smear. But Bryan eventually recovered his composure and scolded himself for his anxiety. Thousands upon thousands of parcels and letters went through this same routine every day. Just because there happened to be an infinitesimally tiny man hidden deep within this one didn’t mean that things would somehow be different. Nobody in the whole wide world knew he was even here.

After an hour or so Mr. Smith finally became accustomed to the various sounds and movements around him. He even began to enjoy it a little: trying to make out the muffled snatches of conversation outside or imagine where exactly his box might be at this precise moment. Once his mind was occupied in this way time seemed to pass more quickly.

Eventually, however, the movements ceased and the noises faded into the distant background. The package had been left somewhere, apparently unattended.

Bryan prided himself on his ability to plan ahead. He had arranged the fastest shipping available, but had nevertheless anticipated that there might still be hours of tedium before him. One of the pieces of “equipment” he had therefore taken care to miniaturize beforehand was a smartphone loaded with articles and e-books for him to read. Unfortunately, there were certain other problems that Bryan had failed to anticipate.

For a start, he hadn’t realized just how dark it would be inside the package. He should have guessed this, of course, but he had been too wrapped up in the excitement of the adventure to give it proper consideration. It wasn’t immediately a problem: the phone provided its own illumination. However, his eyes soon became strained from trying to read the glare of the small screen in the otherwise near-total darkness. Finally he gave up and decided to check his email instead--only to discover there was no signal.

Mr Smith mentally kicked himself. In its highly-miniaturized state - not to mention blanketed by the thick layers of wrapping and packaging - the device was simply incapable of connecting with the outside world. But worse was to come. Close to the icon indicating the (lack of) signal strength was the battery meter - and it was almost empty!

“10%?! It should be full! I’m sure I charged it last... DAMN!” And then he remembered. He had indeed put out the phone for charging the previous evening - only to be distracted by an unexpected phone call. How could he be so stupid?

For the first time Bryan started to feel genuinely apprehensive about the situation. He was by no means claustrophobic but he suddenly became uncomfortably aware of how he was now nothing more than a tiny little speck trapped inside a rather small and ordinary parcel travelling through the nation’s labyrinthine postal system. The phone hadn’t simply been there to keep him amused; it was his lifeline if something serious happened and he needed to contact somebody. It’s inability to function as intended meant that he was now cut off from the normal, everyday world he had previously taken for granted. He was completely alone: just a single teeny ant lost in a mysterious world of oblivious and unfathomable giants. Part of him wanted to scrabble frantically out through the minuscule tear in the wrapping and flee...

The calm and logical scientist warred with the frightened miniaturized human... and finally won. Leaving the relative safety of the box at this point would truly be the worst thing he could do. He had no idea where he was, and without the aid of his phone he had no easy means to communicate with any of the people who might be outside. Like it or not, Bryan told himself he had to remain calm and wait. He was already on his way to his nephew: in a few hours he would be delivered and Zack would open the package. Everything would be fine. He couldn’t wait to see just how huge Zack would be - not to mention the expression on his nephew’s face when he saw how utterly minute his uncle was by comparison!

The thought immediately made him relax and he concentrated on dreaming about all the things he and his nephew could do together. A few minutes later he heard muffled noises outside. The cardboard walls around him creaked as a gigantic pair of hands grasped the box and lifted it up. The package shook gently as it was carried away. “There,” Bryan told himself, “I knew everything would work out okay. It won’t be long now!”

But tiny Mr. Smith had no idea just how wrong he could be...

The delivery truck thudded over a speed bump, roughly jostling the cargo. The driver paid little attention to the tumbling and shifting of the cardboard boxes as he drove. This was all par for the course when maneuvering through suburban neighbourhoods.

Glancing back from his GPS, the driver thrummed around a turn in the road and brought his truck to a halt at an intersection. He squinted, adjusting his cap and frowning. It was midday and the sun attempted to intrude upon his vision.

"Where the hell did I put my sungl-...!" His thought cut short when a screech of tires broke the silence. Not a second later, a tremendous crash sent the postal driver chest-first into the steering wheel.

"Dammit!" Sliding the heavy door open, he stumbled out of the vehicle with a grunt. "What the..." His neck and chest throbbed from the impact.

Cardboard boxes slid from the truck and unto the gravel-ridden asphalt. The impact had smashed the large rear-end doors, allowing them to swing loosely. An audible groan caught his attention. He spotted the responsible party in their car nearby.

"You stupid fuck! What the hell were you doing? I was at a dead stop!"

The postman approached the offending vehicle - a dark blue sedan sporting a cracked windshield with a crumpled hood. He pulled his company cap off, furiously scratching his short, dark hair, and proceeded towards the driver. Rubbing her head with bloodied hand, she pawed aimlessly at the steering wheel with the other. She jolted at the sound of his voice. Her eyes shone wide with terror from behind a mess of hair.

"It was an... Uhm, I am... It happened so-...." Despite a broken window, she smashed the door lock shut and revved the battered vehicle. "Fuuuuuuuuck thisss....!" She bleated shrilly. The sedan lurched forward in response with a whine and a clang.

The delivery man leaped back in surprise, cursing after her. She sped the car over the curb; rolling over her own fallen bumper and smashing more than a few of the scattered packages.

"Crazy bitch! Fuck!" Scraping parts against the road, the woman raced her car out of sight. The postal worker stood dumbfounded: surveying the devastation left in her wake. Many packages were either completely flattened, or partially; their contents laying in pieces on the asphalt. Other vehicles passed slowly, their drivers gawking like awe-struck children at the circus. Ignoring them, the driver grabbed his fallen hat and re-positioned it upon his head. Shards of broken goods and packing materials crunched under his boots as he inspected the devastation.

One cardboard crate had been completely flattened. Electronic bits lay strewn around the ruin of cardboard, mixed with plastic packing nuts. A few other boxes were in a similar state. One particularly small package with a gash in the side sat near a dirty swatch of fabric. Grunting, he gave the little box a good kick with his boot. It landed a few feet away, sounding empty.

"Better call the main office to get this crap cleaned up..." Meaning he would miss lunch. Worse, he would need to give a police report since the bitch ran off.

"Some shit day this turned out to be..."

---

Meanwhile, the accident was only the beginning of Bryan's day...

11132.content:
A free afternoon, no classes, or at least none that he couldn't blow off, and no homework, at least none he intended to do, found Rick sprawled on the sofa in the dorm room, a Mountain Dew in one hand and an open bag of chips in the other. He had just eaten a handful of chips when someone knocked at the door. He got off the couch, brushed a few crumbs out of his chest hair, and walked to the door.

"Delivery for Zack Smith," a man in a postal uniform announced, holding a small package in his right hand, a clipboard in the other.

"Oh, right," Rick said. "He's expecting that."

"You're not Zack?"

"I room here with him," Rick said.

"I guess you can sign for it then," the man said and handed Rick the clipboard and nodded to the pen attached.

Rick scrawled a signature on the form held in place by the clipboard, and the man handed over the small cardboard box.

"Have a good day," the man said.

Rick grunted and closed the door. He wandered back toward the couch, box in hand. Before seating himself, he held the box to his ear and gave it a gentle shake. Nothing rattled.

"Wonder what the hell Zack's getting this time?"

Inside the box, a tiny man only a fourth of an inch tall, tried to crawl deeper into a handkerchief field's many crumpled folds to prevent himself from being ping-ponged around the box by a neck-jolting, vigorous shake.

"Fuck!" Bryan Smith screamed in terror.

He had spent the last 23 hours regretting his impulsive action. From the time that his teenaged neighbor had arrived and picked up the package for mailing, the tiny man had been subject to the harrowing and bruising movements that he would never have noticed at normal size.

He was hungry and thirsty. Constant motion had scattered his supplies in the warehouse-sized box, and he had been too scared to venture out to search for them. Worst of all, he had lost the precious glass vial that contained the antidote. Otherwise, he would certainly have used it to get back to normal. He wasn't worried. He could always find it when he finally arrived in his nephew's hands. Until then, he tried to ignore the nausea resulting from another flurry of shocking, unpredictable motion.

"Well, it's not a car," Rick said, staring at the small box. "Not a pair of sneakers."

He continued to run through the list of cool gifts Zack's uncle and benefactor had sent to him. "Lucky bastard," Rick said, working himself into an envious state. "All I ever get is a damn birthday check from Uncle Ray for ten lousy bucks or new socks and underwear from mom."

He knew it was wrong, but he wanted to discover what waited for Zack inside the box. Nothing else at hand, he tore at the tape with the sharp edge of the pop tab from his can of Mountain Dew. When he shredded the tape sufficiently, he pulled back the flaps on the small box.

Bryan Smith was sure he would throw up if he had to endure much more shaking. Then, he heard a raspy, grating noise and with an extremely loud roar, the flaps of the box were drawn back and he looked up to see an enormous face staring down at him.

Not Zack's face, as it so happened.

Rick plucked the handkerchief out of the box. He then looked through the box. The only contents he saw consisted of a few crumbs and tiny scraps of cloth. "The fuck?"

He had entirely missed the tiny speck that plummeted from the handkerchief as he lifted it from the box. "Makes no sense," he said, scratching his head at discovering Zack's surprise was nothing. Literally, nothing; the damn box was empty.

"Fuck! He'll blame me." Rick leaped off the sofa, box still in hand, and went to his desk. He took several long pieces of tape and reassembled the package. It looked a little battered, but he figured that Zack would dismiss that as normal wear and tear from the shipping process.

He then put the package on the counter in their kitchenette. Next to the bowl for keys and phones, Zack would see that his "surprise" had arrived as soon as he returned from class.

Resuming his sprawled, carefree position on the sofa, he reached for his Mountain Dew and chips.

Bryan awoke when he heard the phone next to his bed ring.

He focused groggily on his alarm clock, which gave the time at 8 a.m. He groaned a bit at the unwanted wakeup call before lifting the phone.

"Hello," he said.

"Bro!" Bryan heard the familiar voice of his younger brother, Matt. "I haven't heard from you in ages."

"Sorry," Bryan said, trying to sound sincere. In truth, he did not mind going for a long length of time without contact from his younger sibling. Matt, in Bryan's estimation, never made contact without wanting to finagle some favor from his older brother. "I've been busy."

"Well, I thought I might swing by your place for a visit," Matt said. "How's this afternoon?"

Bryan felt elated. He was able to inform Matt that he was leaving on a trip. "Maybe when I get back," Bryan said. "I will give you a call."

"Where are you going?" Matt asked, unwilling to take the hint.

Bryan stopped himself from sighing. "I am going to visit our nephew," he said.

"Zack!" Matt said excitedly. "How is he doing?"

"I'm sorry, but I am very busy," Bryan informed his brother. "Give me another call in a week, ok?"

"Sure, bro," Matt said.

Bryan ended the conversation. He thought of going back to sleep, but in truth he did have a lot to do.

He got out of bed, showered and dressed.

After having a light breakfast, he wrote a note for Tommy and left it next to his transport box on the kitchen table.

He then went to his bedroom and took off his clothes. Returning to the kitchen, he held a tiny glass vial in his hand. He stared at it.

Glancing at the clock, he knew he still had a couple of hours before Tommy was due.

"Well, why not enjoy a couple of hours being tiny?" Bryan asked himself. In answer to his own question, he drank the contents of the vial.

He felt the familiar sensation almost immediately. By the time he stepped off a chair seat onto the kitchen tabletop, he was only about four feet tall and going down fast.

Within a couple of minutes the brilliant research scientist had dwindled to a mere quarter of an inch tall.

He took in his surroundings, amazed at the colossal scale of everything. His kitchen looked more like the geographical features of some bizarre landscape.

The tiny man walked over and saw the tiny pre-shrunk clothes he had left near the transport box.

"I'll dress later," he decided, leaving the clothes neatly folded.

According to the distant wall clock, the time was just a few minutes past noon. Bryan took a quick jog across the tabletop to stand in the shadow of the crystal salt and pepper shakers, which had transformed into some towering crystal cathedral structure.

Bryan figured he had time to explore these curiosities before he needed to secure himself in the box. He began the short jog to the middle of the kitchen table.

Suddenly, he heard a loud noise at the back door.

"What the hell?" Bryan said, knowing Tommy would not be this early.

The door opened, admitting both a colossal titan and a hurricane-force wind that swept over the tabletop.

"Matt!" Bryan screamed as he watched his enormous brother stand in the open doorway.

Matt slid the credit card he had used to jimmy the lock to the back door back into his wallet.

"Close the door!" Bryan screamed as the wind blew with even more ferocity.

Suddenly, a powerful gust caught his tiny body in an updraft and the speck-sized man found himself airborne.

Matt closed the door and yelled in an awesome roar. "BRO!" Matt's voice thundered as the storm weakened after the door was shut. "ARE YOU HOME?"

For airborne Bryan, this had an immediate consequence when he received affirmation of the lessons he learned long ago about gravity and its effects. He landed, hard, on a rug spread over the floor in front of the kitchen sink.

He now picked up the transport carton, which Bryan had meant to use for shipment to his nephew. The carton looked as big as a building in Matt's enormous hands.

"Matt!" Bryan shouted in vain. "I'm down here, on the floor!"

Suddenly, the chair scraped against the tiles again, and for a moment, Bryan imagined he had been heard.

Instead, he watched as Matt raised himself to his full height and started stomping across the kitchen. His sneakers sent shockwaves reverberating through the tiles of the floor beneath Bryan's feet.

Matt moved with incredible speed. A paralyzed Bryan watched him move past the rug and continue to stand in front of the monolithic refrigerator. The huge door swung open and the front half of Matt's enormous body disappeared from view.

"What am I going to do?" Bryan gasped as he tried to keep his gaze on his gigantic brother. Not only was he stranded, no bigger than a bug, on his kitchen floor, but the vial of antidote was packed inside the transport carton hopelessly beyond his reach on the tabletop.

His only hope rested with contacting Matt.

Matt, nearly a decade younger than his older brother, also stood a few inches taller. Now that even mere inches made a big difference, he overwhelmed the kitchen, which had seemed so vast before his arrival.

Bryan began running over the woven rug, but found his bare feet kept getting tangled in frayed fibers. He slowed his pace to a steady jog, which allowed him to reach the edge of the rug without continually tripping.

He stepped uneasily onto the vast tile surface of the kitchen floor at the same moment Matt emerged from his raid of the fridge with a can of soda.

With the giant no longer motionless, Bryan waited to see in what direction Matt proceeded.
112111.title: On the Floor

choices: Matt see something
Matt leaves the kitchen
1121112.content:
Bryan watched as his brother's enormous sneakers sailed past as Matt walked from the refrigerator back to the kitchen table.

He pushed out a chair and took a seat at the table. He popped his can of soda and took a long drink.

On the floor in front of the kitchen sink, his tiny brother watched in amazement every move made by his unbelievably enormous sibling.

He heard the explosive pop as Matt opened the soda can, drawing his gaze upward as his enormous brother lifted the can and tilted it toward his throat.

Bryan followed the flow of a river of soda down Matt's throat. This was a moment Bryan had always wanted to experience. Here he was, extremely tiny and observing a juggernaut of muscle and skin. Bryan fell into a state that left him almost unaware of everything save the enormity of his younger sibling.

"I cannot believe how huge he is," Bryan said aloud.

Although he could quickly calculate the disproportionate scale that existed between them, mere numbers did little to drive home the difference between them.

"I am a bug compared to him," Bryan realized with a involuntary shudder, a spasm of nervous fear. In truth, he knew, some bugs were even bigger.

Suddenly, he heard movement again, which snapped him out of his thoughts.

Matt had pushed the chair back and stood from the table. Bryan froze in place, waiting to see what direction his giant brother would take.

That's when he noticed the package in Matt's right hand.

"The shipping package," Bryan cried, realizing that the small box held the antidote capable of restoring his size.

Matt stood between the table and the sink, not aware of the tiny speck on the floor.

Bryan leaped and waved his hands in a frantic manner. He realized belatedly that Matt now represented his only hope of returning to normal size.

"Matt!" Bryan screamed as loudly as he could. "Matt, I am down here! On the floor!"

His tiny voice failed to reach his giant sibling's ears.

Suddenly, instead of turning left or right, Matt started walking directly toward the sink.

"No!" Bryan shouted. His mind, unable to decide which way he should flee, simply left him rooted to the spot.

A shadow darkened everything around Bryan, who gazed up at the rapidly dropping shoe.

The sneaker missed him by mere inches.

For something as tiny as Bryan, the miss was a mixed blessing.

He evaded, by chance alone, being stomped beneath his brother's shoe.

But the blast of displaced air as the sneaker slammed down on the tiles threw Bryan into the air. He landed hard on his back, the breath knocked from his lungs.
1121112.title: It Is What He Wanted

choices: Matt wants a hot shower in Bryan's bathroom
Matt wants a nap on living room sofa
11211122.content:
The tiny man, panting hard in an attempt to steady his breathing, watched helplessly as his colossal sibling continued his trek from the kitchen.

After the punishing near-miss with Matt's sneaker, Bryan didn't mind to see his brother go.

In the stillness, however, with only the sound of his own ragged breaths, Bryan realized that he could not simply wait for Matt to return.

He dragged himself onto two legs. Standing, although painful, wasn't impossible for him. He felt bruised, battered, but not yet defeated.

"Where did he go?" Bryan wondered as he rubbed his right shoulder. His shoulder ached with a dull pain. He began to traverse the kitchen floor, making his way to the unbelievably huge archway through which he could enter the other rooms of his home.

After a long journey, he made his way into the hallway. The dimly illuminated corridor connected to other rooms in the house.

Strangely, he heard none of the commotion he had begun to associate with his titanic brother.

"Where is he?" Bryan spoke aloud.
11211122.title: Pushing On

choices: Take a look inside the sneaker
Start his climb up the sofa
112111222.content:
Bryan made slow progress along the corridor in his home. The distant ceiling and the dim light gave the stark corridor the feel of some ancient cathedral.

As the tiny man approached a massive doorway at the far end of the corridor, he heard a strange noise. To his tiny ears, the sound seemed nothing short of a rumbling roar, repeated in a regular rhythm.

Spurred ahead by the sound, Bryan stood in the doorway to his living room. The loud sound continued to breach the stillness.

Then, from his lowly vantage, he detected the source of the sound. His brother and the living room sofa combined to look like some surreal mountain range.

"He's huge!" Bryan remarked as he gazed across the room at his slumbering sibling.

But, he also realized...this could be his chance to get close to Matt without running the risk his giant brother might accidentally trod on him.

Eager, and willing to ignore a litany of dull pains, Bryan scurried across the living room's hardwood floor.

The closer he came to the sofa, however, the more he began to question his plan.

"How will I ever reach him?" Bryan wondered.

Despite his disadvantage of meager size, Bryan remained resourceful. The knotted fabric of the sofa upholstery offered a possible means of ascent.

As he got closer to the sofa, the roars of his brother's snores increased in volume. For the first time, he also detected a strong odor.

The rank odor seemed to come from Matt's sneakers, which he had discarded haphazardly on the floor next to the sofa. One of the massive shoes had landed on its side.

Momentarily curious, Bryan approached that shoe, peering into the cavernous opening that led deeper into the sneaker.

"I can't believe how big it is!" Bryan exclaimed in a teeny voice swallowed in the vastness of his surroundings.

He faced a choice...
112111222.title: Matt wants a nap on living room sofa

choices: Plunge deeper
Oops! Matt awakes
1121112221.content:
He climbed onto the edge of the sneaker. Although the giant shoe rested on its side, he still had to strain his muscles to lift himself into the cavernous structure.

Standing in the mouth of the cavern, he got a good whiff of Matt's foot sweat, which must have imbued itself into every molecule comprising the interior of the sneaker.

He almost considered turning back, but this was too fascinating to resist.
1121112221.title: Inside Look

choices: Yep! It's Tommy!
Nope! It's one of Matt's buddies!
11211122212.content:
Bryan, standing like some explorer at the entrance to some unmapped mammoth cavern, took a deep breath and nearly strangled from the intensity of Matt's foot odor, which wafted from the interior of the colossal shoe.

Between his strangled coughs, the little man had made the decision to turn back and resume his original plan of making contact with his behemoth of a younger sibling.

During his fascination with the monstrous shoe, however, the change in Matt's breathing had gone undetected by Bryan's tiny ears.

Now, things proceeded so rapidly the shrunken scientist has little time to react.

Matt, yawning and stretching, threw his bare feet over the edge of the sofa. One of his massive feet struck the discarded shoe, tilting it back into an upright position.

Bryan did have time to manage a scream, but one so imperceptible it again went unnoticed by his large brother. The shoe settled back into position as the speck-sized man landed with a soft and squishy thud on the damp bottom of the long-worn sneaker.

His peril flashed into his brain at once, but even as he ran toward the massive walls enclosing him in the shoe, Bryan realized his dilemma. At his current size, he was far too small to make his escape from the shoe.

Fortunately, for the moment, Matt remained uninterested in his sneakers. Instead, he padded across the floor in his bare feet to visit his older brother's bathroom.

Inside the shoe, tiny Bryan had one fleeting glimpse of his god-like brother before Matt vanished. His huge brother's massive footsteps on the floor also became less intense as he departed the living room to visit the facilities.

"Ohgod!" Bryan cried out. "What am I going to do now?"

The toxic fumes fogged his brain as he fought to bring enough clean air into his lungs. "I can't believe his feet smell this bad!"

Suddenly, quite clearly, the trapped little man heard the front doorbell ring.

He didn't have a watch, but he could guess. "That must be Tommy!"

And, with sickening clarity, Bryan realized that his teenaged neighbor was here to pick up the package to mail, without its tiny intended passenger, to Zack at college.

Everything was going increasingly wrong.

Bryan felt the footsteps as vibrations that grew ever steadier as Matt returned to the room and walked toward the front door.

He opened the door...
11211122212.title: Prisoner of the Shoe

choices: To the Post Office
To the Post Office
112111222121.content:
Although quite securely contained within his own brother's shoe, Bryan could detect the rumbling conversation from the two giants after Matt responded to the ringing doorbell.

He knew Matt's voice quite well, but he also recognized the husky tone of Tommy's developing masculine voice.

"Oh, hey," Tommy said as he stepped into the Smith residence. "I saw the car in the drive and figured someone must be home. You must be staying here while Mr. Smith's out of town?"

Matt grinned curiously. "I talked to my big bro just a few hours ago," Matt said. "He didn't mention anything about a trip."

Tommy shrugged and his shoulders rippled beneath his tight T-shirt, that also showed off his bulging biceps to their best effect. "I don't know what to tell you, man."

Tommy had met Mr. Smith's brother, but since Matt only had a few years on him, the teenager didn't look up to Matt as a second "Mr. Smith."

"So, what are you doing here...uh..." Matt slapped at his forehead. "Donnie, isn't it?"

"Tommy, actually."

"Right, right," Matt said. He strode back across the room in his bare feet and stood near the sofa. "Did my brother ask you to water the plants or something?"

Tommy laughed. "No," he answered. "He just asked me to stop by and take a package to the post office for him."

On the floor, leaping up and down at the bottom of Matt's sneaker, Bryan tried desperately to get the attention of one of the towering titans. He found himself awed by his youthful neighbor's now massive form. Tommy wasn't as tall as Matt, but his body looked like an impressive playground.

"I've got to stop thinking like that," Bryan said as he snapped out of his reverie. The giants had moved to the side, preventing the tiny man from seeing them. He continued to hear their loud, disembodied voices.

"I think I saw a package and envelope on the kitchen table," Matt informed the teenager. He led the way into the kitchen and once again took the carton into his hands, but Tommy secured the envelope and removed the cash.

Matt's eyes narrowed as he saw the money. "He left that for you!"

"Yes," Tommy said defensively.

Matt looked at the package and saw it was addressed to his and Byan's nephew.

"So, my bro just took up and left town?"

"As far as I know," Tommy answered.

"Well, I could save you some trouble," Matt said, thinking out loud. "If Bryan's not here, maybe I should just pay a visit to Zack. I could deliver the package."

Tommy folded his fist around the money. "I don't know. I promised Mr. Smith that..."

In the shoe, Bryan yelled for help. "Tommy! Matt!" He looked up as Tommy's gigantic form drifted back into view. "Yes! Down here! Help me!"

"I'm sure my brother wouldn't mind." Matt didn't look ready to hand over the package.

Both giants were now back in view. "Please," Bryan screamed as loudly as he could. "I'm in the shoe!"

"Mr. Smith asked me to mail the package." Tommy's enormous expression showed stubborn determination.

Matt rolled his eyes, but he handed the package to Tommy. "Knock yourself out."

"No!" Bryan continued to rant. "Tommy, don't go! Don't take the box!"

Suddenly, his panicked protest was cut short. Matt's large, tanned arm stretched down as his hand grabbed up his sneakers.

Bryan, caught unready, rolled toward the toe region of the giant shoe.

Matt stood on one leg and slipped the sneaker onto his other foot. He then repeated the process with the other shoe. "So, did my bro leave any word on where he was going?"

"Not to me," Tommy said.

Inside the shoe, Bryan found the spacious environment extremely cramped as his younger brother's row of enormous toes filled up almost every fraction of space directly in front of him.

Then, as Matt began to walk, Bryan was hurled forward to slam against one of the enormous toes.

Matt sighed, now feeling a little bad about giving the kid a hard time. He looked at Tommy and offered a ride to the post office.

Tommy thought of brushing off the offer, but with the price of gas, why should he shell out?

"Ok," he answered. But he also shoved the money from the envelope into the front pocket of his jeans. No way he was parting with the agreed upon payment.
112111222121.title: Tommy and Matt Square Off

choices: Bryan decides to take a bite
Bryan decides to just stay put
1121112221211.content:
When Matt shoved his bare foot into his sneaker, he unknowingly trapped his shrunken sibling in the toe area of the massive shoe.

For teeny Bryan, the dilemma of being trapped in a shoe now looked infinitely worse. He was still trapped in the shoe, but now he was trapped with his younger brother's colossal foot.

As he stepped across the floor toward the front door, his movement resulted in his tiny brother being tossed into the deep crevice between Matt's big toe and its neighbor/

There, the bug-sized scientist managed to stay, even after Matt and Tommy climbed into Matt's automobile for the short drive to the local post office.

But, inside the shoe, conditions became increasingly inhospitable to such a tiny man. The humidity and warmth soon rose to uncomfortable levels. In addition, Bryan feared that any wrong move could result in his getting smeared beneath one of Matt's gigantic toes.

He also realized this could be an unexpected lifeline. Could he possibly take some action to get Matt to notice his presence? Maybe he could scratch the sensitive wall of skin between the two toes. He could even try to bite Matt, but would that even register to someone so monstrously large.
1121112221211.title: Bryan's Ride to the Post Office

choices: Matt took off his shoes
Matt felt an itch in his shoe
11211122212112.content:
Although strongly tempted to attempt a bite at the sensitive area between his younger brother's enormous toes, Bryan's scientific mind reasoned that drastic action might should be avoided.

Sure, it might get him found, but it could just as easily get him crushed should he be mistaken for some irritating insect.

For the time being, he endured the rapidly deteriorating conditions inside his brother's enormous, very smelly shoe.

The humidity and warmth combined at uncomfortable levels to torment the tiny man. He also had to struggle not to roll or stumble beneath the toes or, even worse, beneath the arch or heel of his brother's foot.

A wrong move on his part could get him smeared into an unrecognizable pulp. Fortunately, the trip to the post office proved uneventful, at least for Bryan's teenaged neighbor and his younger brother.

Within 20 minutes, Tommy and Matt arrived back at Bryan's house. Tommy had successfully mailed Bryan's package, absent its intended occupant.

Of course, the package was also on its way to Bryan's nephew, hundreds of miles away, putting the much-needed antidote far from the shrunken scientist's reach.

For the time being, unaware of Bryan's nightmarish dilemma, his brother and his next-door neighbor once again settled at the table in Mr. Smith's kitchen.

Because of Tommy's dedication to doing the job assigned to him, Mr. Smith's future looked increasingly insecure and hazardous, even should he find a way out of Matt's colossal shoe.

Suddenly, that prospect got much less complicated when...
11211122212112.title: Wisdom of staying put

choices: Mr. Smith made a dash for cover
Lifted a sneaker over the unseen shrunken scientist
112111222121121.content:
Mr. Smith's younger brother reached down and pulled off his left sneaker, and tossed it onto the floor near the back door of his brother's house. In a smooth motion, Matt did the same with the right sneaker.

After discarding his footwear, he padded across the floor in his socked feet and collapsed onto the living room sofa.

"What are you doing?" Tommy asked.

"I'm making myself comfortable," Matt answered. "What's it to you?"

Tommy didn't want to admit that he had hoped he could use his neighbor's home for a party with his friends. So, he simply shrugged at Mr. Smith's brother.

"You can run along and play now," Matt said in a disparaging tone.

As the young man and teenager sparred, they didn't notice the tiny pale form on the floor near one of Matt's discarded sneakers.

Tiny Bryan had been unprepared when his gigantic brother suddenly pulled off his shoe and threw it halfway across the kitchen. When the sneaker impacted the floor, the bug-sized man was tossed out of the shoe's interior to land painfully, sprawled awkwardly on the kitchen tiles.

Of course, he realized that his situation was even more desperate now that the package was on its way to its delivery hundreds of miles away at his nephew's dorm, putting the shrunken scientist's much-needed antidote far, far from the tiny man's reach.

As he recovered from his sudden eviction from the shoe, the tiny man gazed up at the behemoths that his brother and teen-aged neighbor had become. Nervously, he realized they represented his final hope at regaining normal size and his former life.

He struggled to get back on his feet as he heard the loud, rumbling words as the titans seemed engaged in a heated discussion.

"I'll go when I am good and ready," Tommy said. "I'm supposed to look after Mr. Smith's home while he is gone."

Matt yawned. "Where has my big brother gone, anyway?"

Neither of the giants noticed the little speck making its way out of the kitchen and into the living room, trying to get closer to them without risking any unfortunate consequences.

"Matt, it's me," he shouted. "Your brother!"

When his gigantic sibling didn't hear, he tried again to reach Tommy. The huge teenager, however, kept pacing around the room, bringing his stomping feet far too close for comfort.

"Tommy! Help me!" Bryan shouted, sprinting forward when Tommy paused for a moment. "It's me! I've shrunk!"

While Tommy remained motionless, the speck of a scientist rushed toward the closest sneaker. He reached the thick, tall rubber sole. He beat on the wall of rubber. It might as well have been a wall of solid rock.

"Please! Please!" The tiny scientist screamed. "You've got to..."

Suddenly, Tommy moved again and...
112111222121121.title: At the feet of gods

choices: Tommy agrees to let Matt take over the house
Tommy challenges Matt's right to stay in the house
1121112221211211.content:
The bug-sized scientist had never expected to encounter such difficulty in simply attempting to communicate with titans.

As he pounded with his tiny fists against the rubber wall of his teenaged neighbor's shoe, the shrunken man tried to keep watch on his enormous sibling.

His brother had taken off his shoes, leaving his colossal feet covered in white socks. Having no luck in making his presence known to Tommy, perhaps he'd have better luck getting noticed if he pounded on his brother's socked feet.

He started to turn and race toward Matt, but Tommy, who had been cooperatively motionless, chose that moment to move. As the teenager's foot shifted, the wall of rubber swept up the tiny man, flinging him halfway across the room to smack painfully against the trim that edged the bottom of the wall.

"So, how long will my brother be gone?" Matt inquired.

"I'm not sure," the teenager answered. "I think about a week."

Matt scratched his chin, pleased to learn that he had the run of his older brother's house for a week. "That sounds great," he said, already thinking about calling up some friends to come over and party.

Neither of the giants saw the pitiful little bug that roused itself to struggle back onto its feet. The simple act of moving his foot slightly had been devastating for the tiny man. It was a miracle things hadn't ended worse for him.

"No!" Mr. Smith protested after hearing of Matt's plans. "You can't just take over my house!"

"I am not sure he would want that," Tommy said.

Matt frowned. "Listen, kid. Play your cards right, maybe you can come over and party, too."

"Don't listen to him, Tommy," Mr. Smith pleaded hopefully.
1121112221211211.title: Matt's plans

choices: A couple of hours later Matt and several friends return
A couple of hours later Tommy and friends arrive first
11211122212112111.content:
Tempted, despite his better judgment, Tommy asked, "Could I bring some friends?"

Matt smiled. "Of course. The more the merrier."

In dismay, the tiny man on the floor listened to a conversation that bode only ill for him and his unusual situation. Having shrunk himself to the size of a bug, the last thing Mr. Smith wanted was a house full of rowdy college students and high school kids.

But, after the earlier painful encounter with Tommy's sneaker, the little man restrained the impulse to run back into the open and demand the two giants notice him. He needed a strategy.

"Look, come back this evening, and bring all the friends you want," Matt said.

"Thanks," Tommy said, excusing himself. After all, Matt was Mr. Smith's brother. How could he get into trouble if Matt decided to throw a party in his big brother's house?

Mr. Smith watched as the enormous teenager made his departure. Perhaps, he decided, Tommy's absence was for the best. He might have better luck trying to confront a single giant.

But he needed a plan. So far, his attempts to communicate with titans hadn't gone well at all.

He was still formulating a plan when Matt took the decision out of his hand by leaving. A party needed snacks and more beer than his brother had on hand in the fridge. He decided to drive to the house of one of his employed buddies, sure they wouldn't mind springing for some of the necessary items.

At the last second, unnoticed by Matt, a tiny figure darted across the floor toward his socked feet. The giant man padded across his brother's living room, grabbed his shoes and put them back on his feet.

As he left the apartment, his shoes slammed down only inches from the little man that had almost ended up only a moment ago plastered beneath one of his socks.

Considering the ordeal his giant sibling was inflicting on him, tiny Mr. Smith wasn't sorry to see him go. But he knew he had only a limited amount of time to come up with a plan for extracting himself from the mess.
11211122212112111.title: Party Planning

choices: Two hours in a shoe
Four hours in a shoe
112111222122.content:
Matt opened his brother's front door.

"Dude!" Matt said. "Come in."

Six-foot-tall Dallas strode through the door, but snapped at his friend. "I expected to hear from you hours ago, man," he said.

Across the room, still trapped in the shoe, Matt's shrunken brother received an unexpected surprise. "That's not Tommy," he realized.

"I've been crashing here, trying to give my big brother a chance to get home," Matt explained as he walked back toward the couch.

Below, inside Matt's discarded sneaker, his bug-sized sibling stared in wonder at the way his younger brother loomed over him.

Then, Dallas stepped into view. The boot-clad real-life cowboy towered over the unseen little man. The shrunken scientist gazed in awe at the muscle-bound man in tight jeans, smudged white T-shirt and a Stetson hat.

"So, you haven't wrangled any emergency funds from your brother?"

"No," Matt said. "He's not even here."

Inside the shoe, Bryan felt a surge of irritation at being proven correct. His younger brother never showed up unless he wanted something.

"Look, it doesn't matter," Dallas said as he adjusted the crotch of his tight jeans. "I'll spring for anything we need."

"That doesn't seem fair..." Matt said.

"It's just a campin' and fishin' weekend," Dallas said in his soft drawl. "Now, get your shoes on and let's hit the road!"

Inside the shoe, the speck of a man panicked. "No!" He cried as he saw Matt's hand reach down for his sneaker.

His only hope was to get back onto the table and get his hands on the vial of antidote.

Shoe held in his hand, Matt sat on the sofa. Inside the sneaker, hurled into the toe region of the enormous shoe, the screams of Matt's tiny sibling went unheard. Matt slipped on the shoe, then reached for its mate.

His brother's toes left barely enough room at the front of the sneaker to keep the bug-sized scientist free of any immediate danger.

By the time Matt followed Dallas outside to his pickup truck, his feet were already starting to heat up inside the well-worn sneakers. As they did, they also sweated.

His naked, quarter-inch-tall brother had no idea that the ordeal was only beginning...
112111222122.title: Dallas

choices: Bait
Beer
1121112221221.content:
In a very short time, the interior of Matt's shoes got much hotter. The immediate result, especially for his entrapped tiny "big' brother was to find himself under assault from the heat, humidity and reeking stench.

"Oh my god!" The little scientist groaned as he felt his own naked body sweat profusely from the heat. "His feet smell worse than anything I've ever experienced."

If the next couple of hours had been intended as an experiment in torture, the tiny man would have spilled every secret he knew to escape the odious conditions inside his younger brother's massive sneaker.

Finally, Dallas and Matt arrived at their destination, a rustic campground next to a waterlily-clogged lake. Surveying the scene beneath the hot summer sun, Dallas let known his confidence in what might be waiting for them.

"There's gotta be some big-ass bass in that lake," he told Matt. "I can't hardly wait to bait a hook and sink a line."

Matt, not as big a fan of fishing, smiled at his buddy's eagerness. "Well, first things first," he said. "I think I'll visit the camp store and buy some beer."

Dallas grinned. "Yea, I reckon we'll need some bait, too. Maybe wigglers and minnows."
1121112221221.title: Two hours in a shoe

choices: Down on the dock, they kick off their shoes
Inside the cabin, the guys kick off their shoes
11211122212211.content:
They entered the rustic camp store together, but Matt headed to the back of the store for refrigerated beer while his buddy asked the burly, bearded proprietor where he could find the bait.

"What kind of bait you wanting, son?"

Dallas grinned and informed him he needed wigglers and maybe a couple of dozen minnows.

"I can do that up for you," the man said.

He got off the stool behind the counter and ambled away. When he returned, he placed a Styrofoam cup on the counter next to a small plastic bag filled with water and tied in a knot. Inside the bag, a school of crowded small fish swam to and fro.

"How much?" Dallas inquired.

The man charged five bucks for the bait, and Dallas was pulling out his rattlesnake-leather wallet to pay when Matt placed a carton of beer on the counter. "Wanna pay for this while you're at it?" Matt asked.

Dallas grinned. "You may owe me a favor later."

"Count on it," Matt responded.

Although the bill had now tripled, Dallas gladly paid for Matt's beers. He liked it when Matt got drunk. It made him ripe for suggestions, which always made their times together more interesting.

The whole time, tiny Mr. Smith continued to sweat and suffer inside his younger brother's smelly shoe. He continued to hope for delivery from the shoe. Little did he know that his ordeal in the shoe would soon end, only to introduce him to an entirely new chain of disturbing events.
11211122212211.title: Bait

choices: Down the pathway
Towards the nearest camp site
11211122212212.content:
Matt waved a passive departure to his buddy and started down the rocky path leading into the camp ground proper.

Lush trees of green leaves and needles crowded on either side of the lane. Matt sniffed the refreshing air heavily, slowing down his pace to enjoy the scenery. It was always great to venture out here for a change of scenery. His feet crunched the gravel and fallen leaves underfoot noisily as he continued, unaware that his brother was enjoying the complete opposite with every step.

Rounding a bend, Matt could see the camp store in the distance. Made of brick, mortar, and heavy logs the store looked picture-perfect in the idyllic camp ground setting. It offered the only bit of civilization offered in the largely untouched woods. Other camp sites surrounded the store, each nicely spaced for privacy and comfort. Tantalizing smells of cooking meat wafted from a nearby site, making Matt's stomach rumble.

Matt tried to ignore a prickling obstruction in his shoe. His brow furrowed with annoyance as the pesky object seemed bent on injuring his sensitive foot.

"Dammit..." He muttered.

Trotting to a rock, he plopped down on it and raised the offending foot for inspection. With a pull, he undid the laces and pulled the sweaty sneaker off.

"A wood chip!" Matt looked at the small chunk of bark that landed in the dirt. He failed to notice the small screaming speck that accompanied its fall.

He quickly re-laced the sneaker and bounded back onto the path, forgetting the pesky wood chip.

-----

Meanwhile, Bryan found himself thrown haphazardly into a new world.

His gigantic brother stomped away, leaving tiny Bryan face down in the soft dirt at the base of the rock. The tiny scientist could only watch as the only trustworthy person only vanished quickly into the distance with huge strides.

Bryan couldn't even muster the energy to cry out or chase Matt. His weak little body throbbed and felt absolutely drained from his traumatizing experience inside Matt's shoe.

He now faced a new, helpless situation. Dropped into a strange world that looked harsh and frightening to such a minuscule being. Nothing about this new place seemed logical to the shrunken man. Why was Matt here? More importantly, where is here?

Bryan gawked at these surroundings with a feeling of abandonment and terror. The tiny man had no idea where his oblivious brother had inadvertently taken him.

He began wandering...
11211122212212.title: Change of scenery

choices: The ground begins to tremble!
The journey continues!
112111222122121.content:
"I have to find Matt!" Bryan resolved as he stumbled past an enormous woodchip.

The surrounding scenery was anything but idyllic for shrunken Bryan Smith. Far before him stretched a mass plain of sandy dirt strewn with leaves and pebbles. Footprints left by gigantic campers made difficult craters in the soft ground, deep enough for tiny Bryan to fall into! Beyond that, monumental trees loomed high into the seemingly limitless sky.

Bryan narrowly avoided sliding into a deep depression. He watched an enormous buzzing bee soar overhead, easily larger than a tank. Many more whisked through the open air above. The tiny man trembled - he hated insects!

"Holy crap, I need to get out of here before some huge bug eats me!"

This thought spurred his actions. He gazed in the direction his gigantic brother took, hoping to see him returning. No such luck.

At Bryan's diminutive size, he was unable to even peer over the large pebbles, bits of bark, and hilly dirt that made up the path. His little heart threatened to sink from desolation, but still he continued.

Tirelessly scuttling over hill and dale, Bryan came upon another terrifying enemy. "Ants!" He squeaked from a crouched position. "Fucking ants!"

The hulking creatures skittered over a shred of leaf larger than all of them. They appeared to be searching the dry ground for food - scraping their powerful antennae over anything within reach. Bryan swallowed hard, hoping not to be suddenly detected by the horrific insects. Luck seemed on his side, causing the ants to continue in a direction away from the tiny man. Bryan gave a hefty sigh. He felt like an invader hiding from native beasts on an unknown planet.

Not wanting to remain any longer, Bryan continued trekking...
112111222122121.title: Down the pathway

choices: Bryan is carried away by the huge bug!
Bryan flings himself off the gigantic bug!
1121112221221212.content:
It seemed like hours had passed. High above, the sun shone from the early-afternoon position and cheerily sent sweltering beams of light to warm to Earth.

"Fuck me! This is hopeless..."

Bryan flung his arms and sighed with dejection. It was clear his progress had been little; he could see recognize the same trees that loomed high enough to be in orbit. Everywhere he looked only managed to make him feel smaller and more helpless. He felt his eyes begin to well up.

"No! I won't allow myself to crack," The tiny man stated, rubbing away his tears angrily. "I'm going to get through this!"

In truth, the diminished scientist barely believed his own words. He was in fact inexperienced with nature (especially when smaller than most bugs!), and lacked any physical prowess. These thoughts made him frightened - yet, one thing was able to keep him going.

His invention of the shrinking formula was nothing short of remarkable. It was believed to be impossible, yet here he was; smaller than the common ant. Bryan had to survive. He could not allow all his work to be wasted!

He kept marching along, constantly repeating these sentiments in his head. Trekking over giant twigs and house-sized leaves, Bryan allowed himself to hum and mumble musical lyrics to keep himself occupied. Every so often pausing to find cover from large buzzing insects and fierce scavenging ants. He gazed up once more, noting the subtle change in branches like an explorer might study the stars.

Bryan had no idea where he was heading - nor did he have any plan set for his arrival. He just knew that when he located his brother, everything would be okay.

"Yep..." He huffed while climbing a large boulder in his path. "I'll get rescued... and, laugh about this a year from now."

His frail arms miraculously proved able enough to pull him onto the bumpy rock. Settling himself down, he let out a deep sigh and prepared to take a well earned rest.

"What the hell?"

The surface of the boulder seemed to shift under him and he swore it made a noise. Before he could react any further, Bryan fell forward as the strange rock began moving violently. Bryan could only muster a terrified shout as two long antennae whipped into view and proceeded to flail randomly.

He clutched the hard surface, realizing this "boulder" was in fact alive!
1121112221221212.title: Trekking

choices: The campsite has guests
A gigantic bird takes interest in the hole
11211122212212121.content:
As if being stranded in the woods - just larger than a grain of salt - wasn't enough, Bryan found himself in now trapped atop a raging insect of monstrous proportions.

He clutched the hard, knobby surface, managing to find a hand hold in the shifting plates of exoskeleton. The bus-sized beetle roared, angered by the tiny creature that clutched it's backside.

Overpowering the ornery insect's actions started a heavy rhythmic pounding that steadily disturbed the ground. The beetle froze and Bryan clutched tightly, unable to tear his gaze from what approached.

"Matt!" He managed to squeak, before the now threatened insect sped off at break-neck speed.

Looming far off, Bryan's younger sibling lumbered closer with every step. His large hand held a red slushie that he periodically sipped, while his other held a bag filled with various goodies. Enjoying his walk, Matt looked anywhere but the ground, too busy admiring the nature around him and utterly unaware of the nature he smashed underfoot.

"Heeeeeeeelp meeee!" Bryan screeched.

His pleas were quickly silenced as the large bug scuttled off the pathway in order to avoid the titan's careless step. Bryan found himself paralyzed from fear, unable to release himself from the monster bug. He could only watch as the beetle carried him away from his gigantic brother. The dizzying speed allowing him one last glance before they vanished through a forest of grass and away from the path.

---

The beetle raced towards home; a sapling pine tree located in one of the nearby campsites. The pesky creature that dared to mount the beastly insect had been all but forgotten as it fled. The titanic human's approach was far more concerning, and required the beetle to flee for fear of detection.

It paused momentarily, glaring at the currently unoccupied site before scuttling up the enormous tree. The beetle easily scaled the craggy tower of bark, deftly avoiding other insects that inhabited the tree and wasting no time vanishing into a particularly large hole to hide from the oblivious giant.

---

"Guuuu-... UACKK!"

Bryan could not described the terror he felt during the journey. All the way, he considered leaping from the rampaging beetle until it began crawling upwards. Barely able to hold on, he used all his stamina to keep from passing out from hysteria.

His strength finally failed him and Bryan tumbled painfully from the giant insect's back and landed upon solid ground. He found himself in a cavernous tunnel - light glaring from one end, and blackness gaping from the other.

Laying alone in the dark, Bryan cried. Fear, trauma, and his once-more lost brother. He looked upwards and shouted weakly.

"Why?!"

Then he settled backwards, detached from his dark surroundings and fell unconscious.
11211122212212121.title: Bryan is carried away by the huge bug!

choices: Bryan is spared
Bryan can't escape
112111222122121212.content:
Jolted from his rest, Bryan immediately was thrown aside.

"What the hell!" He grunted, rubbing his bruised forehead as he looked around.

Light cast in from the gaping entrance, allowing the dimness of the burled tunnel to be slightly illuminated. Another large, bulky shape scurried past Bryan with little regard to his personal space. The tiny man leaned against the wall, watching. He was both angry and indignant, yet filled with healthy fear of these gigantic bugs.

They were beetles - or so he figured. Dozens of legs were barely visible under a canopy of hard, dense plating that made the beasts look like animated rocks instead of common bugs.

"Agh-ouch! What are they doing! Get away...!"

Bryan pressed himself harder after nearly ending up beneath one of the sedan-sized creatures. They appeared to be moving in such frantic order and with speed that seemed beyond their abilities. None of them even gave Bryan the slightest regard; not a glance, nor pause, or even a twitch of the antennae. If anything, they appeared to be fleeing.

Then a loud, gusting swoosh of air intruded upon the space. Bryan snapped his head to look at the entrance and belted out screaming.

Nearest him, a particularly plump beetle had been trundling past. Bryan gasped when the frightened beast was simply plucked between two massive shapes of hardened skin and pulled from his view out of the tunnel. "Holy fuck!" The tiny man gaped at the tunnel, able to see a terrific shape blocking the rays of light. Without warning, the huge beak intruded once more. It crashed into the rough bark with a dull thud before wrenching itself free and descending upon another beetle.

The light framing whatever it was outside was suddenly blocked, giving Bryan a dim, but definitive view of the monstrous assailant's features.

"Jesus Christ... a..a...a bird! It's a freaking bird!" His shrill observations seemed to echo off the hard wood around him. In the darkness, the bird peered inside with huge gibbous eyes that were devoid of anything but instinct.

Retracting out of sight, the creature returned suddenly, jamming an enormous beak into the tunnel. It nearly maimed the tiny scientist, instead focusing on another insect that attempted sanctuary in the cramped darkness. A small, shrill screech was audible before the massive appendage pulled the helpless bug in and closed around it.

Bryan slunk down, screaming in complete terror. He now found himself alone in the badly lit tunnel - all the beetles either escaped or devoured; leaving him to the same fate.
112111222122121212.title: Bird Food

choices: In an empty campsite
Near the camping supply shop
1121112221221212121.content:
The tunnel was empty; all except for one tiny pink ball, barely the size of a rice grain. Afraid, alone, and unable to defend himself, the shrunken man remained coiled in preparation for his fate at the beak of an enormous bird.

Feeling a slight disturbance, Bryan dared a peek from his bundle of limbs. He immediately shrieked. A bulging black orb throbbed at his sudden movement, blinked, and then quickly rotated to allow entrance for a beak big enough to park his car and then some. Looking like the jaws of Hell, Bryan vainly scuttled backwards, trying to escape but ultimately failing.

"No!" The huge appendage clamped around his leg, and to his horror, began effortlessly pulling his tiny form back.

Bryan struggled, beating his fists against the hard yellow surface. It felt as if it were made of some impossibly strong fiberglass. The beak held his thin leg tightly, pulling him roughly against the gnarled wood and out into the open air.

The tiny man dangled, his held leg straining from both the pressure of his body and the cruel strength of the gigantic bird. "I don't want to dieee! God! Anyone, please help me!" Bryan wailed.

He could now make out the entire bird, in all its godzilla-sized glory as it perched against the towering tree. If anything, the terrifying creature was nothing but a mere songbird - rather small, and completely unnoteworthy as far as birds go. It twitched around, attempting to deduce how to effectively swallow the tiny man without losing him. Most prey was swallowed in one bite, but this one proved troublesome as it flailed around.

The bird hopped from the tree and glided towards the ground, but failed to realize just how awkward the hold it had upon the tiny man was.

"Aiiiiieeeee!" Bryan screamed as his leg simply slid loose of the gigantic beak.

Immediately, his minute body was swept up in raging winds caused by the birds flight. He sailed through the air, like a bit of pollen, and after moments of twisting and turning, smacked into the ground.

Despite such a tumultuous fall, Bryan rose up quickly. He searched the skies, frightened at the slightest hint of the dragon-sized bird. Suddenly, an angry chirp roared over the landscape, and Bryan about-faced to see the bird hopping two and fro in search of him. The tiny man fled to a haven of leaves and twigs, hiding himself under their canopy. He watched the monster bird as it pounded around the terrain of forest debris, scouring with globular eyes that seemed inflated with fury.

Only seconds later, the frightening beak opened with another chirp, and the bird snatched up a fleeing ant. Bryan felt himself deflate - all fear, worry, and his impending doom escaping as he watched the satisfied bird lift off with the unlucky bug.

"Bloody hell, thank God!" He said. The ominous shape of the bird vanished quickly into the endless world of branches high above.

Bryan allowed himself a respite beneath his cover, but knew he was still in danger. His locale was changed thanks to the blundering beetle, and Bryan knew his chances of finding his brother lessened with every moment wasted. It was vital he found rescue before nightfall - the mere idea of wandering this landscape in the dark, rife with prehistoric-sized creatures, was nothing but blood-curdling.

Standing up, he padded forward and gazed around. He was...
1121112221221212121.title: Dropped

choices: He reaches it
Another bird spots his tiny form
11211122212212121212.content:
Body still trembling, Bryan couldn't begin to handle his current situation. Here he was: alone, desolate, and more importantly lost in the majesty of nature. This alone would normally be trouble enough to cause any person significant alarm, but tack on the fact Bryan was smaller than a mere ant? He felt near hysterics.

"I can't believe a damn songbird almost ate me!" He cried to the large twigs and leaves around him. "God almighty, what the fuck did I do to deserve this?"

He hated nature more than ever. It was cruel, dirty, and unfair. A nagging anger lurked inside him for his blundering younger brother. If Matt didn't have to be such a jerk and pop over to Bryan's house uninvited, then all this might have never happened. Bryan would be safely stowed, shipped off to surprise his nephew with such an impossible trick. It had been a sure-fire plan until Matt fucked it up. His grumbles trailed to silence before finishing with a sigh. Matt may have caused this, but he remained Bryan's only possible link in this ungodly maddness. Wherever his brother had gone, Bryan had to find him. Before nightfall, he realized with a swallow. The sort of beastly critters and bugs that lurked these woods then he hoped never to meet.

Finished with his interior elucidation, the shrunken scientist stood, dusted himself off, and proceeded from his cover of over-sized twigs and dried leaves. The view was anything but beautiful. At such a small angle, the forest looked a monstrous wasteland. Huge leaves lay almost everywhere. Some broken like the facades of a building, while others gracefully shaded large patches of land. Breaking up the monotony lay twigs ranging from sapling size to larger than the tallest redwood. Dusty boulders interjected between both of these, making the terrain rough and treacherous.

Bryan saw something else that sparked a flame of hope in his eyes. Far off, almost indescribably so, stood a structure made of concrete and wood, Rustic in appearance by all means, featuring a sign that read, Oakdale Supply Shop.

Scampering forward, Bryan quickly scaled a rock to get a better view of the distant building. He blinked at the window containing more signs advertising bait, sport gear, and camping equipment. "Oakdale? Oakdale Campground?" Bryan could hardly believe it. Yet there it was, the proof that he had in fact been brought to the very place he refused to go as a kid with his brother and father. "Dammitt, Matt! Only you would walk into my house, fuck up my life, and then strand me here to top it off!"

It seemed deliberate. Bryan knew better of course, but he couldn't help feeling angry. Still, it wouldn't do him any good to keep cursing his luck. He needed to find help and the supply store was a monument of possibilities right now!

The journey to reach it was daunting. Leaves and twigs seemed to lessen as he approached until it was just a nearly clean expanse of dusty brown dirt. Dunes and rolling hills shaped the dry land, caused by giant campers and their monster vehicles. He breathlessly traversed one, realizing that it was just one impression of many left by an unimaginably huge tire.

Passing the smashed remains of a cigarette larger than his house, Bryan checked his progress...
11211122212212121212.title: Oakdale Campground

choices: Curiosities? No way! Head towards the store and get rescued!
Alright! Head towards the mulchy mountain range of dirt.
Smoke break!
112111222122121212121.content:
The ground was soft, unforgivingly soft that each tiny step felt sluggish and all the more exhausting. More than a few times, Bryan paused in order to thrust his head back and gasp. This, or any type of outdoorsy shit, was NOT something Bryan had any skill or taste for.

Yet what else could he do? The intertwining threads of fate had seen fit to remove Bryan from his constructed plan and relocate him to the middle of nowhere. Tommy and his dumbass younger brother their tools. This was all their fault.

Another hill rose before him. He crested it, only to see more seemingly endless dirt-dunes, and looking back to see his trail of pinprick footsteps marking his journey. Nobody would see them, he thought with a frown. Too small. Too damn small. Why did he make himself this fucking small? The regret floated for a moment before Bryan relented, knowing full well why he chose such a diminutive stature when concocting his miraculous formula. Deep down, Bryan liked this size -- he even loved it. Well, in a sort-of superficial way one might love their most terrifying fantasy. Now it just seemed insane. A bulky black ant scurried over a neighboring dune, quickly pacing up the next before vanishing from sight. Not even vehicle-sized ants bothered him at this point. They only annoyed him. Their many legs, seemingly limitless stamina and strength. Nature had a way of adapting, and the genius man was anything but adaptable. But nature be fucked. If he could shrink himself, then sure as shit he could do something about his physical prowess.

Distant, but startling noise brought Bryan's attention to his distant destination. From a massive doorway emerged a huge man carrying a bag in one hand and a plastic scoop in the other. Bryan felt his skin prickle, both excitement and anxiety at the sight of even such a distant, but gargantuan human being. Watching his vast legs move with slow, exaggerated animation.

"Not much longer before I get some damn attention! This guy looks good as any!"

Both statements seemed stale as the silty landscape ate his squeaky words up. He did feel pretty confident about getting the attention he deserved -- and then showing his irresponsible prick of a brother a thing or two. That should be easy enough. "This guy" was some stranger, though. His huge features mostly indiscernible at this distance. With slow, lumbering steps the giant man walked from the building, paused to spit out something on the ground, and continued towards a mulchy pile of dark dirt set against a nearby tree. Bryan stumbled down another dune, wanting to get closer and see. He quickly moved up the next one. The giant was now crouched, scooping dirt into shallow containers one-by-one.

"What is he doing?" Came the unheard question out of the tiny man's lips.

The giant was both too far and oblivious to hear, and instead merely finished one last scoop before depositing the container back into his bag. Then he rose back up, slowly like some mammoth force out of a space movie, and began stomping back to the supply shop.

Bryan watched, annoyed that the titan had not remained to wait for him. That left the tiny scientist back to his journey -- back to his arduous, endless walking. He kept on, padding up, down, and over dune after dune. Just an hour or so later, he had a legitimate close call when a dark shadow swept over the land. It was easily mistaken for a dragon, which sent Bryan into comical defensive measures that belonged to the brainless peasants of a sword-and-magic story. He glanced up, realizing it was another bird, yet then doubled himself down with a yelp. Not again. Not another fucking bird. One close call was more than enough and made any dragon out of fairytale sound fun.

It flew away, pecking up some unlucky insects, utterly unaware of the exotic meal of tiny human close-by. Returning to the vast heavens above. Bryan sighed and resumed his trek with an eye constantly turned to the distant heavens.

The log and stone building slowly but completely became the horizon. It loomed like a mountain at first, high enough to block out light and sky as the minuscule man traveled closer and closer. The terrain changed as well. Instead of rolling dunes, it flattened out somewhat roughly, populated loosely with boulders and plant life. Huge flattened cigarettes and normally tiny debris stood out, looking more post-apocalyptic than anything. Bryan also confirmed what he had thought before, that he had somehow ventured to the backside of the building and not the front. Huge garbage cans towered near an even taller door that was kept slightly ajar by a boulder. Opposing that vista was the rugged mountain of soil that he saw earlier, now appearing more like looming tundra and hills. It was odd, Bryan wondered, and the fact the gigantic man had been scooping from it was even more curious.

Time wasn’t quite on his side, but surely an excursion wouldn’t hurt after all that walking? He was tiny for a reason afterall: to satisfy curiosities (among other things). What should he do?
112111222122121212121.title: The back door

choices: The huge man looks down, but sees only a breached bait container and bugs
The huge man never looks down, and instead moves forward
1121112221221212121211.content:
Did anything else really matter right now? Bryan wiped his forehead, knowing full well that any other excursion would like waste precious time and his (very) limited stamina.

Plus, he sniffed suspiciously, the air wafting from that direction wasn’t exactly tantalizing. It smelled like compost or at least something earthy and gross like that. He decided to progress his journey and head for rescue.

Rescue from that place. All he could do was gaze up at the towering portal that denoted what was only a backdoor into the building. It barely looked like a door. Bryan couldn’t quite justify applying that banal word to such an entrance. It was propped open via a boulder that looked like an entire peak torn from the Rockies. High up in stark proclamation was a sign that read “EMPLOYEES ONLY”. Those words might have deterred the tiny man before, but it seemed anything his size or comparable was exempt of this rule, as proved by noticeable buzzing specks that entered and exited at their leisure. He gulped, but kept up his minuscule approach.

Standing before a steep mound of dirt crusted metal, which was merely part of the weather strip making up the threshold, Bryan clamored over and entered a new world. The outside had made Bryan feel small. That creepy vertigo experience that happened when viewing the Grand Canyon or the enormity of any natural wonder. Now he saw such vast monuments of far greater scale than those and all created by things Bryan would normally be familiar with. Counters and shelves looming up and up, and still higher up. A cement floor that spanned out for daunting miles, coated with dirt and grime like any regular landscape might. And to make this all somewhat comical, it had the definite look of any dated interior of a backwoods truck stop.

“Here begins the next part of my "fantastic" journey...I should be keeping notes!” he said, scoffing.

Loud continuous noise throbbed through the air, detectable as it even pulsed through the ground itself. The more Bryan heard, he recognized it as mere background music, rock or something similar, now exaggerated to a degree only mother nature enjoyed during a thunderstorm. He could also hear what resembled voices. Deep and powerful, and far off. Deciding to find their source, Bryan headed towards the nearest counter.

Lining each towering shelf were shallow styrofoam containers, looking at this point like mammoth industrial canisters. By all means, not the least bit impressive but for their enormity. Each one had billboard-sized strips of tape plastered on the sides with rough marker-written names denoting their contents that made Bryan uneasy.

“EARTH WORMS”

“MEALIES”

“BUGS”

There were over a dozen of them filling the shelf, all placed together with their respective labels. If he tried, the lowest shelf was even accessible to something as tiny as Bryan. He could reach them. Tiny as he was, Bryan tried to fathom the monster-sized earthworms, meal worms, and whatever bugs contained within each huge styrofoam prison. Each one could hold enough to populate a continent. All together, it seemed as if there would be enough to populate a planet. One of the containers mark “Bugs” had been breached, dirt streaming out with stray ants or beetles escaping like animals from a twisted zoo. It occurred to him that most of these tinier bugs might be innocent collateral -- scooped up with larger victims fated for a cruel end on a barbed hook.

Faint noises could be heard from the “mealies” containers. “I hate worms. Huh...better you guys stay in there than out here!,” he said, feeling tinier than ever. Those “bait” worms were undoubtedly humongous.

He also enjoyed the benefit of an answer to his earlier curiosity. The giant he had seen earlier and what he had been doing and the purpose of that strange earthy mound. It was definitely a compost pile and the guy had been filling these containers with worms and other creepy crawlies for sale.

“Lucky I didn’t venture there! Gross worms and bugs...and what if he had come back to get more?” Bryan said, faltering at the last part as he nervously considered the fate of these imprisoned creatures.

Not that this environment seemed any better to the tiny man. He had made zero progress since he had been here and the place frankly disgusted him. The floor looked like the aftermath of a tornado, bits of debris strewn around and fallen rubbish that went unnoticed to whomever cleaned this place. Adding to the atmosphere was stale, humid air that reeked of cigarettes and fish musk.

“Oh...oh my god…” He said, recoiling in disgust.

His foot pulled back, dislodging from what at first glance seemed like further smashed grime but was clearly the smashed, congealed remains of an insect. It smelled too. Bryan seemed to recall reading at some point that insects gave off some sort of scent or something. This one was barely recognizable in such a state of obliteration. Whatever it had been, it was far larger than the shrunken scientist and had been literally flattened as if it were nothing. He looked at other stains, both dark and light, dotting the cement terrain with apprehensive eyes. What had they once been? Alive? Genius or not, it surely did bode well for Bryan.

Just then, what had been minor disruptions became louder and clearer, rumbling from somewhere high above.

“...ALRIGHT...WHAT BRAND YOU LOOKIN’ FOR? CAMEL...SPIRIT…?”

Bryan understood them, yet they seemed nonsensical and distorted. Not meant for his microscopic ears. The ground quaked, shuddering slightly as an enormous figure loomed around the counter. For but a moment, Bryan tried to comprehend what he saw, but instead gawked dumbly. Towering legs seemed to be all this behemoth was from his teeny vantage point. The huge pants capped enormous black sneakers. On suddenly shifted, lifting and...

BOOOM.

The tiny speck of a scientist was sent reeling, scampering in the tumultuous wake as one colossal black sneaker slammed down nearby. Dust and dirt sprinkled around, upset by the crash landing. Another slightly duller impact was felt as the second landed. Any flooring once before Bryan had been cut off beneath an immense wall of dark, coal-gray rubber sole and high up sheer mountainside of black suede. He could hear it shifting, adjusting, groaning under what must be immeasurable weight before it lifted, loudly peeling off the floor and rising into the air. The underside became visible: tan colored lugs with what looked to be large letters spelling out some brand stretching across. Chunks of large debris crumbled free, falling in the wake as the enormity soared off, thundering over huge amounts of land in search of another crash site. Where what previously was dirty, but otherwise barren floor was now lined with dusty dirt, dried flora, and other shit dislodged and left behind. Something twisted and dark moved, bits of what looked to be legs and carapace protruding from a mangled mess of dirt and guts. Bryan gaped, feeling sick. A dull rumble took his attention and in the distance was the other black mountain, shifting before it pulled off the floor, following suit.

Bryan watched them, daring his vision upwards in order to better identify the force of nature he nearly ended up beneath. It wasn't human. All he could comprehend were gargantuan, towering columns that stretched higher than Bryan could properly conceive into the sky. Two huge monoliths of rugged brown material, cargo pockets big enough to contain entire cities stitched on the sides, ending with those enormous bulky sneakers. He could stand to discern more, but he already knew -- it had to be that guy he saw earlier, the same dude stomping around outside to scoop up more bait. Same guy who’s bad handwriting was sharpied on those tape labels. The same guy who’s dirty footwear tracked in all this dirt, crushed plant matter, and pulverized arthropodal fauna that was invisible to him but littered the landscape. Back then, the giant seemed identifiable, but now....fucking now....Bryan had no idea anything, much less a fellow human, could be this fucking big. Fucking huge.

He was supposed to get his titan’s attention and expect rescue?

Bryan heard more thunder from above, more speech. He shambled back, straining his eyes to perceive the distant face: grinning at someone Bryan couldn’t see, a swarthy face, the kind that belongs to somebody who enjoys the outdoors, would want to live and run a camp supply store. The kind of guy who would help you change a tire with a smile, but sooner swat down a gnat or fly without a second thought.

The stark, literally cold reality began setting in. How the hell was Bryan going to get any meaningful attention from some-...-thing...this gargantuan?

“I’ve gotta try for chrissakes. It-....uh….He is my only option!”

He didn’t pause to think when the huge camp supply owner finished the transaction, looming high above a world unnoticed by him. Acutely aware of his own utter insignificance, Bryan broke through his intense flight instinct and ran out, waving his arm and bounding ostentatiously. Anything to be more visible against the enormous dusty floor. Screaming all the while with enough force and emotion to make any ant-sized opera company proud.

“Heeeeeree! Dooooooowwwwnnnnnn…-gasp-...heeeeeeeerreeee! Heeeelppp meee!”

Hope filled Bryan as he sprinted, waving and screaming. This was it! Or was it?
1121112221221212121211.title: Bigger up close
