“Y’know dude,” he started, his face twisted into mock disappointment, “I left my wallet at home!”

“Motherfucker!” Troy laughed, standing up to slug Sean in the shoulder.

---

Troy polished off another burger, accompanied with good portions of chips and beer. After a good time around the campfire, he fell asleep in the tent with a comfortably full stomach, deaf to the gentle gurgles as his stomach worked to digest his meal.

The next morning, Troy was left with an empty stomach as the remains of his previous meal, a few unfortunate ants, and one tiny man were working their way through his intestines. Following a hearty breakfast of scrambled eggs, fried potatoes and bacon courtesy of Kyle yet again, Troy and his friends set out to hike up the peak that towered over their campsite.

Several hours later, the three young men stood on a ridge, taking in the majestic wildlife scenery spread before them.

“I feel like a giant!” Sean laughed.

Feeling a pressure in his bowels, Troy faced Sean, “Well this giant needs to take a dump!” he replied bluntly.

“Lovely!” Sean said sarcastically.

“Dude, you’ll turn this place into a fuckin’ toxic waste zone!” Kyle joked.

Troy chuckled, flipping them off as he pushed into the thick underbrush behind them for some privacy. He found a small open space beneath a towering pine and figured it was as good a place as any. Unnoticed at his feet, a number of different insects fled from the sudden appearance of the behemoth. Quickly undoing his belt and dropping his pants, Troy squatted on the ground and let out a grunt as he started to push. He inhaled sharply as pain jolted through his anus.

“Better out than in,” he muttered to himself through gritted teeth as he pushed harder. Finally the turd plopped onto the ground, eliciting a sigh of relief from Troy. Pulling a roll of toilet paper from his backpack, Troy wiped his butt as he looked down at his poop. He leaned in, hoping to learn the cause of his pain, when the smell of his shit assaulted his nose. Grimacing, Troy stood up straight and chalked it up to the ants’ last revenge for being eaten. He failed to notice the minuscule human skeleton embedded into the waste that had scraped him on its way out of his body.

Unaffected by the ants’ grisly fate within his gut, Troy carelessly dropped the waded toilet paper onto the turd and pushed through the bushes to rejoin his friends and continue their hike. Left uncovered by the discarded tissue, Bryan’s skull was left with a permanent grin, staring blankly up at the clear, blue, sky.
112111222122122222121121.title: Down and Out

choices: Nice
Nasty
112111222122122222122.content:
Could it be? The tiny scientist thought. It was too good to be true.

"Guys, this...this is a tiny person," the giant called Sean said. Bryan heard derisive laughter, but he didn't care; joyfully, he redoubled his efforts to get Sean's attention. Sean broke into a disbelieving smile. "Honestly. Come here. Look. He's absolutely freaking minute."

His two friends got up and came over, clearly curious and believing Sean had seen something, even if it wasn't a tiny little scientist.

Bryan cringed as a huge fingertip tapped the bun very close to him, and Bryan realised this was Sean pointing him out to his friends. He heard two "...wow"s, and it was clear they agreed.
"Well what is up with you, little man..." said Sean in a low, curious voice. Very carefully, Sean carried the burger bun over to the bench and sat down. His friends followed. Bryan had to cling to the bun to make sure he didn't fall, and it was very disconcerting to have 6 gigantic eyes all staring at him.

Sean set the bun down on the table, but the tiny scientist stayed on it, having a feeling you were more visible there. He began yelling about what happened, but obviously it was no use. In his panic, Bryan hadn't really realised that all the old rules still applied.

"He's trying to say something," Kyle said, and he couldn't keep his amazement out of his voice.
"Yeah, no shit," said Sean, but he was clearly also amazed. "Climb on, little guy." And with that, Sean reached out with a finger and without hesitation you clambered onto it. It was either trust Sean or die at this point.

You held on tight as the finger was lifted up, up, up, all the way to the gian'ts ear, and before you could even think about it you were being brushed off inside it, in the cave. You clambered behind the flap, behind the bones, and Sean laughed out loud before you stopped moving, then said, "OK...what's going on?"

So you told him the story so far.

How did him and his friends react?
112111222122122222122.title: "Guys, this ain't no bug..."

choices: Matt walks for help
Matt stays with the truck
1121112221222.content:
Still more than 100 miles from their destination, their vehicle broke down in the middle of nowhere.

Dallas looked under the hood, but cursed in irritation. "I can't tell what the hell's wrong with it."

Matt stood by the side of the road unable to offer any suggestions. "How far back is it to civilization?"

Dallas scowled. "I saw a gas station at that exit we passed."

"That must have been four or five miles back!"

"Yeah," Dallas said. "So, you want to walk there or stick with the truck?"

Inside the shoe, sweltering in the heat and coated with his brother's stinking foot sweat, the tiny scientist had no idea that his ordeal was about to get a lot worse and last a lot longer.

He was already at a breaking point, and several times wished that Matt would just end the torture with a quick stomp.

Unfortunately, that would have been too easy a way out.
1121112221222.title: Four hours in a shoe

choices: Matt inspects the box
Matt shrugs it off
112112.content:
"Bro!" Matt called out. "Are you home?"

Shutting the door behind him, the gentle breeze that had been fluttering through his hair abruptly stops. Without an immediate response Matt took another step forward, his shoe squeaking on the tile.

"Hellllloooooo!!" he called out. "Bryyyyyyaaaaan!" Still without a response Matt walks through the kitchen to search the house. Every footstep Matt makes echoes around the room, but Matt fails to notice the noise.

---

Bryan lands roughly on the table with a grunt and rolls to a stop. His massive brother roars overhead, his words lost to tiny Bryan who is more focused on the pain radiating all over his body. He glares in the direction of his towering sibling who is staring at the archway leading into the living room as though he expects something. He then moves forward, which oddly shocks Bryan. He hears, as well as feels, a quake-like thud which could only be Matt's footstep. Bryan struggles to comprehend Matt's odd combination of speed and size. Before Bryan knows it Matt thuds out of the room, disappearing pass the archway.

His first experience with a regular human fades quickly into anger. "Damn it Matt, I said I was going on a fucking trip! I fucking said next week! What the hell are you doing here!" Bryan directs his temper at his younger sibling. Matt had disregarded his request and as a result (unintentionally) caused him all this pain. "Why don't you ever listen?" Bryan wonders out loud.

He forces himself to stand up, groaning from the quickly forming bruises. Thankfully those seem to be the worst of his injuries. Bryan spends a minute wondering what to do about his brother before deciding there's not much he can do, and to just move forward. With an exasperated sigh Bryan looks across the table where the box sits at the far end. He begins walking toward it to begin his journey.

---

Matt checks each room, continuing to call out his brother's name. After a few minutes of searching he confirms that the house is empty. Disappointed he couldn't find Bryan, Matt drops onto the overstuffed couch in the living room.

He was a little short on cash at the moment... not that it was his only reason for visiting. He missed his older brother, but was generally too busy to visit... until now. A grumble from his stomach tells Matt it's time for lunch. He runs a few fast food restaurants through his mind before remembering where he's at.

Standing up, Matt turns towards the kitchen. Surely Bryan would rather Matt eat his food than see it go rotten while he was gone! Matt enters the doorway but stops when he stares at the table. A box sits at the end of the table. More importantly there is a $100 bill next to it.

"Sweet!" Matt cheers. "Bryan you never let me down. I owe ya big bro!" he says snatching up the money and stuffing it into his pocket. Matt then turns his attention to the small box.

---

Bryan crosses the table ignoring the sounds of his massive brother wandering his home. Halfway to the box, the sounds stop and less than a minute later a loud plop sounds from the living room. "How long will the freeloader stick around?" Bryan mutters unhappily.He stops when he sees his miniature clothing just ahead. The gust from outside had sent it flying as well! Bryan decides if he's getting ready to go getting dressed was part of it.

As he pulls his shirt over his head he hears pounding footsteps behind him. He turns around to see his towering brother who seems to be staring at him with an excited look. "Matt..." Bryan says cautiously.

"SWEET!" he roars "BRYAN YOU NEVER LET ME DOWN! I OWE YA BIG BRO!" as he speaks he approaches the table. His tall form, which even at normal size dwarfed Bryan, soon is above the box. Matt's large hand reaches down and clutches a banner like $100 dollar bill.

"NO!" Bryan bellows. "THAT'S NOT FOR YOU, DUMBASS!" Bryan bolts forward waving his arms up at his titanic brother. However Matt clearly doesn't hear him as he stuffs the money into his pocket. As he runs, he see's Matt's eyes flick onto the box. A look of curiosity flashes across the mega sized face.

“Oh God, please help me,” Bryan screamed as he ran for his life. “Just gotta get away!”

Bryan could barely keep his balance as the earth around him shook violently with a POUND! POUND! POUND! Bryan kept running as fast as he could as he nervously glanced back. Closing in on him were a pair of mammoth Airwalks twice the size of a football field. The monstrosities covered an enormous distance with each ominous stomp.

Within a matter of seconds, the gargantuan treads of an unknown giant’s shoes were right on top of him, ready to flatten him with one gigantic stomp. Bryan crouched down with his arms over his head and screamed.

- - -

Bryan awoke suddenly in a mild sweat around noon, and groggily glanced at the clock.

“What a dream,” Bryan thought as he checked the time. “Oh Shit! I overslept.”

Bryan rushed around in a frenzy getting ready for his little trip. Tommy would arrive in just three hours, but Bryan wanted to have everything ready well in advance. He grabbed a bite to eat and took a quick shower.

Bryan carefully prepared a single batch of shrinking formula. He went to the kitchen to give everything one last check. He took a yellow sticky pad and wrote a note for Tommy:

TOMMY,
THANKS FOR MAILING THE PACKAGE. BE SURE AND LOCK UP WHEN YOU LEAVE. I’LL PROBABLY BE BACK IN A WEEK OR SO. IF YOU COULD PICK UP THE NEWSPAPER FOR ME, AND KEEP AN EYE ON THINGS AROUND HERE, I’D APPRECIATE IT.
BRYAN SMITH

Bryan stuck the note next to the transport box. He then went to his bedroom and got undressed. He downed the shrinking formula and rushed to the kitchen and sat on the table. Within two minutes the brilliant research scientist had shrunk to a mere quarter of an inch. He took in his surroundings with as much awe as his first shrinking experience. He walked over and got dressed in the clothes he had left there the night before.

It was 2 p.m. Tommy would arrive in one hour. Bryan looked over nearly mesmerized at the hundred dollar bill he left for Tommy. The bill and the salt shaker that secured it were titanic. Bryan figured he had time to explore these curiosities before he needed to secure himself in the box. He began the short jog to the middle of the kitchen table.

Bryan wanted desperately to end this misguided adventure, but now it was impossible. After Tommy’s unanticipated extra taping, the small transport box had now become his prison, and with the shrinking antidote sitting on his kitchen table back home, all circumstances were now beyond his control.

"I've just got to make sure he sees me," Bryan said, thinking ahead to his titanic nephew opening the box. "And recognizes me." He contemplated the latter thought with an unshakable sense of foreboding.

The sale sign on the marquee grabbed Tommy's attention as he pedaled his bike past his favorite skateboard shop.

He stopped his bike in front of the shop. How could he afford not to check out the shop with a promise of a 30 percent discount?

He shoved a hand into the pocket of his baggy pants. He drew out the package and then kept searching until he pulled out the hundred dollar bill left by Dr. Smith for the purpose of mailing the package.

"As long as I keep enough to still mail his package..." Tommy said aloud. He chained his bike outside the store, and then entered, the package still in his hand.

The young guy behind the counter in the store waved at Tommy as he entered the store.

"Yo, Shawn. I saw your sign," Tommy said.

"Yeah, we've got some sweet deals," Shawn replied.

Shawn, a fellow skateboard enthusiast, wore baggy jeans, an oversized sweatshirt and kept his unruly blond hair covered by a woven cloth hat.

Shawn lowered his voice. "Listen, dawg. Let me show you some stuff in the back room."

Tommy's eyes widened. "Good deal!"

As he moved behind the counter, Tommy placed the package on the surface of the counter before he followed Shawn into a small storage room.

••••••

Bryan celebrated a brief reprieve from the constant motion ever since Tommy had left the scientist's home to mail the package and its tiny, unknown occupant.

Had Tommy dropped the package in the mail?

Bryan felt better knowing that he might soon arrive in the hands of his nephew.

He crept closer to the single remaining air hole left uncovered by Tommy's obsessive bout with the tape.

As he peered out, he saw an enormous door. He continued to look until he saw Tommy and another giant emerge. Bryan enjoyed this look at another giant. The guy, who looked a little older than Tommy, looked enormous and, beyond that, good looking.

Bryan soon realized that Tommy still hadn't reached the post office.

The tiny, unseen voyeur continued to spy.

Shawn directed Tommy to another part of the store, and the giants moved out of range. Bryan continued, however, to detect their loud but muffled voices as they penetrated the cardboard walls of the box.

Bryan paced in the spacious confines of the shipping box. "What the hell's the delay now?" Bryan wondered aloud.

"I'll be back after I drop off this package at the post office," Tommy said. "I should have plenty of cash."

"You're out of luck," Shawn said.

"What do you mean? Is the sale ending?" Tommy asked with a disappointed voice.

"No, man, but the post office closes at 4," Shawn answered.

Tommy glanced at a clock on the wall. "Shit, man! I was supposed to mail this package overnight."

"Mail it in the morning," Shawn said.

"I can't! I've got class." Tommy complained.

Inside the box, Bryan listened in dismay. "No!" The tiny scientist cried in outrage. "Stupid kid! I should never have trusted..."

“Don’t sweat it buddy,” Shawn said to Tommy. “I’ll mail that little box for ya on the way to the shop tomorrow.”

“I was really supposed to do it myself,” Tommy responded a little sheepishly. “But I don’t guess there’d be anything wrong with it.”

“Kewl beanz,” Shawn replied as he slid the box across the counter until it rested next to a rotating rack of mirrored sunglasses. “Now let’s pick you out a board. These over here are really fine.”

* * *

Bryan fell backwards as the box was repositioned on the counter. “What the fuck is going on?” He hurried back to the peephole and anxiously peered out. The box’s new position had given Bryan a nearly complete view of the merchandise area of the store.

A kaleidoscope of colors from the giant skateboards reflected off the mirrored sunglasses and beamed through the peephole. Multiple shelves extending to the ceiling were packed with skate shoes, ball caps, and an array of skateboard paraphernalia.

Bryan watched angrily as Shawn and Tommy perused the vast assortment of skateboards. “I’ve got to get to the post office!” Bryan began beating on the box with both fists. He couldn’t believe he had been so careless to leave his entire fate in the hands of a teenager.

* * *

“This one is awesome,” Tommy beamed as he took a gold and black skateboard from the shelf to examine. “It’s way rad!”

“It’s about ninety dollars after the discount,” Shawn informed Tommy. “It’s a great deal.”

“I’ll take it,” Tommy replied excitedly as the two guys walked over to the cash register. Tommy guiltily glanced over at the small box Mr. Smith had entrusted to him. “Shawn, you gotta promise me you’ll mail that package tomorrow.”

“Dude. I promise,” Shawn tried to ease Tommy’s worries. “That will be ninety six fifty seven.”

“What? I thought you said it was only ninety dollars,” Tommy responded anxiously. “That only leaves about three bucks to mail the package.”

“Sales tax, dude,” the lanky, young skateboard shop worker explained. “But I think three dollars should be enough to mail that little box.”

“Well, okay,” Tommy agreed, failing to inform Shawn the package needed to be sent overnight mail. “Man, this really is a cool board!”

“Just leave everything to me,” Shawn said as he gave Tommy a quick high five. “Now, go enjoy that new board.”

* * *

“Nooh Tommy. Please come back,” Bryan screamed as he watched Tommy exit the skateboard shop. “This can’t be happening to me!”

Suddenly, Bryan froze in a fascinated horror as three enormous teenagers stormed into the store.

“Yo Shawn. What up?” one of the teens greeted Shawn as he walked up to the counter. The other two scattered about the store. “What kinda deals ya got today bro?”

Exposed from his meager shelter, Bryan reeled as the ground rattled following every step by this new titan. Not a moment was wasted by the tiny scientist. Bryan sped into action, waving and skipping to attract attention.

Soaring faster than anticipated, the strange giant planted a gargantuan shoe next to the tiny man. The impact jolted the gritty earth violently, elliciting a shriek from the minuscule man who nearly went face first to the ground. Bryan instead fell to his knees, allowing them to scrape painfully against the ground instead of his face. Moments later, the second sneaker landed far to his left.

Bryan gazed at the nearest, gawking like prey faced by an enormous predator. The huge footwear was filthy. No, Bryan couldn't be that kind to the towering shoe as to call it just filthy. It was ragged. Torn, stained, worn and utterly mouldering from use.

"Oh God!" It also reeked. Bryan craned back to view the titanic owner. His feeling of rescue draining to be replaced with fear.

Up, up, and still higher loomed the massive man wearing these disgusting shoes. Long wiry arms displaying faded tattoos and bandages descended from a cascading t-shirt of stained, worn cotton. Above that was a countenance Bryan would sneer in disgust at normally. Dirt and sweat speckled the huge features, visible only through a twisting jungle of reddish facial hairs growing without fear of being trimmed. The eyes made shrunken Mr. Smith whimper. Wide and rolling, they immediately denoted their humongous owner's mental state as very unstable.

Merely cowering between the huge feet of this drug-addled ruffian wasn't what caused Bryan to freeze: This giant hobo was looking right at him.

"Holy shit," Breathed the frightened insect of a man. What was going to happen? Was he about to meet his end underneath this filthy giant's foot? As if waiting for his internal thoughts to finish, the giant suddenly moved into action. Bryan screamed. "HOLY SHIT!"

---

He knew it. He had been right!

Larry lowered his hand, plucking the speck-sized being between his dirty, calloused fingers. He didn't leave anything to chance and immediately deposited the fugitive in a containment more than adequate to imprison it.

"Heh, they thought it wouldn't happen," The thin man babbled to the plastic cap in his hands. "I knew it though. I knew that you small bastards would come back! Just like my dreams!"

His vile breath washed over the trapped being, causing the flailing speck to halt any resistance. Larry peered closer, but kept a cautious distance from the conniving creature. He grinned triumphantly. Everyone would have to take back what they said about him. His brother and mother would welcome him back, begging for his protection from the coming scourge of tiny people. All the non-believers at the shelter would look at Larry differently. They had all been wrong; he was right!

A tick contorted his gaunt features, sending the homeless wanderer into full alert. What if there were others? They would surely attempt to save their comrade and silence Larry for good!

Glancing at the ground suspiciously, he held the dirty bottle cap protectively and cautiously retreated from the dark alley. He couldn't waste time gloating his discovery. If humanity would have a fighting chance, he needed to warn the authorities! He set down the street with this thought. Shambling awkwardly for a bit before another thought struck his addled mind. Larry had needs, as well. This tiny insurgent was surely worth a decent hit or two. Perhaps more!

Gazing down at the contained speck of a man, Larry considered his options. Humanity or his addiction?

He scuttled block after block, sidling past pedestrians who either ignored him or looked at him warily. All fools who would be eating both their cruel words and thoughts when Larry delivered the proof of an impending devastation by teeny evil people-bugs!

It was then he spotted a familiar figure just up the sidewalk. A man in dark blue uniform, police hat, and black boots that Larry knew as Officer Curtis Graham, one of the local beat cops. And one that had been friendly to Larry over the years.

"Hu-huh, Curtis, h-h-hey man," he said, coming up to the officers side who was finishing up a cup of coffee. "I've got, uh, I mean, they...th-th-the invasion..."

"Larry, how's it going?" The officer responded, friendly but somewhat sympathetically.

The dirty drug addict swallowed hard, mindful yet rather callous about the cap held in his hands. "The invasion...I-I found one! A scout!" He presented the rather grimy plastic cap, sticking his hands closer to the cop who glanced down at it.

"Oh, yeah?" He said, squinting for a moment at what could only be an empty, dirty cap before noticing an ant moving around. He smirked, always a friend to the local homeless, and looked back to the excited Larry. "Yeah...definitely got one. A big one, by the looks of him. Good work, man!"

Larry looked pleased, but still ready to go on, which Curtis ultimately didn't have time for. He glanced at the unfortunate ant again, and pulled a stamp-ridden deli card from his pocket, and said, "Here, I'll take care of the, uh, invader and you take this and get yourself something to eat, alright?" Curtis plucked the cap between two fingers and dropped the filled-out lunch card in its place. It seemed Larry wanted more, but the ragged man looked at the card and smiled.

"Y-y-y-ou're a good, uh, real good guy. Just...make sure....be sure that it, well, that they send it to the president for questioning. I was right! Right?" Larry sputtered, his thoughts running a mile a minute. "Thanks a lot. Curtis, man, your a good guy!"

Larry eyed the cap as if it had been a bomb and was now defused, before turning around and hurrying back the way he came, awkwardly turning to wave goodbye. Officer Graham nodded in response, glad to see the unfortunate Larry happy and with means to eat.

"He outta feel better for a week or two again...hell, until he finds another bug!"

Curtis looked down at the bug in question, frowning. He couldn't figure how Larry's mind worked. One week it was a ladybug, another week it was a moth, and many other times, like now, just an ant. "Alright. Time to go, little guy", He said, smirking thoughtlessly.

He decided to start climbing. "I'll worry about contacting him once I make it to the countertop."

He knew one thing. Lost on the wide surface of his oak kitchen table rested a tiny glass vial so small it would have been almost invisible for humans of ordinary size. The minuscule container contained his vital counter-agent to reverse his shrinkage into the realm of bugs.

As he climbed, he tried to channel his mind and body into a single-minded focus, but he could not seem to shake his obsession with his earlier dream... the dream that ended with him getting stomped beneath an enormous sneaker.

The little man, no bigger than a bug, stopped to rest. He had climbed almost 10 inches or the equivalent of 240 feet, which left at least another 600 feet to go.

As he rested, he flashed back to that awful dream. "I don't believe dreams can come true," he said aloud.

So, why did it bother him so much to have recognized that the shoes in his dream were the giant Airwalks worn by Tommy's friend, Joe?

"Just a coincidence," he muttered aloud.

He started his climb again, reminding himself that he needed to spend less time dwelling on his absurd nightmare and more time on climbing to the countertop.

Only from a position lofty enough to avoid any possible contact with the feet of either Tommy or Joe did he feel secure enough to again attempt communication with the teenaged titans.

He shivered at a passing remembrance of how awesome the two teens had looked when he had gazed on them from his puny perspective of a quarter-inch tall. He had managed to climb another couple of hundred feet on the winding, twisted utility cords.

He stopped to rest, almost exhausted. He could not spare much time to let his speck-sized body recover. He knew he needed on the countertop before the giants returned...

So, sooner than he would have liked, he began climbing again. He made good time, reaching within 300 feet of the flat countertop when he slipped. Some splatter of grease from the stove had landed on the utility cord. He hadn't seen the slick spot until the last second.

The tiny man struggled to regain his balance, but...
112122111.title: Long Climb...

choices: Loses his balance
Jumps
1121221112.content:
If anything, his unexpected plunge had delivered him into a metaphor for his current run of bad luck. A speck lost amidst enormous everyday items tossed into a garbage can in his kitchen, he pondered for a moment how he had been so reduced he was literally sharing space with the discarded trash from what had been his former life.

Such musings took a back seat when he realized how badly the contents of the garbage can smelled. Putrid food scraps littered the interior of the plastic-lined can, which he had to avoid as if they were greasy pools of quicksand.

"I've got to get out of here," he told himself. His destiny, he reminded himself, wasn't to be thrown out like garbage. I'm going to be a big man of science!

Even as he thought it, he realized how utterly ridiculous the claim sounded. None of his ambitious objective would ever be realized if he didn't get out of the trash can, contact Tommy and get himself back to normal.

It took some effort, but he finally achieved the goal of getting out of the trash can, only to find himself stranded far above the kitchen floor.
1121221112.title: New Lows

choices: Tommy sees something
Tommy doesn't see anything
11212211121.content:
The naked, shrunken scientist stood on the rim of the plastic trash receptacle, staring into the pit of stinking kitchen garbage. He was relieved to have escaped, but as he peered over the other edge, he saw the dizzying precipice that towered above the tiles of the kitchen floor.

A scientist with level-headed clarity of the working of simple physics, Bryan Smith saw no possible means of reaching the floor. "I can't be trapped," he squeaked aloud, frustrated by how his incredibly shrunken size made life so infernally difficult.

Still standing on the narrow plastic ledge, he was astonished when the back door opened. One titan — a familiar one — entered the tiny man's home. He recognized Tommy with a mix of awe and anxiety. He began leaping and waving his arms, doing everything he could to get himself noticed.

"Tommy!" The shrunken scientist screamed. "Here! I'm here! Please... Aiiiiieee!"

Tommy stomped into Mr. Smith's kitchen, a new pair of vibrant sneakers on his feet. He'd bought the new shoes with part of the money he'd earned mailing Mr. Smith's little package. He was quite proud of them, continually glancing down to admire the handsome, colorful shoes. He was so grateful to Mr. Smith for making the sneakers affordable that he'd made a point to come back to the house to see if there might be something he could tidy. His eyes locked on the huge garbage can, which looked almost full. He figured the least he could was to take out Mr. Smith's trash.

The vibrations from the first few steps made by the titan were all that it took to dislodge the speck-sized man from the precarious perch. As he screamed, the floor rushed to meet him.

Somehow, he survived. As he applied his intellect to the surprising fact, he realized something that should have been fairly obvious. At such a tiny size, a fall, even from a tremendous height, need not prove lethal. After all, ants and other tiny bugs took tumbles all the time without suffering extensive injury.

He didn't get to celebrate his survival for long. His plunge had left him stranded on a wide, flat kitchen tile, which was now directly in the path of the bright red, yellow and blue sneakers covering Tommy's feet. With a startled scream, the tiny man's eyes darted around the room, seeking a place of refuge as the sneakers — more like a thunderous blur of colors — slammed onto the tiles, coming closer.

The entire floor shook beneath the immense weight of each of the titan's footsteps.

The tiny man prepared to flee from his colossal neighbor when he felt a sharp pain in his left leg. His fall to the floor hadn't been as fortuitous as he first thought. He ran, with a prominent limp, in a desperate attempt to get out of Tommy's path.
11212211121.title: One Slippery Step

choices: Mr. Smith's luck runs out
Mr. Smith catches a lucky break
112122111212.content:
In a situation that screamed for the need for speed, the shrunken scientist found that his injured leg left him with an egregious disadvantage as Tommy's colorful sneakers bore down on him. He heard the squeak of the rubber soles like a horde of bats as Tommy walked on the kitchen tiles. Like a metal spike through the skull, the horrific squeak of the new shoes erupted with sonic discomfort in the tiny man's brain as he fled a hazard that was difficult to comprehend.

A day ago, Tommy had been the teenager next door, a solid, reliable youth that Bryan Smith enjoyed hiring for odd jobs around his home. Now, by merely walking into the room, oblivious to anything as tiny as the shrunken scientist, the skinny teenager became an unstoppable natural force that threatened to rain down destruction.

"Fuck!" Mr. Smith squeaked as one of the shoes dropped, inches from his body. The concussive displacement of the surrounding air slammed into the speck-sized man's body, almost knocking him off his feet. He stumbled, regained his balance (no small feat with an injured leg) and kept sprinting away from the vicinity of the teen titan. His progress across the vast, flat plain of the kitchen tiles was painfully slow.

Tommy stopped in front of the plastic garbage can. The receptacle was roughly waist high to the teenager, who used one arm to pull the stuff plastic bag from the plastic confines of the can. He twirled the bag, a trick he had learned from taking his own family's trash out on many occasions, to tie off the bag and ensure none of the smelly contents spilled onto Mr. Smith's immaculate floor.

As he noticed that the titan's movement had slowed, the terrified scientist paused, dared to look over his shoulder at the awe-inspiring sight of Tommy lifting the full garbage can from the can. From the tiny man's perspective, the ease with which Tommy accomplished his task looked impressive and forced Mr. Smith to look at the teenager with new eyes. Tommy now looked like a powerful, strong, potentially lethal giant.

Tommy turned to face the back door, and Mr. Smith realized the folly of hesitating even for a second. Tommy was backtracking, his enormous new sneakers bringing him right back toward the ant-sized scientist on the tiles. "Oh shit!" Mr. Smith screamed and began running again.

The enormous garbage bag cast a substantial, dark shadow over the tiles as Tommy, holding it in one hand, carried it over the tiles. Mr. Smith, suddenly plunged into darkness and not knowing whether the shadow was cast by one of the teenager's mothership-sized sneakers, dropped and curled into a fetal ball.

The sneakers slammed onto the tiles, but seemingly hundreds of feet from the shrunken man's location. The enormous door swung open for Tommy, who stepped outside with the full garbage can.

Mr. Smith, still shaken, tried to get back onto his feet. "I could have been stomped," his voice wavered. "Like a bug!"

Near tears, he wanted the nightmare to end. He vowed to summon bravery enough to stand and demand attention from Tommy. His resolve melted like snow in warm rain as soon as the teenager returned.

From his crouching position, preparatory to leaping and waving at Tommy, the tiny man instead screamed and fled once again across the tiles. At least he had an objective, his eyes fastened on the geological plateau of the kitchen table. I've got to get under the table. I should be safe there.

There was an unfortunate expanse of open space between his tiny self and the dim shadow of the colossal table. Rapidly invading that space came Tommy in his bright sneakers again.
112122111212.title: Tommy doesn't see anything

1121221112121.content:
"Fuck!" Bryan Smith screamed, changed direction, and sprinted toward his right.

Another sneaker crashed down, forcing another on-the-move decision to change direction again. "Tommy!" The shrunken scientist screamed like a tiny banshee. "Fucking stop! You're going to crush me!"

Almost as if in response, the first shoe, having lifted again, crashed down, inches from the tiny's man vulnerable position on his own kitchen floor. The tremors knocked the bug-sized man off his feet, putting a halt to his attempt to remove himself from the vicinity of Tommy's enormous multi-colored sneakers.

The shocking pink rubber soles of the sneakers looked bright enough to burn the tiny man's retinas. The yellow and blue stripes on the sides of the shoes added to the sensory overload bombarding the shrunken scientist. He looked away from the harsh display of colors to the still distant kitchen table and the security of the twilight region beneath the tabletop and four massive supporting legs.

"I can't just wait for him to stomp me," Bryan shouted defiantly as he got to his feet and headed toward the table again.

In a final insult, he finally achieved some attention when Tommy happened to glance down at the floor and noticed the pale, scurrying insect.

"Gross bug," the teenager complained in a rumbling growl of disgust.

"No, no, no!" Bryan protested in a fit of screams. He was so close that he dared not look back. He kept pushing himself to reach the shelter provided by the overhang of the city-sized table.

"Well, that's easy enough to deal with," Tommy said. "Gotta break in these new shoes sooner or later."

Tiny Bryan heard the teenager's gleeful laugh that punctuated the declaration. "No, please. I've shrunk! Look closer..."

Although the tiny bug kept racing across the floor, it's path was soon darkened by an eclipse brought on by Tommy's raised right foot.

The bug-sized man froze, turning to face the teenager. He scanned for Tommy's face, hoping for some way to kickstart an inkling of recognition. After all, why should Tommy just stomp something tiny without asking some careful questions first? Unfortunately, the teenager didn't normally give bugs much thought, other than enough to eradicate them.

But he was too late to find Tommy's face. His field of vision was dominated by an onrushing wall of pink rubber. He had time to throw up his arms in a futile gesture.

Tommy lifted the sneaker, saw the tiny blot of red and chuckled. "Little bastard didn't stand a chance against these," he said, once again looking upon the new sneakers with pride. "I really need to thank Mr. Smith for providing me the money to buy them. I wonder what was so important in that package I mailed for him?"

He never learned the answer to that question or the bigger one concerning Mr. Smith's inexplicable disappearance. He did clean up the bug's meager remains with a tissue dropped into a now newly-emptied kitchen trash can.
1121221112121.title: Out of luck

choices: Tommy enters the living room with Joe
Tommy returns with Joe and two other buddies.
112122112.content:
Bryan gazed around his massive kitchen with a sense of dread and awe. The tiny scientist was surrounded by acres of linoleum. The vial of shrinking antidote along with anything else that could be of any help was completely inaccessible.

Bryan began walking to the door that led to the living room. He climbed over the divider that separated the linoleum kitchen floor and the hardwood floor in the living room.

The shrunken man began the exploration of his now expansive living room. Straight ahead of him was his mountainous glass coffee table and enormous black leather sectional sofa. A black leather recliner loomed just off to the right. The furniture was placed to ensure an excellent view of the sixty inch plasma screen television that set on a sturdy stand directly to his left.

Bryan knew that Tommy and his giant friends would probably be seated on his furniture very soon. He had to find a safe place to contact one of these giants. And he knew the floor was definitely not a safe place.

Bryan thought for a while and focused in on the end table next to the recliner. The leaves from a fake plant hung all the way to the floor. It would be a grueling climb, but Bryan could scale the hanging plant and await Tommy and his friends on the end table. From there, he could contact one of the young giants for help.

As Bryan neared the hanging plant, it appeared more as a giant beanstalk, just like from the fairy tale. He began the arduous climb. It took two hours, but Bryan finally reached the top. He looked around the room and gasped. The view was incredible. It felt so good to be up in a secure place, away from the dangerous floor.

Suddenly, Bryan was jolted as a loud boom vibrated the entire room. The kitchen door had been opened. The bug-sized man shivered as he anticipated what he was about to see.
112122112.title: Waiting For The Giants To Return

choices: Bryan makes a dash for the remote
Bryan decides to await a better opportunity
1121221121.content:
All of his newly-established confidence gained by his success in the difficult climb to the top of his living room end table vanished when Bryan beheld the two teenagers.

Tommy entered, followed closely by his friend. The tiny man heard them move through the kitchen. As they entered the living room, the vibrations of their footsteps on the hardwood floor caused tremors beneath Bryan's feet on the surface of the end table.

Bryan stared at the awesome giants. Joe, dressed in baggy shorts, wore his Airwalk sneakers but no socks.

Bryan still remained cautious of Joe, especially after the earlier close call with the boy's huge Airwalk sneakers. The same sneakers, strangely enough, that Bryan still recalled from his vivid dream.

Those same sneakers had provided the motivation for Bryan to seek out the high ground his home offered.

The two giants with their mere presence overwhelmed the tiny owner of the home. Tommy and his friend, of course, didn't have a clue that their every move was being scrutinized.

Joe dropped into the recliner positioned next to an end table. The youth's bulk rocked the table beneath Bryan's feet.

Terrified by Joe's closeness, Bryan took shelter behind one of fake plant's plastic leaves.

"THIS IS A SWEET DEAL," Joe said. "LUCKY BREAK FOR US THAT YOUR NEIGHBOR LEFT YOU IN CHARGE OF HIS PLACE."

"YEAH, BUT I DON'T WANT TO TRASH HIS PLACE," Tommy said. "WE'LL HAVE TO CLEAN UP LATER."

"NO SWEAT!" Joe said. "SO, ARE WE GOING TO WATCH A GAME OR WHAT?"

"LET ME FIND THE REMOTE," Tommy said.

Bryan, concealed by the fake leaf, saw an opportunity. The remote control for the plasma screen television rested on the end table. He needed to act fast, but this could offer him a chance to make contact.
1121221121.title: They're Back

choices: Joe needs something from the kitchen
Tommy needs something from the kitchen
11212211211.content:
Bryan sprinted as fast as his tiny legs would take his shrunken body across the surface of the table toward the enormous remote control unit resting on the tabletop.

He stopped short at the edge of the smooth wall of black plastic, which loomed twice his height. He got a lucky break when he saw the stone coaster adjacent to the remote. He clambered onto the coaster and used its proximity to the remote to leap onto the surface of the control device.

Bryan ran between the rows of buttons trying to find the optimal spot on the control device to ensure one of the giants would notice him.

He looked up in time to see Joe's huge hand rushing down toward him. "Wait!" Bryan cried.

His protest got cut off when Joe grabbed the remote in one hand and whipped the device around to point toward the large screen plasma television.

Bryan clawed at the smooth plastic, but failed to find a handhold. The tiny man went sailing off the remote control and plunged through the air toward the ever-closer living room floor.

All his work and planning had been for nothing. The tiny man, shocked that he had even survived the immense fall, gazed up and found himself again on the floor at the feet of the two teen titans.

In fact, Joe's enormous Airwalk sneakers looked absolutely intimidating and downright menacing in their closeness to the shrunken scientist.
11212211211.title: Not Where He Wanted To Be

choices: Joe Continues to the Kitchen
Something on television halts Joe
112122112111.content:
Tiny Bryan, still trying to regain his breath after the frightening plunge, found himself feeling a mingled sense of healthy respect for and overawed admiration of the gigantic teenagers.

He tried to gaze up at them with his practiced sense of scientific detachment, but he could not remain unaffected by the sheer enormity of both the teens and his own utter lack of status in their universe.

"I'm gonna check out the fridge again," Joe announced.

Bryan watched in slowly dawning horror as those mammoth Airwalks, each the size of a football field, began to move.

His plunge to the floor, unfortunately, placed him in the direct path from the living room to the kitchen.

"Joe!" Bryan screamed. "Tommy! Please, you've got to hear me!"

His screams to no avail, Bryan began to run after the tremors from Joe's first steps made themselves felt.

“Oh God! I've got to get away!” Bryan shouted as he ran for his life.

Despite running at his best speed, he simply could not cover much ground.

“Just gotta get away!” Bryan repeated, but the tiny man barely remained on his feet balance as the floor around him shook violently with a POUND! POUND! POUND! after each step taken by the giant.

Bryan, running as fast as he could, nervously glanced back. Joe's mammoth Airwalks, twice the size of a football field, closed in on him. The monstrosities covered an enormous distance with each ominous stomp.

In the grip of panic, as he realized he simply could not outrun the colossal shoes, Bryan felt a sense of trepidation as a feeling of deja vu overcame him.

"That fuckin' dream!" Bryan cried out as the shadow of the destructive Airwalk passed overhead.

The dream must have been a warning or an eerie prophecy. Why had he ever allowed himself to find himself anywhere near the feet of these titans?

He gazed skyward toward his ceiling, but the enormous treads of the giant’s shoes were right on top of him, ready to flatten him with one gigantic stomp.

Bryan, falling to his knees, moved his arms over his head and screamed.
112122112111.title: Instant of Awareness

1121221121111.content:
(Prescience is from Latin praescientia, from praescio, praescire, to know beforehand, from prae, before + scio, scire, to know.)

Bryan Smith had spent the past 15 years of his professional career absolutely devoted to the concepts of hard science. The world of the paranormal and supernatural, as far as he was concerned, ranked as no better than cheap science-fiction.

A day ago, he would have dismissed with his elite arrogance the entire concept of prescient dreams.

Now, too late, he knew better. He knew that science is not the limits of the human experience.

The sounds, the impressions, everything came together as some haunting echo of his nightmare— the dream of his destruction beneath a monstrous pair of Airwalks.

He almost felt as if he had fallen back into his dream as he re-lived each frightening second of it, but now wide awake.

Even his strangled cries repeated, almost word by word, what he remembered screaming in his horrific nightmare.

He felt a painful stitch in his side as he ran. "Just gotta get away," he cried as the sound of the gigantic footfalls boomed in his ears. "Oh god, help me!"

POUND! POUND!

The concussions of the footsteps tossed the tiny man off balance. He looked over his shoulder and saw the enormous Airwalks coming closer.

POUND!!!

That step triggered a powerful concussion that, to the speck-sized scientist, felt like an earthquake completely off the scale. He got knocked off his feet and sprawled on the floor.

He tried to stand, but as he looked up his sky became the underside of the gigantic sneaker's tread.

Bryan crouched and brought his arms over his head.

"It's not fair!" Bryan screamed silently in his mind.

If only he had heeded the prophetic warning from his dream.

At the last instant, he still struggled to evade his fate. But he could not cover the distance of a football field in the time he needed to escape Joe's next step.

••••••

When Joe brought his sneaker down on top of the unseen speck, nothing — not a sound, not even the brief squishing sensation — reached him. The Airwalk lifted and Joe continued his casual stride until he reached the kitchen and pulled open the door of the refrigerator.

Tommy walked into the kitchen behind his friend. "Anything?"

"No," Joe said, clearly disgusted. "Doesn't this guy believe in keeping anything good to eat in the house?"

"Well, I guess he didn't want to buy a lot of food before he went out of town on his trip," Tommy said.

They started to return to the living room when Tommy glanced down on the kitchen tiles and saw a insignificant red smear.

"Damn, what's that?"

Joe looked down and shrugged. "Hell if I know."

"I think it is from your shoe, man! You must have stepped in something."

"Well, excuse me!" Joe said in a testy voice.

"I just don't want to trash the place while Mr. Smith's gone," Tommy said. He grabbed a napkin from the kitchen table and wiped the smear off the tile.

"Well, we gonna watch the game or not?" Joe asked impatiently.

"I'm coming," Tommy said. He tossed the wadded napkin into the trash can as he left the kitchen.
1121221121111.title: 13 is Unlucky and Other Superstitions

choices: Bryan decides to approach Tommy
Tommy gets restless
1121221121112.content:
Bryan waited for the obliterating footstep.

When tons of crushing pressure failed to drop onto him, Bryan dared to raise his face and look around the room.

Joe had stopped and turned to face the television. "I love this commercial, man!" Joe said. "Penguins!"

Bryan watched as the huge youth laughed uproariously at a commercial playing on the colossal television screen.

Given this unexpected reprieve, Bryan removed himself from harm's path. He sprinted toward the distant wall, deciding he would be safer away from the room's open spaces.

His close call convinced him not to repeat his stupid risk-taking.

In his strange dream, he had faced oblivion from Joe's Airwalks.

"I've just got to keep away from him," Bryan said to himself.

He decided he should restrict his approach to Tommy. Despite his young neighbor's enormous size, Bryan retained trust in the normally responsible young man.

"But how do I get him to notice me?" Bryan wondered.

The commercial ended, Joe continued toward the kitchen. From near the base of the wall, tiny Bryan watched the titan journey quickly from the living room into the kitchen.

For the moment, Tommy remained seated, alone, on the sofa.
1121221121112.title: Reprieve

choices: Tommy sees something tiny
Joe notices something tiny
11212211211121.content:
The shrunken scientist knew that he should advantage of the momentary absence of Tommy's enormous friend.

However, he remained cowering near the base of the living room wall, unable to forget how he had nearly been stomped like a bug.

The incident had played out almost the same as the scene in his strange dream about his flight from Joe's massive Airwalks.

That far too close call convinced him not to take any other stupid risks.

"I've just got to keep away from him," Bryan said, adding quickly, "and those damn sneakers!"

He wanted to approach Tommy. Despite his young neighbor's enormous size, the tiny man still trusted him.

But, he delayed too long. The floor shook as Tommy emerged from the kitchen and returned to the living room.

From the floor, tiny Mr. Smith watched the titanic teenager join the equally colossal Tommy on the huge sofa.

"SO, WHAT'S THIS GUY LIKE?" Joe asked. "THIS HOUSE IS FANTASTIC!"

Tommy nodded. "OH, MR. SMITH'S OK," he answered. "HE'S A LITTLE STRANGE, THOUGH."

Listening to the loud voices that rumbled and boomed above him, the bug-sized scientist felt indignant.

"I'm strange?" He squeaked aloud. "What's he talking about?"

"STRANGE HOW?" Joe asked.

Tommy yawned and stretched. Mr. Smith found his gaze focused on the muscles that rippled beneath the giant teenager's T-shirt as a result of Tommy's movements.

"I DON'T KNOW, MAN," Tommy said. "HE PAYS ME TO DO ALL THESE CHORES FOR HIM, BUT HE'S ALWAYS LOOKING AT ME."

Joe laughed, but Tommy snapped at him. "IT'S NOT FUNNY!"

The bug-sized scientist felt anger at the unjust accusations.

"THAT'S HILARIOUS," Joe said.

"HE'S JUST A NERD," Tommy said. "AS LONG AS HE KEEPS PAYING ME, WHO CARES?"

"HE MIGHT PAY YOU MORE TO BE HIS BOYFRIEND."

"OH, SHUT UP," Tommy said.

Joe giggled. "SO, HE CAN LOOK BUT NOT TOUCH?"

"YOU'RE AN IDIOT," Tommy said. He got to his feet and headed toward the kitchen, mostly to get away from Joe.

The gigantic teenager's path was taking him right past tiny Mr. Smith, who was still upset by Tommy's unkind remarks.

But, was this the chance he needed? Swallowing his irritation, the speck of a man rushed away from the wall, determined to make Tommy notice him.
11212211211121.title: Come Down

112122112111211.content:
Aggravated by his buddy's poking fun at him, Tommy wasn't in a good mood when he saw the little bug scurry from the wall, right into his path.

"Not a smart move, bug," Tommy thought to himself. He re-directed his need to punch Joe for his smart-ass remarks by making a split-second decision to rid Mr. Smith's home of one less tiny pest.

"Tommy!" The tiny man did an almost comical dance in one spot as he leaped and waved his impossibly thin arms over his head. "Down here! On the floor at you feet! It's me..."

He reined back the strong impulse to flee out of the way of the oncoming titan. The impact of the teenaged god's sneakers on the floor sent violent shockwaves in all directions.

"Tommy, please..." He swallowed his words in a suddenly dry throat when the immense teenager raised his sneaker.

With a surly frown twisting his normally handsome face, Tommy raised his right shoe, ready to slam it down on the pesky bug.

"God, it's got to be one stupid bug," he thought to himself when, instead of fleeing for the shadows, the bug seemed to be jumping in place as if daring him to stomp it. "Guess you're gonna get your wish you filthy little..."

When the shadow of the shoe enveloped him, the tiny man screamed and turned to run. All he could think of was the ignominy of being stomped like a mere insect beneath Tommy's all-powerful foot. "It wasn't supposed to be like this!" He managed to scream as the mammoth sole of the sneaker crashed to the floor.

"What the hell was that?" A mildly interested Joe asked as he stirred himself off the sofa.

"Nothing," Tommy answered, delivering the final insult. "It was just a stupid bug."

Not only was poor Mr. Smith's demise quite final, he would have been even more humiliated by the indignity of a academically unmotivated teenaged slacker obliterating him and his brilliant brain in one carefully placed stomp beneath a well-worn, smelly sneaker.

In his untimely demise, as in life, Mr. Smith was very much beneath Tommy's notice.
112122112111211.title: Ignominious Ending

choices: Nightmare's End
Spared by falling into space between floorboards
112122112111212.content:
He soon realized that he had made a tactical blunder, placing himself into an extremely vulnerable position in relation to Tommy's shoes.

The titanic sneakers slammed down, causing concussive blasts with each step. The tiny man froze in place and screamed when one of the massive shoes rose high above him, slamming down only seconds later, and missing him by only a narrow margin.

When Tommy's footsteps receded as the enormous teenager continued toward the kitchen, the little man breathed a deep sigh of relief.

Despite the close call, the bug-sized scientist didn't abandon hope of contacting his giant neighbor and effecting his rescue.

"I just need to think of a way to get him to notice me," he muttered, "while staying out from underfoot."

He giggled nervously, thinking of how close he had come to getting stomped. In the annals of history, death under a teenager's sneaker might be unique, but was also definitely humiliating and undesirable.

He had all but forgotten that there was still another giant in his home. Unfortunately, as he started to move across the floor, Joe happened to glance at that very spot on the floor from his seat on the sofa.

As he watched, the tiny bug seemed to meander in circles.

The shrunken scientist's first warning came when Joe lazily got off the sofa and planted his Airwalks on the floor. The result tremors reverberated throughout the entire room, reminding the bug-sized man of the presence of Tommy's equally titanic friend.

He turned and saw Joe's monstrous form lurching in his direction. Even worse, he watched the mammoth Airwalks as they slammed down, sounding even louder than Tommy's sneakers had sounded only moments earlier.

Desperate to get out of his path, the tiny man veered toward the right, only to see the giant adjust his own steps. To his horror, he realized that Joe had seen him and drawn a terribly incorrect conclusion.

“Oh God, please help me,” screamed the tiny man as he ran for his life. “Just gotta get away!”

The floorboards along the edge of the wall now looked alarmingly distant.

The tiny man could barely keep his balance as the earth around him shook violently.

POUND! POUND! POUND! Each step brought the gigantic teenager closer.

The little man kept running as fast as he could, but spared a nervous glance back. To his horror, he saw closing in on him the pair of mammoth Airwalks each twice the size of a football field. The monstrosities covered an enormous distance with each ominous stomp.

Within a matter of seconds, the gargantuan treads of an unknown giant’s shoes were right on top of him, ready to flatten him with one gigantic stomp.

In panic, the shrunken man screamed out for Tommy, then crouched with his arms over his head as he ran out of time.
112122112111212.title: Now, back to his nightmare...

1121221121112121.content:
His final seconds seemed to drip like honey, slowing down to a slow scroll of images, sounds and regrets.

The image that filled his consciousness was the oncoming sole of Joe's truly massive Airwalk. The shoe filled up so much of his field of view the shrunken scientist had no view whatsoever of the teenaged titan.

The sounds that echoed in his brain came from his own screams full of shock, futility and denial.

As for regrets, he had an instant to reflect on the stupidity of placing himself in such a vulnerable position. He might have the intellectual prowess to make the scientific breakthrough of the century, but in making himself a test subject he had sealed his own fate.

The impact of shoe with the floor wasn't stopped for even a nano-second by the bug-sized body of research scientist Bryan Smith. It arrived with a clap of thunder followed by silence.


Tommy, having returned, saw Joe raise his foot and stomp.

"What was that?" Tommy asked.

And, with that brief halt to his progress now terminated, he continued toward the kitchen, never looking down and noticing the puny, pale form that attempted in vain to scramble out of his path.

Until the final instant, the speck-sized man continued to scream pleas for Tommy to notice him. Only when the shadow eclipsed his spot on the floor did he attempt to run.

By that point, he had delayed far too long. The shoe dropped with such speed that his final shout got abruptly cut off.

In two more of his giant strides, Tommy reached the kitchen, never having detected the tiny being that perished beneath his right shoe.

When he returned to the living room a few minutes later, he frowned to find Joe's dirty Airwalks propped on Mr. Smith's coffee table.

"Get your feet off Mr. Smith's furniture," he said. "You think he wants to deal with your filthy shoes?"

Joe grunted and slid his shoes back to the floor.

Never in his wildest imagination did Tommy guess that his own well-worn shoe had just stomped his employer and next-door neighbor into oblivion.
1121221121121.title: Dead-End!

choices: Tommy cleans up his mess and finds the hand-held vacuum cleaner
Tommy decides he can clean up the mess later
1121221121122.content:
From his lowly vantage point on the floor, the terrified tiny man watched in disbelief and dismay as the giant teenager stomped loudly into the kitchen.

According to everything his brain wanted to register, the tiny man could not quite comprehend how something so immense and massive could move with such speed and power.

Before he could sprint out of Tommy's path, the teen's enormous stride brought his left foot down only inches from the shrunken scientist's spot on the floor.

The closeness of the huge sneaker's impact and the resulting shock waves sent through the kitchen tiles caught the bug-sized man by surprise, knocking him flat on his back.

He watched, helpless, as the other foot lifted and another sneaker sailed overhead, only to land a safe distance away as Tommy continued to the fridge.

---

Tommy must not have found what he wanted, because he turned back almost immediately for the living room. As he passed the counter, however, he spied the bag of chocolate chip cookies. He veered slightly and grabbed the bag in one hand, but failed to notice the bag had already been opened.

The contents of the bag spilled out, falling onto the floor and shattering into chunks and smaller crumbs.

Tommy cursed at the mess he had made, unaware that a tiny speck-sized man had been caught in the debris field from the dropped cookies.
1121221121122.title: Making a Mess

choices: Tommy cleans up the whole mess
Joe appears and calls out, "30-second rule!"
11212211211221.content:
Tiny Mr. Smith was still celebrating his good fortune in not having been stomped by his oblivious neighbor when the huge teen rained down an avalanche on the speck-sized man.

As the large chunks and crumbs made impact with the floor, they tended to smash into smaller bits, creating a shrapnel of cookie crumbs that spread out in all directions.

A large cookie, more or less intact, smashed onto the same tile occupied by the shrunken scientist. As he pulled his wits together, the tiny man recognized the massive object.

"It's a cookie!" Mr. Smith screamed.

He raced over to the building-sized baked good, navigating through a field of boulder-sized crumbs thrown off by the dropped cookie after it hit the floor.

"Tommy!" Mr. Smith screamed as loudly as he could. "Look for me! Down here! Next to the cookie!"

As he drew closer, and the cookie loomed ever larger, the tiny man realized just how small he was in comparison to the world around him.

But, knowing the conscientious of the teen, he suspected that Tommy would clean up the mess he had made.

"It could be my chance to get him to notice me," he said.

Suddenly, he heard a loud roar and looked up and saw Tommy returning to the scene, the household vacuum cleaner activated and ready to dispose of the mess.

In desperation, the tiny man climbed onto the large cookie and waved his arms. "Please, see me!" Mr. Smith screamed.

The collection bag is too full... time to empty it
112122112112211.content:
"Please, see me!" Mr. Smith screamed from a spot atop the enormous cookie.

The loud roar of the hand-held Dust-Buster obliterated his words as soon as the tiny man uttered them. The shrunken scientist stared in awe and horror at Tommy's enormous form as the teenager hunkered over him, sucking up broken segments of cookies as well as all the larger crumbs.

Tommy watched as the vacuum sucked up crumbs. They disappeared with a satisfying whoosh through the nozzle hose, transported into the collection bag held within the interior of the cleaning device.

He pushed the nozzle over a large nearly unbroken cookie, but the object merely clogged the hose. Of course, the oblivious giant missed seeing the speck that was sucked off the surface of the cookie by the powerful suction from the Dust-Buster.

The teenager reached down, removed the obstructing cookie, then continue to suck up other crumbs, which were rocketed through the nozzle tube to pummel the tiny man already trapped deep inside the collection bag.

Suddenly...

spilled some of the contents onto the kitchen floor

"Damn, the bag must be full," he said.

He walked over to a trash can, snapped open the plastic casing of the Dust-Buster, and prepared to empty the contents of the collection bag.

Inside the bag, poor Mr. Smith felt his lung and nostrils fill with irritating dust and other debris as his tiny body was tossed around with cookie crumbs, dust bunnies and other accumulated debris.

Suddenly, light filtered into the dusty interior of the bag as Tommy's massive hands lifted it from the Dust-Buster's plastic casing.

"Tommy! Get me out of here!" The tiny man screamed.

Tommy, not hearing the pitiful screams, wanted to finish with the task at hand as quickly as possible.

He...

Evading the stomp

Tommy opened the lid on the trash can in Mr. Smith's kitchen, but he found the trash had accumulated almost to the lid.

Undaunted, he held the bag atop the collection of kitchen debris and shook it.

A rain of cookie crumbs, dust bunnies and one bug-sized shrunken scientist fell into the trash can.

Tommy looked down and frowned, then lifted his foot over the entire can, intending to stomp down and compress the trash to a more compact mass.

At the same time, tiny Mr. Smith took the opportunity to dust himself off after landing, only to find himself trapped on a massive mound of garbage.

He gazed up, hoping to find Tommy and do something to attract the teenager's attention. Instead, he saw the bottom of his teenaged neighbor's sneaker getting ready to drop into the overflowing garbage bag.

11212211211221111.title: Dealing with overflow

choices: Does Mr. Smith go flying too or is he stuck in the tread of the giant sneaker?
Did Mr. Smith gets pressed deep into the spaghetti and trapped in the trash?
112122112112211111.content:
If anything could drive home the new and entirely unfamiliar, even alien, universe his shrinking had landed him, it was the incident with the humongous, deafening vacuum cleaner that dealt with the tiny scientist in the same manner as cookie crumbs and dust bunnies by sucking him upward into a maelstrom like a hurricane and transporting him as he tumbled head over heels through a long tube bigger than any that existed for swift commuter bullet trains. Mr. Smith hadn't felt like a respected customer of a transport service as he whooshed through the dark tube, colliding with other bits of flotsam in the invisible stream.

He had had the misplaced relief to almost feel grateful when the enormous winds of the hurricane ceased with the click of a button, but then he had fallen into his own garbage can, trapped with stale food, discarded papers and wrappers, and the other debris from his own life.

He gazed skyward with a view outlined by the plastic oval of the trash can's design and saw Tommy looming over the scene like a savior...or a bringer of destruction. When the teenager's body pulled back and his right foot suddenly loomed high over the can and then dropped, Mr. Smith had the answer. Tommy, no doubt about it, had become a figure of destruction... his own if he didn't do something about it.

He got to his feet and ran across a pool of spaghetti noodles and sauce from the remnants of his last meal as a human being of normal proportions in the universe. As the slippery, cable-size noodles impeded his progress, he dropped to hands and knees in the sticky sauce and lifted his face just as Tommy stomped.

At home, to delay taking out the garbage, Tommy had learned the trick of compacting the contents. It usually worked, but then leftovers rarely survived in his household where the always hungry but eternally skinny teenager usually finished them off. So, the experience of his shoe landing in a squishy mess brought a disgusted groan as he heard the squelch as he pressed heavily on the contents.

He lifted his shoe from the can and shook it, flinging drops of red sauce and stray noodles flying. The question still awaiting answer....
