112122112211221112211211112112122.content:
Bryan lay face down in sandwich meat. He had still been imprisoned in the humongous snack, pressed down on either side by huge slices of meat. Then his edible prison began moving violently. Loud muffled voices and a thunderous crunch followed. Suddenly his world went topsy-turvy.

Cursing himself, he looked at his new surroundings. He sat on a rolling expanse of pale turkey meat. A huge slice of porous bread loomed ahead with a draping sheet of yellow cheese the size of a football field. 'I could solve world hunger easily!' He thought promisingly. Then he burst back into his reality when an enormous hand dropped from above and snatched up the large slice of bread roughly.

He looked up in alarm. Trent loomed overhead with a plate in-hand, his massive form cast a huge shadow over the floor. Bryan yelped and stumbled furiously down the turkey landscape towards the floor just before the huge fingers returned. Building-sized digits plucked the remaining pieces of food off floor, leaving behind only tiny breads crumbs, cheese bits, and one minuscule man.

The tiny man was glad to be freed of the massive sandwich, but his current position offered new dangers.

Bryan's awe-struck gaze darted to a new titan that suddenly spoke. His large mouth moved slowly, emitting deep powerful notes that followed a few seconds after. As the two gigantic young men spoke, Bryan could only pick up a few words, which were predominately, "Dude", "Bro", and various obscenities. He could scarcely believe that these gargantuan titans were just regular teenagers, both unaware of how large and dangerous they were.

Next to a crumble of cheese that was larger than he was, Bryan continued to listen. Despite his remarkable intelligence, his mind remained blank as he gawked at the oblivious giants. He began to pick up names as they spoke. Trent was a name he already knew. Paul seemed to be this new giant. They both wore shirts embezzled with a familiar high school emblem.

"Tommy's school!" Bryan squeaked at the realization. He stifled a jump of joy at the prospect. "They must know Tommy! If I can get them to take me to him, I will be saved!" It was his first stroke of luck!

He looked the two young men over excitedly. Despite Tommy's physical prowess, these two behemoths appeared noticeably larger than Mr. Smith's helpful neighbor. They also seemed far more boisterous and careless.

Fear began to settle in again. If he couldn't get Tommy to recognize him before, how would he get these titans to even notice him?

Suddenly....
112122112211221112211211112112122.title: On the floor

1121221122112211122112111121121221.content:
Paul tried to ignore Trent as he ranted while picking up the ruined pieces of his sandwich. "... and I was so fucking hungry! Then you came along!" Trent continued.

"Bro!" Paul interrupted. "I just wanted a single bite, it was an accident. I'm sorry, move on!" Trent glared at him for a second, before grunting and snatching up the slice of cheese from the floor. Paul's gaze followed his friend's movement.

Just before he looked away he noticed an oddly colored speck on the floor. "Dude, there's a bug on the floor!" Paul said with disdain.

Trent didn't even look over, as he continued to poke the pile of dirty food that had been his sandwich. "Yeah, I knocked the ant off my leg before you showed up," he replied dismissively.

"Well I'll take care of this problem..." Paul trailed off. He stood up to his full height of 6'4", unaware of how impossibly tall he looked to the minuscule creature before him. He casually lifted his shoe over the pest, that just happened to be a tiny scientist. He never once considered the bug's point of view.

Paul couldn't imagine the fear coursing through the tiny speck in the seconds before his shoe hit the ground. He didn't realize that the shrunken man's last sight was the dirt and grime trapped in the black and white tread of his Air Jordan V's. Bryan's terrified screams for mercy never reached Paul's ears.

With a dull thud on the hardwood floor that Paul barely felt, Bryan Smith was gone. Paul, unable to appreciate the consequences of his simple action, turns back to his buddy.

"Hey Trent, your sandwich made me hungry! Let's walk over to McDonald's and grab something." Paul suggests, stepping towards the front door. Trent, past his anger, shrugs and nods. He pushes the plate onto the coffee table and follows Paul outside.

The two boys chat as they stroll down the sidewalk. They are far removed from their monstrous presence in the world at their feet. Where a simple step can eradicate countless lives, whether it was meant to or not. Ultimately though, they all ended up in the same place as Bryan: in the filthy tread of some oblivious teenager’s sneakers.
1121221122112211122112111121121221.title: Same Place

choices: The middle of the street
The front lawn of a neighboring house
11212211221122111221121111212.content:
With every whipping motion, Bryan's stomach bounced around like a rubber ball. His face was a deathly white and his eyes shut tightly in an effort to distance himself from this horrifying predicament.

Close above him, a hearty buffet produced by the fly's wings beat against him. Below, a heart-stopping view of the ground far below made him swoon.

"I can't take much more of this!" His tiny legs dangled bonelessly in open space, but his arms tightly gripped the oily insect leg.

Suddenly, he heard a bone-chilling sound. Tearing fabric! His eyes shot open to see his soiled shirt tearing. "No! No, no, no!" Bryan lets his grip loosen in a fit of panic, causing the clothing to tear further. His vision blurred as he felt himself slide down the fly's leg. What looked like a fall of hundreds of feet stretched beneath him.

Another lurching motion caused by the huge buzzing insects careless movements caused the last shred of clothing to rip free. Bryan's hands frantically grabbed at the leg. He felt himself sliding down, the oily hairs prickling against his bare skin.

He let out a wailing cry. It was hopeless, he couldn't get a grip! The fly kept flying seemingly higher, as if to insure the tiny man's demise. Bryan saw stars flash before his eyes and his body slacken as he once again swooned.

It was enough. Another cruel lurch and Bryan slipped off into a free fall.

"Nooooooo!!!" The massive amount of open space swallowed his pathetic squeal. He was spinning around wildly, unable to even see where he was falling.

A nightmare. "Just a bad nightmare..." He thought to himself before colliding with the ground. Everything went black.

Bryan shot upright as he regained consciousness. His thin little body ached and wretched, but shockingly enough, nothing was broken. He was alive...!

After letting out a sigh of relief, the bug-sized scientist slowly looked around. He had been relocated to...
11212211221122111221121111212.title: First class travel

choices: Something attacks!
The ground begins to tremble!
112122112211221112211211112122.content:
"Oh fuck, where am I?"

Bryan's shrill voice seemed to be instantly absorbed by the thick, massive vegetation surrounding him.

Like something out of Disney Land, the Tiny man found himself helplessly lost in a jungle of towering grass. They stretched in wild angles; upwards, sideways, and into the ground. Bryan felt like he had been thrown backwards in time.

Attempting to move around produced painful shoots from his battered limbs. "God... I can barely move!" He whined, rubbing his tender appendages. "This is a nightmare!"

Loud clicking alerted him to an enormous beast that soared overhead. It paused briefly, studying the minute pink human with faceted eyes. Bryan pealed with fright, falling to the ground. Judging the tiny scientist uninteresting, the humongous insect buzzed off, leaving him alone once more.

Huddled, Bryan could only whimper and shake. His eyes shot from one direction to another - the tall, thick grass forming a foreboding circle around him. Bryan decided this verdant jungle was by far more terrifying than his previous locale.

"Tommy!" Bryan cupped his hands and screeched. "Tommy! Help me!" Only airy wind and distant, unknown noises responded.

"Anyone! HELP!"

He collapsed once more, ignoring complaints from his bruised thighs and sobbing pitifully. All this was a terrible mistake! By his precise plans, he should be safely tucked away in a shipping crate, en route to his trusty nephew Zack. Yet, everything had gone awry. Tommy's early arrival had set into motion the fiasco that Bryan currently found himself. "Damn teenagers... I should of asked somebody more responsible!"

With a sniffle and grunt, he slapped against the ground in anger. Stupid Tommy and his damn friends... This was all their fault!

Bryan found his self-pitying interrupted when...
112122112211221112211211112122.title: Lost

choices: Humongous stone pavers
Hard packed dirt strewn with junk
1121221122112211122112111121221.content:
With a wipe of his nose and a dab of his eyes, Bryan stood up. He felt a wave of determination wash through him. Steel-bound, strong-willed, and undiminishable determination.

"I'm going to get through this! I am going to survive!" Marching forward, he kept his gaze fixed on a pathway leading through the forest of grass. "I made a breakthrough formula, and a remarkable story to tell!"

Truth be told, he was almost parroting a self-confidence tape he bought years ago. He would listen to it on his way to work, but it never seemed to help much. Just telling him to repeat the same lines - over and over.

Until now, he never believed those words. Now they felt powered by his near fatal experiences. More substantial due to the things he had seen and been through. He tapped this new found strength, continuing onward into the jungle.

Minutes of traveling later, Bryan splashed into ankle-deep water. It seemed to coat the ground below. He continued through it, pausing only to take a few (grateful) gulps of the clean, sparkling liquid. Bryan came upon the source when he ducked under a clover leaf the size of a plaza. It was an enormous tubular monument of brown metal and rubber. Easily 30 feet in diameter, Bryan realized what it was as he approached.

"A hose!" His exclamation seemed to echo slightly into the gaping tunnel of darkness. Water steadily trickled from it, babbling into the dirt via a stream no larger than himself. It was a completely insignificant amount of liquid, but more than enough to flood the landscape of his tiny world. He just began to peer into the huge tube when he felt the ground shift beneath him.

"What the....!"

Falling back, he yelped when the waterlogged earth seemed to crack and open before him. The cause of the disturbance revealed itself shortly. Jutting from the ground with tremendous power was a behemoth earthworm. It burst into the air, spraying chunks of dirt and waves of water. Slimy, pink, and squishy, it almost seemed comical. Bryan screamed again, watching the train-sized beast flail around angrily.

Bryan pulled himself out of the water and ran for it. He narrowly avoided being smashed when the gigantic worm slammed down again, burrowing fiercely into the wet dirt. It returned to the surface shortly, appearing to his left. The tiny man screamed at it defensively, darting past large stems of grass in an attempt to escape.

He spotted dry land ahead and leaped onto it, never faltering his pace.

Only many leagues later, did he slow down. Violently panting, Bryan rubbed his arms together, trembling. Once more, he survived the impossible: an encounter with a mega earthworm! It nearly made him laugh, despite himself.

"I was almost killed... by a freaking worm!" He could feel his body calming. "...fucking hell!"

Chocking it to another experience, he decided to rest briefly before continuing. The less time spent in this fucking jungle, the better!

Blades of grass towered over him at every turn. Twisting and jutting into the sky, each one varying between 20 to 30 feet in height. It was surprisngly noiseless. Nary a sound, save for the occasional monster bee soaring overhead, and lazy gusts of wind. Other sounds of unknown origin roared in the far distance occasionally, but nothing worrisome. He stumbled up a low, yet slanting boulder that ended in a drop. An errant blade of grass sloped against the large stone, which Bryan was able to gleefully slide down. It sparked a feeling of mirth in his tiny, battered body.

Rather suddenly, the jungle came to an end. Thickness and colour of the huge grass was his only warning before he found himself looking onto different terrain.
1121221122112211122112111121221.title: Escape the grass jungle!

choices: Gigantic tradesmen are stomping around the lot
A single tradesman is stomping around the lot
1121221122112211122112111122.content:
The liquid had a thick, bordering slime-like consistency and tasted far worse. Bryan gagged and suppressed the desire to heave his stomach.

He managed to swallow a bit of it. The taste was a mix between dirt, something sour, and grease. His body won and he spat a foul mouthful back into the pool.

"Blech...!" Bryan choked, wiping his tongue and lips in an attempt to remove any traces. "That is repulsive! Yuck! Dehydration won't make me THAT desperate again..."

Pulling himself up and backing away from the off-putting pool, Bryan looked around. He was still hopelessly lost. Tangles of dried, browning grass and leaves created a cluster around the clearing. Many choices existed for him to take, but none seemed palatable.

"What the hell am I even looking for? Tommy is probably long gone by now..."

Bryan grumbled, but knew his complaints would only waste time. He needed to make some progress - no matter which direction he took! Taking the nearest route, he jogged under a crumbling leaf canopy and into the unknown. The disgusting pond had been distasteful, yes, but proved to revitalize him and fill him with a feeling akin to confidence.

A twig lay in his path, larger than a stretch of road, but buried enough in the dirt for the tiny man to scramble over it. On the other side, Bryan paused and allowed himself to rest. He felt prideful of his progress. After all, his thin (frail) build had next to no muscle, yet so far he had been able to surpass many over sized obstacles. Bryan began to feel a bubble inside him; real confidence!

"Maybe I actually CAN get through this...!" He allowed himself a pathetic fist-pump. "Nothing can stop-..."

Off in the distance, Bryan heard a strange guttural racket. It sounded deep and big - whatever it was. Then it stopped. Bryan stood frozen and listened with tentative ears. A loud slam echoed dully throughout the gigantic wilderness from the same direction. Other sounds, more indiscernible and slight could be heard.

The sun still shone high and just rightly to be bothersome. Bugs continued their buzzing; gliding to and fro through the open space above. Bryan shaded his eyes and tried to scope out the surrounding horizon. He suddenly remembered how small he was; how vulnerable - and importantly, afraid.

"What now...?"
1121221122112211122112111122.title: A company truck pulls into the lot

choices: Bryan is rooted to the spot
Bryan tries to make it to the fence
11212211221122111221121111222.content:
Bryan looked towards the road, the direction from which the loud slam had come, but he couldn't see anything.

Above the jungle of tall grasses and weeds, he could make out the gap in the fence the teenagers had entered and left through, but behind the fence, other noises began to worry him. A metallic clank rang through the air, followed by another. Metal groaned against metal. Repeated bangs increased in frequency and volume and then abruptly ended in a ding and a loud crashing noise.

The shadow of a dragonfly swept across Bryan, causing him to hide beneath a large hairy leaf. At his size, the dragonfly was the size of a small commercial plane. He recalled that dragonflies are predatory insects, with keen eyesight and vicious jaws that rip their prey apart. Hopefully they only catch flying insects, he thought.

Bryan nearly tripped over a dead stem of grass that lay in front of him like a log. To steady himself, he reached up to the leaf but cut his hand on one of the hairs. "Ow!" That's sharp! Looking up at the plant, he noticed a single tall stem rising from the middle. It reminded him of a palm tree, but instead of green leaves on the top, there were yellow petals. He recognized it as a dandelion. He suddenly noticed a huge, brown, fleshy caterpillar munching on the next leaf. Although it was far bigger than him, he hadn't noticed it. He could hear its munching, but he hadn't noticed it over the din of other sounds. He shivered, wondering what other creatures he hadn't noticed close by.

Another metallic clank assaulted Bryan's ears and to his horror, as he peaked out from under the leaf, he saw a large section of the fence move towards him. The gate was opening towards him. It looked to him like a cliff-face moving on its own. A huge flock of flying insects flew up and overhead as the grassy jungle in front of him was pushed aside by the gate. A butterfly glided by close overhead, the sun shining through its orange and black wings almost like a stained-glass window.

Bryan turned watched the butterfly, awestruck, and wished he had wings so he could get up off the ground where it was dangerous and get back to his house and the potion. Suddenly the butterfly more or less exploded as it was hit from above. Two of its wings came clean off and there was a shower of dust. The dragonfly's wings clattered as they struck together briefly and then it banked sharply as it pulled the rest of the butterfly away to devour. On second thoughts, the air didn't seem to be any safer.

Brian turned around and saw that the head of a man had appeared. Under the black baseball cap, sunglasses and industrial ear protection, he Bryan could really only see this man's long, straight nose and broad, strong jaw covered in stubble. Although at Bryan's current size, everyone looked like an absolute behemoth, he could tell this man was far larger than the four gigantic teenagers who had trashed his house and abandoned him in this terrifying jungle. Brian could only see this man from the chest up, but he could see that he was built like a tank - or rather, a mountain. He was carrying something that Bryan could only see the top of, something orange, and he was he seemed to be pushing something heavy as well. He briefly dropped out of site as he set whatever the orange thing was on the ground and then turned around and pushed the gate closed.

Bryan realized the man had just shut himself in the vacant lot with him. Of course, if Brian had been near enough to reach the fence, he surely would have been able to simply walk underneath it, but what was the man going to do here? Would Bryan be able to attract his attention? Probably not - in this place he was just one bug amongst many, and wearing ear protectors, he would certainly not be able to hear Bryan's feeble shouts. Would he even want to attract this giant's attention? He looked about 30, older and more mature than the college boys who were probably trying to tidy up his house right now, but with his grimly set jaw, he didn't exactly look like the kind of guy who'd worry about the welfare of a tiny bug.

The giant man pulled hard upwards on something a couple of times and a horrible noise started - a loud, rapid hammering accompanied by a frenzied whistling, whooshing sound. The sound was unbearably loud and Bryan stuffed his fingers in his ears. The sound grew even louder and there were shredding and ripping sounds now. The air began to fill with a spray of green particles and even more panicked insects. Slowly, the giant, with his back towards Bryan, began walking along the line of the cliff-like wooden fence. The ear-splitting noise and they spray of green projectiles followed him.

Looking at the back of the man's shirt, Bryan recognized the logo of a landscaping company and put the pieces of the picture together: the man was trimming the edge of the lawn with a weed whacker. As Bryan realized that this meant the giant would probably mow the whole lot, he started shaking with fear. How would he ever survive this?
11212211221122111221121111222.title: A single tradesman is stomping around the lot

choices: Bryan crawls under a tangle of grass stems to the left.
Bryan stays motionless.
112122112211221112211211112222.content:
As the adrenaline rose in Bryan's body, he realized his only hope was to make it out of the lot before the enormous man mowed over him. Thinking about the horrible monsters lurking all around him in the jungle, he armed himself by snapping one of the glassy hairs off a nearby leaf. The hairs on this leaf were bigger than the hairs on the dandelion leaf and it made a fairly convincing dagger. It was basically the only way he could think to protect himself.

He began to run, stumbling over roots and stems of grass, tripping as the stony ground shifted under his feet, dodging hairy leaves and looking around for any threat of insects. He was heading towards the front fence of the empty lot, essentially directly towards the hulking behemoth and the source of the ear-splitting terror. By the time he got anywhere near the fence, he would have moved on from there and he surely wasn't going to trim the same area twice. Although it felt like the wrong direction to run, Bryan knew that, strategically, this was the safest option.

A bee as large as a van took off from a nearby clover flower, causing Bryan to stop abruptly. He realized that it was odd that he could see the individual wingbeats rather than just a blur. Thinking about it scientifically, he realized that, at his tiny size, the distance from one side of his brain to the other, was much, much smaller. Signals could would pass, relatively speaking, a lot more quickly through his brain meaning that his reflexes should be much faster than they were as a normal sized man. This would also account for his perception of everything as happening a lot more slowly than he was used to.

He came into a clearing and suddenly had an uninterrupted view of the enormous man. His huge, hairy calves were planted in enormous work boots, each one more than a football field in length. That meant, with each step, a football field of jungle was being crushed down under his enormous bulk. His massive thighs were mostly bare, covered only at the top by a pair of surprisingly short shorts. As the giant lifted one enormous leg and began to swing it to take the next step, one whole side of his muscular behind tensed and lifted underneath the shorts. Bryan had to stop looking. He was overcome by his own insignificance but knew he had to keep running towards the area that had just been weed-whacked.

As he neared the other side of the clearing, he spotted a line of black ants, each the size of an Alsatian dog but with six legs, antennae, large eyes and two-foot-long mandibles. He gripped his leaf-hair dagger tightly and ran, towards ant line. He stopped just before them and started trying to watch for a break in the line. It was hard because ants were moving in both directions and their movements were much harder to predict than cars.

Just then, the noise of the weed-whacker grew even louder as it hit a large clump of grass and dirt which sprayed up and flew through the air towards Brian. He briefly ran backwards but realized the debris from the melee ahead would overtake him and he'd be safer under the grass. He still had to cross the line of ants though and as he began to consider that again, a strong wind hit him and the pieces began to rain down. There were pieces of grass of all sizes, most of it mangled and barely recognizable, moist on the edges and sticky with sap. Some pieces were as large as sheets of roofing. The smaller ones, when they hit him, stuck to him. As well as that, there were small stones, which he would have called "dust" at his normal size; larger stones, which would be sand and the occasional boulder, which would have been pebbles.

In this onslaught of falling debris, the ants suddenly broke out of the line and began running in all directions. Some of them stopped to pull pieces of grass off themselves. When two ants met face to face, they stopped and tapped their antennae against each other, obviously communicating something. The ants didn't seem to notice Bryan and as he ran through the area where they were running around, he managed to dodge them.

Whack! Suddenly something sticky and hard hit him in the head. He couldn't see as the liquid covered his eyes and frantically pulled whatever it was off and wiped the foul smelling goo from his face. With only one eye open, he realized that he was holding a half-living insect. At his normal size, this would have been a barely noticeable little speck, but to him, it was about the size of a large pigeon. Its abdomen was split open and oozing goo. One of its wings was almost completely gone and it was feebly flapping its stub and the remaining wing. It's antennae were twitching violently and its large, bright red eyes were empty spheres with a mesh-like pattern.

Then he was knocked over by something. An ant had hit him from behind and had clamped his mandibles around his leg. Miraculously, they had only snagged his pants, and hadn't crushed his leg. Thinking quickly, Bryan tried to stab the ant with his dagger. It was no use. The glassy hair of the leaf that he had snapped off couldn't penetrate the ant's armour. Even stabbing its eye seemed to do nothing but annoy the ant, which shook him a bit and sprayed liquid from its abdomen towards him. Bryan thrust the struggling pigeon-fly against the ant's face, just above the jaws and as they opened and shut again on the fly, he got his leg free, rolled to the side and forced himself to his feet and away from the ants.

His left eye, which he had gotten free from the fly's goo, was burning, but the goo had protected his other eye from the ant's acid spray and he simply swapped which eye he had open. He started running and scrambling through the dense vegetation away from the ants and towards the cliff-face of fence palings. He realized he had dropped his dagger in the scuffle with the ant and his his entire body ached. Just then he was hit by a rock in the face. He stumbled backwards and saw stars. He may have briefly been unconscious but he could not tell. His entire body ached and burned and he just wanted to give up. His adrenalin rush turned into an ice cold feeling of dread.

"I'm not going to make it!" he thought. I'm going to be torn apart by ants or mown over or crushed under a boot. He had never felt so powerless and the surge of pitiful anger that he felt towards the four teenage boys, the ant that had attacked him, and had no outlet. He didn't have the energy left to even get up and he began to sob uncontrollably. At this small size, water was much more viscous and his tears were like large balls that he had to physically pull off his face. He noticed that that helped with the burning of his left eye.

Suddenly, the blades of grass in front of his face parted and something like a crocodile the size of a bus burst through the vegetation in front of him and stopped with its car-sized head only snapping distance in front of him. A skink. Tiny pieces of gooey grass clung to its coppery scales which gleamed in the sun. It blinked its huge eyes at him. The sides of its body heaved in and out as it breathed and Bryan could feel its breath.
112122112211221112211211112222.title: Bryan tries to make it to the fence

choices: Bryan waits to think of a strategy
Bryan decides to carfully start climbing
1121221122112211122112111122222.content:
Bryan stayed still - partly because he had neither the will nor the energy to move - he had given up - and partly because he decided movement would convince the lizard he was prey. He had watched Jurassic Park only a few weeks before and the line "their vision is based on movement" rang through his head.

The huge skink suddenly surged forward, its snout bumping Bryan to the side. Its front leg pushed him down against the grass stems he was lying on and its back leg bumped him roughly. Its brilliant blue tail slid past him, coating him in some of the pieces of grass goo that it had picked up. Where it had come from was obviously a lot closer to the terrible action of the weed whacker than he had been. Bryan realized the lizard was probably not interested in food in the least but was scurrying for its life in the jerky stop-start way that skinks have.

Somehow, Brian got to his feet again and started again on his dash towards the fence. It was more of a stumble now than a dash, but he had stopped feeling the pain in his body, his ears or his left eye so keenly. "The adrenaline must be working again," he thought.

By the time he reached the next clearing, he realized the enormous man had trimmed more than half way around the edges of the empty lot. He had seen two more lizards and countless other creepy crawlies, including one enormous centipede, heading in the opposite direction away from the fence line. This was natural, he supposed, as that is where the huge man had been ripping up their habitat, but fleeing into the middle of the grass would most likely ensure their deaths.

Bryan remembered, when Tommy first started mowing his lawn as a fresh-faced 18-year-old, he had initially done the edge trimming last but Bryan had told him to do it first so that the lawnmower would pick up all the trimmings from the edge and leave the lawn cleaner in the end, and to mow from the outside into the middle. This is common practice in the lawn-care business, but Bryan realized now, that also doubtless chased all the little crawling critters in the grass into the center of the lawn where they would not have such a good chance of escaping the lawnmower. He had never cared about such a thing before, but at his current scale, it felt like he was about to be caught up in a massacre of epic proportions. With his human brain, he was probably the only one in the lawn who knew to run towards the edge, not the middle of the lawn. If he thought the lizards and bugs would have understood him, he would have told them "You're going the wrong way! This whole area is about to be destroyed."

As he set out through through the clearing, which was littered with grass debris, he was lost in his own thoughts and didn't notice when the ground suddenly dropped away in front of him. The loose stones he was standing on turned into a landslide which swept him down into some kind of crater. "Am I trapped in the boot print of that giant?" he thought. Suddenly, from the bottom of the crater, something large flipped up, sending a shower of rocks up towards him. As they crashed into the wall of the crater, they unleashed another landslide which swept him closer towards the bottom. When he again came to rest, he got up and tried to climb towards the top of the crater, but his movements unleashed more little landslides and his net movement was downwards. Again, something large reared up from under the rocks at the bottom and hurled rocks towards him. He was partially buried by the rocks, but at this point, his body was beyond feeling pain. Then he saw the jaws.

Rising out of the stones at the bottom of the pit came the front of a head with two enormous, jagged, spiky mandibles spreading apart in a wide V shape. An antlion larva. Bryan remembered being fascinated by them as a child, dropping ants into their pits and watching them struggling to get out and either succeeding or slipping into the center and being devoured by the jaws he was now looking at. "I guess this is karma for what I did to those ants," he thought. "They were just ants ... but now I'm just an ant."

As luck had it, a large piece of shredded grass was right next to Bryan. Being careful not to disturb the loose rocks he was sitting on, which, in reality, were fine grains of sand, he picked up the piece of grass and threw it towards the antlion's head. It landed right next to the head and in one horrifyingly quick movement, the head turned and the jaws snapped shut on the grass. After a few moments of stillness, the head vanished under the rocks again, causing a small landslide which swept Bryan almost to the center of the pit, right above where the jaws had been. He was sitting in the feeding pit of a hungry monster. He was on top of the stones, not buried, and he thought he could probably start moving without disturbing any of the rocks, but any wrong move could send down another cascade of rocks and wake the beast at the bottom of the pit.
1121221122112211122112111122222.title: Bryan stays motionless.

choices: Bryan leaps uphill immediately.
Bryan waits one second then leaps uphill
11212211221122111221121111222222.content:
Bryan started carefully climbing out of the antlion's pit. He checked every stone's stability before he put his weight on it. Any movement made him give up and look elsewhere. The same strategy had made him good at Jenga, but now his life depended on this skill.

The going was slow, and when he was half-way to the top, the roaring of the weed whacker suddenly died away to an eerie silence. "No, no, no, NO, NOOOO! Not yet!" he screamed out loud as though the giant man could have heard him.

He looked around and saw the enormous figure of the man approaching. He was carrying a large stick that must have lying in the long grass. From Bryan's perspective, it was like a mountain carrying a skyscraper towards him. Ordinarily, that would have been a terrifying sight on its own, but considering his precarious position in the death-pit of a horrible monster antlion

As the mountain got closer, Bryan noticed a name embroidered on his company shirt: Josh. "JOOOOOOOOSH!" Bryan yelled, knowing all the while that, even if the volume were loud enough for Mount Josh to hear without ear protectors, let alone with them, his voice would just sound like a tiny high pitched squeak to the enormous man.

As Josh marched relentlessly forward, gazing ahead rather than down, Bryan had a view straight up his nostrils. Josh's enormous legs were bulging with muscles and green with pieces of grass caught in the hairs. Where the legs met, there was a bulge in his shorts that could have concealed a block of apartments. In addition to being terrified, Bryan was humiliated to be so small in relation to another man.

As one of the huge green columns made contact with the ground, the ground shook violently enough for a small landslide to cascade down the opposite side of the pit. Bryan looked nervously down at the bottom, expecting any moment to see the antlion's huge abdomen send a shower of rocks up towards the source of the landslide. That didn't happen though. Bryan reasoned that antlions probably ignore landslides caused by vibration of the whole ground.

Looking back towards Mount Josh, Bryan saw that his enormous right boot was swinging exactly in his direction. It swung up over him, its forward motion began to slow and it started coming down. Bryan looked up at the vicious looking tread pattern as the heel struck the ground. In the arch of the sole there was lettering larger than Bryan's whole body saying "US15".

At the edge of the clearing, some tall blades of grass were pushed forward under the sole of Josh's boot and as these blades were bending down towards Bryan, he realized the inside edge of the boot was right above him. Just before impact, Josh saw that moving just a few feet uphill would take him out from under the colossal slab of rubber and the unimaginable bulk of giant Josh.
11212211221122111221121111222222.title: Bryan decides to carefully start climbing

112122112211221112211211112222221.content:
In desperation, Bryan pushes off from the rocks under him and begins scrambling uphill. The rocks below him on the slope begin tumbling down and as they fall, those uphill begin to fall too. As Josh's size 15 boot makes contact with the top of the antlion pit, Josh is swept helplessly underneath the edge of the rubber sole by the miniature landslide that he started in his haste.

As Josh's huge bulk thuds down into what is, to him, fine sand, Bryan's body is trapped between the rubber sole and the fist-sized rocks. The huge pressure jumbles the rocks and grinds them against one another, forcing them to fill any space available to them. For some of the rocks, the only available space is occupied by Bryan's body, which in comparison to the rocks and the rubber sole, is quite soft. Bryan's tiny body is squeezed and pummeled under the enormous pressures - not to the point that he is crushed completely, as the mass of rocks does have some give in it, but to the point where Bryan's limbs are all dislocated, his spine broken and the fingers of his right hand are ground off between two chunks of rock.

Josh's left boot meets the ground and the huge weight crushing down on Bryan shifts and relents. He begins to bleed and he is briefly stuck to the rubber sole as it lifts. He falls off and lands in sand only inches away in Josh's perspective, crippled and barely alive.

The antlion, having fared only slightly better, unearths itself from its pile of rocks. Its left mandible has been ripped from its face and its abdomen has ruptured. Bryan and the antlion lie face to face, neither aware of the other but only of their own agony. Bryan closes his eyes.

Josh carries the branch to the fence and hurls it over, completely unaware of and unbothered by the death and destruction he causes with every step.

An ant stumbling through the clearing happens across Bryan's mangled body and begins to pull him by his leg towards the nest. Bryan's eyes open again with shock. The ant drags Bryan between tangled grass stems and across a smooth rock. At that very moment, one of Josh's huge boots slams down on the smooth rock. Unlike the mass of smaller rocks, this rock does not give. As the rubber is pressed downwards by Josh's bulk, both the ant and Bryan are flattened into nothing more than a wet smear shared between the rock and the sole of the boot.

Bryan goes back to where he left the weed whacker and finishes trimming the edges before mowing the whole vacant lot. As he finishes, he loads his equipment back into the back of his truck, takes a big drink of water and checks his phone. Out of the corner of his eye, he sees an exhausted baby skink scurrying across the sidewalk in front of the vacant lot, fleeing the destruction he has caused. Without thought or hesitation, he puts his boot on the tiny lizard and scuffs it into non-existence as if it were a cigarette butt. A few moments later, a mother spider carrying hundreds of offspring meets the same fate. He puts his phone away, climbs back into his truck, which rocks as his considerable weight pushes down on the suspension, and then drives away to the next job.
112122112211221112211211112222221.title: Bryan leaps uphill immediately.

choices: Bryan held on to the slightly rough side of Josh's boot
Bryan held onto the blade of grass.
112122112211221112211211112222222.content: Bryan waited until Josh's boot made contact with top of the antlion's pit before leaping uphill. The rocks under his hands and legs began tumbling downhill, sweeping Bryan with them, but the edge of Josh's thick rubber sole had already sunk into what is to Josh nothing more than fine sand. The antlion larva was under Josh's sole. Bryan's downhill slide was halted as he collided with the thick rubber. A blade of grass was pressed down against him and, as the boot shifted and then started to lift ...
112122112211221112211211112222222.title: Bryan waits one second then leaps uphill

choices: Two construction workers arrive at the lot
Someone takes a shortcut through the vacant lot
11212211221122111221121112.content:
In no time, Tommy and his enormous friends cover an enormous distance, leaving the shrunken scientist stranded in the vacant lot.

In none of his over-eager fantasies had Mr. Smith imagined himself tiny and exploring a giant outdoors. He didn't want to imagine it because, even now, his brain began thinking of all the ways he could meet a gruesome end as a bug-sized man marooned in a giant world.

"I can get home again," he told himself. "I can get home, get Tommy's attention and..."

His words stuck in his throat when he climbed to the peak of a mound of pebbly sand. A vast desert of baked red-orange clay stretched as far as he could see. Tough, determined weeds, which now looked like alien trees, provided rare spots of green in the desolate landscape. On the horizon loomed a fence that looked like a strange vertical mountain enclosing the distant perimeter of the lot.

To even escape the lot would represent a major endeavor for a bug-sized man, alone, without any supplies. Fear gnawed at his stomach. The hostile environment looked too daunting.

After the tiny man walked what, for him, seemed a great distance, he realized he wasn't making much progress.

About that time...
11212211221122111221121112.title: Visitors to the lot

choices: Yes, surely they'll see him!
A group of massive ants approach Brian from behind.
112122112211221112211211121.content:
Steven pulled his truck to a halt as he arrived at the vacant lot. He and his co-worker Derrick both worked for a local construction company and were sent to inspect the lot in preparation of the project.

In his mid-twenties, Steven was a hulk of a man. Short-cropped blonde hair, with heavy-set eyebrows shading his eyes on his strong, stern face. His 6-foot-3 frame was clothed in worn work shirt leading to dusty heavy denim jeans, and a pair of muddy work boots with a heavy tread. He was incredibly built from his almost 5 years of construction work. Derrick was of the same stature, but only just having turned 21. He had spikey jet black hair, with a soul-patch on his chin. His tattooed arms were visible from his company t-shirt, and dirty tan work-slacks. The work boots he wore had worn away at the toe revealing the steel-toe on the left boot.

Brian felt the ground tremble as the enormous construction workers began un-loading tools from the mammoth truck. Their movements appeared almost in slow-motion, and their heavy footfall caused slight tremors.

Ant-sized Mr. Smith crouched near a pebble, which easily hid his tiny form, and watched the two behemoths with fear. Should he attempt to contact them?
112122112211221112211211121.title: Two construction workers arrive at the lot

choices: Derrick raises his boot to crush out the cigarette butt
Derrick spits again
1121221122112211122112111211.content:
The tiny man watched the two titans, especially the younger one. The younger giant was as tall as the older one, but he looked much younger. College age at best.

His distant, monumental head was covered with a forest of spiky jet black hair, and he wore a dark soul-patch on his chin. Insanely muscular tattooed arms were visible beyond the sleeves of his company t-shirt. He filled in the dirty tan work-slacks quite nicely. His work boots had worn away at the toe revealing the steel-toe on the left boot.

The enormous titan tilted his face toward the ground.

"He's looking right at me," screamed the elated tiny man. He waved his arms over his head. "Hey! Down here!"

As the bug-sized man gazed up, he heard a harsh, guttural noise. The young cleared his throat and spit on the ground.

Tiny Mr. Smith saw the approaching spit, but was helpless to get out of the way. The slimy spit crashed into him, knocking him away from the safety of the boulder-sized pebble.

"You get the equipment set up here," the older giant said. "I'll start over there."

Neither of them noticed the ant-sized man struggling in the disgusting mix of sand and saliva. Humiliated, he realized precisely how beyond the giant's notice he had become since shrinking himself to the size of a small ant. Still dealing with the slimy mess, the shrunken scientist watched the older giant trudge across the vacant lot. At one point, his step came down on a discard plastic bottle the size of a building. The stomp crushed the container flat and filled the tiny observer with fear.

The older giant was, physically, the more impressive hulk of a man. His towering frame was clothed by a worn work shirt and heavy denim jeans coated by dust. He wore muddy work boots with a heavy tread. Five years of steady construction work had given him an amazing physique.

The speck-sized man's more immediate concern, however, was the younger giant that continued to stomp around in the little man's vicinity.

Only inches from his lowly position on the ground, one of the young titan's massive boot stomps kicked up a maelstrom of dirt, grit and dust that settled over the tiny man's body still drenched with spit.

Derrick had been trying to kick the habit, but with a brief break while he waited for his partner to set up equipment on the far end of the lot, he drew a cigarette from a pack in his pocket and lit up.

As he took in a deep draw of smoke, he kept grinding his boots on the baked clay and gravel.

After the dust had settled from the near-miss, poor Mr. Smith had gotten back to his feet and tried to dust himself off. His clothes were now in a shabby state. But that was the least of his worries.

The young titan kept scuffing his boots along the parched ground. Even if the shrunken scientist had wanted to get closer, the constantly shifting boots would have prevented it.

He finally decided that it was simply too risky to try to approach the giant construction worker. He'd always been intimidated by such men even at his normal size. Now, he felt completely powerless and even imperiled by the giant's presence. The ant-sized man scanned the barren lot for some sort of shelter. He saw a rock that looked as big as a mountain and decided to hide in the shadow of that massive structure until the giants departed.

He had made good progress toward his goal when something flaming and belching smoke dropped from the heavens, almost landing directly on top of him.

The acrid smoke stung his eyes. He saw the glowing end of the huge tube as flame continued to consume the paper and tobacco filler inside the cigarette.

The giant had simply tossed aside a cigarette butt that had almost landed on top of the tiny, unnoticed man.

If Mr. Smith had been a smoker, he might have known what was coming next...
1121221122112211122112111211.title: Oblivious giants

choices: Bryan runs away
Bryan can't outrun them
1121221122112211122112111212.content:
Hunkered behind the car-sized pebble, Bryan considered his options.

"They are so fucking huge..." He said with a trembling voice.

Each movement the gigantic men made sent rumbling vibrations through the hard, packed earth. His eyes flitted from one titan to the other. Their powerful, sluggish motions akin to the Greek titans of history. Hugely powerful and more than capable of extinguishing Bryan's tiny life without even noticing.

The older giant trudged across the vacant lot. His massive hulk seemed so far away, yet still dangerously close. He calmly unscrewed the top and raised a dusty plastic bottle to his lips to drink. Even from so far away, Bryan could both see and hear as the gigantic man swallowed enough water to fill an ocean.

Bryan stepped back, not willing to take his eyes from the titan. "Maybe I should leave," Bryan spoke slowly, taking ginger steps. "If I can find Tommy again, I won't have to deal with these brutes..."

Bryan nodded and turned to begin his retreat. He felt incredibly insecure just looking at the mega-sized workers. Just the mere thought of approaching such giants made the tiny man queasy. Finding Tommy again was surely the better choice. Bryan was assured of this until he saw what waited behind him.

"Ants!"

They skittered across the parched ground with quick steps. Five of them in a loose formation scouting and aggressively investigating all in their path. These creatures presented the already hopeless man with whole new problem. He stood no chance against their superiour size and numbers. His only hope was that they passed by without noticing him.

"Shit!" Bryan squeaked, realizing they were headed in his direction.

Without thinking, he flailed to his immediate right and promptly fell flat on his face. His recovery with quick, but the nearest ant had noticed the movement and alerted it's fellows. He looked into the glinting eyes of each insect, hoping for any sign of mercy. They remained blank. Seemingly devoid of any emotion but basic instinct as they began crawling in his direction.

The thought of dying to these horrific bugs was more than he could handle. Bryan screamed and prepared to run.
1121221122112211122112111212.title: A new problem

choices: Formulate a plan
Approach the massive truck
11212211221122111221121112121.content:
Yipping like a frightened dog, the shrunken man ran like hell.

"Oh, fuck...fuck...oh...fuck!"

His breathless curses escaped between each wheeze, directed at both himself and Tommy for leaving him here. By all rights, Bryan should be safely nestled in the folds of cloth tucked inside a package mailed to his nephew. That was his plan, after all - a flawless one, or so he thought.

"Eeek!" He shrieked. Ducking under another log-sized twig, he stumbled but maintained his pace.

Now he found himself running for his life - from a group of freaking ants! It was humiliating, but Bryan refused to give up.

Daring a harried glance, Bryan realized the ants were gaining on him. The head of the group hissed at him with clashing mandibles, enticing the others to speed up. Six legs to his two, Bryan feared this would be his end.

Too focused on his escape, Bryan was nearly thrown when the ground shuddered suddenly. His body filling with alarm, Bryan felt only confusion as he stumbled. It sounded as if a building had crash landed nearby. Twisting his head back, he took sight of the ants. Their grotesque legs carrying them quickly in pursuit, apparently unfazed by the strange earthquake.

Realizing his staring was costing him precious seconds, Bryan whipped about running.

Another earthshaking crash sent Bryan falling to the side. It was more severe than the last, emitting a guttural crunching of dirt and rock that made Bryan shudder.
This time he looked ahead - and screamed with ghastly vigor. His scream was not directed at the pursuing bugs, or his own situation. It was directed at the colossus that loomed miles ahead.

Not even the Colossus of Rhodes could compare if Bryan had seen it. The calves were massive, draped in a cascade of thick brown denim dusted dirt like the crags of a mountain. Trembling, Bryan felt himself almost falling as he attempted to crane his neck back farther. Barely catching sight of an enormous billowing mass of off-white cotton high above, the terrific sound of grinding, crunching returned.

Lifting into sight, Bryan belted out a note of sheer terror at the mountainous boot soaring overhead.

Bryan devolved into burbling wails, vainly defending himself with wiry arms as light was blocked out by the sole of the giant work boot that was so vast; so wide, that as it lowered itself it removed any other sight. Clods of dirt and pebbles rained down all around, dislodging from deep lugs packed with much more. Gusting air roared, rudely displaced by the monumental boot. It passed slowly, yet somehow moving at a dizzying pace.

While it was still far overhead, Bryan lowered his arms and marveled. Among squashed bits of small foliage, embedded pebbles, and unidentifiable crap, Bryan saw words much taller than himself pressed into the hard rubber, "OIL RESISTANT" and "ANTI-SHOCK" were situated around the mid sole, all circling a brand completely blocked with dried mud and smashed grime. The heavily worn surface of the descending sole seemed to go on forever. It was like a work of an ancient monument, built and constructed, it was so massive.

Bryan was jolted roughly when the huge stomp crashed thunderously behind him. The hard rubber of the work boot, as well as the worn leather, creaked noisily, groaning, flexing, and readjusting constantly as the behemoth owner towered so far overhead that Bryan even fathom just how huge he was.

Scuttling around, he held his breath. The gargantuan boot loomed high, planted only a few dozen feet away. Frayed cords of mud-coated fibers hung down the length of it, hovering just above the dirt-crusted sole. Distant roaring of air announced the passage of the other boot. Bryan watched it soar past, far off that it vanished from view before contacting the ground with a rumbling crash. Bryan's genius mind was reeling. Realization of his utterly insignificant stature returned, chilling him into a constant shiver.

Only a mere moment later, all thought was cut off when the ground trembled, filling the tiny man's ears with a cacophony of grinding gravel; groaning leather; and crunching twigs.

Then, with not an ounce of grace, the huge thing lifted away. With it, much of the landscape was taken; packed deeply into the treads as a mess of unrecognizable debris. Each thick lug creaked and shifted in response to the giant foot controlling it. Chunks broke free, falling noisily as the tread lifted away, leaving the ground branded with a series of huge indentations.

Bryan gazed up as the massive man stomped away, each step emitting lesser quakes, while his massive arms dangled from a torso larger than a city. He wore a cap, facing backwards, with the logo of a local college baseball team. It just made the giant seem all the more surreal.

Helplessness surged into the shaken scientist. For once, he was made aware of his utter insignificance. complete weakness. The colossal man didn't even know he existed. Bryan, a full-grown adult; a scientist....and a freaking genius! And, he had nearly ended up crushed underfoot, crushed with the dirt and mud by the casual step of construction worker.

"He was so big," Bryan said, staring blankly at the expanse of land destroyed by the huge boot. "...no, fucking huge!"

Then he remembered the ants that pursued him so vehemently. Along with many other fauna, they were nowhere to be seen in the aftermath. Bryan wondered just how many tiny creatures - like himself - that were stomped without even the slightest notice on a daily basis. How many bugs had been stuck in those terrifying treads? It made him shudder.

In the far distance, he could see the giant in question speaking with the other giant. Even from such a great distance, looking more like vast towers outlined against the horizon, they were terrifying. With sluggish stomps, they both lumbered towards the massive truck and began pulling things from the flatbed.

"They don't have even the slightest idea...!" From their perspective, this lot was nothing but a barren waste; nothing but weeds and rocks. Bryan knew better. Insects, arachnids, reptiles, and small rodents all called the vacant lot home. "It doesn't even matter to these brutes."

The giant workers were just too huge; too massive in every way to care about such small, and frankly, insignificant lifeforms. They were just doing their jobs, unable to appreciate the destruction they wrought in the process.

"Fuck...there has to be a better way..." Bryan stood, still shaking but recovering. "Screw the bugs! I need help, and they are my only option!"
11212211221122111221121112121.title: Insignificant

choices: Giant intervention
Bug food!
11212211221122111221121112122.content:
His feet slid clumsily in the dry dirt. Scampering around the boulder he had been hiding behind, Bryan looked for any means of escape.

He saw the younger giant stomping around in the far distance. "Oh, God! Please, help me... I don't want to die!" The humongous worker ignored him. Both uncaring and oblivious to something so small as Bryan.

Behind him, the three insects made quick passage. Climbing over any obstacle with relative ease, and closing in on the fleeing scientist quickly. Unlike Bryan, they were completely adapted to such terrain: easily passing large boulders and climbing hills that would exhaust any human. Bryan was at a ridiculous disadvantage to these big insects.

Dropping off the edge of a desiccated leaf, Bryan came upon an enormous nail laying like a fallen tree in the dirt. He approached it, wondering if he might be able to use it, but groan loudly. "Crap," He kicked the side of the almost train-sized nail. "If I was maybe an inch taller, I might be able to use it! I'm too damn small!"

Then he heard the bone chilling clash of pincers behind him as the ants appeared over the crest of the dried leaf. Bryan screamed, looking at each one in-turn, nearly falling to his butt. All of them larger than automobiles and capable of tearing through much more than just his soft flesh.

"Stay back!" He motioned fruitlessly at them - waggling his hand, then both arms defensively. "Away with you bugs!"

The ants were unmoved by this and moved expertly into position to neutralize the tiny fidgeting man.
11212211221122111221121112122.title: Surrounded

112122112211221112211211121222.content:
"AAAAIEEEEE!!!"

One of the revolting ants lunged at him like a car at full throttle. It dug two sharp pincers into the ground next to him, splintering a twig he had been huddled against not a moment before.

His breathing increased as his mind raced. The idea that he was surrounded by nothing but mere ants was incredulous. They encircled him as a gang of ruffians would trap a would-be victim. Bryan looked from ant to ant, imploring their dark bulging eyes for any mercy.

"Please... Go away! Leave me alone, I can't die like this! I'm not bug food!"

Too preoccupied with his vain pleas, he failed to notice one ant approaching from behind. It scuttled across the uneven dirt, underneath a tree-sized twig, and fell upon the unsuspecting scientist with clashing mandibles.

Bryan screamed when the cruel appendages closed around his arm. They held tight, allowing him a momentary struggle before clamping hard with a sickening snap.

Pain shot through his broken limb, burning him like nothing he had ever experienced before. He cried out, using his other arm to defend, but found it useless as the ant merely dropped him to the dirt. Bryan glared up at the huge insect, misty-eyed with a bloody nose. The creature showed no sympathy as it lashed again. Both long, jagged pincers wrapped around the shrunken man's thin waist and lifted him like a toy doll.

Blinded by pain, he continued screaming. Bryan felt his voice grow quieter with each cry. He wanted to live. No matter how unhappy, or how difficult his life had been, this was far worse of an end than he could ever have imagined. He had discovered the impossible, for God's sakes! The ability to shrink living matter without a single repercussion. It was worthy of many awards; worthy of a new award, in fact.

But, he would never benefit from it, Bryan realized. His vision blurred as the ant roughly transported him increasingly limp body over the rough terrain, headed for an impressive hill in the near distance. Looming past in, miles away, but framing the ant hill almost perfectly, stood a gigantic worker. Bryan blinked at the oblivious titan. The gigantic man would never realize that a human life was coming to an end not more than six feet away from him. Moaning, the defeated scientist succumbed to his trauma and fell unconscious.

---

The ant scampered up the grainy hill, accompanied by the rest of the hunting party from behind. Other ants paused with curious clicks and bobs, swishing their antennae at the interesting pink creature held between the ant's pincers. Food had been scarce, so any discovery caused excited stirs in the burgeoning colony.

A distant quaking signaled the movement of a humongous human nearby. The ants took note, but ignored the rather common disturbance.

Nearing the top, the ant brushed antennae with a bulkier soldier ant and quickly descended inside to offer up the strange prey as a boon to the queen ant.
112122112211221112211211121222.title: Bug food!

112122112211221112211212.content:
Tommy considered simply scooping up the bug and depositing outside Mr. Smith's home to live out its life.

But, with his impatient friends hounding him, it seemed a little too much effort for a stupid bug.


"OH MY GOD! JUST STOMP IT, AND BE DONE WITH IT," Joe said again.

Tommy tossed the shard of pottery aside.

"What's he doing?" The terrified little scientist wondered.

As much as he hated taking orders from his two so-called friends, especially after they had wrecked so much in Mr. Smith's home, Tommy realized they had a point. There were thousands of bugs in the world. What was one more in the greater scheme of things?

"ANY DAY NOW," an exasperated Andy said.

Mr. Smith listened in horror as the merciless teenaged titan coldly encouraged Tommy to finish him off.

He prepared to run, but he could see no avenue of escape. The shrunken scientist tried one more time, shouting Tommy's name, imploring him to look closer. "It's me!" Mr. Smith screamed. "Just look!"

In a casual motion, with no particular urgency, Tommy raised his foot above the tiny bug trapped on the floor among the shattered segments of Mr. Smith's broken lamp.

"No!" The teenaged titan's bug-sized neighbor screamed.

From the boy who had always run his errands and helped out with household chores, Tommy had been transformed into a fearsome executioner.

The other two teenagers, frankly bored, barely watched as Tommy, finally goaded into action, prepared to stomp.

The shadow swallowed him up, and the tiny man looked upward to see the onrushing rubber sole of the massive shoe. He made one futile attempt to throw up his arms to ward off the inevitable impact.

In the end, it really wasn't much trouble to squash the bug.

Tommy didn't even feel too guilty. The stupid insect had just seemed to await its fate when trying to escape would have made more sense.

He figured it simply didn't recognize him as a threat.

At least, despite all the other accidents, he had rid Mr. Smith's home of one less pest.

Turning to his friends, he asked, "So, now what you guys wanna do?"
112122112211221112211212.title: Not-so-humane Tommy

choices: Joe puts the glass down, planning to take the bug home later
Joe takes a look at the bug
11212211221122112.content:
"Nah" says Tommy and Bryan breathes a sigh of relief.

"I'm just gonna throw it down the sink," Tommy says and Bryan leaps to his feet.

"Wait," says Joe, coming over to Tommy. He puts his hand on top of the glass. Bryan can see just a few kinks of light coming through the gaps between the giant teen's fingers.

"My brother needs to collect bugs for a project for school," Joe says, "I'll take it later."

Bryan shrieks, "I'm not a bug!" But from the depths of the glass, under Joe's huge hand, he still can't be heard.

Tommy shrugs and hands the glass over to Joe.
11212211221122112.title: Saved?

choices: Tommy says yes, Joe takes the glass.
Tommy says no, Joe has to find another way to carry the bug.
112122112211221121.content:
"Don't let me forget about it," Joe says, and puts the shot glass down on the mantle of Bryan's fireplace. Bryan sat down at the bottom of the glass, stunned by this turn of events.

He looked up to the top of the glass. The tiny glass was much too high for him to try to scale, and it was up way too high for him to try to tip over. He was stuck here until one of the boys came for him.

He watched them enjoy watching TV and steeled himself for what would happen when the boys were going to leave. It would be his only opportunity of staying at the house, of trying to get them to understand what had happened.

A cell phone rang. Joe answered it.

"Yeah, OK, I'm coming now," he said, standing up and stowing the phone.

"Sorry guys, gotta go early." He had just made it to the door when he turned back.

"Oh yeah, that bug," he said and Bryan swore he felt the floor shake with each step Joe took towards the tiny man.

With horrified fascination, Bryan watched Joe's form get larger and larger, distorted though it was through the glass. He reacted even more when Joe's outstretched hand began to approach the glass.

He was knocked off his feet when the giant teen picked up the glass.

"Hey, Tommy, can it take it home in this?" Joe asked, holding out the tiny shot glass.
112122112211221121.title: Waiting Game

choices: The shot glass tips over
Joe arrives home
1121221122112211211.content:
"Tommy! No!" Bryan shouted. He tried to stay on his feet on the smooth glass flooring of the bottom of the shot glass. "You can't let him take me!"

"Sure," Tommy said. "Just bring me back the shot glass later."

"You got it, man," Joe said.

The giant teenager's fist completely encircled the tiny shot glass, blocking Bryan's view of the outside world and, in turn, keeping Tommy from seeing him.

The giant youth only notice of the shrunken man thus far had been to mistake him for a bug. Now, it would seem, Bryan's next destination rested with some kid in need of bugs for a school project.

Once Joe reached his car, he stashed the shot glass in a plastic cup holder. The tiny shot glass didn't come close to filling up the space within the holder.

Bryan, knowing this turn of events signaled nothing good for his prospects of getting back to normal size, kept trying to shout at Joe. The tiny man simply could not make himself heard, especially once Joe started his car and cranked up the radio.

Through the transparent walls of the glass, Bryan saw other items inside the cup holder, including spare coins and an opened roll of breath mints. The coins, including several pennies, a nickel and two dimes, dwarfed the tiny man. He also stared inside a tunnel formed by the tube of mints.

He looked up from the bottom of the shot glass and saw Joe's huge body as the enormous teenager strummed his fingers on the vehicle's steering wheel.

"What should I do?" Bryan asked himself.
1121221122112211211.title: Going Home With Joe

choices: Bryan is thrown towards the seat...
Bryan is thrown towards the pedals...
11212211221122112111.content:
Joe began to crank his radio up real loud, and Bryan felt very, very frustrated. "JOE!" he yelled. He remember his name from before. "JOE?" But it was useless now, with the radio.

It was very hard to attempt to get attention, especially with the bumpy road. Bryan was frequently thrown around the tiny shot glass. They had only been driving for a short while when suddenly, Joe hit a speed bump.

Bryan screamed from the shock, as the shot glass flipped. He felt himself go airborne, flying towards Joe.

He tumbled through the air, first striking the knee of Joe's jeans. Bryan clung for stray strings, frays, anything - but there was none. He fell all the way down, below the seat.

There was a throbbing pain in his head, but Matt was otherwise unharmed. He pulled himself up to find himself on a fuzzy material, which he quickly discerned to be the car matt. Then, with a realization, Bryan remembered where he was.

Joe looked like a god to Bryan. In fact, he looked like a king on a throne, and Bryan, he realized, was at his feet.

Literally. Turning around, he saw two huge structures: Joe's Adidas Airwalks. They were more than 100 feet tall, and 300 feet long. Joe's feet looked huge enough to be buildings.

They were stationary for only a moment, and then Joe began to drive.
11212211221122112111.title: On the Car Matts
