Tommy stopped by a little early
11212211221122112211221.content:
Thrilled to be back to normal size, scientist Bryan Smith around his home for the rest of the day, marveling how only a few hours earlier everyday objects had been almost overwhelming in their immensity in contrast to the diminutive size to which he had shrunk.

"I won't repeat that experiment any time soon," he vowed as he glanced at his watch.

When he saw the time, he remembered his promise to the boys to reward them with dinner. "I better get a move on," he said.

He headed to the bedroom to change his clothes, but as he disrobed, he began to feel strange. The room began to spin and he felt himself collapse again as he rapidly lost size.

Even when, to his horror, he found himself shrunk again, the sensation of change didn't cease.

Completely dismayed, he felt the spasms of transformation as his body continued to change. Unbeknownst to him or the teenagers he had sent to the lab to obtain his antidote, this particular batch had become contaminated when a tiny winged insect blundered into the vial.

Now, with the DNA of a gnat added to the antidote, the weird transformation sped up. The tiny man felt his body change as he grew the six wiry limbs of an insect and wings sprouted from his back. In no time, for all intents and purposes, the brilliant scientist had been reduced to the status of an insect in his very own home. Not simply the size of an insect... he was one!

That wasn't the worst of it! As he desperately tried to adjust and navigate yet another solution to a brand-new dilemma, he heard the opening of the front door to his house.
11212211221122112211221.title: Weird reaction

choices: The guys decide to order pizza and hang out in Mr. Smith's home
Tommy and Joe decide to pick up the pizza and then come back
112122112211221122112211.content:
Poor Mr. Smith didn't have time to adjust to his sudden transformation into a gnat before the entrance of next-door neighbor, Tommy, along with Tommy's sullen friend, Joe, made the baffling situation much, much more complicated for the unfortunate scientist.

Their entry into his home was accompanied by gales of hurricane-force wind and a terrific amount of noise as their sneakers tromped over his floors. In addition, Tommy called out for his neighbor in an extremely loud voice.

Once again tiny in size, Mr. Smith's situation was made all the more untenable because of the fact he was a mere insect with a gnat's wings, body and six legs. He would have been unmistakable from other bugs if not for the fact that his transformation had spared his head, leaving him with the a puny face attached to an insectoid's winged form.

He tried to use this to advantage by flying directly toward Tommy. He could still speak, after a fashion, although his words were soft, shrill and rather buzzy.

"Tom-meee. Help mere!" The tiny human-gnat hybrid buzzed as he drew closer to the two enormous teenagers.

"Well, where is he?" Joe grumbled. "You think he bailed on us?"

Tommy shrugged, then noticed something on the table.

"Maybe he left this for us," picking up the twenty dollar bill.

"Why would he leave that?"

"He's a busy guy, and maybe something came up," Tommy said. "Hey, we could use it to order a pizza or something!"

Joe looked dubious.

Mr. Smith had forgotten that he'd left the money on the table, but he had simply been counting out if he had enough cash for the dinner he had promised the boys for their efforts at securing his antidote from the lab when he had been shrunken.

Of course, that same antidote appeared to have left him in an even worse situation.

Determined to be heard and/or seen, he zipped through the air, making his way closer to Tommy's huge face.

His buzzy wings and swift movement, however, caught the attention of Joe, who swatted at the insignificant, pale bug and grumbled, "Your neighbor's got a fruit-fly problem, dude!"

Tommy just rolled his eyes as Joe tried repeatedly to swat at the gnat, missing each time.

Ignoring his friend, he walked over to Mr. Smith's fridge and found the number to a pizza place on one of the advertisement magnets plastered on the side of the appliance.

"Quit acting like an idiot," Tommy said. "What you want on a pizza?"

While the two titans huddled to discuss pizza toppings, Mr. Smith took stock of the situation after barely evading several swats from Joe's unfriendly hand.

"If I'm not careful, I'm going to end up pulverized," he realized.
112122112211221122112211.title: The guys are ready to be taken to dinner

choices: Try to get Tommy's attention
Pizza and wings... messy, sticky food
1121221122112211221122111.content:
Tiny Mr. Smith flew away from the two titans as they contemplated ordering a pizza to be delivered to Mr. Smith's home.

"How about some chicken wings, too?" Joe tempted his buddy.

With increasing frustration, Tommy's tiny, transformed neighbor listened indignantly. "They're only thinking about food," he whined. "I've been turned into a stupid bug probably because of some mistake they made at the lab, and they're just wanting to have a big party!"

Even as he held out hope Tommy might prove sensible, his teenaged neighbor disappointed him. "Sure," Tommy said. He dialed the phone and quickly placed an order for a large pizza with an order of wings.

The tiny man watched from the kitchen counter near the toaster. He thought back on the perilously close swats from Joe's definitely unfriendly, gigantic hand.

"He could have crushed me!" The tiny man-turned-gnat realized with despair.

Across the room, Tommy ended his phone call. "Food should be here in 15 minutes," he said.

"Great," Joe responded. "Let's get comfortable."

"All right," Tommy relented. "But don't make any messes. If Mr. Smith gets home, I don't want to get him mad at us."


"He left that money there for us to have some fun, right?" Joe prodded. "He's not going to mind us watching his television and having some food."


Infuriated, all Mr. Smith could do was listen helplessly while trying to think of a new plan for contacting Tommy. If he could only find a way to communicate his problem, he was certain Tommy could return to his lab… this time to fetch the correct antidote.

"I just have to make sure I don't get crushed by one of them in the meantime," he whispered to himself while keeping a wary watch as the two teenaged titans made themselves at home in his living room.

He got his first opportunity when the delivery guy arrived with the pizza. With his houseguests distracted, he flew into the living room and looked for a place to lift his profile slightly in the eyes of the two teenagers.

He watched Tommy pay the delivery guy, who often brought deliveries of food to Mr. Smith. "He's huge!" The little man exclaimed as he hovered in the air watching the scene.

Soon enough, the delivery guy left and Tommy and Joe returned to the living room with their pizza and wings.

Tiny Mr. Smith was waiting patiently until he saw that Joe was lowering a stadium-sized pizza box right on top of his spot on the coffee table.

"Oh no!" He cried, taking flight as the huge cardboard box crashed down onto the tabletop.
1121221122112211221122111.title: Gnat among Titans

choices: Recognizes Mr. Smith
Game gets exciting and he puts down the magnifying glass
11212211221122112211221111.content:
Joe found two large mugs in Mr. Smith's cabinet. While Tommy removed some slices of pizza from the box, Joe took two bottles of beer from the fridge belonging to Tommy's neighbor. By the time Tommy had arranged pizza slices on two plates that he put on the coffee table, Joe arrived with the mugs filled with ice-cold beer.

"What's this?" Tommy asked sharply. "Beer? From Mr. Smith's fridge?"

"Relax, the old guy isn't going to miss a couple of cans," Joe said. He lifted his mug and clinked it against the one he presented to Tommy. "Besides, he owes us. We saved his shrunken butt, remember?"

Tommy, although doubtful, enjoyed the cold beer with the hot, delicious pizza. The boys also enjoyed the chicken wings, licking the spicy, flavorful sauce from their fingers. As they ate, they enjoyed a game on Mr. Smith's high-def television, with the volume cranked up to the max.

As a result, even when the tiny man flew around their heads, his new wings buzzing in protest at their disrespect for his home and property, they could not hear him.

He was simply too small to make himself heard, even when buzzing only inches from the side of Tommy's colossal face.

"Tom-mee! Pe-lease! Help mee!" The little gnat-guy screamed as loudly as he could into one of Tommy's cavernous ears. "It's mee! Mr. Smith!"

With the loud volume of the television, Tommy detected only the faintest of a high-pitched, buzzy whine that prompted him to raise one of his hands with fingertips stained with the sauce from the chicken wings. He waved his hand in an irritated gesture at the side of his face, generating terrific air currents that buffeted his tiny transformed neighbor.

For Mr. Smith, trapped in gnat form, it was like a sudden hurricane. He dived lower, desperate to evade the terrific winds.

At the same time, Joe finished off his beer and noticed his buddy swiping a hand at a pale, almost invisible flying insect land on the coffee table between the pizza carton and the container of chicken wings.

With a triumphant gesture, he turned the large glass mug upside down and brought it down suddenly atop the tiny bug.

"Hey! Got the little pest!" Joe proclaimed.

"No! Lemee out!" The terrified little gnat with Mr. Smith's head yelled. He stared through the thick glass and saw the greasy streaks from Joe's sauce-stained fingers on the other side of the transparent prison.

Tommy didn't even look away from the television screen. "Big deal. What you gonna do with it now?"

Joe shrugged and looked through the glass. He had to strain to detect the tiny, pale winged bug. "It's a little pest! What do you think I'd do with it? I'm gonna crush it!"

"Tom-mee! No! Don't let him crush mee!"

Thanks to a lull in the game, Tommy deigned to turn his head and look down at the trapped gnat. After his experience with his shrunken neighbor, he'd gotten better at paying attention to tiny details.

"Something's odd about this bug," he said.

The enormous teenager lifted himself off the couch and walked toward a book shelf at the other end of the room where he had spotted a large magnifying glass with an ornate brass handle.

"I think I should have a better look…"
11212211221122112211221111.title: Trying to make contact

choices: Mr. Smith changes... but not in a good way
Mr. Smith is human again...but still tiny
112122112211221122112211111.content:
Joe continued to give baleful looks at the tiny insect trapped beneath the enormous glass mug. With a grunt, he brought his hands together in a mighty clap, demonstrating his intentions both to his friend and the tiny, terrified gnat.

"That's what I'd do with the pest," Joe said, chuckling.

Tommy, picking up the ornate magnifying glass from the book shelf, rolled his eyes.

"You can do that just as soon as I have a look, OK?"

"No! It's me!" The horrified little bug-man tried to scream. His wings buzzed as he made a swoop around the confines of the glass before settling his six tiny feet once again on the curved glass.

Tommy's eye on the other side of the lens was magnified to even more epic proportion as he stared at the magnified insect and got the shock of his life.

"Oh my god! You've gotta see this!" He said in excitable tones to his buddy.

Joe grimaced but accepted the magnifying glass. He stared through the lens and saw the tiny winged bug... and its human head.

"Is that..."

"It is," Tommy said. "It's Mr. Smith!"

Listening with immense gratitude, the transformed scientist felt once again obliged to thank his teenaged neighbor. "Yes, thank you!" He buzzed. "I knew I could depend on you!"

"Why's he half bug?" Joe got down to the critical question.

Tommy shrugged. "Don't know... Unless... Yes, that must be it. That formula we used to grow him back must have had some side effect."

The scientist-turned-bug continued to stare from beneath the enclosing glass. "At least let me out of here!"

Almost as if he could read his mind, Tommy lifted the mug. "Sorry about that," he said sheepishly.

Mr. Smith used his gnat wings to buzz closer to the boys. He landed atop the TV remote resting on the coffee table, sensing their eyes fastened on him as he did so.

"There should be more of the formula left," Tommy said. "Maybe another dose can put things right."

"I'll get it," Joe volunteered.

Mr. Smith was wondering if it could be that simple. In fact, he had almost decided to reject another dose of the formula when Joe returned and handed the glass vial to Tommy.

When Mr. Smith looked skyward, he saw Tommy's huge hand tilt the vial enough to release a single drop of formula. The huge drop plummeted toward him, slamming into him and knocking him off his perch near the remote's on/off button.

For the tiny gnat-man, it had felt like getting hit by a truck.
112122112211221122112211111.title: Recognition

choices: Joe discovers Mr. Smith is gone and he is babysitting a real bug
Mr. Smith tries to avoid Joe until Tommy returns
1121221122112211221122111111.content:
Although the result of a drop of formula falling on him felt like being slammed by a 100-pound bag of wet cement, Mr. Smith shook off the pain when he realized that his body had started tingling.

The formula seemed to be working!

"I think something's happening," he shouted in such a feeble voice that there was no way the teenagers looming overhead could have heard him.

Tommy brought the magnifying glass down for a look, but sighed in frustration.

"Nothing's changed..." The teenager said. "He's still half bug, half Mr. Smith."

"That sucks," Joe said. "But we tried..."

"I need more of the formula," Mr. Smith decided. He hadn't imagined the tingling sensation. He flew from the TV remote and hovered near the vial in Tommy's hand. "Please, more of the formula!"

"What's he doing?" Joe wondered.

Tommy's thumb was positioned over the opening to the vial, blocking access to the formula.

The tiny bug-man hovered higher and stopped in front of Tommy's face. "Try again!" The tiny man shouted.

"Here, take this," Tommy said, handing the vial to Joe. Tommy then held out his hand, palm facing up. "Come here, Mr. Smith."

Frustrated, Mr. Smith did as Tommy commanded and landed on the strange, warm surface of the teenager's hand.

"Don't you worry," Tommy said. "We'll figure something out."

He heard Joe's scoffing noise. "What do you think you can do?"

Tommy glared at his pessimistic friend. "Well, we can at least keep him safe," he reasoned. "I don't even want to think of all the things that could happen to a tiny bug, uhhh, I mean guy."

"Well, I'm thirsty," Joe said, heading toward the kitchen.

As he moved past his friend, he stirred up air currents that slammed into Mr. Smith and blew him off Tommy's palm. Once free of the treacherous breezes, the tiny bug-man returned to the remote on the coffee table. Tommy's eyes followed every twist and turn in his neighbor's flight. Once he saw that he had landed safely, he excused himself.

"You wait here! I want to speak to Joe in the kitchen."

A disappointed Mr. Smith obeyed. A moment later he heard raised voices from the kitchen as the teenagers once again disagreed.

"I don't want to babysit a bug," Joe said.

"Dude, it's my neighbor," Tommy countered.

"Exactly! Your neighbor, not mine."

At the same time, Mr. Smith felt tingling again. He didn't realize that things had changed until Tommy returned. As he looked up, he saw multiple versions of his gigantic teenaged neighbor looming over him.

The formula had worked, but not as they had hoped. Mr. Smith's human head had been replaced. He now stared at Tommy with the multi-faceted compound eyes of a true insect.

"Mr. Smith, I am going back to your lab," Tommy explained. "But Joe is going to stay here and make sure you stay safe."

Tommy's words slammed into him.

"Wait! Tommy! Don't leave me here.... Not with him!"

As he stared up, multiple versions of Tommy's huge buddy also came into view. Joe frowned, obviously a reluctant participant in Tommy's latest plan.

"I'll be back soon," Tommy promised.
1121221122112211221122111111.title: 100 percent Gnat

choices: During a commercial break, Joe pays more attention to the bug
Mr. Smith feels more and more bug-like
11212211221122112211221111111.content:
"Wait! Tommy! Don't leave me here.... Not with him!"

As he stared up, multiple versions of Tommy's huge buddy also came into view. Joe frowned, obviously a reluctant participant in Tommy's latest plan.

"I'll be back soon," Tommy promised.

Mr. Smith zoomed into the air, using his tiny wings to carry him toward the departing Tommy. "Please, don't go!" The transformed scientist buzzed in a futile gesture as the gigantic teenager opened the front door. "Tommy! No!"

The door slammed back into its frame, and the tiny man-turned-insect hovered on his frail, transparent wings. He couldn't believe that Tommy would just so casually abandon him to the careless attention of…

He turned and saw Tommy's equally gigantic friend Joe turn his head in his direction. The teenager's face scowled as he saw the bug flit through the air, so small it looked no more than a mobile speck.

"JUST DON'T GET IN MY WAY AND WE'LL BE FINE," Joe said in a loud voice. "WE SIMPATICO?"

Mr. Smith felt offended. The ill-mannered youth was standing in his house, acting like he owned the place and got to set the rules.

In a huff, he flew over the vast landscape of his living room coffee table, eventually landing on the cover of one of those freebie arts and entertainment event magazines he always picked up during visits to the grocery store.

His tiny wings made the slightest whiny buzz, hardly noticeable, but enough to set Joe's nerves on end.

The teenager swept an empty plastic cup on his hand. "AND I AM NOT LISTENING TO THAT UNTIL TOMMY GETS BACK."

With no additional fanfare, the teenager slammed the transparent plastic cup down on the tiny bug, entrapping it.

"What the…" Mr. Smith buzzed in outrage. He banged energetically against the plastic walls until he tired out his tiny body.

Joe ignored the little bug. He had said he would keep watch over Mr. Smith, not keep him entertained.

The tiny scientist finally landed on the cover of the magazine once again. He was infuriated with Tommy for entrusting him to his imbecile friend, but his emotions seemed to have little affect.

"I'll just have to wait for him to get back," the little bug-man realized.

But Joe...
11212211221122112211221111111.title: Hands-off Joe

choices: Determined to practice some pest prevention
Fly to his bedroom to hide
112122112211221122112211111111.content:
"I'll just have to wait for him to get back," the little bug-man realized.

All he could do was stare through the plastic walls of the makeshift prison as Joe, his legs kicked up on the coffee table, watched a boring game on the television.

He should be furious with Tommy for entrusting him to this moron, but that seemed uncharitable since Tommy was, presumably, out there trying to find something that could help him.

He had been so caught up in his thoughts that he hadn't noticed the lull in the game and the fact that Joe had lowered his huge mug directly in front of the plastic cup to stare at him.

The teenager's lips twisted back into a grimace. "Gross, you're just too freaky, bug-man."

Mr. Smith felt his wings buzz. He hovered beneath the plastic dome, determined to try to communicate with the enormous teenager.

"Just let me out," he wanted to scream in anger. "I refuse to be kept prisoner in my own home."

"Oh, fuck," Joe exploded, noticing something a bit off about the bug. "That's what I get for listening to Tommy. Sitting here taking care of a real bug."

He had noticed, with his casual scan, that this bug lacked Mr. Smith's human head.

"No! That's a side effect," the transformed scientist tried to scream. "It's really me."

With a surge of irritation, Joe swept his hand over the coffee table, smacking the frail plastic cup off the table and to the floor.

He then stood from the sofa and raised one of his sneakers over the cup. He grinned as he brought the shoe down, hearing the crunch that was louder than the irritating, high-pitched whine produced by that fucking bug.

Mr. Smith had managed to escape the displaced plastic cup, but his wings were beginning to slow. He had been a long time without food and was starting to get weak.

But when he heard a malevolent chuckle and gazed up, finding something to replenish his energy became the last thing on his mind.

"There you are, little shit," Joe said and raised a huge hand to smack the gnat out of the air.

With the shock of fear as motivation, the tiny transformed man flew in the opposite direction. He just needed to stay out of reach long enough for Tommy to return. He clung to the hope Tommy would rescue him.

"Not getting away that easy," Joe warned as he lumbered across the room toward him.
112122112211221122112211111111.title: Joe gets mean with a bug

choices: Sprayed and squished
Joe misses, which just make him angrier
1121221122112211221122111111111.content:
The shock of seeing a teenager the size of a mountain suddenly lurching across the room toward him left Mr. Smith, who had been transformed into a pathetic bug, shocked and confused.

He didn't know what course of action would prove safer, not with a titanic, suddenly malevolent teenager bearing down upon him.

Why had Tommy ever trusted this moron to look after him?

Although the questions screamed in his head, answers were much less important than actions. As Joe careened toward him, an enormous hand raised to swat him like the bug he had indeed become, a twitch of his wings took the tiny, transformed scientist toward the ceiling, beyond even the reach of his neighbor's titanic friend.

"Be still, you little pest," Joe growled as the object of his pursuit flew toward the ceiling.

Mr. Smith wanted to scream at the gigantic, potentially deadly teenager to get out of his house. It was so unfair to be chased and ridicule in his own home by Tommy's less than markedly intelligent friend.

"Don't think that this means you're getting away from me, little shit," Joe shouted at the flying bug.

Concerned, Mr. Smith turned his attention to the titan, who walked toward the kitchen. Keeping at what he considered a safe elevation, the transformed scientist kept watch over the teenager's actions.

Joe pulled open cabinets and drawers, looking for anything he could employ in his arsenal as he made war on a single, solitary, tiny bug.

The teenager's chuckling at a discovery sent chills through the transformed scientist's body. When Joe turned toward him, the tiny bug-man could not help but notice the towering canister of bug spray.

"This should put an end to you, you filthy pest," Joe promised as he tried to pinpoint the gnat's location as he prepared to spray the contents of the can with the insect's direction.

"No!" The tiny transformed man screamed. It was all just so unfair he thought as the teenager sprayed a stream of the lethal insecticide in his direction.
1121221122112211221122111111111.title: Pest Prevention Measures

11212211221122112211221111111111.content:
The transformed scientist choked and gagged as the stream of insecticide drenched his tiny gnat body.

His wings began to falter, sending the bug that had been a scientist toward the kitchen tiles. He tried to focus his eyes, but then wished he hadn't looked up and saw the enormous teenager crouched over him, prepared to spray him with another blast of the incapacitating toxin.

"Joe, no! It is me! I'm still changing!" The scientist did his best to communicate with the arrogant and terrifying teenager.

"It's one thing taking care of Tommy's stupid neighbor who went and got himself turned into a half-bug, half-man hybrid, but I am not going to start babysitting real bugs!" Joe bellowed as he placed the can of bug spray on Mr. Smith's kitchen table.

The spray had done its work, knocking the pesky bug to the floor. The feeble little creature's wings twitched.

The floor tiles shook with each step taken by Joe and his enormous Airwalks.

"Oh god no!" The scientist realized. "He's going to do it! He's going to stomp me!"

Tommy would be back soon, hopefully with some way of reversing the change. "Just don't crush me!"

The teenager raised his enormous shoe over the tiny bug as the entire chain of events that had brought him to this moment raced through Bryan Smith's frenzied brain.

"Time to die, you little bastard," Joe said, stomping down. He grinned and then ground the sole of his sneaker on Mr. Smith's tiles.

Lifting the shoe, there was very little left of the irritating gnat. He did see a single tiny limb as it continued to twitch spasmodically.

"Ooh, gross," Joe said, just as the back door opened and Tommy returned.

"I have good news," Tommy said, without any realization of the irony.
11212211221122112211221111111111.title: Sprayed and squished

choices: Joe feeds the tiny gnat to Tommy
Mr. Smith escapes the sticky foam
11212211221122112211221111111112.content:
Joe sprayed the insecticide, but the stream of toxin fizzled and finally evaporated without even getting close to the buzzing bug.

"What the hell?" He shook the can and tried again. "Empty! Well, dammit."

He angrily tossed the huge can toward the transformed scientist, relieved by the unexpected reprieve. The gnat-man's tiny wings helped him easily evade the tossed can, which crashed noisily into the wall.

The dent in the wall, however, just made the tiny man-bug even more angry. "Who are you to come in my home and start trashing the place?" But his fury simply made his wings vibrate faster, causing the buzzing sound to increase in a way guaranteed to further irritate Joe.

"I'm going to get you," Joe swore. "Stupid little pest."

Joe flung open the door to the refrigerator, plunging his entire head and shoulders inside to look for something useful. He saw something interesting. With a big grin, he grabbed the item and cocked his head to listen for the tell-tale buzzing.

The transformed scientist had moved to a countertop in the kitchen, landing on the rim of a white ceramic bowl for a brief rest. Evading the angry teenager had sapped his energy.

Unfortunately, Joe spotted him and the tiny bug-man found himself facing another towering spray canister.

"Joe, you idiot," he buzzed futilely. "It is me! I'm not really a bug."

Joe just heard the irritating buzzing and squeezed the trigger. Tiny Mr. Smith saw a white cloud of foam erupt from the red and white can. As the foam enveloped him, he tumbled into the bowl as Joe continued to empty the contents of the dairy whipped cream.

Joe laughed when he saw the tiny gnat engulfed in a sea of the whipped cream at the same moment Tommy returned. With a gleam in his eye, Joe shouted, "Hey, buddy. Want an ice cream sundae?"
11212211221122112211221111111112.title: Angry Joe

choices: Fly into the drawer
Fly to the bathroom
1121221122112211221122111111112.content:
The tiny gnat-man knew that, if Joe caught up with him, things wouldn't go well. No, not at all. So, without any more delay, the transformed scientist flew out of the kitchen, determined to stay one step ahead of the enormous teenager.

With his wings tiring, the tiny gnat-man headed toward his bedroom thinking that familiar territory would provide him some hiding places for keeping a low profile until Joe tired of looking for him or Tommy returned. He wished he had found some food in his kitchen prior to Joe's ill-mannered interruption. Flying to evade Joe's determined hunt had depleted his energy reserves quite severely.

As his wings slowed, the buzz grew somewhat erratic, which instantly attracted Joe's attention. His teenaged eyes fastened on the pale speck zipping through the hallway of Mr. Smith's house.

"A-ha," he yelled aloud. "Found you."

As the behemoth thundered down the corridor, Mr. Smith ducked into his room, which was made accessible to him thanks to an open door. Unfortunately, the open door was also an invitation for the disrespectful teenager to barge into the room, being no great respecter of privacy.

As he buzzed around his now gigantic room, the tiny transformed scientist scanned desperately for a place to land, rest and stay out of sight.

He was flying over his bed. The blue and black covers looked like a vast plain beneath him as he used his weakening wings to stay aloft.

He knew if he didn't land soon, his wings would fail and he'd plummet out of the sky.

He spied two possible hide-outs. One was his nightstand next to the bed with the drawer open enough to easily admit the entry of a tiny, insignificant gnat. The second choice involved trying to keep his wings moving long enough to reach the adjacent bathroom.

His decision was forced upon him when Joe walked boldly into the room, boldly wondering aloud where the damn bug had gone.
1121221122112211221122111111112.title: Hide out in his bedroom

choices: A few hours later...
Several weeks later...
11212211221122112211221111111121.content:
His tiny wings failing, his energy nearly spent, the gigantic teenager still in hostile pursuit, the transformed scientist managed with his ebbing strength to fly across the vast savannah represented by the blue and black bedcovers before he began to descent into am enormous, shadowy chamber.

The interior of his drawer reminded him of the scenes from a recent viewing of a documentary on the burial chambers of some of the ancient Egyptian pharaohs. When his six tiny legs landed on the "floor" of the bottom of the drawer, he raised his eyes to peer out just as Joe's colossal shadow cast the drawer and all its contents, including one tiny gnat, into utter darkness.

"I heard it go in here," Joe said, scanning the area around Mr. Smith's bed, stubborn in his pursuit of the tiny insect. "I'm not going to let that pathetic insect get away!"

"Please, don't let him find me," the tiny scientist-turned-bug hoped, knowing that he lacked the strength to evade the lethal teenager another time.

After scanning the room, especially the area around the bed, a frustrated Joe lashed out, slamming closed the drawer of Mr. Smith's bedside night-stand.

Inside the stand, Mr. Smith barely had time to realize what was about to happen as a teenager's gigantic fist violently slammed closed the drawer serving as his hiding place.

In the dimly illuminated interior, the tiny bug buzzed weakly as it sought an escape only to realize all possible exits were denied him.

"Oh no! I'm trapped!" The transformed scientist realized. His energy reserves spent, he faced a bleak future marked by lack of resources.
11212211221122112211221111111121.title: Into the drawer

choices: Tommy returns
Back yard surprises
112122112211221122112211111112.content:
The little insect crawled over the inside surface of the upturned plastic cup, which Joe had used so effectively to imprison the transformed scientist.

The little bug, formerly a man, seemed to forget more and more of its humanity as it allowed itself to perform more and more insect actions.

He awoke once, alarmed to find that an entire chunk of time had just passed without his knowledge, after an excited Joe bumped the plastic cup as he celebrated an impressive on-screen accomplishment by one of his favorite athletes as he watched the game on the big screen that belonged to his best friend's occasional employer.

"What's happening to me?" The tiny transformed scientist wondered. He felt very apprehensive about these mental lapses.

Joe turned off the television, in a good mood now that his team had won a victory. He looked down and smiled as he reached out to tap the plastic cup.

"You wanna stretch your wings?" The enormous teenager asked the tiny bug-man.

Excited, the transformed man watched an enormous hand lift the plastic prison, freeing him to fly toward the mothership-sized light and ceiling fan in the middle of the living room.

He let his little wings allow him to hover over one of the wide fan blades, finally coming to rest in a delicate landing that let all six wiry limbs make contact with the wide surface.

Joe's eyes flashed, but he dropped the vial into a large bowl on the table that held coupons, a set of keys, a tube of breath mints, and assorted other trivial items from Mr. Smith's daily life.

"Let's go," Tommy said. "I'll stop by tomorrow to see if there's any word from Mr. Smith."

Neither of the teenager saw the floundering insect struggling to stay afloat inside the glass confines of the vial.
1121221122112211221122111111122122122.title: A Break?

choices: Mr. Smith tries to reach the antidote
Joe notices that Tommy is tracking a gnat and finds it before Tommy does
11212211221122112211221111111221222.content:
If it wasn't scary enough finding himself transformed into one of the most insignificant of insects, now poor Mr. Smith faced the prospect of being squished by one of the two teenaged titans making themselves comfortable in his own home.

His impulse to confront Tommy, to demand the attention necessary to regain his lost humanity, evaporated when he saw Joe squish a tiny gnat.

Even worse, Tommy had told Joe to do it — to wipe out the blameless gnat.

He had decided to hide and live to fight another day when Joe picked up the bottle of antidote. He sniffed of the contents and grimaced. "That stuff smells like your old gym shoes!"

"Then why did you take the damn stopper off?" Tommy replied distractedly. He had zeroed in on the whiny buzz of another gnat and followed the tiny insect to a landing on a windowsill.

Joe put the vial and the stopper back on the tabletop.

"Yes," the little bug-man celebrated, realizing that Joe had neglected to place the stopper in the antidote container.

With a stealthy approach, Tommy, in the meantime, got close enough to the windowsill to confirm the gnat was a true insect, not one with Mr. Smith's tiny face on its body. Before the little bug suspected his intent, Tommy crushed it with a casual swat of his hand.

"Down one more," he said wearily to Joe.

"This could take forever," Joe said. "Why don't we just grab a can of bug spray and wipe them all out at one time?"

Tommy sighed. "Because, numb-skull, we don't want to kill Mr. Smith, too! What if he's here somewhere?"

Joe scowled. After a moment to think, he retorted, "Yeah? If your nerdy neighbor's here, why doesn't he just show himself?"

Tommy frowned, whether from Joe's remark or from the fact he heard another gnat buzzing, and answered, "I've thought about that."

"And?"

"Well, again, if you had simply kept track of him..."

"Not that again!" Joe complained.

"Well, this isn't helping anyone. Maybe Mr. Smith got hurt..."

Joe scoffed. "Maybe a bigger bug ate him."

"Damn, that's cold, Joe!"

"Well, it's the truth. It's a bug-eat-bug world for someone stupid enough to change himself into a gnat."

"He didn't do it on purpose," Tommy said. "There was a problem with the antidote."

"Well, he shrunk himself to the size of a bug," Joe countered. "Same difference. Strange, if you ask me."

All the time, Mr. Smith listened with dismay to the way the teens discussed him. Nevertheless, he tried not to let them distract him from his purpose. He used his tiny wings to transport himself over the kitchen table. He hovered, trying to determine if he could land on the lip of the glass vial and access the antidote, all without getting noticed by one of the dangerous teenaged titans.

Tommy kept tilting his head. He now heard the distinct buzzy sounds of two different gnats in differing locations in the room. He continued to listen to Joe put down Mr. Smith for his crazy experiments, grunting an occasional "Uh-huh" to keep Joe from interrupting him while he tracked down the two tiny insects.
11212211221122112211221111111221222.title: Scared of his Saviors

choices: Mr. Smith renews efforts to contact Tommy
The boys pile brown bananas into a bowl as bait
112122112211221122112211111112212221.content:
Ignoring Tommy, Joe took out his phone and decided to conduct a Google search on gnat. As he scanned the results, Tommy kept trying without much success to pinpoint the location of the irritating insects he continued to hear.

"It could take forever to get rid of all the gnats that aren't Mr. Smith," Tommy groaned.

Joe chuckled. "It won't take forever," he predicted confidently.

"Huh?" Tommy asked, noticing that his buddy was huddled over his phone.

"Gnats live only about a week," Joe said.

"Just a week!" Tommy exclaimed. "That's awful!"

Joe shrugged. "Says they die after they lay hundreds of eggs," he said.

"Don't be a moron," Tommy said. "Mr. Smith isn't going to be laying eggs. He's not female."

Joe chuckled. "Hey, guess you're right about that."

"Guess what their scientific name is?" Tommy said. He had now used his own phone to do his own research.

Joe snapped, "How the hell do you expect me to know that?"

"Says gnats belong to the super-family Sciaroidea," Tommy said, butchering the proper pronunciation.

He kept reading. "They are attracted to damp soil and over-ripe fruit," he said. "Maybe we could put out some brown bananas to get all the damn gnats in one place."

"Yeah," Joe said. "And then we can wipe them all out at the same time!"

"No!" Tommy exclaimed. "We have to find Mr. Smith first, you moron."

"That was implied," Joe said dryly.

In the meantime, Mr. Smith had overheard their conversation with increasing alarm, especially the part about having only a week to live. In six to seven days, if Joe didn't squish him first, he would drop dead of old age!
112122112211221122112211111112212221.title: Mr. Smith tries to reach the antidote

1121221122112211221122111111122122211.content:
He saw the world around him in disjointed flashes. He felt his hyperactive brain sending out messages...he could even feel a wiry leg twitch or a wing flex in response.

He had done his best to avoid Joe, the careless one. He had trusted in the conviction that Tommy would be careful, attentive and less bloodthirsty than his moronic but deadly friend.

"It should have worked," he wailed in his mind since he lacked the capacity for human speech. He couldn't even tell the teenager of this mistake, that he really wasn't a bug and that Tommy, to the tiny gnat-man's horrified surprise, had just squished him.

Well, squishing might have been a nice way of phrasing what the frustrated teenager had done to the unfortunate scientist in one of those teenaged mood swings brought about in a fateful moment of pique.

When the tiny gnat-man had locked his tiny faceted eyes on Tommy's huge face and saw the two dark eyes staring back at him, his heart had soared. "He has to recognize me!" Mr. Smith told himself confidently.

Instead, Tommy took one glance and saw that this gnat, too, lacked his neighbor's human head, having no way of knowing that the erroneous antidote had fully transformed the ill-served researched fully into a common gnat.

From his vertical perch on the wall, a jubilant Mr. Smith launched himself into flight, singing Tommy's praises as he flew toward the massive teenager. "I knew you'd find me and figure it out," he tried to convey through the sibilant buzzing of his wings. "I knew...."

His moment of relief had been so unfairly short-lived. In an instant, his relief had turned to horror when a hand bigger than a building lashed out at him, smacking him back against the vertical surface of the white wall and smearing his tiny gnat form into some mangled components.

But, if he had expected a quick end, Mr. Smith was cheated yet again.

His tiny head continued to observe and, although without success, transmit messages to other parts of his tiny insect form that had been streaked in a gory display of abstract art on his own wall.

Joe came into view. "Is that one more down?"

"Yeah," Tommy said, heaving a deep sigh. "For just a second, something told me it was the one. But it was just another fucking stupid bug like all those others. I don't think we're ever going to find him. You're probably right. Some other fucking bug probably had Mr. Smith for its dinner."

"Well, you tried," Joe said. "Want to go play some video-games?"

Mr. Smith groaned in horror in a brain that went on functioning although the gnat's head had been physically severed from its smashed gnat's body. The inane workings of Joe's brain, which so quickly lost interest in the situation, felt like the final insult.

"Eew! Fuck!" Joe said and moved his enormous, slack-jawed face close to the twitchy remains of the bug smeared on the wall. "It's still moving, man."

The tiny eyes in the head registered the look of utter disgust on Joe's face. Was that going to be the last thing he ever saw?

Joe saw the tiny mangled wings adhered to the wall a short distance from the head and a section of the body with a few wiry legs still attached. "You really made a mess of this stupid bug," Joe said with admiration.

"I guess we should keep looking," Tommy said, but with such an obvious lack of conviction that Joe picked up the hint.

"Wouldn't you rather go back to my place and play video-games?"

No! It seemed so unfair. Tommy could at least act as if he cared!

With another sigh, Tommy agreed. "Doesn't seem much point now."

Joe laughed. "Besides, I was thinking of something.

Mr. Smith groaned in his head as things started to get cold and foggy.

"Well, Mr. Smith was already an old guy, right?"

"He was in his thirties, I think."

"Well, maybe that meant the formula turned him into an old gnat," Joe theorized. "You saw on that website they only live about a week. Mr. Smith was probably so old that he had like some kind of insect heart attack and keeled over dead."

Sometimes, Tommy didn't understand how Joe's brain worked. But, it seemed a better alternative than poor Mr. Smith getting eaten by a bug.

Mr Smith groaned. He was going to die and the last words he would hear were the inane thoughts of one of the world's most stupid teenagers.

"Guess we'll never know," he said, turning away from the smear on the wall that, unknown to Tommy and Joe, showed the true end of the brilliant if unlucky research scientist.
1121221122112211221122111111122122211.title: Should Have Worked

choices: Eggs
Something Else
1121221122112211221122111111122122212.content:
"This was a great idea," Tommy said as he placed the bananas into a bowl. At best, one of the bananas retained a somewhat yellow peel marred by large brown blotches. The other peels had already taken on brown and black hues as they advanced into their ripeness.

"Yeah," Joe agreed. "This should bring every little gnat and fruit-fly in the place swarming to the bowl."

"So, what do we do now?" Tommy wondered.

Joe shrugged. "Let's watch some TV," he said. "I love that huge-ass screen."

The boys left the kitchen, leaving behind a very worried Mr. Smith. Was he only tired or did his feeling weary mean he was getting old for a gnat and that much closer to his death at the pitiful age of seven days?

Distracting him from his own morbid thoughts was the awareness of the fragrant scent of the over-ripe bananas in the bowl. His gnat instincts took over and he buzzed over to the bowl.

He wasn't the only bug with the same idea. Dozens of other gnats swarmed and buzzed around the bowl. Some landed and feasted on the juices of the decaying brown peels. Full of energy and already excited by the intense aroma of the bananas, some of the gnats began to pursue other interests. In no time, the swarm continued to grow and to whirl in a massive, loosely organized ball of insects. Poor Mr. Smith found himself trapped near the center of the chaotic assembly of bugs.

One of the other gnats landed on him.

"Get off," Mr. Smith cried and tried to shake free. The clinging bug caused him to tumble into a knot of bugs. The other insects swarmed on top of him. "Get off me! What are they doing?"

Disturbed by the free-for-all, he was even more aghast when his scientific mind put the facts together. The gnats were in a mating swarm!

Another gnat landed on the tiny gnat-scientist.

"Why me?" Mr. Smith buzzed.

"Oh no!" Mr. Smith realized. "Oh, please no!"

The chance of fate had caused the formula to transform him. Another quirk of fate had also arisen when the gnat that had fallen into his formula and corrupted it to begin with had been female.

"No!" Mr. Smith tried to fly away, but several excited male gnats clung to him and pulled him back down into a swarm of fellow winged insects.
1121221122112211221122111111122122212.title: Bait

choices: Eggs
More Males Swarm to Mr. Smith
11212211221122112211221111111221222121.content:
Mr. Smith felt the swarm of gnats gather around him, piling onto him, nearly crushing him with their combined weight.
At the same time, the game ended. The boys got onto their feet. "It was a boring game, but I love watching anything on your weird neighbor's huge-ass television set," Joe said.

"We should check the bowl of bananas," Tommy said.

Meanwhile, Mr. Smith had made it as far as the countertop when he felt weird. He has a spasm of pain in his guts and was forced to make an emergency landing just as the boys entered the kitchen. No matter how many times he saw them, he could barely accept how huge they had become. Beings of wanton destruction, they could not destroy him on a whim and never realize it.

"I've got to get to Tommy," Mr. Smith realized. "He's my only chance of getting back to human form."

He watched the boys get closer. Tommy grabbed a magnifying glass and began scanning for gnats. The swarm had not quite dispensed.

"These bananas were a great idea," Tommy said. "It's attracted a swarm of these little pests."

He swiped one into his fist and examined it with his magnifying glass. "Not Mr. Smith," he said before indecorously squishing the insect.

After he eliminated about a dozen other gnats, his interest level waned. He put down the magnifying glass.

At the same time, Mr. Smith felt the pain in his guts worsen. Was this it? He had heard the boys discuss how gnats lived seven days or less. Was he having the gnat equivalent of a heart attack? He remained worried when he heard a familiar buzzing. One of his fellow gnats had found him again.

A moment later, Joe now held the magnifying glass. "Hey, Tommy. Come look at these two bugs."

Tommy walked over and squinted down. "I just see one bug."

"No, they're two," Joe said. "They're connected! I think they're having sex."

Mr. Smith cringed at the thought, but the other insect remained determined.

"That's gross," Tommy said. "But at least we can get rid of those two."

"No!" Mr. Smith cried. "Tommy! It's me!"

Joe laughed. "Dude, this is so weird," he said. "Look, the male is making love to the female."

Tommy squinted again. "Which is the female?"

"The bottom, of course, you moron," Joe said.

"It can't be true!" Mr. Smith screamed, as the stronger male fruit fly held him in place all the time on the top.

"Tommy, please. Get him off me!"

For Mr. Smith, it was a humiliating discovery. He was female as well as an insect, and the overly zealous male fruit fly kept raping him repeatedly with the two teenagers making fun of him as they watching from above.

Joe leaned closer and studied the bugs with the magnifying glass. "This is really interesting," he said. "I think the female enjoys it."

Tommy felt totally grossed out.

"Joe, just please stop it. This is gross!"

Joe shrugged and continued. "Hey look, I think this is the moment when they are..."

"Would you shut up already?" Tommy said. "No one wants to see two bugs having sex. Just squish them."

Joe made an effort to swipe at the bugs, but the male buzzed off and the littler bug got blown off the countertop.


"Huh, where did they go?"


"You moron!" Tommy exclaimed. "Now the female will start to lay eggs in Mr Smith's kitchen."


"Yeah," Joe said. "And then we can wipe them all out at the same time!"

"No!" Tommy exclaimed. "We have to find Mr. Smith first, you moron."

"That was implied," Joe said dryly.
11212211221122112211221111111221222121.title: A New Discovery

choices: Tommy returns and examines him
Joe returns and squishes him
112122112211221122112211111112212221211.content:
Joe's casual swipe could have been disastrous for the humiliated scientist turned bug. The fumbled effort, which lacked Joe's full enthusiasm, only knocked the tiny insect to the floor. He had been too distracted to use his power of flight.

The worst part of one humbling discovery after another had been his rape by another insect. Well, that and the discovery that his own tainted formula had also turned him into a female gnat.

Even as he tried to buzz his wings and take to the air, his body felt heavy and bloated. As with the total lifespan of his new form, all physical processes seemed wildly accelerated. Once again, the scent of the over-ripe bananas seized control of his instincts. Mr. Smith flew to the bowl and landed on the soft exterior of some of the enormous browning yellow fruits. His tiny insect form probed for particularly soft spots. He didn't seem particularly hungry and wasn't sure why the banana peel held such fascination until he felt the long tube extend from his abdomen. He felt something both pleasant and unpleasant as his insect guts re-arranged with the extension of the tube.

He felt pressure all along the tube that was finally relieved as something passed from the open end. The process repeated itself a couple of times before the tiny bug screamed. "I'm laying eggs!"

Driven by his instinct for procreation and the survival of his insect kind, he continued to pump out more of the eggs triggered by the rape from the male gnat. He groaned, from pain, from pleasure, from the mortification from his dull human awareness of exactly what he was doing.

He was only midway through the depositing of his eggs in the slowly decaying peel when...
112122112211221122112211111112212221211.title: Genetic Imperative

11212211221122112211221111111222.content:
The more he thought about it, the more Joe resented having been conned (at least that's how he felt about it) into babysitting for a nerdy scientist with no more common sense than to get himself transformed into a stupid bug.

He tried calling Tommy to voice his complaints, but the calls went right to his friend's voicemail. "Whatever," Joe declared aloud inside Mr. Smith's house. "I am outta here."

The skinny teenager pushed back some brown hair that swept over his forehead as he headed toward the backdoor. It was bad enough the tiny bug-man had crawled all over his sandwich. It had — almost — made Joe not eat the sandwich. But, he had shrugged it off. Most teenage boys will ignore quite a lot before losing their usually hearty appetites. Joe was no exception. Considering the amount of food he could put away each day, it was good he had a metabolism that kept him as a skinny, lazy, arrogant teen.

When he slammed the back door behind him, Joe noticed a swarm of pesky bugs fly from the open trash can. The stench from the garbage held in the can smacked him in the face.

"Gross," he said, slapping randomly at some of the buzzing gnats and flies. One of the tiny insects seemed slower than the others, which made it easy for Joe's hand to swat the little creature right out of the air.

For Mr. Smith, it was like waking from one nightmare and landing in another bad dream. As his human mind regained control, his first sight to greet him was the image of Joe's enormous hand heading right toward him. The violent blow knocked him out of the air and onto the hard concrete sidewalk running through the yard to the back gate.

"Oooh…" the tiny gnat-man groaned from the brutal crash. But he had no time to deal with any aches or pains as an enormous shadow fell on him.

In panic, the transformed scientist looked skyward in time to see Joe's looming form just as the teenager lifted a foot to take a step along the walk.

The shadow blocked out the sun, and the tiny gnat-man would have screamed, if possible, as the dirty sole of the shoe crashed down.

"No! Don't…"

BOOM!

That should have been the end, but by some tortured twist of fate, the tiny gnat's body was left mangled and broken.

On his way toward the gate, Joe stopped when he saw his friend approaching.

"Where are you going?" Tommy asked.

"I've had enough of bug-sitting," Joe said.

"But where's Mr. Smith?" Tommy asked, confused. He had been excited to return. He had a vial in his pocket that he hoped would help return Mr. Smith to his true form.

Joe shrugged. "Your neighbor's disgusting," Joe said. "He was acting like a real bug, so I've had enough."

Tommy cursed as Joe pushed past him and walked through the gate. Then, he shrugged off Joe's behavior as typical for his friend.

He pulled the vial from his pocket and looked at the potential antidote.

Far below, the tiny gnat, wings nearly torn away, buzzed weakly. "Tommy! It's meeee! Help!"

Tommy started toward the back door.

Of course, he could be excused from failing to notice when one of his dirty sneakers stomped down on an insignificant bug, finishing the job that his friend had started.

The antidote, as it turned out, would have worked… if only Mr. Smith had survived long enough to receive it.

He ended up, instead, simply crushed flat, stomped not once but twice by one well-meaning teenager and his friend who could not really have given a damn.
11212211221122112211221111111222.title: One-two Punch

11212211221122112211221111112.content:
Tommy opened the back door, but then returned to the kitchen table. He placed the magnifying glass that he had kept in his hand down on the table. "Don't guess I would need this," he said.

He also chose to issue one last warning to Joe. "Don't fuck up," Tommy said.

Joe rolled his eyes. "How hard can it be to babysit a bug?"

Unfortunately, the door had remained open the entire time, admitting a host of winged insects from the backyard.

Tommy, keys jangling in his hand, made his exit without bothering to reply to Joe.

Mr. Smith, thinking a low profile might be wise, buzzed his wings and flew off the remote. He hovered past Tommy's sullen teenaged friend and headed to the kitchen. Joe wasn't in the least concerned to see him go.

"Don't get into anything that's gonna take me to save your sorry bug-ass," he said as the tiny bug-man flew out of the room.

Steamed by the teenager's insolence, Mr. Smith vowed to have a long talk with Tommy about his choice of friends once this dilemma was solved.

The flight from the living room to the kitchen tired him, so he came to rest on the windowsill where a filter sunbeam warmed his tiny insect form. He felt lazy and reasonably secure, even drifting off to sleep. He didn't hear the buzzing of other wings as another gnat, introduced to the home during Tommy's departure, flew around the room and eventually made its way toward the living room.

With his focus on the television, Joe didn't bother to pay much attention when he heard a faint buzzing and saw Tommy's bug-man neighbor return. The tiny insect landed on the coffee table near Joe's huge socked feet.

"Better watch out," Joe teased. "Little pest like you wouldn't stand a chance against these." The teenager wiggled his toes for emphasis, the movement disturbing the gnat, which flew to the far side of the coffee table.

"Suit yourself," Joe smirked. "It's not like you're fascinating company."

His stomach rumbled loudly like a train rumbling slowly along its tracks, motivating the teenager to get to his feet. "Don't guess you mind if I grab a snack?" Joe directed his question at the mindless bug. When he didn't get a response, he shrugged. "I didn't think so."

In the kitchen, Mr. Smith continue to sleep on the warm, sunny windowsill, oblivious to Joe's entry into the kitchen. He would have kept sleeping, dreaming of an idealized Tommy, who unable to restore the tiny man to human form, had agreed to look after him. In his dream, the shirtless teenager let the tiny bug-man rest on his chest against his right nipple. Beneath him, Tommy's skin warmed his body and the powerful strum of the teenager's heart beat reverberated through him.

"Don't you worry, Mr. Smith. You'll always be…."

And then the loud crash had interrupted the dream, alarming the tiny transformed man. He saw Joe across the room. The colossal teenager had kneeled in front of the fridge to clean up a mess he had created by dropping a building-sized container of onion dip.

"This is the moron he leaves in charge?" Mr. Smith thought to himself as he buzzed his wings and flew over to investigate.

Already upset by the mess, Joe heard the buzzing near his ear and snarled, "I thought I left you in the living room."

Confused, Mr. Smith flew a few feet and came to rest on a narrow strip of granite in front of the deep, stainless steel basin of his kitchen sink.

He watched as the teenager made a half-hearted attempt to clean up the mess. Standing tall again, Joe grabbed something off the table and stomped toward the sink.

"What is it you want?" Joe growled, raising up the magnifying glass in order to get a better look at the tiny creature.

Mr. Smith felt Joe's stale breath blow over him, causing his wings to vibrate.

"I don't want anything!" The tiny transformed scientist tried to communicate. He saw multiple versions of the enormous teenager through his faceted eyes.

"Wait a minute!" Joe proclaimed, getting a revealing look through the thick lens of the magnifying glass. "You're just some bug."

Mr. Smith heard the words with a sense of shock. He was still trying to interpret them when Joe grabbed something else — the morning's newspaper — from the kitchen table. The teenager rolled the paper into a huge tube.

Remembering he had left Mr. Smith safe and sound in the living room, Joe declared, "No way in hell I am going to babysit real bugs!"

He lifted the newspaper high into the air.

"Noooh!" The transformed scientist cried in anguish as the titanic teenager brought the rolled up paper down on top of him.

••••••

Tommy found Joe with his socked feet propped on the coffee table when he returned about a half hour later.

"You been sitting here the whole time I've been gone?" Tommy asked.

Joe shrugged. "What if I have?"

"Well, where's Mr. Smith?"

Joe, eyes still fixed on the TV, just grunted.

"Joe, where is it?" Tommy asked, his voice rising in concern. "I mean him, dammit. I gotta quit calling him an it."

Joe grabbed the rolled up newspaper and handed it to his friend. Tommy glanced at the paper tube and saw a blotch of red. When he looked closer, he felt sick.

"What did you do? Did you smash Mr. Smith?"

"Sorry. I forgot that he turned himself into a fucking bug."

Tommy looked pale as snow.

"You idiot!"

Joe broke down into laughter. "So totally worth it! You should see your face, man."

"Joe, this isn't funny," Tommy said. "What did you do?"

"Oh, shut up," Joe said. He shoved the magnifying glass at his friend.

Tommy used the lens to get a closer look. He saw the smashed remains of a tiny bug but, most important, or so he though, there was no tiny human head. It was a real bug.

"How stupid you think I am?" Joe asked. "It was a real bug, not your weird neighbor."

"Well, where is he?"

"I think he flew away and hid after what I did to his friend," Joe joked.

Tommy continued to stare at the carnage on the newspaper. Some of the wiry, thin insect legs continued to twitch.

•••••

Mr. Smith didn't know how much time had elapsed since the huge, powerful teenager had slammed the destructive newspaper on top of his tiny, frail form.

He only knew that Tommy had returned. He saw his teenaged neighbor's huge form, although the multiple images kept blinking in and out. He tried to buzz his wings, but they no longer worked.

Where had Tommy gone?

He thought he buzzed a question, but it went unheard. He gazed up, and saw Tommy's naturally youthful face twisted into a disgusted grimace.

"Sorry I yelled at you," Tommy told Joe, who just smirked at him.

"Whatever, dude. So, any luck at the lab?"

"No," Tommy said. "That's why I need to talk to Mr. Smith."

Once again, the fading scientist made a renewed effort. "Tommy… I'm here… I'm… hurt… help me."

Tommy saw at least two of the tiny bug's legs twitch. "Eew, you didn't do the job right, Joe."

"You always gotta complain, don't you?"

Ignoring his friend, Tommy shouted, "Mr. Smith! I'm back! Where are you?"

The loud words obstructed the tiny scientist's attempt to get back to the pleasant dream.

"Well, fuck this!" Tommy said, disgusted by the twitching, mashed bug.

He raised the newspaper and brought it down with a thunderous slap, finally succeeding in obliterating even the last remains of the pesky insect.

Once again, he called out for his neighbor.

"Mr. Smith, I'm back. Don't worry about stupid Joe. I'll protect you."

A thorough search later turned up another gnat, but like the one they had destroyed with the rolled-up newspaper, this one, too, lacked a human head. They never did realize what had happened to Mr. Smith because they failed too realize that the scientist's formula had worked just a little too well.
11212211221122112211221111112.title: Misplaced Trust

choices: Joe grabs a magazine and lifts the mug...
The game resumes and Joe loses interest in the bug...
112122112211221122112211112.content:
The transformed scientist watched with increasing optimism as his gigantic teenaged neighbor, holding a huge magnifying glass in one hand, loomed over the upturned mug that effectively held Mr. Smith prisoner.

Staring through both the walls of the glass mug and the lens of the magnifying glass made Tommy's eye look both blurry and enormous.

"Tom-Mee! Help mee!" In his impatience and excitement, Mr. Smith began buzzing around the confines of the glass prison.

"Little pest won't stay still," Tommy growled in aggravation as he tried to follow the gnat's movements with the magnifying glass.

Realizing his mistake, the little man flew back to the side of the glass, landing near a sticky droplet of beer that still adhere to the sleek wall.

"Look at this!" Joe interrupted, clearly excited by action happening on screen in the game.

"No! Wait!" Mr. Smith tried to plead.

Tommy put the giant magnifying glass on the table next to the mug that held his transformed neighbor a helpless prisoner.

Tommy rejoined Joe as they watched mesmerized as their team mounted a valiant, unexpected comeback.

"What a play!" Joe shouted, punching his friend's shoulder.

"That was something!" Tommy agreed, having all but forgotten the strange, tiny insect.

Mr. Smith could not believe how close rescue had been. If Tommy had only looked at him with the assistance of the magnifying glass, he would surely have noticed his teeny, still-human head.

"Oh, please, come back," he whined.

Almost in response, Tommy moved. The teenager left the couch, and Mr. Smith felt his heart racing! This could be the moment he had been awaiting…

"I've got to go to the bathroom," Tommy told his friend. "Yell at me when the time-out's over."

The teenager's enormous form walked right past the trapped, transformed scientist without so much as a second look.

Joe, bored with the lull in the game's action, did notice the overturned mug and the tiny, flitting gnat held trapped.

"Might as well deal with you," the bored teenager announced.
112122112211221122112211112.title: Typical teenaged attention span

choices: Look for food in the kitchen
Explore elsewhere in his home as the boys watch the game
1121221122112211221122111121.content:
Mr. Smith was ready.

The on-screen competition has resumed, motivating Tommy to suggest Joe leave off his attempts to squish the bug and return to enjoying their game viewing.

I did beat the teenaged moron!

He zipped away from the huge teenager, deciding he needed to think more carefully about contact with someone capable of squishing him like a proverbial bug.

"Where'd they go?" He wondered.

••••••

"Does he think I wanted to make myself a bug?" Mr. Smith thought to himself indignantly, buzzing back into flight. He needed to put a stop to this nonsense.

He flew directly toward Tommy's face. When the noise of his wings got the teenager's attention, he flew toward the large mosaic tile bowl on the center of the dining room table. Earlier, he had spied something that had given him an idea.

Tommy, now that his attention had been attracted, followed the flight of the tiny gnat. The insect landed inside the large bowl. He walked closer, keeping his eye on the gnat, which was crawling on the surface of one of Mr. Smith's business cards.

The card identified his neighbor as Mr. Bryan Smith, Professor, Experimental Physics. The card included contact information and a cool logo.

The tiny bug looked like it was buzzing around Mr. Smith's name.

As he flew, Mr. Smith tried to scream. "See? It's me! Tommy, make the connection! Please!"

Tommy's hand reached toward the bowl. The teenager picked up the card, scanned it.

"Wonder why it's so obsessed with that card?" Tommy said aloud.

"What did you say?" Joe asked, walking over to the kitchen table.

"Oh, nothing," Tommy said. "It's just there's another one of those little pests in here. It was hovering around the bowl where Mr. Smith keeps his keys and other junk."

"Just swat the little pest and let's get out of here," Joe said. "I am bored."

"No!" The tiny bug flew again toward Tommy's face. He needed the teenager to figure out the mystery, and the business card was the only clue he had. "It's me! Help me!"


"You're right," Tommy said. "And if you let these little pests start multiplying, you never get rid of them."

The tiny gnat-man saw the teenager spread his hands apart.

The transformed scientist had witnessed that maneuver earlier, and he'd also seen the aftermath of that poor crushed bug.

"I've got to get out of here before Tommy crushes me," he said, zipping away from Tommy. In his panic, he had forgotten to keep track of the teenager's buddy. "I've got to…."

BLAM!

Joe smacked his hands together the instant the tiny bug had blundered into range.

When he open them, he grinned and announced, "Got the tiny shit!"

"Oh, gross," Tommy said as he detected the tiny smear on his buddy's palm. "You sure did pulverize that little sucker."

"Still doesn't help us find out what happened to your weird neighbor," Joe said. "But he will be glad we're helping deal with this pest problem."

"It was just a couple of freakin' gnats," Tommy said.

"Correction," Joe said. "A couple of former freakin' gnats."

He rubbed his hand on the front of his jeans, effectively erasing the last trace of Mr. Bryan Smith, Professor, Experimental Physics.
1121221122112211221122111121112.title: Former Mr. Smith, Professor, Experimental Physics

112122112211221122112211112112.content:
When Tommy separated his hands, he saw a pale, puny insect plummet to the tabletop.

The powerful clap had stunned the tiny bug-man, leaving him paralyzed from the massive force inflicted on his fragile form.

"What are you doing?" Joe asked, joining his buddy in the kitchen.

"Dealing with that gnat that you let escape," Tommy said resentfully. "Little sucker's tough, though. It just won't die!"

"Oh yeah?" A curious Joe loomed overhead. "Where is it?"

Tommy pointed at Mr. Smith's transformed speck-sized form.

"I've got a wild idea," Joe said, pinching the tiny bug between two fingertips.

Having secured the gnat, he walked back into the living room toward Mr. Smith's fish tank with two large goldfish.

Joe used his free hand to lift the lid on the tank.

"What are you doing?" Tommy asked, instantly suspicious. He needed to make sure Joe didn't damage anything.

"You think it's OK to feed this gnat to the goldfish?" Joe asked.

Tommy frowned. "Why wouldn't it be? Fish eat all sorts of things."

"Yeah, guess you're right," Joe said. "Besides, at least this way, the stupid bug will at least have led a useful life if it can end as food for your neighbor's fish."

Useful life! Mr. Smith thought indignantly at the oblivious teenager's words. I'm smarter than you by an order of magnitude!

His tiny body twitched between Joe's colossal fingers as he tried desperately to free himself from the pinching grip.

When the fingers pulled apart, however, he wasn't prepared and landed after a swift plunge in the warm, wet water in the fish tank.

He tried to buzz his wings, but the incredible surface tension of the water held him fast.

He noticed the boys watching with amazement.

"Aww, damn," Joe said, tapping on the glass walls of the tank. "Come get your food you stupid fish."

"No!" Mr. Smith screamed. "I'm not fish food! I'm a man! Help!"

"That one is coming up for dinner," Tommy noted, indicating a large golden fish with bubble eyes.

Mr. Smith could see the huge form, bigger than a whale, slowly surfacing from the depths of the tank.

"This is sort of cool!" Tommy said excitedly.

"Yeah," Joe agreed. "Bye-bye, bug!"

Joe lowered his face so he could see better through the transparent pane of glass.

The fish poked through the surface of the water, but wasn't really close to Mr. Smith. Then the fish sank back into the tank.

"Stupid fish!" Joe said. "What's wrong with it?"

"I'll add some of these!" Tommy said, grabbing a small yellow can, opening the lid and sprinkling fish flakes on the surface of the water.

"Yeah!" Joe exclaimed as both fish in the tank rose toward the surface.

"Tom-mee! It's meee! Mr. Smith!" The tiny scientist tried to get his teenaged neighbor to hear him.

"Wonder what will happen to it?" Joe asked.

Tommy laughed. "Shit, man."

"No, I am serious," Joe said.

"So am I," Tommy said. "It will be fish shit soon."

"Oh!" Joe said, finally recognizing Tommy's meaning.

No…no…nooohh! The tiny man screamed in panic as he felt a whirlpool open beneath him as one of the enormous fish switched from flakes to the twitching bug on the water's surface.

Pulled down into the fish, he saw Joe's stupid, grinning face on the other side of the glass enclosure.

Then, the fish swallowed him.

The boys continued to watch the fish for a few minutes, but soon lost interest.

"You'll have to tell your neighbor you fed his fish for him," Joe said. "Maybe he will reward you for that, too."

"Yeah," Tommy agreed. "Mr. Smith doesn't seem to ever want to do anything for himself. Doesn't bother me… just means he pays me more cash to do stuff for him."

"Yeah. Wish I had a neighbor like him," Joe said.

As for poor Mr. Smith, he was a victim of circumstance… of his own research that had gone so terribly wrong, of two oblivious teenagers and, finally, of a mere goldfish in a tank in his own home.

The next day, when Tommy visited, he stopped by the tank and noticed what messy fish the goldfish were.

"If Mr. Smith ever shows up, I'll ask him if he wants me to clean out that filthy tank," he said aloud to himself.
112122112211221122112211112112.title: Fish Food

The center of the greasy, cheese-smothered pizza
11212211221122112211221112.content:
With the monstrously large cardboard pizza box descending toward the coffee table, the tiny gnat-scientist used its wings to take flight. He zipped out of the path of the enormous box, making his way to an monumental lamp shade covering one of the decorative lamps located on his living room end tables.

While he tried to recover his shaken confidence, the two enormous youths unfolded a massive banquet of hot, greasy pizza slices and sticky, sauce-drenched chicken wings.

Tommy, his next-door neighbor now transformed into a fearsome, towering titan, grabbed one of the wings with his fingers and tore a massive hunk of sauce-covered meat from the morsel of food. His mammoth jaws moved as they demolished the morsel of food before he swallowed, sending the chewed chicken on a one-way trip down his throat to his stomach.

While Tommy enjoyed the zesty wings, his buddy, Joe, peeled a mega-sized slice of pizza from the cardboard box. Strands of melted cheese dangled from the wedge as Joe maneuvered the pizza slice toward his open mouth. In one bite, Joe made at least a third of the large slice disappear.

The tiny scientist-turned-insect watched all their actions with increasing alarm. The teenagers were so absorbed in their food, they had little inclination (he hoped) to notice a tiny winged bug flitting near their faces.

"Now's my chance," Mr. Smith thought, taking flight and zipping across the room toward his titanic teenaged neighbor. He knew he would need Tommy's assistance to solve this baffling, terrifying setback.

"Tommy, it's me," he buzzed as his wings brought him closer to Tommy. "Oh, god, please, help me!"

Tommy, having already downed another chicken wing, had turned to the pizza to continue feeding his hunger. As he bit down on the blend of greasy crust, pepperoni and cheese, he heard a faint buzz near his left ear.

With a casual swipe, his huge hand brushed the air near his head, sending the unseen gnat spiraling out of control.

Thankful that the huge hand had missed smacking him, the tiny transformed man celebrated until he saw that his out-of-control dive was taking him directly toward the….

Seeming to zoom up to meet him was a misshapen chicken wing, it's tattered skin smothered with thick, dark sauce. His rough was collision was halted immediately by the sticky sauce. Pain coursed through his bug body, causing his legs and wings to randomly twitch. Mr. Smith groaned, seeing stars from the impact.

Tommy and Joe towered high above, none the wiser to the tiny man’s plight. Mr. Smith watched as Tommy lifted the slice of pizza to his mouth, extending an impossibly long tongue to catch a swinging strand of cheese. He flinched as the tongue greedily withdrew with its catch and the teeth came together with a muted crunch.

A wet gulp catches Bryan’s attention. He flicks his eyes to Tommy’s equally huge friend who is speaking while pointing in the direction of the TV, his hand holding a pizza crust. “ -remote to turn the TV on?” his voice booms, Mr. Smith only catches the tail end of the question.

Without waiting for a response, Joe brings the crust towards his widening mouth. Mr. Smith can see light reflecting off the slimy, pink interior before Joe folds the crust and effortlessly shoves it into his mouth with one finger. Mr. Smith is awed by this display of casual power.
