“Wait no!” Mr. Smith buzzes weakly, still in pain from the impact. His plea goes unheard, as the sounds of a commercial fill the room and light begins to flash off the titanic teens’ faces. It gives them a surreal and disturbing appearance.

Mr. Smith sighs, now he would have to compete with the TV to get Tommy’s attention. Another muted crunch sounds from above as Tommy tears another huge chunk of pizza away. Mr. Smith watches his jaw rise and fall to a steady rhythm, ending abruptly with a bob of the Adam’s apple.

Mr. Smith shivered at how easily these two teens were obliterating mountains of food. Feeling recovered, Mr. Smith mumbled some words of encouragement to himself, and used his wings to fly free.

Or at least that’s what he intended. He found however that they were stuck fast to the surface behind him. Struggling also proved to be pointless since his legs were also caught. Mr. Smith however didn’t immediately give up. He buzzed ineffectually against the sticky sauce coating the wing. “Help me please!” he begged miserably, turning his gaze upwards.

Mr. Smith let's out a surprised buzz when immediately his view is dominated by the fast approaching, broad palm of…
112122112211221122112211121.title: Wings that won't fly

choices: Tommy's big bite
Tommy drops the chicken wing when he sees a bug on it
1121221122112211221122111211.content:
If there's anything worse than finding himself change into a tiny, winged pest, it's finding that his wings are worse than useless, which in effect has stranded him on the enormous mound of sauce-covered cooked chicken.

Never give up being his philosophy, however, the tiny, transformed scientist kept imploring help from the two unaware teenaged titans.

He had just witnessed Tommy's demolishing of a slice of pizza when the enormous teenager turned his attention to the assortment of chicken wings.

Seeing Tommy's greasy, huge fingers descending toward him, Mr. Smith renewed his feeble attempts at escape.

"You think your neighbor's ever gonna get home?" Joe asked.

Looking around at the mess from their impromptu feast, Tommy picked up a chicken wing and answered, "Well, I'd rather he wait until after the game and we've had time to finish off all this food."

Joe laughed and bit into a pizza slice. "You can say that again," he said.

The unnoticed, transformed scientist listened to this casual, almost indifferent discussion of himself by these two teens, throwing themselves an spur-of-the-moment party in his own home, financed with his own money.

The worst part was the dwindling amount of food, as the hungry titans ate more and more. Finally, spared with each grab from the box, only one chicken wing remained. It was the sticky, sauce-covered wing that had so securely entrapped the scientist-turned-gnat.

Both Joe and Tommy look at the wing, wondering if they can grab faster than the other.

That's when Joe spies the squirming, tiny gnat mired in the heavy sauce on the lone, remaining chicken wing.

"Why don't you have it, buddy," Joe says, with a grin.

"No! No!" Mr. Smith tried once again to scream. "Tommy, don't!"

The teenager lifted the last wing from the box. "Thanks, man."

He lifted the morsel toward his open mouth. Mr. Smith saw the oncoming cavernous mouth and the the rows of gleaming, white teeth.

"God! No!"
1121221122112211221122111211.title: Dwindling Food Supply

11212211221122112211221112111.content:
Mr. Smith didn't stop struggling even though he was fully aware how hopeless his situation had become.

“Tommy! Please no!” he begged ineffectually as Tommy’s long tongue show out of his mouth. Soggy bits of crust and strands yellow cheese were scattered across his tongue like the debris of a battlefield. Barely visible were Tommy’s jagged teeth that glinted ominously just before Mr. Smith was hit with a gust of Tommy’s warm, foul-smelling breath.

A millisecond later Mr. Smith’s ears were assaulted by the grotesque sound of Tommy sinking his teeth into the flesh of the chicken wing. “You already saved me!” he cried as the light thinned before disappearing altogether as Tommy’s jaws came together.

“Why couldn’t you do it again!?”

Mr. Smith’s gave no more thought to it as Tommy began to chew.

---

Tommy savored the flavor of the juicy wing as he chewed. With his mouth still full of food, he parted his lips to slurp the remaining meat from the bone. For a split second his chewed food mired in thick saliva glinted in the light. The weak struggles of battered gnat mixed amongst the half-chewed meat went completely unnoticed.

Tommy pulled the bone from between his lips with a pop, licking his lips before resuming chewing.

As the game went to commercial, Tommy turned to face Joe. He was surprised to friend already staring at him, with a suspicious half-smile plastered across his face.

“Woht?” Tommy grumbled through a full mouth.

“Nothing,” Joe replied in a tone that clearly meant he was up to something.

Tommy furrowed his eyebrows as he forcibly swallowed his mouthful.

“Seriously, what!” he demanded.

“Nothing!” Joe insisted “Just there was a gnat on that chicken wing!” he punctuated the end of his sentence with a mischievous chuckle.

“Augh!” Tommy shouted, sticking his tongue out. “Is it there?!” he asked loudly, pointing at his tongue.

Joe sneered at the exposed bits of chewed food on Tommy’s tongue. “I’m not looking in your mouth to find some bug! You probably swallowed it!” he snapped.

Tommy withdrew his tongue, “You’re an asshole!” he growled.

“Get over it! You’ll live, you pussy!” Joe shot back.

Tommy sighed, “Yeah I guess my stomach’ll take care of it.”
“Yeah, whatever, the game’s back!” Joe replied dismissively.

Both boys returned their attention to the big screen, any thoughts of the downed bug purged from their minds. Tommy enjoyed the rest of the game with a comfortably full gut.

“Maybe since your weird neighbor never showed up he’ll still treat us to a meal next time he sees us!” Joe said hopefully as they cleaned up.

“Maybe,” Tommy shrugged, “Honestly I’m too full to think about eating right now!” he replied. With that he patted his stomach, deaf to the screams of a gnat-man trapped amongst the mountains of chewed food within.
11212211221122112211221112111.title: Nommed Gnat

choices: Joe and Tommy return before he can complete the message
Joe and Tommy return, but will they see the "Help Me" plea?
1121221122112211221122112.content:
As the transformed scientist listened to the two enormous teenagers, he grew more depressed and desperate. How would he ever get back to human form without assistance from Tommy?

Their concentration, however, focused exclusively on an argument about pizza toppings, with Joe advocating for pepperoni and extra cheese. "We get that every time," Tommy complained.

Eventually, they came to an agreement and ordered the pizza. As Tommy's tiny gnat-man neighbor listened, the teenager spoke into the phone. "That's great. We will come and pick it up."

They can't just leave me here! Mr. Smith panicked.

His frantic buzzing and flight into their path almost ended disastrously for him when Joe, who must have the world's best hearing, detected the whiny buzz of the insect wings and almost slapped him out of the air.

"Cut it out," Tommy growled. "Let's go get that pizza."

"We should wipe out these pests before they multiply," Joe objected.

"Later," Tommy promised, focused more on going after their pizza.

As they departed his home, transformed Mr. Smith could have cried. Tommy had as much as promised to let Joe wipe out any bug still in the house when they returned.

Thinking desperately, he wondered if he could possibly write a message. He hovered over the sink in his own kitchen, noticed some dirty dishes in the stainless steel basin. One plate showed a residue of congealed spaghetti sauce. Mr. Smith's brilliant mind kicked into gear. If he smeared his feet in the red sauce, perhaps he could write out a message. He was too tiny to write an extensive message. He decided that he should start with the obvious "Help Me!"

He had managed to smear a crude H and E on the white kitchen countertop before he began to weaken. Even writing out a simple two-word plea for help was an exhausting undertaking. But he had to continue... he shuddered to think what Joe would have in store for him if the teenagers continued to mistake him for a real bug.

He renewed his efforts...
1121221122112211221122112.title: Going for Pizza

choices: Stay out of their way
Try to get Tommy's attention
11212211221122112211221121.content:
After recovering his strength, and making another trip to the dirty dishes in the sink, the tiny transformed scientist managed to start work on the third letter in the word "help."

The bug-man hadn't quite finished fashioning the letter L for his message when the door opened and Tommy entered, followed by Joe, who had an enormous cardboard carton in his hands.

"No!" The tiny scientist panicked. "They can't be back yet. I'm not finished."

Joe slapped the pizza carton onto Mr. Smith's kitchen table. "Damn, I am hungry," he said.

"I'll grab us some drinks from Mr. Smith's fridge," Tommy said, moving around the table and heading toward the refrigerator.

His former neighbor used his new wings to take to the air and intercept Tommy. He buzzed between the teenager and the open fridge. "Here!" The tiny man tried to scream. "It's me! Tommy, you've got to help me!"

All Tommy heard was the irritating buzz of a pesky insect that he directed an unenthusiastic slap toward. If the teenager had been determined, Mr. Smith could have ended up crushed. The gigantic hand didn't even deal him a glancing blow, but then Tommy moved to the cabinet for a couple of glasses. His path took him near the countertop with Mr. Smith's incomplete message.

The huge teenager looked down as saw "HEL..." spelled out on the gleaming surface of the otherwise clean countertop. He just saw a funny stain and, to further diminish all of the scientist's crumbling hopes, he grabbed a sponge from the back of Mr. Smith's sink and used it to clean and erase the start of the bug-man's desperate message.

"No!" The little gnat once a human wailed as he saw Tommy casually swipe out his hard labor. Tommy turned and saw that Joe had already removed a large slice of pizza from the box. A string of cheese dangled from the piece that hovered in front of the hungry teenager's mouth.

"Wait for me," Tommy joked. "I want to make sure you don't eat it all."

Joe, having taken a bite of pizza, heard a familiar buzz. With his mouthful, he grumbled, "You hear that?"

"What?" Tommy asked, reaching for his own slice of the hot, greasy pepperoni pizza.

"That buzz! I can hear one of those little pests."

"Just relax and enjoy the food."

"I can't relax knowing that little pest is roaming around."

Tommy rolled his eyes. "You're obsessed, dude."

Joe grunted and tore free another chunk of the pizza slice.

The tiny gnat-man watched the teen devour a huge swath of baked dough, tomato sauce and pepperoni.

"How can I get them to realize it's me?" He buzzed.
11212211221122112211221121.title: Time Runs Out

choices: Joe goes for the kill
Tommy is no help at all
112122112211221122112211211.content:
He had been doing his best to figure a way out of his nightmare.

He had been trying to stay out of the way of the two fearsome teenage giants.

But all the strain got to him, and he forgot the wisdom of avoiding the attention of such massive giants.

Something just snapped.

Tiny Mr. Smith, now nothing but a pathetic gnat, watched Tommy erase all his hard work, using a sponge to soak up the sauce the transformed scientist had used to form “HEL” on his way to spelling out the word HELP.

The tiny bug man watched as Joe grunted and tore free another chunk of the pizza slice.

The tiny gnat-man watched the teen annihilate a wide swath of baked dough, tomato sauce and pepperoni.

He watched the ignorant teenager sitting in his kitchen, stuffing his face, and something just snapped.

In dismay, he used his wings to fly toward Tommy.

“Why?” Mr. Smith buzzed, anguished at the way Tommy had so casually wiped out his progress.

Tommy reached for his own slice of pizza.

“What did you do, you moron?” Mr. Smith wanted to scream, which made his wings buzz furiously. “It was a message! I need help!”

Even as he focused his attention on Tommy, it was Joe he should have kept in his sights.

Joe continued to chew on a large hunk of pizza, but his ears tried to pinpoint the location of the whiny, irritating buzz.

Joe saw a pale, almost invisible form, hovering over the pizza box almost directly in front of Tommy’s seat at the table.

He swallowed the pizza and chuckled softly.

“I’m gonna get you now, you shitty little pest.”

“What did you say?” Tommy asked.

“No!” Mr. Smith buzzed closer to Tommy. “Don’t pay attention to him! Pay attention to me!”
112122112211221122112211211.title: Abandoning the Plan

choices: Evade Joe
Contact Tommy
1121221122112211221122112112.content:
Poor Mr. Smith continued to discover just how the actions of two blundering teenagers could result in horrific consequences for himself.

The latest example was Tommy’s casually wiping away the message for help that the tiny, transformed scientist had labored so hard to produce. In an instant, Tommy had obliterated it.

To make matters even more dire, Tommy’s friend, Joe, continued to want to apply lethal pest control measures on the helpless scientist. The teenager even chuckled with glee as he contemplated what he wanted to do to the little flying pest.

“Tommy!” Mr. Smith put his faith back in his teenaged neighbor. “Save me! Don’t let Joe kill me!”

Tommy reached for another slice of pizza, his hand slicing through the air and causing the gnat some rough flying. “Nooh!” Mr. Smith screamed as hurricane-force air current slammed into his body. “Tommy! It’s meeeee!”

The gnat continued to make that shrill buzz that set Joe’s nerves on end. He smiled, however, when he saw that Tommy reaching for the pizza had forced the little pest to fly closer to his side of the table.

The terrified gnat-man saw that Joe had located him. What should he do? Evade Joe or keep trying to communicate his problem to Tommy?
1121221122112211221122112112.title: Tommy is no help at all

choices: Joe suggests they call some of their buddies to the house
Tommy notices a teeny-tiny gnat
112122112211221122112211212.content:
The tiny transformed scientist watched as the two titanic teens tore through pizza slices like mechanical wrecking cranes demolished old buildings. Enormous amounts of baked dough, tomato sauce and salted meats disappeared into their cavernous mouths and into their deep gullets.

Mr. Smith dared not fly too close to the teenagers. Joe's freakishly good hearing kept detecting the shrill buzzing of the transformed man's wings, which stood to trigger another murderous attempt to eradicate the tiny, helpless gnat-man. But, at the same time, he knew that regaining his normal life rested in getting help from the two monstrous teenagers.

If only Tommy's impulse to "do the right thing" while taking care of Mr. Smith's house hadn't led him to erasing the little gnat-man's message without even glancing at the three letters the tiny creature had managed to write on the counter by by dipping his six tiny limbs in a sauce. The unfortunate scientist had felt utterly defeated when Tommy wiped out all his hard work with a single swipe of his huge hand.

Speaking of swipes, he realized that he needed to stay a safe distance from Joe. He told himself he could easily contact Tommy if his neighbor hadn't brought along his clueless and violent best friend. Joe had already come scarily close to squishing the tiny bug-guy.

He would focus on Tommy, who had so far not dismayed Mr. Smith with many instances of irresponsible behavior. The trick would be getting close enough to his next-door neighbor without getting detected by Joe. He took another glance toward Tommy's enormous friend and watched him guzzle what looked like gallons of soda to wash down his latest slice of pizza from a rapidly diminishing pie.

The tiny gnat-man felt his entire body shiver as he contemplated once again making his approach to the titans.

"I've got no choice," he told himself as he took flight and made his way toward Tommy.
112122112211221122112211212.title: Try to get Tommy's attention

1121221122112211221122112122.content:
He would focus on Tommy, who had so far not dismayed Mr. Smith with many instances of irresponsible behavior. The trick would be getting close enough to his next-door neighbor without getting detected by Joe. He took another glance toward Tommy's enormous friend and watched him guzzle what looked like gallons of soda to wash down his latest slice of pizza from a rapidly diminishing pie.

The tiny gnat-man felt his entire body shiver as he contemplated once again making his approach to the titans.

"I've got no choice," he told himself as he took flight and made his way toward Tommy.


His winged form reminded him of one of those sci-fi hover pods from the movies, when the hero flies through an off-the-charts mega-sized metropolis, only in this circumstance the towering spires were not buildings, but two teenagers. Not only did Tommy and his buddy look like impossible skyscrapers, they were also mobile, moving at time in almost slow motion but also capable of unexpected bursts of blur-like speed. Needless to say, flying toward them involved a great deal of nerve, something which was tested as the tiny gnat-man veered off to avoid flying too near Joe. His earlier experiences with Tommy's friend had shown him the dangerous folly of getting anywhere in the vicinity of the huge but almost laughably stupid gigantic jerk.

Mr. Smith tried to take his mind off how much the enormous scale of this new universe unnerved him by playing some inner theme music in his mind as he careened, dived, ascended and swerved around the room that was his own kitchen.

Although he had given Joe a healthy wide berth, the tiny, inexperienced flyer had not anticipated the wake the gigantic teenager made by just moving through the room. He had flown past Joe and was on his way toward Tommy when the first of the air currents stirred up by Joe's movements slammed into the tiny transformed scientist. It was like getting ambushed by a hurricane. Mr. Smith's theme music vanished, replaced by panicked if inaudible screams as the tiny flying creature went hurtling through the air in an out-of-control dive.

Mr. Smith fought to regain control, but he saw a strange surface that looked like a massive red and orange swamp rising up to meet him. "Fuck!" The tiny gnat-man screamed in his overtaxed brain. "It's the pizza!"

In the meantime, Tommy had taken a seat a Mr. Smith's table and reached for another pizza slice from the cardboard container. His eyes happened to pick up the erratic trajectory of something pale and tiny moving through the air between him and the pizza. He followed it as the movement became less haphazard. Finally, the tiny shape set down on the tabletop barely a foot in front of Tommy, who narrowed his eyes and recognized it as a tiny gnat. He did nothing, at first, but stare at the delicately tiny creature.

At some point, the exhausted Mr. Smith got the sensation of being watched. As he became more aware of his surroundings, he realized that half of his goal had been accomplished. Tommy had seen him! Tommy was watching him!

Now, the true test of his intelligence... getting the enormous but trusted teenager to make the intuitive leaps that would let him recognize — and help — Mr. Smith get back into his human form.
1121221122112211221122112122.title: Tommy notices a teeny-tiny gnat

11212211221122112211221121221.content:
Mr. Smith, despite the limitations of his current form, retained his intelligence and creativity. Tommy, despite at times coming across as a dull-witted youth interested in little more than a good time, restored Mr. Smith's faith in human nature.

Some well-placed dots pizza sauce on a white counter surface and the teenager's curious and seemingly boundless patience, allowed Mr. Smith to craft a message.

"Tommy, it is me! Mr. Smith! I am not a bug! Help!"

He saw Tommy's dark eyes go wide as he read the message and comprehended its meaning.

"Oh shit!" Tommy exclaimed. "How did this happen?"

The tiny insect felt too exhausted to craft more messages.

"No worries, Mr. Smith," Tommy declared. "You're safe now."

The transformed scientist celebrated until Tommy mentioned that he should put the tiny bug some place safe.

"That way I can take you home until we figure out what to do," Tommy said as he gazed around the kitchen in Mr. Smith's home.

He saw a plastic smoothie cup atop the garbage in the kitchen trash can. He also saw an empty jar nestled near the shiny stainless steel toaster.

"Glass or plastic, Mr. Smith?" Tommy asked without even a hint of irony.

Mr. Smith didn't much favor being imprisoned again, but he saw little alternative. He did need to stay safe, and Tommy represented his best bet for achieving that.
11212211221122112211221121221.title: A curious and observant Tommy

choices: Tommy investigates food for bugs
Tommy lets Mr. Smith stretch his wings
Mr. Smith remains trapped
112122112211221122112211212212.content:
In the end, he wasn't even really given a choice. Tommy opted for convenience, fishing a plastic cup and lid from the garbage can in Mr. Smith's kitchen. The scientist had purchased himself a strawberry smoothie a few days ago.

Now, before he even knew what was happening, Tommy finagled the tiny insect into the gigantic plastic cup coated with a sticky strawberry glop. and attached the plastic lid.

"Hey!" Mr. Smith buzzed in irritation after Tommy nudged/swatted at him to force him to enter the cup.

"Why the lid? Tommy!" Mr. Smith had thought that Tommy might treat him better knowing his true identity.

The teenager noticed that the tiny insect looked a bit agitated. "Sorry, Mr. Smith, but I have got to keep you safe while I figure out our next step."

"Consulting with me!" Mr. Smith wanted to yell. Did Tommy really think he knew better than a trained, professional research scientist? Albeit, he was a scientist who had somehow managed to accidentally transform himself into a tiny winged bug.

Mr. Smith tried to land on the plastic walls of the cup, but the strawberry puree wanted to cling to his tiny feet. "Ugh, this is disgusting," he said to himself.

"Joe, let's go," Tommy yelled.

Joe suddenly appeared. "What's the rush?"

The tiny transformed man gazed through the pink-coated walls of the plastic cup. Joe looked huge and plenty scary.

He felt relief when Tommy elected to keep Joe in the dark. "I've got to do something at home," Tommy muttered, curving his fingers around the plastic cup as he and Joe walked to the front door.

"No problem," Joe said.

Mr. Smith settled in the bottom of the cup and managed to peer out in the narrow space not covered by Tommy's enormous fingers. He felt relieved that he would only have to work with Tommy and not a bumbling, erratic teenager like Joe.

He remained confident he could count on Tommy.

Tommy walked back to his house and holed up in his room. He sat the plastic cup to the side of his desk and turned on the desktop computer.

He brought up a page of hits to his query seeking some basic information on how to best keep Mr. Smith safe and sound.

He didn't like one of the first things he read and exclaimed, "Well, damn! That's harsh."

Mr. Smith buzzed his wings in agitation. "Tommy! What's wrong?"

Tommy wondered if he should tell his unfortunate neighbor, but the little bug began to batter itself against the walls of the plastic cup.

"Easy, Mr. Smith," the teenager said. "It's just that... we need to hurry and figure out how to get you back to normal. This page says that flies and gnats usually only live a few weeks, maybe a month or two at most."

Mr. Smith felt a chill splash him like a cup of ice water being poured on him. He hadn't bothered to focus on any possible concerns other than avoiding being crushed or swatted.

Tommy squinted at him. "You look young-ish to me," he said, intending to reassure. "I'm sure you have a couple of months, and not just a week."

Mr. Smith buzzed weakly. He felt suddenly queasy.
112122112211221122112211212212.title: More worries

choices: Mr. Smith struggle to be treated as an equal with Tommy
Tommy continues to treat Mr. Smith more like a bug
Someone finds the cup and the fly in Tommy's absence
1121221122112211221122112122123.content:
Tommy brightened. "I've got an idea."

He curved his enormous fingers around the outside of the cup and carried it to the table next to his bed. The journey across the room was anything but gentle for the tiny insect as Tommy's steps caused him to get bounced off the sticky plastic walls. He felt a sharp pain caused by one of the collisions and saw his front left limb had crumpled at a bizarre angle.

Tommy situated the cup beneath an enormous desk lamp and activated the bulb. The interior of the cup was immediately bathed with intensely bright light.

Mr. Smith squinted and tried to gaze up at the blinding bulb, which was located beneath a heavy dome that focused all of the light down onto the cup. Surprisingly quickly, the temperature inside the cup began to rise. His other front limb moved to wipe his eyes, but its partner limb remained crumpled and useless.

Mr. Smith felt nervous knowing how a simple careless action on Tommy's part had left him with only five viable limbs. Even worse, the giant teenager hadn't even noticed the injury.

"That should take care of keeping you warm," Tommy said. "Now I just have to find you some food."

Mr. Smith buzzed his wings in irritation.

"Tommy, let me out of the cup at least!"

To his dismay and fury, the teenager had already left the room without another glance at the entrapped neighbor-turned-insect.

Tommy had figured out his identity, but he continued to treat him more like a real bug than a person. He needed to put a stop to that when the teenager returned.
1121221122112211221122112122123.title: Mr. Smith remains trapped

choices: Tommy lets him out of the cup
Tommy keeps him in the cup while he plays video games
Tommy discusses the need for better communication
11212211221122112211221121221232.content:
Alone in the plastic prison, a bored Mr. Smith began to make plans. Once he was back to his human self, he could think of ways to expand on his research. His formula could shrink and transform people. He wondered what practical applications could be made to his research. He also wondered how much money he could make by selling his research to the highest bidder.

For years, he had barely managed to stay afloat. He taught his full load of classes at the university, but he hated teaching morons with hardly any more intelligence than Tommy's friend, Joe. "I can finally retire from teaching once I reveal my formula to the world," he predicted.

In his excitement, the tiny wings on his back began to twitch, producing that low, irritating buzzing sound, reminding him of his current predicament. He was a long, long way from being able to auction off the fruits of his scientific labors. Everything depended on Tommy helping him to regain his human form. He trusted the teenager, but not enough to completely erase the nagging doubts about Tommy's ability to focus on the challenging obstacles ahead.

Almost on cue, the door to Tommy's room opened and the huge teenager entered. Tommy walked confidently across the room, shoved himself into his chair, and stared through the plastic walls of the huge cup as Mr. Smith's tiny insect feet allowed him to cling to the vertical, slightly curved surface.

"Hey Mr. Bug," Tommy said in a sing-song voice like one might use with a pet or very young child. "You don't mind if I call you Mr. Bug, do you?"

Mr. Smith buzzed his wings and exploded in fury. "Yes, I do mind!" The scientist poured out his frustration and fears. Unfortunately, from Tommy's perspective, the tirade amount to the proverbial tempest in a teapot. He saw the little insect crawling on the interior of the plastic cup while buzzing its wings to make an extremely faint buzz.

"I knew you'd be a sport about it, Mr. Bug."

Suddenly, Tommy completely disarmed him by seizing the cup in one hand and bringing it closer to his face, which Mr. Smith stared at in horrified dismay. Every sprout of hair from the chin, to every emerging pimple, looked so massively magnified and duplicated by Mr. Smith's faceted, compound eyes.

"Ughh, he looks like a monster," Mr. Smith thought.

"He looks so creepy," Tommy thought to himself as he stared at the loathsome form of the winged bug that had been his next-door neighbor.

11212211221122112211221121222.content:
It was the most eerie feeling he had ever experienced in his entire life. Although exhausted and terrified, his brain continued to work on both pure instinct and calculate intellect, and at the moment he had the unsettling realization of being watched.

His brain hearkened back to early origins when great beasts had stalked the naked, defenseless primates across savannas and in jungles. Bryan Smith got the unsettling impression that he was being stalked by some predatory creature.

Then, he blinked, and Tommy's distant but enormous face came back into focus as his greatest hope. More than that! Finally, the tiny gnat-man had gotten himself noticed. Tommy was watching him!

But he worried that the teenager's interest might prove mercurial. "What can I do to get him to connect me to my gnat body?"


That represented the real test of his intelligence... getting the gigantic, potentially destructive, but ultimately trusted teenager to make the connection between all the dots that would let him recognize — and help — Mr. Smith get back into his human form.

Tommy took a bite of pizza. The tiny gnat-man saw yards and yards of dough and sauce and greasy meat disappear into the teenager's massive maw. Even as he started chewing, Tommy continued to gaze at the little winged bug.

Mr. Smith wished that his message for help that he had formed with sauce hadn't been wiped away by a gigantic teenaged hand. He could have flown to the saucy letters and begged Tommy to recognize him.

"I've got to get close enough to him," the little gnat-man decided.

His wings sprung into action and he found himself flying over the great bog of pizza sauce and cheese.

Tommy had reached for another slice. The movement of his hand sent out air currents that made flying difficult. As he pulled his hand back from the cardboard box, he saw the little gnat was flying across the table, getting closer.

His eyes continued to track the insect's movement.

"Yes," Mr. Smith celebrated. "He still sees me."

Even better, the teenager had made no hostile moves to signal an intent to swat or crush the insignificant bug.

Bryan Smith flew down onto the table, inches away from his gigantic teenaged neighbor. "Tommy!" Bryan Smith buzzed. "For god's sake, look down! I can't explain it, but I've turned into a bug. Please, you've got to help me!"

Tommy's face formed a frown. Up close, the gnat looked not only tiny but also rather hideously alien.

"Tommy!" Mr. Smith begged. "Please!"

Suddenly, a shadow fell over him. The darkness took him completely by surprise.

With all his attention devoted to Tommy, he had failed to keep track of Joe.

Joe, in the meantime, had noticed Tommy's distracted gaze and saw the little pest that had landed on the tabletop. It was a simple matter to stretch out his hand and slam the flat of his palm down onto the tiny, frail gnat.

Joe smirked. "Well, be sure to tell Mr. Smith that, thanks to me, he has less of a fruit-fly problem now."

Tommy chewed his pizza, undisturbed by Joe's act of wanton destruction. "Whatever, dude. It was just one pathetic bug. I'm sure there's more where that one came from."

Joe rubbed his hand onto his shirt. Most, but not all, of the crushed bug remained behind on the tabletop. One wing, although badly mangled, continued to twitch for a few seconds.

"So gross,"Joe muttered and reached for another slice of pizza.

"Come here so I can grab a slice!"

Joe turned to give Tommy a dirty look as stopped next to the counter.

“Come here and get it yourself!” he shot back.

Tommy sighed as he complied and approached his friend. As he reached into the box to grab a slice, his gaze wandered across the kitchen.

“Oh shit, look!” Tommy gasped, staring at the kitchen counter.

“Hm?” Joe grunted, the last of his slice hanging from between his lips. He turned to look down at the counter next to him. In shaky, red letters about 3” tall a message was clearly spelled out “HELP ME”

“What the fuck? Is that spaghetti sauce?” Joe snorted.

“Who cares!” Tommy snapped, “That’s gotta be why Mr. Smith isn’t replying, he’s shrunk… again!”

Tommy leaned down to the counter. “Mr. Smith?” he whispered, closely scanning the surface for the figure of a shrunken man. Instead a small fly came rushing into his face.

“Pfew!” Tommy exhaled sharply and shot up, instinctively swatting his hands at the annoying insect.

Joe stared at his friend with a bemused expression as he gulped down the food in his mouth. “I don’t get it, why would he shrink again?

Tommy stared at him in exasperation, “I don’t know! Just help me look!”

Joe didn’t move as Tommy inched along the counter, scanning its surface for some tiny movement. “Mr. Smith?” he asked again. Again the gnat came rushing in.

“Augh! Stupid, fucking bug” Tommy growled, swatting ineffectively at the bug.

“I’m just saying dude, it doesn’t make sense. No way he shrinks a second time without having his shit together,” Joe insisted from where he stood.

Tommy glared at him for a second, but said nothing as he looked into the kitchen sink.

“Maybe he likes being tiny. Maybe he likes seeing us big? Maybe… he thinks it’s funny that he can be so tiny and still control what you do even though you’re waaaay bigger than him?” Joe guessed, as Tommy gingerly lifted dishes out of the sink.

“I’m not doing it!” Joe said abruptly, dropping the pizza box onto the counter.

“Joe! Careful, that could squish him!” Tommy said, his eyes wide in alarm.

“You already looked there,” Joe replied dismissively. With that he dropped into a barstool next to the counter.

“I don’t think Mr. Smith would do that,” Tommy said, though his voice betrayed some hesitation.

Joe picked up on it in a heartbeat. “Well, if you’re so sure!” He replied, his voice dripping with sarcasm. He leaned over and pulled another slice free of the box.

“Before the other day did you think he would shrink himself at all? Or that shrinking was even a thing?” Joe asked, giving Tommy a pointed look before lifting the pizza over his mouth and lowering it in.

“Makes sense…” Tommy trailed off as he walked away from the sink. The gnat came out of nowhere, assaulting his face. “Augh!” Tommy groaned, swatting at the annoying insect.

“Maybe thaht fly ate him!” Joe said through a full mouth, spewing crumbs.

“Would it do that?” Tommy gasped, “You think he’s dead?”

Joe shrugged and swallowed his food. “I dunno dude.” Looking up, Joe saw his friend’s crest fallen face and felt a twinge of guilt.

“How about this? We’ll give him some time to go right here on the counter-“ Joe pointed to a spot next to the pizza box “- and we can help him. He’ll have a way easier time finding us than we will finding him.”

Tommy looked at Joe, “Yeah ok. That makes sense!”

With a plan hammered out, Tommy no longer felt too guilty to grab a slice of pizza.
Joe watched as Tommy made his selection, before letting out a laugh. “Your new friend the gnat landed right where I pointed!”

Tommy grinned at the puny bug before taking his first bite, “Maybe that’s Mr. Smith!” he joked. The bug took flight and hovered, as if in response.

“Ha, right!” Joe chuckled, putting the pizza in his right to free the hand closest to the gnat. “That doesn’t even make sense!” he said, simultaneously bringing his hand down onto the defenseless bug.

SMACK!!

Mr. Smith had been so sure as long as he got the massive teens to read his message, this new ordeal would be over almost before it began.

While he had been able to get his message communicated, he then faced a new problem. One of mistaken identity.

He had rushed Tommy’s face, but each time was nearly swatted out of the air by a gargantuan palm or Tommy’s gusting breaths. In spite of that, it had been an incredible site to rush at his face. It dwarfed any of the presidents at Rushmore. Every pore on the vast surface of his face was visible, every bump on the slope of his nose, each tiny hair over his luscious lips or lining his glistening eyes.

When Joe had come up with the solution of the once again tiny man making himself visible at a specific location, Mr. Smith had been elated. The massive buffoon was for once being helpful instead of being an obstacle! Surely they would make the connection when what seemed to be a simple gnat did exactly as they instructed.

And so Mr. Smith had landed in place as instructed, only to hear the giants immediately dismiss it as coincidence, it didn’t even cross their minds. Why should it? Shrinking had been a foreign concept the day before, transforming into a bug was a whole different realm.

Balancing the slice of pizza must have misdirected his aim, causing the palm of his hand to give the airborne insect a glancing blow, actually knocking it halfway across the counter to bump into a wall of cardboard represented by the stadium-sized pizza container so casually abandoned earlier by a heedless Joe.

"Damn, must have missed," Joe grunted, turning over his hand and failing to detect the mashed and mangled remains of the irritating pest.

Tommy had shoved his friend's words and actions aside as he concentrated. Joe's careless deposit of the pizza box on the counter had obliterated the curious two-word message. Had it really been written in spaghetti sauce, or ketchup?

"That message," he said, putting his confusion into words. "You know what was odd about it?"

Joe had just taken a bite of pizza, so he needed time to eat it. He didn't take the necessary time.

"Whaddaya mean?" He said, still chewing as he spoke. He sprayed particles of pizza into the air to rain down on the counter and pizza box. "Nothing your creepy neighbor does could surprise me."

Tommy scowled and Mr. Smith's wings buzzed. "How dare that ignorant behemoth disparage my name?"

"No, think about it. How did tiny Mr. Smith get that much sauce into position to write out that message?"

Joe shrugged. His head hurt from too much thinking. "Why the hell you asking me?"

In a flash, Mr. Smith flew toward the sink. He needed more sauce!

"Something is not making sense..." Tommy tried to put the few clues together.

Mr. Smith soaked up more sauce on his feet and flew toward Tommy. He needed to think of a short message and find a suitable surface for using the sauce to spell it out.

Joe heard the drone of tiny wings and lazily scanned the area as he reached for another slice of pizza.

The tiny gnat-man flew in a path to avoid Joe's moving hand, but the giant teenager's action of lifting a slice of pizza from the box disturbed the air currents. "Tommy, please pay attention!"

He flew directly toward his gigantic next-door neighbor, circled wide of Tommy's enormous and intimidating form, before he landed on a bare stretch of counter. His flight had attracted Tommy's attention, but in a merely distracted fashion.

"Shoo! Get out of here!" Tommy waved a huge hand in his direction.

The tiny insect stood its ground as it used its feet to spell out a perfectly serviceable M. Satisfied with that effort, he scrambled to attach an E and finish the message.

"It's me!" The hopeful but exhausted scientist buzzed. "Help me!"

With focus on Tommy, he didn't detect the shadow of Joe's descending hand in time. "There's that damn pest!"

He slammed his hand onto the tiny insect and squished it.

"No!" Tommy yelled. "You moron!"

After Tommy voiced his theory, Joe looked down. The tiny bug's remains now added a gruesome red dot to accompany the smeared letters M and E. "You're nuts! No way that damn gnat was Mr. Smith."

As one of the tiny insect limbs twitched, Tommy allowed himself to be convinced. "Yea, guess you're right."

Although, as he thought about it, Joe smiled. Unspoken, he decided that, if by some chance it had been Mr. Smith, the little sucker got what he deserved.

"Let's get out of here," he suggested.

Tommy, with a shudder, looked away from the carnage on the counter. "Right behind you, bro."

Each of their quaking steps sent forceful vibrations through the floor, rattling the exhausted gnat on the counter. It wasn’t enough for the titanic teens to ever notice. However at such a small size, with a gnat’s heightened sensitivity to vibration, each step shook Mr. Smith to his core.

Joe balanced in one hand a city-sized package Mr. Smith could only assume was the pizza they had left to retrieve. With his other hand, he lifted a massive slice of pizza free, long tendrils of cheese stretching as he brought it towards his lips. He gaped at their forms from where he lay, awed simply by their hulking presence. Their innocent roughhousing exuded a casual power that could easily turn deadly for a creature of Mr. Smith’s current stature. In spite of having already witnessed the teens at such an impressive size, it was not a sight Mr. Smith felt he would ever find commonplace.

“MR. SMITH?” Tommy bellowed without warning. The shock of hearing Tommy’s voice triggered something instinctive and the tiny gnat-man took flight. He groaned, his tiny bug body still tired from frantically writing the message for Tommy and Joe only a few minutes before.

“Tommeeeeeee” he buzzed pathetically as he landed back on the counter. As Tommy seemed to turn towards his location, the man turned gnat was mowed down by a hurricane gust followed by a thundering crash. 11212211221122112211221122212.title: Five Second Rule

choices: Tells Joe he isn't looking at a thing
Tells Joe he is just thinking about Mr. Smith
112122112211221122112211222122.content:
Sure, they're friends, but there are times when Joe gets on Tommy's last nerve.

This day has been one of those times. If he hasn't been complaining, Joe has been rude, loud, and bossy.

So, when Tommy saw the tiny bug struggling in a puddle of greasy cheese on Joe's slice of pizza, he didn't blurt out a warning, as he might have any other time.

From his position on the huge slice of pizza, stuck in the disgusting semi-solid lump of cheese, tiny Mr. Smith managed to keep one of the insect's six legs and his head above the surface of the melted goop.

He saw Tommy's huge eyes a relatively short distance away. He tried to wave with his one free arm, and he could have sworn Tommy saw him.

"Yes," he screamed. "It's me! Help! Help!"

Joe took a huge bite, tearing it free from the rest of the slice. One peek told Tommy that the trapped bug had survived. For now.

Mr. Smith shrieked continuously as the huge mouth and teeth tore into the slice. He heard the baked crust tear free, taking gallons of tomato sauces and volumes of the sticky cheese with it. He, however, remained stuck in what would now almost without a doubt be the next bite consumed.

"Tommy, what are you doing?" The tiny transformed scientist tried to scream again. "It's me...I'm not a bug. Help me!"

Tommy broke into a wide grin as he saw Joe prepare for another bite of the pizza. Joe almost chomped down, then noticed the intent stare.

"What are you looking at?" Joe asked suspiciously.

Tommy smiled innocently.
112122112211221122112211222122.title: Tommy notices a bug on the slice

choices: One of the boys sees him and stomps on him
One of the boys stomps him without even noticing him
1121221122112211221122112221221.content:
"It's nothing," Tommy lied.

Joe, not buying it, glanced down at the remainder of the pizza slice in his hand and saw a tiny, flailing form in a pocket of melted cheese. "It's that filthy bug!" He shouted, flinging the fragment of pizza onto the coffee table.

The impact did two things. First, the transformed scientist was wrenched free of the sticky cheese, but freedom was elusive. His wings, smeared with oil and grease, didn't work and, as a result, he fluttered ineffectively toward the floor.

Second, the two titanic teenagers lost track of the bug in question.

"I would have told you," Tommy lied. "I wasn't going to really let you eat a bug."

"Sure," Joe growled. "Like hell I believe anything you have to say."

"Come on," Tommy cajoled. "Don't get all pissy about it."

Joe got to his feet. "Where did that disgusting insect end up?" Joe asked. "I'm going to take care of it, once and for all. I'll be damned if some bug's gonna make a fool of me."

Tommy picked up the mangled slice of pizza from the coffee table and examined it. "Strange. Bug's gone," he said.

"It's here somewhere," Joe said with single-minded determination. "Find it."

"Can't we just forget it?" Tommy asked. "It's an itty-bitty gnat. Sooner or later, some bigger bug will eat it and it will be out of our lives forever."

The tiny transformed scientist listened to the discussion from the floor, feeling his hopes for rescue crushed by the total lack of empathy from Tommy and Joe.

But, when Joe's sneakers caused the entire floor to erupt with tremors every step he took, it made Mr. Smith realize that much more than his hopes were in danger of being crushed.

"I've got to get somewhere safe," he realized, abandoning his attempt to get his smeared wings functional in favor of using his six tiny, thin legs to transport him somewhere he could avoid the enormous footwear of the two teenagers rampaging through his house.

If he ever hoped to be a man again, he must escape the lethal footsteps of Tommy and Joe. "Just go already!" He buzzed angrily at them.

It wasn't going to be easy. Now Tommy, too, had joined the search, stomping around the room.

"If we can find the stupid little bug and kill it, can we finally just get out of here?" Tommy asked as he scanned for any sign of the gnat.

"Deal," Joe said.

"No!" Mr. Smith shouted in vain. He crawled toward the distant wall. Remaining in the open spaces of the room made him feel far too exposed and vulnerable.
1121221122112211221122112221221.title: Tells Joe he isn't looking at a thing

11212211221122112211221122212212.content:
The tiny gnat-man discovered that, without his wings, he had no way to quickly move in the immense universe that surrounded him.

And, with both gigantic teenagers on the prowl for him, hoping to snuff out his little bug life, moving quickly took on new urgency.

"Please," he buzzed. "Tommy! Stop this!"

He kept crawling at an agonizingly slow rate.

Joe stomped past. His sneakers rose and fell like alien motherships crashing to Earth and then roaring back into space again. The tiny scientist turned bug felt the floor shake and vibrate as the titanic teenager took a few steps past him.

While still watching Joe wander to the far side of the kitchen, the tiny bug-man felt the floor shake again. His little faceted eyes turned and watched as his neighbor and errand boy stomped toward him with footwear as equally fearsome as Joe's.

"I hope we can find it quick and get out of here," he said. "You really know how to live it up, Joe."

Joe turned and told Tommy to fuck off, but Tommy laughed it off and kept walking through the kitchen, his eyes darting to and fro searching for a tiny bug buzzing near the cabinets or over the table.

A giant shoe pounded the floor and rose again. The transformed scientist crawled, but the baseboard at the bottom of the wall remained too far.

"I'm not going to make it!" The tiny scientist screamed with his buzzy bug voice.

The shoes continued their deadly onslaught. The tiny bug-man had seen them soar overhead many times since his mishap. He prayed the shoes would spare him again.

He kept crawling. He noticed his right wing twitch. He tried it. It worked!

He tried the other wing. "I can fly again!"

He launched into the air just as the sole of Tommy's shoe dropped. The filthy rubber sole, stained with debris, crashed into the tiny gnat and slammed it down toward the floor where it got caught between the hard floor and the bottom of the teenager's shoe.

"No!" The tiny gnat buzzed just before tons of force caused its tiny body to go splat.

As for Tommy, he never suspected what he had so thoughtlessly done.

After a half hour of fruitless searching, both boys gave up on the notion of doing some free pest control for Mr. Smith.

Later, when Tommy took off his shoes at home, he glanced at the sole of his left shoe. The messy remains of the great scientist squished and stuck to the bottom of the shoe were far too puny for him to even notice.
11212211221122112211221122212212.title: Unnoticed Death Under A Shoe

choices: Follow Tommy into the great outdoors
Left behind and trapped in his own home
112122112211221122112212.content:
He watched as the teenager from next door entered his house. Just a skinny kid with most of his untamed hair trapped beneath a baseball cap, Tommy had arrived right on time for the promised dinner, a reward for helping his neighbor and occasional employer recover the formula that had rectified his dilemma with his radical shrinking formula.

Now, though, the teenager had taken on all the dimensions of a monstrous, all-powerful titan. The transformed, and still tiny, scientist flew on his brand-new wings, gaining altitude for a more complete survey of Tommy's enormous form.

While he hovered in the air, Tommy advanced into the house and, without warning, bellowed out words that destroyed the silence. "MR. SMITH! WHERE ARE YOU?"

He would have answered, if he could, but thanks to his tainted formula, the only sound he could make came from the incessant buzzing of his wings as the tiny gnat-man careened around the room, keeping his distance from Tommy-zilla as the massive teenager stomped through his home.

He remembered how Tommy and his friend had been so huge after he had used his shrink formula on himself. He had felt like a bug in their presence and now, thanks to another unkind twist of fate, the revolutionary scientist had been reduced to the status of an insect in his very own home. It was actually worse than on the last occasion because he wasn't simply the size of an insect... he had turned into a real bug.

He was so absorbed in his thoughts that he had almost lost track of Tommy until he heard the teenager's thunderous voice again. His attention re-focused on the titanic teenager, he saw him speaking into his phone.

"Yeah, I am here and no sign of Mr. Smith," Tommy was saying.

The tiny gnat-man flew closer, trying to think of a plan to contact Tommy and finally deciding to wing it.

"Anyway, looks like dinner is off, but I think I will stick around for a while and see if Mr. Smith shows up. Later."

Tommy finished his call to Mr. Smith and walked into his neighbor's living room. As he took a seat on the sofa, he placed his phone on the coffee table.

He wanted to look for the remote for the TV, but a thin, incessant buzzing sounded in his ears. A thought popped into his head. What if Mr. Smith had shrunk again?

He became alert, straining to hear any tiny cries or detect any sign of movement. He was distracted, however, by a gnat that buzzed past his face and then settled atop the phone he had left on the surface of the coffee table.

He waved his hand over his phone and said, "Shoo!"

The tiny insect took to the air, but flew erratically thanks to the air currents stirred by the teenager's huge hand.

He also decided that he had to be wrong. He had seen firsthand the relief Mr. Smith had felt when restored to his normal size. No way he would have gone and shrunk himself again after his harrowing adventures.

In the time it took him to come to this conclusion, the gnat returned. The tiny insect flew over the coffee table and landed once again on his phone.

An enormous touch-pad of colorful apps spread out beneath him as the transformed scientist gazed up at Tommy's immense form. How could a scrawny teenager look so overwhelming?

Tommy frowned and marveled at the stupidity of bugs. He waved his hand to shoo the bug away again.

"Look, I don't want to swat you, bug," the teenager said aloud. "But I will!"

The tiny man had flown in panic from the descending hand, which looked capable of smashing him in an instant. Then, hearing Tommy's warning, he felt even more panic.

"But it's me! I'm Mr Smith, not a bug!" He tried in vain to protest against Tommy's unfair stance.

All his experiences from last time, however, suggested Tommy was probably bluffing. The teenager probably wouldn't hurt a fly. The only thing that left him uncomfortable was the word "probably."

He flew closer, directly toward Tommy's face. "I have to get him to associate me with this bug I've become," the tiny gnat-man realized.

Tommy experienced a surge of irritation when the gnat flew toward his face. He disliked bugs enough without one getting in his face. He brushed away the flying insect with another swipe of his hand, vowing next time he wouldn't be so kind.

Mr. Smith retreated after another close call. Getting close to Tommy always ended in a near miss, and he doubted his luck would continue indefinitely.

He tried to formulate a new plan when Tommy arose from the sofa and walked toward the front door. He'd had enough of waiting for his neighbor and being bugged by stupid gnats. He did make a mental note to tell Mr. Smith he might benefit from having an exterminator check out his house for pests.

"No!" Mr. Smith tried to cry out. "He's leaving."

As the door opened, he forced his wings into overdrive, determined to overtake the teenager before he departed. The open door, however, permitted a hurricane to sweep into the house, hampering the tiny insect's efforts.
112122112211221122112212.title: New Perspective on Tommy

choices: Tommy rides his bike to the park
Tommy rides his bike to the mall
1121221122112211221122121.content:
It was all happening so fast, and despite his efforts, the tiny gnat-man saw all the situation continuing to spiral out of control.

The open door admitted a gust of wind that roared across the room with the force of a Category Four hurricane.


"No!" Mr. Smith tried to cry out. "Tommy, please! You can't leave me here!"

He forced his wings to move more rapidly, shooting in a straight line toward the departing teenaged titan. Most of Tommy's enormous body was already through the door, and one arm that looked like a crane on a major construction project reached back to pull the door closed.


He flew faster, skimming over the top of Tommy's enormous head. He escaped his home just as Tommy closed the door, effectively barring any return for the scientist turned winged insect.

Not that it matter. Mr. Smith had already decided to gamble everything on gaining the teenager's attention. "Tommy's my only hope," he realized with a pang of desperation.

The world looked big and scary as the tiny bug-man continued to orbit his next-door neighbor like a tiny asteroid making its way around planet-sized Tommy. Getting too close to the unsuspecting, oblivious teenager was foolhardy; letting Tommy get too far away from him also invited another array of perils.

As he hovered, trying to decide on his next step, a much bigger bug with its own massive wings zipped past the little bug-guy. The wake from its powerful flight buffeted the tiny creature.

"What the hell was that?" Mr. Smith wondered in near panic.

It had been a mere fly, but it had looked like a flying tank to the tiny, transformed scientist who was not at all certain the horrible monster might not be capable of eating something as small and helpless as his new form left him.

Tommy left his neighbor's home and walked directly to his bike. He balanced the bike, climbed on and shot onto the street as soon as he got his feet on the pedals. Unknown to him, a tiny gnat had chosen a spot on the sleeve of his T-shirt for the duration of the teenager's journey.

Of course, the tiny gnat-man had no way of knowing where the bike would take Tommy, who had decided to...
1121221122112211221122121.title: Sticking close to Tommy

choices: Tommy swats the gnat successfully
Tommy swats the gnat, missing
11212211221122112211221211.content:
The teenager's lips mouthed lyrics to a song he heard. It played over and over in his head while he peddled over the sidewalk.

His first inclination had been to visit the mall. There was always something to do there; shop, or meet up with his buddies; but, Tommy let all thoughts of the mall escape his mind when he spotted the activity at the city park.

"Looks like some kind of festival... Awesome!"

His decision made, Tommy maneuvered his bike past gaggles of park goers, heading towards the clusters of tents and cars.

Music guided the visitors down rows of stalls and tents displaying delectable foods and interesting goods. Tommy creaked his bike to a halt, steadying himself and dismounting. His eyes shot from stall to stall, all serving flows of excited visitors. Walking his bike, the teenager began browsing with them.

His attention settled upon something just when a pesky buzz bothered his ear.
11212211221122112211221211.title: Fun at the Park

choices: Mr. Smith's too deep inside
Fingertip nabs the tiny bug-man
112122112211221122112212111.content:
Tommy swatted his hand in the vicinity of the pesky, buzzing little flying pest, successfully slapping the tiny scientist-turned-gnat.

"Oh no!" Mr. Smith managed to cry before the huge hand slapped into him with the force of a dozen locomotives, sending the tiny winged insect hurtling toward a deep, dim cavern.

When the dazed scientist found he was still alive, that was only briefly cause for celebration once he discovered his location. All six tiny legs were mired in a thick field of amber-colored wax on the floor of the "cavern," which was actually the inside of Tommy's ear.

"Gross! Doesn't he ever clean in here!" Mr. Smith complained.

His irritation manifested itself with the rapid buzzing of the wings on his back, a noise bound to generate supreme annoyance from the enormous teenager.

"Fucking gnats," Tommy said, realizing one of the pests must have flown inside his ears. He could hear it buzzing deep inside his ear canal. In exasperation, he dug into his ear with one of his huge fingers, determined to dig out the offending gnat.
112122112211221122112212111.title: Ill-timed slap

1121221122112211221122121112.content:
Tommy slapped the side of his head, trying to dislodge the gnat that had flown into his ear canal and now showed no sign of flying back out.

"Damn it to hell!" The teenager's frustration rose sharply knowing a stupid, tiny, probably filthy bug was inside his ear.

The transformed scientist vibrated his wings, desperate to pull himself free from the layer of ear wax that had mired his six wiry legs. The vibration of the wings produced a shrill whine that continued to drive Tommy insane.

He shoved his fingertip deeper and then withdrew it.

For the tiny bug-man, Tommy's former neighbor, the increasingly frantic efforts by Tommy to remove him only added to the terrifying thought of finding himself trapped in the teenager's ear. He would have screamed had that been possible when Tommy's huge fingertip slammed into the tunnel of the ear canal. The fingertip picked up a thin layer of wax on its journey, so when Tommy withdrew his finger, one tiny, helpless insect came along for the ride.

The bright light once the finger exited almost overwhelmed the tiny gnat. Everything had become a monstrous assault on his senses, from nearly being crushed by a digging finger to the rumbling noise produced when Tommy examined the fingertip he lifted toward his face.

"Fucking gross!" The teenager said as he saw a pale, teeny winged insect adhered to the tip of his finger.

It was only for a split second. Mr. Smith tried one final time. "Tom-mee! It's meeee!"

The only sound he succeeded in producing was the faint, shrill buzz from his wings.

Tommy lowered his hand and wiped off the fingertip on the front of his jeans. The rough action destroyed the fragile body of the tiny gnat, but life clung stubbornly as the transformed scientist tumbled onto the floor.

He knew that Tommy's simple gesture of swiping his fingertip on his denim jeans had almost crushed his tiny body. Three of his wiry legs had been ripped free of his body, and now the wings were so crumpled and mangled that even a buzz from the vibrating was almost impossible to produce.

He tried to orient himself. He saw the teenager looming over him like an incomprehensible and uncomprehending god.

"Tommy..." The scientist struggled.

"Well, I guess there's no point waiting any longer for Mr. Smith," Tommy said aloud and headed toward the back door. His sneaker raised off the floor and then slammed back down.

The destroyed gnat rested right in the center of the landing zone for the enormous sneaker, which finished the process of completely eradicating any clue of Mr. Smith's existence.

In the end, the body of the tiny gnat had been so tiny and unnoticed that the squishing of the body hadn't even produced so much as a dot of mess to leave behind as evidence.

Tommy left Mr. Smith's house without the slightest inkling of what he had done. In the weeks to come, he did wander about his neighbor's disappearance.

But he had a life and the disappearance of his somewhat strange next-door neighbor didn't cause any lasting disruptions for the oblivious teenager.
1121221122112211221122121112.title: Fingered

choices: Into something sticky!
Into another park goer's face!
112122112211221122112212112.content:
Nestled in a wrinkled in the fabric of his gigantic neighbour's T-shirt, Bryan steeled himself. His teeny insect body was plastered against the huge fabric, kept in check by increasingly intense winds.

"Tooooommmmeeee! It's me!" He tried to screamed, but found himself immediately silenced by the roaring winds.

His still-human head wrinkled in despair - it was no use! Tommy couldn't possibly hear his buzzing voice. He needed to wait for a better opportunity once the giant teenager stopped.

"Just gotta keep myself from being thrown off..." He realized with a gulp.

The mere thought of what might happen to him if he were to be left alone - a mere bug - in the enormous outdoors was utterly terrifying. Bryan knew his only chance of survival was getting Tommy's attention, no matter what the cost.

Seemingly moments later, the winds subsided and the G-forces pinning him against the thick fabric lessened. Blinking his eyes, Bryan looked out from his fabric haven and saw two arms bigger than skyscrapers clutching a set of huge handlebars. Tommy's massive fingers relaxed, and began to lift away, signaling the teenaged titan's intention to dismount the bike.

Bryan took to the air with a dainty jump from the shifting fabric. His thin wings easily caught the currents, carrying him aloft as he tried to maneuver himself around the moving behemoth that seemed anything but his helpful teenaged neighbour. Tommy's feet thudded heavily on the ground, carrying him a tremendous distance with each step. Bryan fell behind, vainly attempting to keep himself aligned in the titan's wake.

The gnat-man fluttered past the teenager's huge hand. It was like banking over the surface of an island, coated with thick tree-sized hairs and sloping terrain. "Tooommyy!" Bryan buzzed desperately, his buzzing breath ragged. "You've got to help meee." Nearing Tommy's moon-sized face, the gnat managed to position his flitting form above the oblivious teenager's nose. It looked like the craggy overhang of a mountain, coated in grease and pores, and emitting explosive blasts of hot air from cavernous nostrils. The tiny transformed man ignored this, focusing his doe-eyed expression upon the eyes of his continental-sized neighbour.

"It's me! Mr. Smith!" The bubbling gnat-man attempted to communicate. "I've been transformed! Help!"

Like a tidal wave of thick flesh, the gargantuan teenager blinked. A sound like a distant crash was audible when each lid connected. Bryan winced at the tremendous scale of his next-door neighbour, but felt overwhelmed with joy when he realized Tommy was looking right at him.

"Yes!" His joy was premature and quickly turned sour when a great disturbance approached from his right. "Oh, no! Tommy, what are yo-...!"

Tommy's enormous hand blasted through the air, crashing through it like an airborne island. The tiny gnat barely avoided it, but was caught in an intense rush of displaced air that thrashed his tiny insect body as if he were caught in a tornado.

His attempts at regaining control were useless, and he finds himself careening through the air...
112122112211221122112212112.title: Dodged

choices: The giant noticed something tiny in his food
The giant reaches for another bite
1121221122112211221122121121.content:
Bryan had felt thankful that he was spared the incredible force of Tommy's monumental hand. Even as he tumbled through the air, flung at a dizzying velocity, he figured he would just continue his pursuit for attention after regaining control.

One problem impeded this simple plan, much to his dismay. He couldn't seem to stop his twirling descent, and each time he tried only seemed to make it worse as he was thwarted by strong currents that carried his tiny body.

He gathered a momentary glance at his destination before impact. Some sort of alien structure that twisted like a gigantic spring amidst gobs of reddish goo. "What the hell!" Then he made contact with a wet splat.

The gnat-man groaned from the impact. Dots of light danced like giddy stars across his vision, making his head feel as though it were still spinning through the open air. He tried to move, but found his body weighed down by a slimy substance.

"Tommy...?" He muttered, dazed. "Where am I?"

It was a very good question. Looking around, Bryan found nothing but more questionable surroundings. Craning high above from a bed of thick goop was the strangest structure he had ever laid eyes upon. Brown with a surface of mottled golden crust and gleaming with grease - it looked like a prop from some 1970s Sci-Fi movie. He also felt overwhelmed by a scent that was remarkably familiar. "It looks like..." The entire world tilted suddenly, rocking with terrific force. "Whatshuh?! Oh, my God!"

Still aching from the impact, Bryan let out a buzz in surprise as huge towers descended from above. He buzzed louder, realizing they were fingers - huge fingers coated in grease, streaks of ketchup, and salt!

Bryan became panicked. The realization of his situation - and his current location - dawning on him. He was in somebodies food!

The massive digits thudded against the curling spire of fried food. A loud crunching, followed by a squishy tear, and the fingers tore away a giant quantity of the structure. It made Bryan think of what steel beams might look and sound like if they could be torn with such ease. Drops of grease large as the tiny gnat-man crashed into the sea of gooey ketchup at random, followed by meteor-sized crumbs that dislodged from the torn chunk as it lifted to the sky.

"Oh. My. God." Bryan repeated with dumbstruck awe.

He watched the digits, each big as a building, carry the rough section of fried food towards a set of lips that looked more like sloped mountains coated with grease and salt. They parted, presenting a city-scape of yellowed teeth that stood before a cavernous interior dripping beads of saliva and expelling a wave of humid air that stank of potato, and condiments. Too much in awe for any type of thought, the transformed man could only watch as a monstrous landmass of pink muscle slid over both towering teeth and lip, revealing a bumpy surface dotted with soggy mounds of food. His attention was so rapt, that he didn't react as huge globules of discoloured saliva fell from the tongue and slammed against the ketchup surrounding him.

Suddenly, the tremendous amount of food is deposited into the huge maw and the moist world inside crashes shut with a dull boom.

Bryan screamed loudly, popping back into himself like somebody out of a daydream. He struggled, but focused his efforts on moving his wings to fly free. Flying free had been his intended action, but he found them to be hopelessly mired in the thick ketchup that held him. "Oh, no! No, no, no!" The scientist-turned-gnat wriggled, trying vainly to move his legs, but found the same result: he was trapped!

He refused to give up. Hearing the booming crash of the giant's chewing high above, Bryan twisted and buzzed ineffectually against the slimy sauce around him.

Completely overwhelmed and now tuckered out, Bryan buzzes desperately. "This is not good!" He turns his gaze upwards, looking over the huge face that loomed more like an approaching planet than a stranger's face. "Help me!"

The oblivious behemoth is unaffected by this plea. And, instead, parts his huge lips with a dull smacking squelch, and slides out a huge tongue that rolls over both lips to clean them of any grease and salt. Bryan watches granules of potato and salt fall into a tangle of dark blond hair that grew along the titan's chin like a great cape of jungle draping off a near-vertical cliff. Looking from this gruesome display to the giant's eyes, Bryan sees nothing in their great blueish gaze. In fact, the expression upon this huge guy's face was nearly blank: bored, perhaps somewhat stoic, mixed with stolid indifference.

Bryan realized with a sinking heart, that this monstrous guy was paying utterly no attention to the food he was consuming, and much less to what might be trapped in it.

The fingers returned again, dropping from above towards another massive section of the fried potato twist. They rived a chunk from the monumental fair food and lowered it towards Bryan's location in the landscape of ketchup.

"Eeek! No! I'm in here you big fool!" The tiny gnat buzzed.

The huge chunk of food crashed into the sauce. And, guided by the godly fingers, began scraping mass amounts of the red goo onto the park-sized section of potato. Lifting away, the departure was serenaded by the gnat-man's terrified screams. He watched the huge digits raise up, soaring towards the distant lips that parted to accept the massive delivery of fried food. The impassive titan didn't even glance down at the bite as he shoved it into his huge mouth. Bryan screamed up at him, looking from his eyes, to the thick blond brows sporting a dull hunk of metal pierced in one, and then the bill of a gargantuan hat that shaded the entire scene.

He needed to do something - now! "Fuck this... I'm gonna be eaten if I don't get the hell out of here!" The thought of ending up in this strange giant's mouth, mashed into paste, or - god forbid, digested alive - made him shudder. Pressed deeper into the mire of ketchup, Bryan could only buzz in vain.

High above, the thunderous jaw halted chewing...
1121221122112211221122121121.title: Potato Twists

11212211221122112211221211212.content:
The enormous mouth closed, and the tiny gnat-man felt a moment of relief at his reprieve.


"DUDE!" Tommy said with enthusiasm as he walked toward his best friend, Joe. "DIDN'T KNOW YOU WERE GONNA BE HERE."

"GOT BORED," Joe said, popping half a potato twist into his mouth. He demolished the morsel, swallowed, smiled and added, "AND HUNGRY."

"CAN I HAVE ONE?" Tommy asked, instantly craving the crunchy, savory snack.

"JUST ONE," Joe said, somewhat reluctantly. "WANT MORE, YOU CAN BUY YOUR OWN."

As the tiny gnat-man saw Tommy reach into the paper container to draw out one of the spirals of fried potato, he screamed in vain. "Yes, buy your own," the tiny man pleaded. "I have paid you plenty enough money….Oh no!"

As Tommy withdrew the potato twist, a drop of ketchup and the mired insect came with it. Of course, the gargantuan teenager barely spared a glance for his food, simply opening his mouth wide and using his fingers to deliver the twist closer.

"Fuck this!" The tiny bug-man buzzed his wings in a last-second attempt to evade his fate. "Tommy, please stop! You can't eat me!"

The spiral structure of the fried potato disappeared into Tommy's wide-open mouth. His teeth slammed down, slicing through the golden spires of fried potato. He left just a ketchup-smeared fragment still between his fingers. He paused, looking critically at his friend.

"WHERE'D YOU GET THAT HAT?" Tommy asked.

"BORROWED IT," Joe replied.

"FROM YOUR GRANDFATHER?" Tommy asked sarcastically.

"SHUT UP," Joe said and shoved Tommy back.

"IT'S LAME, DUDE," Tommy said, almost forgetting the last morsel of snack still in his fingers.

Mr. Smith had used the teenager's momentary lapse in interest in his food to try one last time to escape. He had managed to extract a few of his wiry insect limbs from the sticky ketchup before Tommy remembered he had one last bite.

"No, just a little more time," the tiny gnat-man pleaded. "Please!"

Tommy tossed the morsel into his open mouth. It landed behind his teeth, so he just used his tongue to move it toward the back of his mouth.

"To-MEEE!" The tiny man tried to scream. "Don't swallow me-eeeee….."

Tommy gulped and then tried to wheedle more of his buddy's potato twists.

"No," Joe said. "I told you get your own."

Instead, Tommy walked over to a water fountain and drank heavily, flooding his stomach. He had no idea he was just prolonging the torture for the tiny bug-man he had swallowed.

He continued to roam around the park with Joe and, being a ravenous teenager, he eventually shelled out some of the cash he had earned from Mr. Smith to buy some more junk food that he quickly consumed.

They had wandered around the park for quite some time when Tommy saw the row of portable restrooms. "Excuse me," he said. "I really need one of those."

His stomach had been rumbling for some time. "Must have been something I ate," he said, grinning as he closed the door and made Joe wait for him.
11212211221122112211221211212.title: Never know who you will run into

choices: The food court to meet Joe
The mall's restrooms
11212211221122112211221212.content:
As the wind picked up speed as Tommy pedaled his bike onto the road, his unseen passenger tried to take shelter in a wrinkle in the fabric of the teenager's T-shirt.

"Tommy! It's me! Mr. Smith!" The tiny gnat-man tried to scream. "Here! On your shirt!"

Ten harrowing minutes later, Tommy chained his bike to a rack outside the local shopping mall. When the violent air currents calmed down, Mr. Smith took to the air to try to get close enough to communicate with the enormous teenager. Carried aloft on tiny wings, he hovered near Tommy's right ear, which looked like the entrance to a colossal cavern.

"Tommy!" The tiny gnat-man buzzed desperately. "Please, you've got to help me."

Tommy heard the faint buzz and lifted a hand to swipe at the offending bug. The gnat careened away from the teenager's huge hand.

Tommy approached the large doors at the entrance to the mall, which was a colossal collection of enclosed stores and businesses. Tiny Mr. Smith felt thoroughly depleted, but he managed to stay close to the huge teenager as he made his way through the doors. The monolithic structures would have been an impossible barrier if the tiny transformed man hadn't zipped inside the mall with the oblivious teenager.

"Just gotta stick close to him," Mr. Smith told himself. But, he needed to rest. He flew to one of the fronds of a potted palm in the cathedral-like corridor that led into the heart of the shopping mall.

Tommy made a bee-line toward his destination, which turned out to be...

Mr. Smith used his new wings to carry him the long distance from the front door, which Tommy had closed on his way out, back to his own kitchen.


His mind raced with frantic thoughts. "I'm going to die in my own home!"

No, he could beat this setback, he told himself with more confidence than he really felt.

But he felt like he was starving. Simply flying from room to gigantic room in his house had drained him of all his energy. He needed food, nourishment, something to replenish his energy.

"What the hell do gnats eat?"

The answer presented itself when he found himself attracted to an overwhelming odor. Following it, judging the intensity of the scent, he found himself hovering over a bowl of fruit on the kitchen counter. Bananas the size of submarines and apples looking like fallen planetoids amazed him. The fruit looked so tempting. His tired wings managed to permit a landing on the vast yellow surface of a banana skin.

The banana had ripened over the past few days, and upon closer observation, large brown blotches had formed all over the vast peel. He discovered that the soft brown spots allowed his new mouthparts to suck up nutrients from the sweetly decaying peel.

He had taken care of one problem. There was enough fruit in the bowl to supply his food needs for the immediate future.

But the transformed scientist had no idea how he would become human again without help. He was exhausted, however. For now, he slept, a tiny insect the size of a pin's head, curled on the vast marble surface of the kitchen counter.

He dreamed of a world of enormous fruits, constantly supplying his nourishment, in a boundless garden of Eden.

The dream took a turn, and he found himself perched on Tommy's nose, telling the now mesmerized teenager every details of his dilemma. The teenager seemed able to understand his buzzy words.

Tommy's mouth opened, and in thunderous words the teenager promised to help him again.

Before the teenaged titan could deliver salvation, however, the dream was crashed by reality.

The back door opened, admitting Tommy and his friend, Joe.

"He came back," the tiny man celebrated as he launched into the air as he watched the two titans overwhelm the kitchen.

The comfort of the dream seemed so far away, however, as he gazed at them.

The transformed scientist wondered how the hell he would ever communicate with them?
