The teenagers strode into the kitchen like they owned the place. Tommy saw the bowl of fruit and grabbed one of the bananas from the ceramic holder.

For the tiny, frightened Mr. Smith, the hand that plunged into the bowl looked like it belong to a fearsome titan. He barely had time to work his tiny wings and fly away.

Tommy peeled the banana and began eating it in huge bites.

"What are we doing here again?" Joe grumbled.

"Well, something doesn't make any sense," Tommy answered. "We're supposed to meet Mr. Smith for him to take us out to eat, but he's not here. Now, hours later, he's still not here."

"So?" Joe asked, reaching into the bowl for another of the bananas. After all, if he has to spend time here, no need to be hungry.

The tiny gnat-man hovered in the air above the heads of the two massive titans, watching their every action most carefully.

"Please, figure it out," the tiny scientist pleaded. He had faith in Tommy. The teenager was an intelligent guy.

"What if he shrunk again?"

"Why would he shrink himself again?" Joe argued.

"Well, I am staying here until Mr. Smith gets home," Tommy proclaimed. "You know, just in case he does need us."

The two teenagers finished off their bananas, leaving much less food available to the tiny, transformed scientist.

"You've got to be kidding me," Joe complained. "Haven't we waste enough time with your weird neighbor?"

Mr. Smith took offense and buzzed Joe's enormous head. "Who you calling weird, buddy?" He wanted to know. His action, although goaded by Joe's callous remarks, wasn't a wise one.

He swatted toward the sound, but his fingers raked through empty air.

Tommy looked at the bowl of fruit. "My mom says fruit attracts gnats and fruit-flies."

"Well, least we can do is rid Mr. Smith's place of a few bugs," Joe said, gleeful to have something to do amid his boredom.

"You see it?" Tommy asked, not all that interested.

"No, but I heard the little sucker," Joe said. "And I hate those pesky, little things."

As he spoke, Joe picked up a newspaper from Mr. Smith's table and rolled it into a long, tight cylinder. "Come out, you little pest!"

Mr. Smith felt a sense of panic at finding himself trapped with two teenagers suddenly bent on his destruction.

He took a cue from the dream and flew toward Tommy's face. He didn't trust Joe, but surely he could persuade his neighbor to accept the truth.

Tommy heard the buzzing of tiny wings and then a moment of shock when a tiny gnat landed on the tip of his nose, looking toward his face.

Tommy thought about it….

Obviously, the simple flick of Tommy's giant finger had caused considerable damage to Mr. Smith's transformed body. The casual action on the part of the enormous teenager had sent him spiraling to a crash landing on the living room floor. Now, as Tommy scanned for any sign of the gnat, the transformed scientist tried to make his six tiny legs carry him to safety.

After the exhilarating sensation of flight, having to rely on his legs, even six of them, made it seem like he was moving at slow speed.

Suddenly, and with alarming repercussions for the tiny gnat-man, Joe stomped back into the room after his visit to the kitchen. He still had his rolled-up newspaper in one hand.

"There's nothing decent to drink in this guy's kitchen," Joe complained.

"Well, I guess Mr. Smith didn't take your tastes into consideration when he went shopping," Tommy said, still scanning the room for any sign of the gnat he had flicked off his nose.

"What's the matter? Lose something?"

"Oh, I flicked that damn gnat, and now I don't know where it is."

Joe's expression enlivened with in interest. "Yeah? Where is it?"

Tommy shrugged. Don't know. If it knows what is good for it, I guess it cleared out."

"Still weird about your neighbor flaking out on us," Joe said. "I mean, he did promise us a meal for saving his sorry ass."

"Yeah, I can't figure that out," Tommy said, looking stumped.

"Oh! What do we have here?" Joe crowed in triumph as he saw a tiny speck of movement on the floor near his feet.

Joe bent his legs and squatted down for a better look at the struggling bug. One of the gnat's tiny wings looked bent, which had effectively grounded the pesky bug.

"I'm going to rock your world, you little pest," Joe declared.

The tiny gnat-man felt his blood chill. "Oh no!" The enormous teenager filled his entire view, even blocking off his sight of Tommy.

"Well, I did promise you that I'd take care of you, didn't I?" Joe gloated as he looked down at the insect, which kept trying to crawl across the floor.

Hope leaped into the little bug-man's mind. Had Joe just offered to help? The lifted newspaper showed the tiny man-bug that he had misunderstood Joe's phrasing.

"Take care of….oh no! He means to kill me!" The terrified little bug-guy realized.

Joe, with a smirk wide on his face, continued to describe what was about to happen.

"You're going to be a tiny little smear," Joe promised as he prepared to bring the full force of the rolled-up newspaper down on the gnat.

"You just gonna talk to it and bore it to death?" Tommy asked.

The injured wing twitched, and the frail design began to bounce back into its proper shape. "Wait!" Mr. Smith cried. "Please, don't."

To add to the comic horror of the situation, Tommy had stirred himself to stand. He walked over and stood behind Joe, looking down as the little bug twitched its wings desperately in a chance to take to the air again.

"Smashing it with a newspaper?" Tommy said in a joking manner. "Not terribly inventive, dude."

The tiny man felt his wing strengthen. "Almost there," he cried, followed by an attempt to send a plea to his gigantic neighbor. "Tommy, please. It's me! Don't let him do this!"

Arriving back at his home, Bryan Smith found himself prone to odd spells of hysterical laughter. He sat down at his kitchen table, thinking back to only a few hours earlier when the table had loomed overhead as a construction of impossible physics.

He crossed the room and looked down into the sink. He reacted with a jolt of shock when he saw the oddly familiar plate that still contained the remnants of a gnawed chicken wing. He recalled how immense the plate had looked when he ran across it in a desperate attempt to derive some nourishment from the scraps the crowd of Tommy's teenaged friends left behind during their impromptu party in his home.

He saw something else that set his heart to pounding and his pulse to racing. He lifted up the tiny shot glass, marveling that the tiny glass had seemed like an immense, inescapable prison when he had been at the mercy of Tommy and his giant friends.

A cold chill passed along his spine as the realization dawned on him of how closely he had came to an untimely end at the unaware hands of his enormous teenaged neighbor and his equally colossal friends.

How had he ever convinced himself that shrinking himself down to the size of a bug to mail himself to his nephew was a good idea?

His laughter, giddy and nervous, betrayed his nervousness. "I know what would make me feel better," he thought. "As soon as I can, I will make a trip to see Zack."

And the trip would involve a car trip or flight on a plane at normal size. The more he thought about it, the more he convinced himself that he should file away his notes on the shrinking formula and never re-visit the project.

More than anything, he decided he needed a good night's rest. First, he stripped off his old work-out clothes and took a long, relaxing hot shower.

He fell asleep soon after going to bed, but his mind remained quite active and haunted by his long, unusual day.

As he slept, he dreamed. In his dream, he found himself back to the insignificant size of a mere quarter-inch tall and trapped again in the shot glass.

Tommy's huge eyes stared at him.

"Mr. Smith, what the heck did you do to yourself?"

Tommy's booming voice echoed inside the glass chamber.

The tiny man fell on his knees, begging the teenager to help him. "I need this nightmare to end!"

As he stared at the titan's face, he noticed the smirk that formed on the handsome features.

"I think that can be arranged," Tommy announced. He tilted his head back and lifted his hand holding the shot glass high into the air.

"Tommy!" The tiny man cried in apprehension. "What are you doing?"

Instead of answering, the teenager opened his mouth wide and began to tilt the glass.

When he began to slide along the smooth glass surface, the tiny man scrambled to find anything to hold.

"Tommy! Don't!" He screamed as he slid toward the lip of the glass. Below, he saw Tommy's open maw, and the teenager's enormous tongue and the dark cavern at the back of the huge throat.

He produced a strangled scream as he fell, dropping into the open mouth, which then snapped closed, imprisoning him behind rows of teeth, with each tooth much bigger than his entire body!

He awoke in a dark room, quite except for his ragged breathing. "Oh my god," he muttered. "What a nightmare!"

As he lay still, trying to calm himself, the rising morning sun filtered through the enormous windows.

"What?" He snapped to attention.

The windows looked colossal.

"No!" He cried, but as the sun began to provide enough illumination for him to see, he realized that he had shrunk.

His size had dwindled to...

112122112211221122112222.content:
Stranded on his bed, which now resembled a vast plain of uneven terrain, the tiny scientist felt reality crashing down on him.

Obviously, the antidote had proved unstable, as he had feared. In many ways, his situation now looked even more dire than originally, when he had at least put some planning into his venture.

Now, totally unprepared, he found himself stripped of all resources, including clothing. With sunshine gradually flooding through a distant window, providing ample illumination, the bug-sized man took a few tentative steps across the bedcovers. Furniture, such as his dresser and a chest of drawers, looked like huge monuments separated by immense gulfs. Closer to the bed, rendered apart by a gulf more than 70 feet wide, stood his nightstand. Even more important, he saw his cellphone resting on the polished surface of the stand.

In his mind, the tiny man imagined using the phone to call Tommy to arrange a second rescue. After venturing as close to the edge as possible, however, he had to surrender to reality and let go of the lure of gaining access to his phone. The gap of several inches, translated into more than 70 feet from his current perspective, could not possibly be bridged.

As he gave up one alternative, he remembered the plans to treat Tommy and Joe to dinner as a reward for their assistance. In less than 12 hours, they would arrive as requested.

"I just need to be ready for them," he told himself.

That eventuality necessitated getting off the bed and into a more prominent position. As much as he disliked the prospect of having to venture through his colossal home, he realized that the two teenagers would never look for him in his bedroom.

"I just have to hope they'll look for me at all," he said aloud. He didn't dare put his next thought into words. "At least they shouldn't mistake me for a bug."

Was his optimism justified? Had his earlier encounters with Tommy and Joe rendered them more sensitive and alert to interactions with creatures no bigger than small insects?

The covers of his bed draped over the edge and descended almost to the floor.

"I'm glad I got rid of that shag carpet in favor of hardwood floors," he said. His former carpet would have swallowed him into a jungle of fibers many times the size of his tiny form.

His muscles strained as he began a descent toward the distant floor. In the end, he had to drop the last inch or so, which represented a plunge of almost 25 feet, straight down, to the hardwood floor boards. He landed without incident, although the cold floor sucked the heat from his measly body. He shivered and wished for clothes.

The trek to the door, which had looked easy from atop his bed, now proved slow going. Between every floor board was a chasm almost 12 feet deep and a body length wide. Leaping from board to board left him exhausted after crossing a span of only three boards. Forced to stop for rest, he stared toward the monolithic and still distant door.

He repeated the process several times, leaping several boards, resting for a brief time, and then resuming his journey. Finally reaching the door after almost an hour of travel, he found it absurdly easy to exit his room. Although the door was closed, he walked beneath the door with no difficulty at all.

On the other side of the door, the wood floors of the corridor represented the same challenge, but not to the same degree as the bedroom. He reached the end of the corridor in less than half an hour, finding himself on the verge of his gigantic living room where so much of the earlier drama and trauma had taken place after his initial reduction in size to the level of insects.

The coffee table represented an attractive location for seeking the notice of the giants, but the huge structure, supported on four massive columns, offered no means of ascent.

Fortunately, he remembered he had enjoyed success in reaching the surface of one of the living room end tables.

The end table next to his recliner stood close enough for the plastic leaves of a fake plant to provide a means of getting off the floor and to a higher vantage.

If he had managed the feat once, he could do it again. With that in mind, the tiny man began another grueling climb.

Once again, the strenuous climb required a couple of hours. He stopped for several rest breaks, but finally he reached the top.
He leapt from a massive plastic leaf that didn't even tremble as he walked across its horizontal surface. The leap from the flimsy artificial leaf took him to the surface of the massive end table.

He would have, ideally, preferred even closer proximity to the giants. At this location, he would be level with their crotches.

He looked around for anything he could use to signal to them. Except for a lamp, which looked like some ancient pagoda, the surface of the end table held nothing at all.

He could return to the floor, look for a scrap of paper, and then repeat the climb. That meant another four hours of intensive labor, and he wasn't even certain he would find anything useful. He decided to remain on the round plateau of the tabletop. He entertained the notion that, when they arrived and found him missing, they would be on alert to the possibility that he was once again small.

"When they find me, I'll have to get them to take me to the lab," he said. "Maybe I can still salvage one of my other experimental antidotes."

He had no way to judge time, but he guessed that it was well into the afternoon hours. In four or five hours, his titanic teenaged neighbor and his equally colossal friend would arrive. His body experienced a not unpleasant tingle as he remembered the way they looked as giants.

"No, I can't think about that," he said. The tiny man resolved to sit quietly and wait...
112122112211221122112222.title: Revisiting Old Tactics

1121221122112211221122222.content:
Mr. Smith kept alive the hope that, eventually, the boys would arrive and he could put a definitive end to his ordeal.

In a few hours, his titanic teenaged neighbor and his equally colossal friend would arrive for their promised dinner.

His body experienced a not unpleasant sensation as he remembered the way they looked as giants.

"No, I can't think about that," he said. The tiny man resolved to sit quietly and wait.

As the minutes ticked slowly away, the tiny little man found himself immensely bored on the barren landscape formed by the surface of the living room end table.

The more bored he got, the more his thoughts strayed to memories of what he had begun to think of as "Invasion of the Giant Teenagers" when Tommy and his friends had wandered freely though his home, unaware of the peril their every move represented to a tiny, unseen man only a quarter of an inch tall at their feet.

"Ohgod!" Mr. Smith though as he recalled the immense scale of Tommy's body.

The little man gave his hard-on a few jerks as he remembered the awe of seeing his giant teenage neighbor.

Then, dismayed at himself, he stopped and tried to cool himself down. His body and mind had thoughts of their own.

He saw himself as tiny as a ant on the floor among several pairs of sneakers the size of cruise ships.

Panting wildly, he abandoned himself to the rising urgency of his pressing need for release. Laying on his back on the unyielding surface of the table, he kept stroking himself toward release.

What did the trick was the memory of being trapped, helpless and tiny, in a massive shot glass held in Tommy's immense hand.

He exploded with pent-up energy, blowing a load all over his abs.

With his mind blanked out from the climax, he barely registered the sound of his front door opening to admit the giant teenaged form of his next-door neighbor.

When it did dawn on him that he was no longer alone, he was mortified to find himself sticky, messy and naked, with no means of trying to clean himself.

"YO!" Tommy's loud voice shattered the silence. "MR. SMITH, ARE YOU HOME?"

He was torn between remaining silent or shouting for the teenager's attention.

Of course, getting no immediate reply, the teenager passed quickly through the living room, entering the kitchen and again bellowing for Mr. Smith.

"Tommy!" The bug-sized man screamed as loudly as he could. "Over here! On the table!"

The little man threw himself flat on the tabletop as a horrific blast of wind followed in Tommy's hurried wake. Once the storm calmed, he stood again.

Tommy was bewildered at finding no one home, but then he was about an hour early. He returned to the living room and took his phone out of his pocket. He took a seat in the arm chair next to the end table as he punched in his neighbor's number.

In the distance, Tommy and tiny Mr. Smith heard the shrunken man's cell phone ringing from the bedroom. Tommy shrugged, figuring that Mr. Smith had left his phone at home while running an errand.

"BETTER LEAVE HIM A MESSAGE," Tommy said aloud. He waited for Mr. Smith's phone to pick up and for the pre-recorded message to run its course. At the beep, he left a message.

"HI, MR. SMITH. IT'S TOMMY. JOE AND I NEED TO TAKE A RAIN CHECK ON THE DINNER INVITATION," Tommy said.

Below, on the tabletop, the intended recipient of the message, listened to every word.

"I DO APPRECIATE IT, BUT YOU DON'T OWE US ANYTHING," Tommy said.

"No!" The tiny man screamed. He ran dangerously close to the edge of the table, hoping to make himself heard. "I've shrunk again!"

After he left the message, Tommy ended the call and slid his phone back into his pocket.

"Tommy, please," the tiny man screamed. "Don't leave! I am here!"

Tommy got out of the chair, but as he got to his feet, he jostled the edge of the table. He barely nudged the table, but the resulting movement was more than enough to pitch the shrunken scientist over the edge of the precipice. Screaming, the tiny man plunged to the floor in much quicker time than he had needed to reach the tabletop.
1121221122112211221122222.title: Highs and lows

11212211221122112211222221.content:
The tiny man's shock at having plunged from the tabletop to the kitchen floor was dwarfed by the immediate peril he faced when his teenaged neighbor stepped toward the back door.

Tommy's sneaker lifted, then smacked back to the tile floor, sending mild quakes through the unyielding tiles to be experienced by the bug-sized scientist who now found himself ant-sized at the feet of his titanic neighbor.

His fantasy, suddenly brought to horrifying life, terrified him.

"Tommy! Please!" He screamed. "Be careful. I've shrunk again!"

Tommy, far from hearing his tiny neighbor's pitiful pleas, dialed up his friend, Joe.

"I'm over at Mr. Smith's," he explained as he paced in a tight circle. "No sign of Mr. Smith."

"Good," Joe said. "I didn't want to have dinner with some old guy, anyway."

Tommy sounded critical. "Don't be like that, dude," he said. "Mr. Smith's an OK guy, and he's not that old."

The little man kept screaming as the massive sneakers dropped all around him. Once, the shoe landed a mere fraction from him. The explosive force as the huge shoe smacked into the titles blew the bug-sized scientist roughly off his feet.

"Ooof!" The little man grunted when he landed on his back.

He smelled something horrible and saw that with each step on the clean kitchen tiles, Tommy was tracking something thoroughly unwelcome into the otherwise immaculate kitchen.

"Gross, what the hell did you step in?" Mr. Smith yelled.

Tommy seemed to notice his messy footprints at about the same time. "Oh, hell. I must have stepped in something, and now I've tracked it all over Mr. Smith's floor. He'll kill me!"

"Better clean it up," Joe suggested.

"Yeah, no kidding," Tommy said. "Gotta go. See you later."

He shoved the phone into his pocket. "Wonder if Mr. Smith has a mop?"

The bug-sized man saw his chance. He started running toward Tommy, crossing into one of the foul-smelling impressions of his gigantic neighbor's sneaker sole. It was the worst possible place to make himself seen. Surrounded by deposits of the stinking dog waste that Tommy had collected on his right shoe, the speck of a man wasn't even visible.

He ran through the dirty footprint impressed on the light-colored tile. "Tommy! Please! Help…"

Suddenly, he was engulfed in a dark shadow and saw the dirty underside of the enormous shoe headed right toward him. "Oh sh..–"

The shoe smashed down, flattening the bug-sized man in an instant. By then, Tommy had found Mr. Smith's mop. Ten minutes later, the kitchen look spic-and-span again.

Tommy, carrying the shoes he had now slipped off his feet, reflected that Mr. Smith would appreciate his efforts to keep the kitchen clean.

"I wonder where he got to?" The teenager said idly as he left by the back door.
11212211221122112211222221.title: Tommy steps on him

choices: Try to scrounge and survive
Try to escape and make his way to Tommy's home
11212211221122112211222222.content:
From the tiny man's perspective, the floor rushed upward to meet him after he fell off the tabletop. The impact, when it came, rattled him but did no real damage. He scrambled to his feet and looked skyward, trying to track his teenaged neighbor's movements.

Tommy hadn't moved far from the table. In fact, he had taken only a couple of steps, placing him halfway out of the living room via the door providing entry into the kitchen.

After leaving the message for Mr. Smith, he had meant to leave. The buzz from his phone vibrating in his pocket stopped him in his tracks. He fished the phone back out of his pocket and flipped it open. He saw that he'd received a text message from his girlfriend, Jessica. Smiling, he prepared to enter a reply to text back to her.

Starting with the sneakers that looked the size of naval destroyers, the frightened little man gazed up at the teenaged titan's towering form. Massive amounts of denim fabric wrapped around Tommy's legs and continued upward toward his waist and butt. From there, a red-and-white striped pullover covered his immense torso. The tight shirt accented quite precisely Tommy's admirable pecs and abs. With his face bent over his phone, the titan provided the unseen shrunken scientist with a good view of his mighty visage.

Mr. Smith had taken off more than a week from work to fully enjoy what he had intended to be a long visit with his nephew.

Thanks to a string of unfortunate events, his madcap scheme to mail himself to Zack's campus had gone wildly awry. Once Tommy departed, no one was likely to come looking for the tiny man any time soon.

Rather than risk being left behind in his home while stuck the size of an ant, the tiny man pushed himself into immediate action. He knew that if he could just gain Tommy's notice, he could salvage the situation that seemed to once again be spiraling out of control.

Like a puny bug, he sprinted with surprising speed across the floor. Against his instincts, he ran in a straight path toward the massive sneakers.

"Tommy, down here!" He screamed. "It's me! I'm on the floor!"

Tommy finished his text message and hit "send" to reply to Jessica's earlier one. He kept the phone in his hand and once again made ready to depart.

From far below on the floor, the shrunken scientist screamed when Tommy's massive body lurched into motion again. An enormous sneaker rose hundreds of feet into the air and stretched forward for hundreds of additional feet as the titan took a single step.

The sneaker landed with a deafening impact that shook the floor and tossed the bug-sized man off his feet. Taking another step, the titan lowered his sneaker only a few mere yards from his tiny neighbor's spot on the floor.

The second footfall hit just as the little man had been getting back onto his feet. The earth-shaking impact knocked him onto his back. Tommy's other massive leg swung into action, moving forward and propelling Tommy's immense form closer to the kitchen.

For a moment, the huge sneaker had been almost close enough for him to touch. Then, in a cruel blow, the shoe lifted and continued its thunderous progress across the room, leaving the little man far behind in its wake.

The bug-sized scientist wanted to cry at the way his potential salvation had been ripped from him. By the time he got safely on his feet again, his titanic neighbor had left the room and entered the kitchen.

Refusing to surrender, he started running again, even shouting his futile pleas for rescue to a giant who could not possibly discern his feeble squeaks.

He was still a long way from the threshold into the kitchen when he heard the kitchen door open and, only second later, slam shut to announce that the quarter-inch-tall scientist was now quite alone in his huge home.
11212211221122112211222222.title: Beyond notice

choices: To exit beneath the back door
To seek an alternative way out of his home
112122112211221122112222221.content:
After two days of being marooned in his own home, the shrunken scientist began to feel the push of desperation.

No one came into the house, but he didn't expect any visitors. His stomach grumbled and his throat felt parched. He had eaten, and he had found a source of water, but neither supply of these necessary items looked dependable.

Scrounging on the kitchen floor, first beneath the massive table supported by four monolithic wooden columns, and then in the dark, dank space beneath the fridge, the bug-sized man found food.

Beneath the fridge he recovered a peanut, dropped who knows how long ago, and more or less intact. He tried to move the massive legume, but since the peanut was twice his size, he wasn't able to budge it.

He bit small chunks from the peanut, which tasted foul and rancid. "It's probably rotten with filth," he told himself, but he told himself it was probably more nutritious than the alternative.

Now, reduced to a speck, he easily located every crumb and dry morsel that had fallen and accumulated beneath his table. Some of the crumbs he could hold in one of his own tiny hands. Others, much like the peanut, were larger than his teeny body and he had to break dry, tough manageable chunks.

Water wasn't as easy to locate. He dreamed of climbing the kitchen counter and reaching the distant sink, but knew that even if he could succeed at such an undertaking (no guarantee considering his tiny size) he still faced the impossibility of manipulating faucets as big as buildings.

Condensation of water beneath the fridge had mixed with black gunk and mildew, making the water unpalatable and probably unhealthy.

A trek down the long hallway to the bathroom solved his immediate need for water. Drops of cool, if unappetizing, water condensed along the porcelain base of the toilet. He sucked at a droplet of water adhered to the size of the monumental porcelain structure.

The disappointing aspect of his dilemma rested in the fact the sources of food and water were located distantly apart. The bathroom tiles offered no food, no crumbs, no dropped peanuts.

The kitchen offered no hope of water for someone the size of an ant.

He could eat his fill in the kitchen, but then had to make a trek back to the bathroom that took hours to complete.

In his depression, he wondered why it mattered. It wasn't like he had anything better to do.

He got a few hours of sleep, usually content to curl up and rest wherever he was when his body felt too tired to continue.

He stayed cold, and so far he hadn't managed to find anything that could protect him from the chill and cover his nakedness. The few scraps of paper he found defeated his efforts to even fashion anything similar to a crude toga.

His life became a grueling routine. He scavenged for food when he awoke and when he filled his belly, he burned all the energy he had just consumed in the long trek to obtain water. Thirst temporarily at bay, he was hungry by the time he returned to the kitchen.

On the third morning, with a warming sun shining through the window and chasing off the chill as he basked in the glow, he made a decision.

"Life's not worth living like this," the former scientist said aloud. "I've got to take a risk and travel to Tommy's home. He's my last chance of regaining my normal life."

He didn't feel optimistic. Tommy's mountain-sized home, although located next door to his own, represented a journey of miles through the enormous wilderness.

He decided to visit the peanut beneath his fridge again. Even if rancid, the giant legume offered much-needed protein.

Now, he faced another challenge. How could he best escape his own house?

He had already tried the front door. Even for someone reduced to the size of an ant, the door was sealed tight at the floor.

The back door offered a better prospect, but that door exited into the wild territory of the wide lawn located between the two houses.

He decided...
112122112211221122112222221.title: Survival tactics

choices: Tommy's huge form
A bird flying overhead
1121221122112211221122222211.content:
For once, he felt thankful for his habit of procrastination. He had meant to replace the backdoor to his home, and had even placed the project on a "to-do" list.

In winter, the crack under the door admitted a cold draft into the home. In summer, insects and other creepy-crawlies used the wide space between the floor and the underside of the door to gain entry into his otherwise immaculate home.

After stuffing himself on a few more dry crumbs he located on the kitchen floor, the tiny man walked to the back door. The crevice between floor and the bottom of the door loomed larger than closer he approached.

In the end, he walked easily beneath his own door, directly onto the cracked concrete sidewalk that led through the yard to the gate at the fence that curtailed his home away from passersby walking along the street.

Of course, the bug-sized man didn't follow the sidewalk. His destination lay in the other direction, on the other side of an immense jungle of grass, weeds and shrubs.

As he stood on the sidewalk, he saw Tommy's home looming like a distant plateau fixed against the distant horizon. Even from that distance, the home looked immense and made the journey he was about to undertake look even more daunting.

He had meant to get an early start, but by the time he had managed to scavenge enough crumbs for a decent meal the sun had already been rising in the sky for a couple of hours.

Now that he was outside in the vast expanse of his own backyard, he felt smaller than ever. He considered reversing course, and running back into the security of his own home. He shook his head.

What choice did he have? He could seek out Tommy or face living the rest of his life the size of an ant.

He had carried a crumb in one fist, and he nibbled on the stale food as he made his trek into the jungle. The thick canopy of grass blades made him uneasy, so he decided to make his crossing through the barren, brown stretches of the yard in spots where the poor soil managed to nourish only a few scattered weeds that looked as tall as redwoods to a man no more than a quarter-inch tall.

Pebbles looked the size of boulders, and meant inconvenient detours when he was forced to walk around them.

He had traveled for about an hour when the hot sun beating down on his pale, naked form caused his thirst to return with a vengeance. He swallowed hard with a dry throat and tried to ignore the desire for clear, refreshing water.

He had entered a wide stretch of cracked, baked clay (the remnants of a lake-sized mud puddle that had evaporated in the sun) when a large shadow engulfed him and much of the surrounding terrain in darkness.

He looked up in sudden fright and saw...
1121221122112211221122222211.title: Out the back door

choices: Tommy's arrival spooks the bird
Into the bird's beak
11212211221122112211222222112.content:
From high in the air, the dark-feathered bird surveyed the ground. Flying from yard to yard in the suburban neighborhood, the bird had been busy since sunrise, searching for signs of movement, swooping lower whenever something of interest caught its attention.

The pale little form wandering across a flat region of cracked and dry mud acted like a magnet. The bird folded its wings and plunged earthward.

The huge shadow caught him unprepared. He looked desperately around for some shelter or refuge. In the meantime, the shadow passed by, but then circled and started back in his direction, dropping lower the entire time.

Despite its immense size, he recognized the familiar silhouette of a bird as the creature flew out of the heavens, swooping lower and causing the bug-sized human even more alarm.

He darted toward a boulder-sized pebble, pressing his soft, naked form against its rough surface.

As he reached this dubious shelter, the bird dropped to earth, extending its scaly feet that acted like the landing gear of some massive aircraft.

It hit the ground and immediately did a little hop, moving closer to the last location of the interesting tiny creature.

It pivoted and focused a single black eye on the pale form huddled against a small rock.

"Go away!" The shrunken scientist ordered in a bellicose tone. He scrambled and grabbed small pebbles in each fist. He tossed them with impotent fury at the staring bird. "You heard me! Go!"

The bird squawked and opened its bill wide. The raucous noise immediately terrified the little man, who now realized his peril.

The dark bird loomed over everything. The little man tried to scramble around the rock, keeping the boulder between him and the bird.

In two smooth hops, the bird closed the gap and found itself looking straight down at the tiny creature.

The bug-sized man had time only to scream and throw up his arms when the bird ducked its head and snapped its bill closed.
11212211221122112211222222112.title: Bird's Eye View

choices: Step on the pebble
Kick the pebble with his shoe
112122112211221122112222221121.content:
Tiny Bryan, no more than a mere bug in a world populated by hungry giants, screamed as the dark bird snapped its bill closed only inches from his hiding place behind a pebble that was as big as a boulder to the shrunken scientist.

The bird missed, but looked determined to try again. As the tiny professor contemplated the indignity of being eaten by a mere songbird, he didn't notice the arrival of an even larger threat.

Determined to make a last-ditch attempt to save himself, he scooped some gravel into his fists and flung the small particles at the stubborn bird. "Go! Get out of here!" The tiny man screamed.

To his shock, the bird lifted its wing — and flew!

Then, the shadow fell over him and the boulder that was serving as his hiding place. He turned and gazed up in awe at a familiar form.

"Tommy!" The tiny man shouted. "Oh my god! Tommy, I shrunk again. You have to…"

He didn't get to finish. The teen kept walking toward him and was now so close each step literally shook the ground beneath tiny Bryan's feet.

"Oh no! I'm still too tiny for him to notice!" The little man cried in anguish.

As for Tommy, he was still worried about Mr. Smith's confusing disappearance. He had discussed the situation with Joe, who had suggested that maybe Mr. Smith was back at his laboratory, making up for lost time. Still, he remained worried, and had decided to take another look around Mr. Smith's home.

As he walked, he didn't pay too much attention to the ground beneath his feet, but he did see the dark bird, its attention fastened on a small pebble on the ground. When the bird saw him, however, it quickly flew away to some nearby trees.

Not thinking much about it, Tommy continued toward his neighbor's back door, his path taking him toward the small pebble. He could have stepped over it, but he decided to…
112122112211221122112222221121.title: Tommy's Timely Arrival

1121221122112211221122222211211.content:
It was, after all, nothing more than a pebble, and the teenager wasn't in the habit of going out of his way to avoid stepping on such things.

Mr. Smith saw that Tommy's path was advancing toward him as he glanced from behind the pebble.

It wasn't fair!

"No," he screamed as loudly as he could. "Tommy! I shrunk again! Please, look for me."

Tommy shoes kept crunching down on the hardened earth between his house and his neighbor's. When begging an unhearing god didn't work, Mr. Smith decided at the last second to try to evade his fate.

He'd waited too long.

Tommy's shoe came down with a crunch that drove both the boulder-sized pebble and the tiny man crouching in its shadow into the sand and grit. When the huge shoe lifted, the boulder stayed behind, but tiny Mr. Smith's pulverized body continued for a step or two before falling off onto the dirt.

Tommy, despite his recent practice with noticing tiny objects, missed the entire incident and continued on his way.

After the human teenager left the scene, the bird dropped back onto the ground, intent on snapping up the mangled prize. Usually, bugs tried to at least run away, but it mattered very little to the bird as it snapped its beak closed around the tiny man's remains and quite neatly disposed of him before flying off to look for more insects.
1121221122112211221122222211211.title: Just a pebble

112122112211221122112222221122.content:
The bill clacked closed, cutting off the little man's terrified scream.

Inside the darkness, he felt sure the bird would end him with a single gulp.

When the slide over the strange tongue and down the throat didn't follow the expected schedule, he stopped screaming and tried to figure out what was happening.

The curved lower mandible forming the bird's beak formed a perfect scoop for holding him imprisoned.

The bird lifted from the evaporated puddle and took back to the sky. It flew in a direct path toward a distant tree standing in a yard of a home about a block from Mr. Smith's residence.

The black-feathered bird landed on a perch provided by a thick limb. Looking down, the bird saw its three nestlings, all sleeping peaceably enough until its arrival triggered their feeding response.

In a crowded nest woven of plant fibers and twigs, three hungry young birds opened their beaks and shrieked for food.

The large bird lowered its head and opened its beak over the gaping maw of one of the young birds. At this stage of development, the nestling looked gangling, just a bulging body and a tiny head.

From inside the bird's beak, the shrunken scientist looked down into the gaping red and yellow maw of the nestling bird's gullet.

"Oh my god..." the little man managed to cry just as the adult bird shook its head to fling him out of the bill and into the eager beak of the nestling.

The baby bird's beak snapped closed, and it swallowed the "insect," only to immediately screech for more food.

The adult bird lifted its wings and flew away to begin gathering more insects for a hungry brood.

It had been bad enough when the large dark bird snatched him into its beak. He had felt humiliated to end as a morsel for a monster bird. He had enough conscious thought left to ponder the even more humiliating aspect of being stuffed into the gaping maw of a hungry, growing baby bird, to provide a measure of protein to help the bird mature and eventually take wing and leave its nest in Mr. Smith's suburban neighborhood.
112122112211221122112222221122.title: The Nest

choices: It's a large centipede
It's a large spider
1121221122112211221122222212.content:
After a meal of small bites from the somewhat rancid peanut beneath the monolithic refrigerator, the tiny man made his way out of his kitchen and through the cathedral-like hallway that led to his utility room.

He had formulated a plan of escape from his home that didn't entail a journey through the jungle wilderness of his back yard.

The utility room led to a door that opened directly into his garage, which was the one part of his house located closer to his neighbor's residence. By taking a long detour through the garage, his journey would take more time but he could avoid the dangers of the gigantic outdoors.

His bug-sized form found squeezing under the utility room door a fairly easy step in his progress. He walked past an enormous plastic laundry basket still filled with some unwashed clothes. The huge washer and dryer loomed over everything else in the untidy room, which also provided a stop-gap place for him to discard items, including some gardening implements and old chipped flower pots.

When his stomach rumbled, he kept his eyes open for any morsel or crumb. The utility room proved a sterile environment, offering nothing at all in the way of nourishment.

"I just have to push ahead and get to Tommy," the shrunken scientist told himself. "If I can get his help, everything will be better."

He reached the other end of the utility room and slipped easily under the door into the garage.

Stepping into the garage transported him onto a vast, cracked plain of cement surrounded by rough walls formed of massive concrete blocks stacked one upon the other. His automobile, parked inside the garage, looked like a mountain of red metal and plastic. An old cabinet pushed against one wall stored his few tools and an assorted collection of odds and ends.

He sighed when he gazed across the vast plain of cement and realized the trek through the massive structure would take longer than he had anticipated.

Realizing he had little choice, he forced himself to forge ahead. From instinct, he stayed close to the wall. As he got closer, he realized the concrete blocks were not as smooth as they appeared from a distance. Deep crevices and crannies appeared between some of the massive blocks. When he peered into the caverns, his eyes made out only inky darkness.

However, inside the wall, other creatures with better-developed senses, began to monitor his travels deeper into their domain.

He had walked past a particularly large, jagged gash in the wall when he heard a rasping sound coming closer...
1121221122112211221122222212.title: Into the garage

11212211221122112211222222121.content:
This was like some terrible Sci-fi movie for tiny Bryan Smith. When the huge metro train sized centipede burst forth from the dark recesses, Bryan froze in shock. To the shrunken scientist, who was already terrified of insects at normal size, the centipede was his worst nightmare.

A high pitched screech rang from his mouth as he burst into a desperate flight. Many dozens of legs that were easily more agile than the tiny man allowed the fearsome creature to cut off Bryan's escape. It curved around him like a snake, trapping him.

"No! No, no, no!" Bryan cried in utter terror, his face white as a sheet and his eyes bulging. He looked around desperately for an opening, but all he saw were the grotesque and spindly legs. They were taller than he was alone. He was trapped.

A rasping sound caught his attention, causing him to turn to the horrendous centipede's head. It loomed over him like a building, huge antennae lashing about like bridge supports, and two inky black eyes that leeched all hope from him. Huge, powerful mandibles clashed together in preparation for a meal. Bryan fall backwards with a loud whimper.

With a swift advance the mammoth centipede was upon the tiny man. The cruel mandibles deftly snatched Bryan's leg, breaking it easily and lifted him up. He let out one final scream, his thoughts racing at a mile a minute as he went over every twist of fate and regret. He had been saved! Why didn't he realize the cure might not work? Why did he cancel the exterminator a week ago? Why...?

It was all over a second later. The centipede, acting on pure instinct, was unable to reason what it had just eaten. All it knew was that it was satisfied for now, and it had better return to the safety of the crevice before a human appeared. With a series of clickety, clack, it slinked back into the crevice.

------

Only after three days passed, would Tommy begin to suspect why Mr. Smith vanished once again. He stopped by the empty house, and made the effort to search the floors and tabletops. Tommy found no trace of him, only a couple spiders, and a rather gross centipede that he promptly smashed seemed to remain in the house. What could have happened?

Tommy gave up hope rather quickly, feeling confused about the situation. The teenager returned his focus to school, his friends, and the unfortunate prospect of finding more paying work.
11212211221122112211222222121.title: His worst nightmare

choices: An even larger spider intrudes.
Bryan's neighbor Mike is trimming the bush
11212211221122112211222222122.content:
Curious, the tiny man stopped and squinted in to the darkness of the cavernous crevice. In the intense darkness, tiny Bryan thought he saw what looked to be glossy dark orbs hovering in the darkness. A sudden chill ran down the little man's spine and before he could turn to run, a dark mass revealed itself from the shadows.

A spider that normally would of been no larger than a dime, was easily the size of a bus depot to the tiny scientist. The horrid creature sported eight hair legs, and greedily stared Brayn down with six cold eyes.

Without further adieu, Bryan let out a yelp and bolted, his tiny legs feeling clumsy and slow. No more than a second later, he was knocked down as one of the spider's horrific legs blocked his flight. Turning around, he didn't have a chance to scream before the spider grabbed hold of him and began quickly binding the little man in a disgusting silken prison.

The tiny man's vision faded as he fainted from terror.

The spider made quick work wrapping up it's tiny prey, spinning the strong silk around the man. Clutching the immobilized scientist like a take-away dinner, the spider swiftly set out in the direction of it's home.

Usually this common garden spider was able to catch unsuspecting flies, moths, and the occasional beetle in the intricate web it had spun on the limb of a massive bush bordering Bryan's yard. Lately, the spider found itself lacking the desired level of prey and decided to venture out to distant lands in search of small unwary insects.

The large spider found itself very satisfied with this find and quickly climbed the overgrown bush in anticipation of devouring the captured food in the safety of it's webby home.

Placing the tiny prey carefully on the intricate web, the spider prepared to make quick work of this juicy morsel.
11212211221122112211222222122.title: It's a large spider

choices: He landed on a large leaf
Something else
112122112211221122112222221221.content:
Bryan Smith, shrunken to a size smaller than a common ant, returned to consciousness with a lurch.

His terrifying capture by the monster arachnid came back to him in a flash. His face was mostly exposed, but his body was tightly bound, the powerful silken webbing held tightly around him.

The tiny man screamed out at the sight of the huge spider's form poised overhead. The grotesque creature looked ravenous, saliva dripping from it's threatening mandibles, and an animalistic glare in the bulging red eyes. His terrified squealing only seemed to excite the creature like the sound of a dinner bell.

"No! Not like this!" He choked. Bryan couldn't believe he had been saved by Tommy, only to shrink again, and now he was going to be devoured by a garden spider! His body shook uncontrollably, despite the spider's bindings, and his blood seemed to turn to ice.

Bryan's eyes shut tightly as the spider seemed to prepare to dig in. He opened his mouth to let out another yelp, when the spider suddenly retracted. It's entire body seemed to turn to stone, as it appeared to be listening. This onset of inaction by the spider left the tiny scientist motionless despite his terrified predicament.

The web seemed to tremble slightly, as if something else was moving on the sticky surface. What could it be?

------------

Almost overwhelmed with hunger, and in a fit of hysteria induced by it's prey's fearful squeaks, the spider was just about to devour the helpless creature when something unfamiliar disturbed the web.

Freezing itself in order to concentrate on the vibrating strands of web, the spider waited. Something large was traversing the complex webbing of the spider's home. This something was quite rude, interrupting a long-awaited meal, the spider noted angrily. The prey seemed to fall still, giving the spider a pinpoint of the invader's point of entry.

A threatening hiss emitted from the direction before a large form rushed forward. The spider reared itself up as the larger arachnid attacked.

------------

Mr. Smith watched with horrified amazement as the spider that kidnapped him was assaulted by an even larger spider. This invader appeared even more ferocious if possible to Bryan.

The two arachnids lunged at each other in an attempt to sink their poison-filled fangs into the opponent. It was like some gladiatorial match between two mythic beasts, which might have interested him, except that he was in the ring with the two monsters. As the two spiders lurched viciously, the webbing tore and began falling apart, causing tiny Bryan great alarm. He tried to concentrate on escaping.

Wriggling violently, he began to feel his sticky bindings loosen slightly. He finally caught a frightening break when the larger spider crashed one of it's legs into him, breaking through the webbing and freeing Bryan's left arm. This sudden luck turned sour as moments later the webbing that precariously supported him gave way, sending him into a free fall.

Tiny Bryan Smith screamed as his half-freed form plummeted and was battered by the leaves below.

He fell until...
112122112211221122112222221221.title: An uninvited guest

choices: Climb down!
A huge flying insect lands!
1121221122112211221122222212211.content:
Bryan fell. He continued to fall seemingly forever. Branches thicker than trains and streets whipped past him, while leaves both dried and green offered to catch him.

The entire experience was akin to a theme park ride. More than once Bryan feared he would splat against one of the huge leaves, or be dashed upon a massive branch, but every time he missed and continued falling. All the while, his tiny body whipped around in violent spins and rotations.

He just screamed as the rushing winds forced him around once more.

Then he met with an abrupt splash.

"Accckkk!" Watered coated him, running over his dirt-stricken face. He spat some out. "Goddd! Fucking God! Oh, my..."

Wriggling around, he cursed and splashed in the ankle-high puddle with feverish panic. He still felt as if he was plummeting.

"Oh, shit... shit, shit, shitting fuck!"

Finally, he stopped and released his breath in a deep sigh. It was over. He had landed - alive - and it was over. He had survived!

Elation washed over the tiny scientist. It was like he had discovered the cure for cancer, or plucked the largest pearl from the ocean floor. He had escaped certain doom at the mandibles of an over-sized spider and lived!

Leaping to his feet, Bryan rubbed his face. The moisture felt delightful and even soothed his numerous cuts and scrapes. Giddily splashing like a child, he sashayed from the puddle to dry ground.

"Wait... Where the frilly fuck am I?"

Looking around confirmed his initial fear. He had only fallen seemingly so far to land upon a leaf! To top it off, the "puddle" that had broken his descent was nothing more than a collection of morning dew! The green, veiny surface spanned around him for over a dozen feet. It was huge!

"Nothing more than a damn leaf on that freaking bush in my yard..." He spoke with disappointed variations in his tone.

Scampering to the edge, Bryan only confirmed his fears. His current position was still many hundreds of feet above ground. He was effectively trapped unless he could manage to climb down. "...Or grow a pair of wings! That would be a great addition to my damnable formula!"

Sighing, Bryan considered his options.
1121221122112211221122222212211.title: Morning dew

choices: Climb something to gain his bearings
Danger is never far
11212211221122112211222222122111.content:
Scampering from edge to edge, Bryan peered off the leaf with a gulp. He never liked heights to begin with, but this was just ridiculous.

"I must be a few hundred feet above the ground"

Glancing up into the tangle of dark leaves and branches, he wondered how far he had fallen to get to this point. The thought only made him shiver.

Padding the firm, yet rubbery surface, he squinted at the tower of hard bark that supported both his leaf and many others. One branch twisted by, careening to the ground like Jack's beanstalk from fairytale. A scurrying highway of black ants went to and fro, climbing and descending the branch busily. Some carried bits of leaf or small insects.

Bryan looked back to his own branch. He would need to teeter across the thick stem and hopefully latch upon the rough bark to climb down.

"I can do this; I can do this..." He shivered. "Just remember who you are and what you accomplished."

Steeled, Bryan stepped from the rubbery leaf and unto the hard stem. He nearly lost his balance, barely recovering with a gasp, and hurriedly crossing the span with a leap onto the branches slanted surface.

"Down I go..."

Down he went with careful consideration for each placement of hand and foot. He surprised himself how agile he was. Climbing the massive pillar of plant with nary a problem. That was until he placed his foot down upon a dark lump that protruded most conveniently. Without warning, the odd lump hissed at him and shifted. Bryan screeched in response, his foothold moving from under him, forcing him to scrape desperately for another.

Regaining his hold, he glanced down, wide-eyed and clammy. "What the hell!" Below, the rude perpetrator scuttled lazily, nestling itself into a gap of bark. "Damn bugs - I better watch my step...!"

Insect life existed all around him, all previously beneath his notice before reducing himself, but now buzzing and clicking loudly from every direction.

He dared a glance down, desperate to check his progress. Expecting to look down and feel vertigo, he nearly pealed with excitement to see that ground a mere thirty or so feet below. Higher than any normal person would like, but a huge improvement to before!

Bryan quickly finished the remaining climb. His confidence nearly bursting with such an impressive display of bravery and athleticism. "I can't believe I just did that!" He said, gazing up the looming length he just scaled. The leaves were so thick, it was impossible to determine where he began. Smiling, he turned and looked upon his new surroundings.

Immediately, he released all confidence like a deflating bagpipe. "Shit... Not out of danger yet," Bryan looked around, unsure. "Where the hell am I?"
11212211221122112211222222122111.title: The Great Climb

choices: Bryan goes for the ride of his life
Bryan is taken for a long ride
11212211221122112211222222122112.content:
It was a rather idyllic scene. Sun trickled in through the many hundreds of leaves, adding a sort of fairy-tale look to Bryan's magnified world. The leaf he stood upon was a vibrant green when lit by the ray of sunlight, and the moisture glittered like crystal.

Bryan, of course, had never been much for nature. He rarely ventured outdoors; always refusing to partake in family camping trips with his dad and younger brother. In fact, he vehemently disliked nature and all it offered. Bugs and other creepy crawlies topping the list.

Crossing his arms, Bryan frowned and looked around. His options were slim: climb or jump down. The latter only happening if he slipped while climbing.

"Ugh... I survive the impossible only to end up here! How can this get any worse!"

Cliches always rise to the challenge, and just as the words left his sour lips, he found out.

First came a gale of turbulent wind. Then, roaring and buzzing loud enough to make a jet engine envious. Bryan screeched in terror at the sight of such a huge insect. It swept through the labyrinth of leaves and headed directly for his leaf.

Still screaming, Bryan curled himself up, hoping the earthquake position worked against giant bugs.

The massive creature landed. Each hair-coated leg landing with surprising grace upon the rubbery surface. Ignoring the balled-up scientist, the common fly skittered towards the pool of dew water and extended a long, greasy tube into it.

Bryan poked his head out from under his arms and watched.

The huge fly was nothing short of hideous. Bulging, glassy, crystalline eyes. Hardened opalescent body armour coated with dark hairs and shining with grease. Bryan couldn't help but pinch his face in disgust. He hated bugs, after all.

This bug in particular could care less about him. It merely slurped away at the collection of dew, twitching and adjusting a pair of translucent wings that looked larger than a six lane road.

"Wait a second... Wings!" Bryan whispered excitedly. "It works in the movies; why not for me?"

He knew the idea was more than crazy, but it seemed viable in comparison to climbing hundreds of feet down the branches of a bush. Commandeering this mindless insect, he could just fly down - Brilliant!

Not allowing himself to over think, Bryan jumped up and sped towards the drinking fly. It didn't even react as he approached. Something as tiny as Bryan was no threat to the garage-sized bug. Pausing next to a dark, segmented leg, Bryan stared with widened eyes.

"Here goes nothing!"

He propelled himself an impressive distance and latched onto the upper section of the prickly leg. Immediately, he felt the sharp hairs lock onto his clothing like Velcro. He let out a wild yip, feeling the humongous creature begin to stir.

Then the gigantic fly trundled backwards, wings stretching, and took to the air.
11212211221122112211222222122112.title: Wings

choices: Bryan encounters the large spider again!
Mike finishes, stomping towards tiny Bryan!
112122112211221122112222221222.content:
The tiny scientist awoke with a start. His small form was almost completely bound in the spider's heinous silk. Miraculously, Bryan's face was spared, giving the minute man a heart-stopping view of the spider's menacing mandibles.

Bits of what Bryan thought to be saliva dripped from the hungry spider's mouth. His pathetic struggles seemed to only excite the fearsome creature.

"I don't want to die like this!" He yelped as a disgusting hairy leg pulled him closer to the large, gnawing mandibles. The tiny mans arms seemed to loosen a bit, but he was unable to break the thick silk that was swaddled around him. Closing his eyes tightly, he prepared for the worst.

----------------

The sky was clear and a pleasant breeze made this Saturday afternoon an almost perfect day. Michael Duggan adjusted his baseball cap slightly as he surveyed his progress. The large Alpine Currant hedge that separated Mike's yard from his neighbor Bryan's was a beast of intruding branches. His wife had been hinting that he needed to trim the overgrown plant, and to avoid any bothersome conflict, Mike pulled out a pair of shears from the shed that morning and set to work.

Considered a very nice, likable guy, Michael moved in to the neighborhood only a year before with his family. A Navy man, the 26 year old and his wife decided to re-locate out of their apartment when their son was born. Tall, and well-built, he quickly became known around the neighborhood as the go-to guy when something stopped working, or needed moving. Bryan often made use of Mike's help whenever Tommy was unavailable.

When off-duty, Mike dressed casually. He wore a light grey t-shirt his brother had bought him a year ago, on the front it said, "New Dad 2012". Denim jeans, and a pair of Vans high-top sneakers made up the rest of his attire.

Cutting through the tangling branches of the bush, Mike was utterly unaware of the havoc he was causing to the small occupants of the bush. He paused for a moment when he heard a tiny shriek after felling a large branch. Shrugging, he lifted the tool again to cut the next branch, when he noticed a small spider on his forearm.

With a slight grin, he brushed the spider off and didn't give it a second thought.

----------------

CRACK!

A loud sound, followed by a distant crash caused the tiny man and his arachnid captor to jump with surprise. Another was heard, and sounded closer.

The spider had rotated itself towards the ruckus in preparation for a battle with this unknown entity, while tiny Bryan lay swaddled in the same position. The shrunken scientist didn't have long to lay still as a huge rusted blade burst through the surrounding leaves with a crash. From his position, he was able to watch in horror as a second blade made itself known, and the two came together crushing the supporting branch with unfathomable strength.

CRUNCH!

The minute man felt the web breaking apart beneath him as his entire world went topsy-turvy. His little voice rang out with a screech as he fell, catching a glimpse of the large spider lunging in an unknown direction. Bryan collided with a pool-sized leaf, and roughly slid down, sharp sticks cutting him from all sides.

As it's home fell, the angry spider reacted quickly and propelled itself off a leaf towards the destroyer of it's home. Landing on an alien landscape cluttered with rope-like hairs, the spider attempted to attack this threatening being, until a huge shadow came overhead, and a massive force threw the spider down to the grassy forest below.

Bruises and cuts all over, the tiny genius pulled himself loose from the torn silken bindings. Rubbing his tear-stricken eyes, Bryan tried to get his bearings after his most recent ordeal.

"What was that!?" He thought out loud. Surrounded by tall blades of grass, and huge broken branches, the shrunken man felt a sigh of relief that he didn't endd up as spider chow. His entire body shuddered at the memory of the Hellish mandibles.

A heavy explosive force thudded behind him, the concussion knocking him flat on his face. The tiny scientist craned his head back as he took in the awe-inspiring sight of an enormous sneaker. Its thick, white sole was stained with dirt and grass from stomping around on the lawn. Bryan whimpered and covered his head as the huge footwear lifted again and soared overhead.

BOOM!

The ground lurched once more throwing the tiny man off kilter. The gigantic sneaker had stepped further away, sparing the frightened scientist. Bryan craned his head and took in the awesome sight, following the titan's colossal form. A spark of recognition brightened in the little man's brain.

"Mike!" Cried the puny voice. His gargantuan neighbor's form loomed massively in the distance, causing everything else to seem small. Bryan looked watery-eyed, knowing that he could trust the helpful Mike to rescue him, forgetting his close call with the giant's sneakers.

Bryan sprinted hopefully toward the huge titan, his only plan that Mike would surely notice him.
112122112211221122112222221222.title: Bryan's neighbor Mike is trimming the bush

choices: Austin, the toddler son wants to play with the bugs
A huge lawnmower is approaching!
1121221122112211221122222212221.content:
Distant dull booms made themselves heard and felt as Mike continued his work. The tiny scientist slowed his pace, breathing heavily. The colossal Mike grew more distant with each step, covering large distances with ease.

"Please, wait! I need help!" Bryan's shrill voice whined. "I can't possibly keep up..." He mumbled, looking sadly at the looming figure in the distance.

The surrounding forest of grass resembled a prehistoric jungle to the bug-sized man. This comparison wasn't too far off, since the inhabitants of this jungle would easily challenge any dinosaur in size and power. All this without mention of the enormous Michael stomping around.

Large branches and leaves cut from the bush littered the landscape, and hindered the little man's progress even further. He saw a menagerie of insects recovering from the disaster caused by the shears. As he pulled himself over a particularly large log, Bryan felt as if he was being watched. A feeling he had felt before.

From above a large shape descended, landing with a heavy plop before him. It was the spider.

Upset over the destruction of it's home, and injured from the fall from the giant man's arm, the spider was determined to gain some satisfaction by eating it's escaped prey.

"No! Not again!" He screamed, and fled at full-speed away from the fearsome monster. A quick glance behind him showed the spider in furious pursuit. It's injured leg causing it to move in an irregular fashion. The tiny scientist was able to keep a slight lead running from the injured spider.

Adrenaline coarsing through his little veins, Bryan ran for what seemed like hours. He saw what looked to be a clearing up ahead, and closed his eyes as he burst through the clustered foliage.

Stumbling forward, he barely stopped himself from falling on his face. The clearing was about the size of a football field, and to his despair, cluttered with ants. A heavy noise brought his attention back to the pursuing spider which had just arrived.

Hoping the ants would protect him, the little genius ran towards the center of the clearing. Bryan looked back to see the spider reluctantly not pursuing. With a rush of triumphant relief Bryan shouted back to the spider, "Giving up? Hah!"

Bryan's smirk faded as a huge shadow encompassed the clearing.
1121221122112211221122222212221.title: Bryan encounters the large spider again!

choices: Mike decides to stomp the pesky ants out
Mike goes to grab some insect repellant
11212211221122112211222222122211.content:
Having perfected the skill of walking only recently, the curious Austin was giddy with laughter as he played in the grass. Nearby, his father Michael continued trimming the bush.

As he stumbled through the grass, Austin discovered to his delight a busy ant hill. The invasive ants had killed off a small circle of grass in order to build their empire. The toddler giggled as he poked at the crawling insects, his little mind curious if they would react in any particular way.

With big eyes he held his pudgy hand up, three angry ants crawling on it. Before the child could emit another excited giggle, the ants reacted in a way Austin did not expect.

They bit him.

----------------

Gazing up, Bryan swallowed hard with surprise. Austin, the bundle of joy that he had playfully tickled, and "talked" to during one of Mike's barbecues, was now the size of a mountain.

The huge toddler no longer seemed cute, or even annoying, but now appeared downright dangerous. Austin dug his building-sized hand into the ground, apparently trying to "play" with the ants. The tiny man was sure getting this monster child's attention would not end well.

Austin crashed his fat hand nearby, causing tiny Bryan to fall over. He watched as the toddler raised his hand, carrying three furious-looking ants. The child didn't seem to understand, Bryan thought, before the inevitable happened.

----------------

A loud shriek rang out causing the pre-occupied Michael to turn around. Dropping his shears, the tall man rushed to the bawling toddler.

"Hey, Buddy. What happened?" He said, patting the kid's head. He planted his huge foot right on the edge of the ant hill, crushing some ants underneath without noticing.

The disturbed child thrust his injured hand up, and pointed at the helpless ants indignantly.

----------------

The shrunken scientist covered his ears in desparation as the giant toddler screeched. He glared up at the dangerous, yet revoltingly annoying child as the ear-splitting cry ended.

A distant heavy boom accompanied by tremors caught Bryan's attention suddenly. Followed by another, and another. An impossibly large shadow covered the area, and Bryan was roughly knocked to the ground as a mountian-sized sneaker crashed down on the other end of the clearing.

"HEY, BUDDY. WHAT HAPPENED?" Thundered Mike's deep voice from above. Mike's massive Vans skate shoe crushed part of the now tiny looking ant hill, and numerous ants with it.

Craning his tiny head back, the little man looked in awe at the huge form looming directly over him. The dusty jean-clad legs seemed to stretched endlessly until met by the huge bulky torso. Bryan couldn't believe that he was able to interact with this titan normally before. Mike seemed less friendly, and more like a huge, un-forgiving titan.

A loud, indignant grunt signaled Austin informing his huge father of the guilty ants. Bryan watched Mike's face look toward the ground, raising his thick eyebrows inquisitively.

"ANTS? CRAP, I JUST SPRAYED A WEEK AGO" Mike's huge voice thundered to the tiny man's ears.

Bryan lept from his fallen position, and desperately waved his arms in vain. "Mike! It's me Bryan Smith! Help!" His voice felt shrill and small.

The shrunken man noticed a small form scaling the heel of the colossal shoe. The displaced spider crawled up the dirty white sole, and was making it's way to the hem of the huge denim jeans when Mike suddenly shifted his foot.

Falling back to the ground at the heel of the gigantic sneaker, the spider had barely a second before the footwear lifted slightly, and crushed the spider under it's immeasurable weight. Mike took no notice of the insignificant creature.

Watching this, Bryan couldn't help feeling a pang of sympathy for the determined arachnid. Bryan knew that just as easy, he could end up the same way.

Frozen in fear, the little man braced himself for what happened next.
11212211221122112211222222122211.title: Mike, the protective father

choices: Climb Mike's Shoe
Run Away!
112122112211221122112222221222112.content:
Mike leans down and scoops up Austin. Looking at the ant hill he frowns and mutters "I guess I'll spray again!". He turns toward the house, brushing Austin's hand and trying to comfort the unhappy boy. He enters the garage and pushes through a door leading to the kitchen. From there he walks through and places Austin into his playpen in front of the TV. "Just stay here buddy, while I get the mean ants!" Mike coos to Austin.

As he walks back through the kitchen he notices the footsteps of dirt he had tracked inside. "Shit, I'll get that in a sec." he promises to himself.

Back in the garage he approaches a shelf and picks up the can he had used before. He puts it down when he sees a can of maximum strength stuff his neighbor Bryan had given him as a thanks for fixing something Mike couldn't remember. Mike had saved it just in case, and now was the perfect time for it.

He holds the can in his hand and heads back to the yard.

---

Bryan had already been amazed by the mountainous toddler. Mike completely dwarfed him. Mike had already easily been a head taller than Bryan at 6'2", but now his height was beyond compare. He watches as the man bends down to his son. He easily scoops the large child into his arms, lifting him above the ground. He looks down with a grunt and mutters "I GUESS I'LL SPRAY AGAIN."

His foot lifts away raining dust, blades of grass, and smashed ants onto the hill. His foot flies directly above Bryan, his filthy sole crammed with dirt and unfortunate bugs who had crossed his path as he worked, crushed into oblivion without being noticed. Bryan watches as his view of Mike slowly disappears, the loud stomps fading as he walks away.

He looks around at the ants who will soon be writhing in pain from the spray. Bryan slowly retreats back to the grass trying to get as much distance from the anthill as possible.

---

Mike walks swiftly through the grass. He stops about 3 feet from the ant hill and looks at the can in his hand. The stuff supposedly trickles into the dirt to get to the ants underground. Mike smiles, it sounds perfect!

He steps forward, shakes the can, and starts spraying. The stuff douses the ground at his feet and he sees the ants struggle in the thick spray. When the smell starts to get to him he stops and admires his handy work. He decides to destroy any progress they had and lifts his foot over the anthill. He stomps onto it and it collapses.

Mike turns around and takes a couple steps before stopping and realizing ants rarely have one entrance. He slowly scans his yard for anymore bare spots or protruding hills. Not seeing any after a minute, returns to his house satisfied.

---

Bryan doesn't get far before Mike returns. The giant stomps past, not too far from the tiny man. Bryan stares at his titanic neighbor as he contemplates the can in his hand. From this raised part of the lawn, the shrunken scientist can see the clearing and ant hill.

He hears a loud clicking as Mike shakes the can in his hand and begins to spray. A thick cloud of deadly chemicals descends onto the clearing and Bryan watches the ants that had seemed so large to him begin to die. He walks away slowly, unable to tear his eyes away. Mere minutes ago he had been right there! He is chilled by the thought.

The spray stops but Mike doesn't step away. His foot suddenly rises and crashes down onto the ant hill. What had appeared to be an immovable part of the landscape to Bryan crumbles easily under Mike's weight. His shoe lifts away and Mike turns away from the carnage, his mission successful. In a single step Mike halves the distance between himself and Tiny Bryan. His second step flattens the tree-like grass blades just in front of Bryan.

Bryan cries out, falling over in shock. He whimpers and looks up, believing he has been mistaken for a bug. However Mike is staring into the distance, slowly turning his head. The gigantic man hadn't even noticed Bryan.

Bryan stares at the wall of rubber in front of him. Grass stains and dirt cake the sides of the sole that easily crushed through the forest of grass Bryan was currently trapped in. If he wants Mike's help he realizes he must take advantage of the standstill and start climbing. On the other hand Mike is a terrifying giant who could just as easily be Bryan's doom rather than his salvation.
112122112211221122112222221222112.title: Problem Solved

choices: Try scaling the table
Head for the living room
1121221122112211221122222212221121.content:
Mike returns the can of spray to its shelf in the garage and walks into the kitchen. He sees his wife there clearly unhappy. "What the hell Mike?" she says pointing at his footprints across the kitchen. "It's even in the living room, aren't you paying attention?" Mike starts to step towards her when she lets out a noise of irritation. He looks down at his filthy sneakers and quickly kicks them off.

He walks to her and holds her in his arms. "Sorry baby, I got into a rush. I'll clean it up, I promise." His wife, Ella, softens at his touch. She knows when Mike makes a promise he will follow through. "Okay" she murmurs. "I'm sorry for yelling" she adds guiltily.

Mike shrugs "You gotta get after a big, messy oaf like me!" he says smiling. Ella kisses him briefly. "I have to go right now, I'm taking Austin to Mary's so he can play with David."

"Okay have fun!" Mike follows Ella into the living room where she picks up a now giggling Austin. "Bye big boy!" Mike says, letting Austin grab and shake his finger. He waves at his wife and son as they depart through the front door.He heads back to the kitchen and looks out the window over looking the yard. He sees the shears he had dropped still waiting on the ground.

He had forgotten them because of the ants. Out of coincidence he had pretty much finished trimming just as Austin had cried out. He walks over to his shoes, slips them back on and heads out to retrieve the shears.

---

Bryan climbs up the shoe and manages to sink his arms into the thick thread of a hanging shoelace. Mike begins walking, his shoelace whipping back. Bryan screams as the world goes by in a blur before becoming visible again with a thundering stomp. Then everything is a blur again.

The landscape slowly changes but Bryan quickly becomes nauseous from the violent, jarring movement. Finally he is granted a reprieve as the giant man halts. Bryan looks around and sees Mike has (thankfully) gone inside. A towering woman stands a few feet from Mike, although her height is no competition for his. She yells something that Bryan's jumbled mind fails to process. Before he knows it the shoes he is on are kicked away and he hits the floor and is knocked unconscious.

He wakes a minute later to see the giant couple strolling out of the kitchen. As the sound of their footsteps fade he scans the kitchen for some kind of advantage but stops when he sees what is in front of him.

Mike's sneaker is on its side giving Bryan a full view of what had nearly ended his life. Dirt is packed between the lines of tread, bits of grass protruding from it. Mangled ant bodies hang loosely without the pressure of the ground pushing them into the shoe. The spider that Mike had failed to notice is at the heel, shaped into the tread of the shoe. That thing mere minutes ago had been alive, dangerous, and pursuing Bryan. But Mike's careless step had ended its life and he hadn't even noticed. Bryan can only hope he doesn't end p the same way.

He hears a slam in the distance and stomps nearing. He rushes away from the terrifying footwear as Mike reenters the room. His eyes are anywhere but on the floor and Bryan knows it won't be an easy feat to get Mike's attention. The gigantic man stomps up to his shoes, rights them and slips his long feet into them. In a second the massive man is out of sight.

Bryan tries to hatch a plan in the giant's absence. He looks around the room. Counters line the opposite wall, towering high above. Closer is the dining table that looks to have a pattern on its legs. Perhaps he could scale it. Mike would definitely never see him on the floor. On the other hand better opportunities may lie in the living room.
1121221122112211221122222212221121.title: Follow in Mike's Footsteps

choices: Can't stop tradition! Pizza and wings!
There's plenty in the cabinets, just make something.
11212211221122112211222222122211211.content:
Mike walks swiftly through the grass towards the shears. Unnoticed below, his long feet flatten the grass and end the lives of hapless pill bugs and ants exploring his yard. Mike snatches up the shears but hears a snap as he turns to leave. A branch had broken in half where he had stepped on it. Mike decides he ought to pick them up before he does anything inside.
