"Here! I'm right here! Look!" He gazed up at the masculine face high above. It showed no signs of recognition or even sympathy. Bryan looked on incredulously as the behemoth of a man peered seemingly right at him. "Please! I don't want to die!"

Then the gigantic hand appeared once more. Fingers longer than office buildings dropped from above, making the terrified scientist recoil as they snatched the very ant that was responsible for Bryan's dilemma. He watched in horror as the helpless insect was roughly pressed between the massive gloved digits and torn from the sticky glue. The ant's twitching legs remained behind as the titan raised the tiny bug to his face and consulted a book in his other hand.

Bryan watched mortified. "Shit, what the...-" With a smooth motion, the massive fingers rubbed the tiny ant from existence. Bryan belted out another scream. He wasn't sure if he wanted to be noticed anymore, at least by this callous titan.

As ever, Fate was unkind to the tiny man's wishes. High above, the giant exterminator's piercing gaze suddenly locked onto him. Bryan felt a rush as he stared back. Was he noticed?

Swallowing his fears, he decided to go for it. "Yes! Yes! I'm a human! Help! I need heeeeeeeelppp!" His pleas bled into screams of terror when the enormous hand suddenly loomed overhead, the giant fingers surrounding him.

"Stop! NO! Stop!!!" Suddenly he was pressed into by both index and thumb, his teeny form engulfed. Without warning an unbelievable force wretched him from the glue.

Despite his muffled shape, Bryan Smith screamed louder than he ever thought possible when his legs and arm were torn off in the cement-like glue.

-----

Eric squinted his already keen eyes to see the tiny insect between his large fingers.

"What the fuck..." The exterminator muttered. His brow furrowed as he came to an identification.

He noticed bits of red around the minuscule bug. "Blood," Eric grunted. "A fucking flea." The guide book wasn't needed to tell him that.

Without a second thought, he rubbed the stupid flea out with his fingers--glad he always wore thick work gloves. Wiping his hand on his jeans, he stood and grabbed his clipboard. He scrawled confirmation about the ants, and a note about a possible flea infestation. Over 7 years of exterminating taught him to always think, "Where there is smoke, there is fire", and this flea sure as hell wasn't alone.

Feeling satisfied that he checked, Eric continued his investigation of the kitchen space. He didn't give any thought to the suffering he brought. It was no more than a job to him. As he continued his work, stomping from room to room, tiny ants scuttled away at the vibrations his huge boots caused. Thorough and methodical, the exterminator coated the kitchen and each room in turn with strong toxins.

Satisfied with a job well done, he left. Never knowing that the barely visible spot of red wiped onto his jeans was anything but a "flea."

1121221122112211221221121121.content:
From his lowly position on the floorboards, the shrunken scientist enjoyed an unobstructed view as his teenaged neighbor descended the staircase. Gazing upward at the titan, the bug-sized man felt dizzy as he craned his neck back to follow the shockingly swift progress Tommy made on the stairs, taking the steep steps two at a time, arriving on the floor with an impact that sent out violent vibrations spreading in all directions.

Knocked off his feet, the tiny man scrambled on all fours to get out of Tommy's path as the enormous teenager walked toward him. Without time to do little more than scream, he watched helplessly as the titan's right shoe sailed overhead and landed a few hundred feet ahead of him.

Before he could rejoice, the other shoe dropped, much closer to the speck-sized man position on the floor. Having just regained his footing, the thunderous impact once again knocked the tiny man onto his butt.

Then, as suddenly as the giant had intruded, his footsteps receded as Tommy left the house, making his exit through the front door. Dismayed at having his only hope walk out the front door, the shrunken scientist got to his feet and raced after the teenaged giant, screaming Tommy's name as loudly as he could.

The only answer came with the slamming of the monolithic door. Almost at once, an eerie silence descended on the vast house as the little man slowed his advance toward the door.

His nerves felt on edge as adrenaline continued to surge through his body. Everything had happened so quickly, and ended so abruptly.

He fought to calm himself, slowly getting his ragged breathing back under control. He spoke aloud to reassure himself and help his brain formulate his next move.

"My only hope just walked out the front door," he said with bitter frustration.

Andy barely had a chance to react further when Tommy's deep voice declared, "DAMN ANTS ARE EVERYWHERE!"

The massive sneaker lifted into the air suddenly. Andy fell back, covering his head with his arms, sobbing. Bryan looked up, Tommy's face looked down at them indifferently, his face seemingly as distant as the moon.

Everything was blocked by the huge sneaker sole, the treads crammed with mud and grime. The sneaker brand logo was barely recognizable from the dirt covering it. Bryan's mind was blank as the impossible mass of rubber descended rapidly, frozen with fear.

------------

"I swear, there is a freaking infestation." Tommy groaned as he stamped his sneaker on the two ants that stupidly ran right up to him. "Mr. Smith is going to blame me if he finds a bunch of them here."

As his shoe lifted away, one tiny ant was left behind, a tiny speck on the vast wood floor. Tommy didn't even consider that the tiny pathetic ant would survive his callous attempt to stomp them out.

The two teens entered the kitchen, chatting. "Where the hell did Andy go?" Joe wondered. Andy's brother was coming to deliver a new television, and Andy obviously needed to be here to receive it.

"That ass is always messing around. He probably wants us to deal with his brother." Tommy remarked as he walked around the kitchen island, unaware that each stomping footfall was endangering a shrunken Andy. Tommy had already forgotten about the two insignificant ants.

"Well what'dya want to do, dude?" Joe swatted at a buzzing fly as he pulled a chair and sat down, feeling bored.

---------------

After the enormous sneaker slammed down, Bryan was more than certain he was dead. "After all of my work... This is how I die." He barely finished that thought when a heavy creaking was heard, and light blinded him.

Tommy's booming voice was audible, his ringing ears unable to discern it. The familiar crashing footsteps were felt and heard, and he heard thrust himself upright when he heard Andy's screeching for a split second before being cut off. His head throbbed and his entire body was trembling as Bryan watched Tommy stomping away, every time the giant's left sneaker lifted, he could hear the faint cries before it slammed down again. The heavy stomps diminished as the two behemoths disappeared from view.

"Oh my God..." The tiny man muttered gravely as he watched, awe struck. Andy was alive for now, precariously stuck in the dangerous tread of his best friend's sneaker. Bryan could hear the two thunderous voices echoing from the kitchen.

Fear, guilt, and hopelessness washed over the shrunken scientist as he stood there. He needed to do something!
1121221122112222221121211.title: Matters get worse

choices: Tommy finishes off the bug
Another bug appears
1121221122112222221121212.content:
The shrunken research scientist watched in mounting horror as his teenaged neighbor's path brought his titanic shoes closer and closer to shrunken Andy, who still refused to acknowledge the wisdom of the advice Mr. Smith had given him.

Andy, defiant and reckless, continued to shout demands that his gigantic friends would never hear.

The bug-sized scientist put aside his own fears when he decided he could not just stand by and let Andy get stomped. He dashed away from the wall, determined to save the senseless teenager.

Using his momentum, Mr. Smith gave Andy a rude shove that send the tiny teen careening toward the nearby base of the hallway wall. However, by the time he recovered from his impulsive action, his frantic movements attracted Tommy's attention.

"What the hell? Another bug?"

Hearing the words from the mouth of his teenaged neighbor, the little man panicked. He ran as fast as he could until a titanic sneaker smashed down only a few body lengths from his position on the floor.

"Damn!" Tommy exclaimed. "Missed."

The speck-sized man ran again, but he saw no cover or hiding places in the barren corridor. Tommy's thunderous words of frustration sent shocks of fear through his tiny body. Once again, Tommy raised a foot and prepared to bring it down atop the bug before it could make good its escape.

As he fled the long length of the corridor, the little man felt the darkness of a shadow building over him. He pushed himself harder, aiming for the line of light at the edge of the falling shadow.

The shoe dropped with a concussive blast of strength, barely missing the tiny form, which was propelled through the air to land crumpled on the floor.

The shrunken man felt sick from the dizziness. He struggled to remain conscious. If he didn't move, his neighbor would crush him like an insect.
1121221122112222221121212.title: Tommy sees a little bug

11212211221122222211212121.content:
"TOMMY! YOU'VE GOT TO SEE THIS!" Joe intruded onto the life-and-death scene.

"ONE MOMENT," Tommy retorted. He raised his sneaker and lifted it directly over the tiny bug.

The last stomp of the teenaged titan's foot had doomed the tiny man. As much as he struggled, he didn't have time to recover.

"Tommy, stop!" The shrunken scientist pleaded in vain. "I am not a...."

A loud bang put an end to the nightmare.

Tommy turned. "SO? WHAT IS IT?"

Joe, who had also noticed a tiny bug, had taken a closer look. He opened his fist. "It's Andy!"

Tommy gasped. "Oh my god! Andy!"

Even faced with his huge friends, Andy remained oblivious and determined. In a complicated series of gestures, he got Joe to lift him closer to Tommy's ear, where he screamed out commands and instructions. He led the two titans right to the almost invisible glass vial lost on the vastness of Mr. Smith's tabletop.

The shrunken teenager soon restored himself to normal size using the antidote that Mr. Smith had intended for himself.

The first thing he did, at finding himself back to normal, was berate Tommy. "Your neighbor's nuts, man!" Andy said. "Why would he keep a shrinking formula in his fridge?"

Tommy shrugged. "Where is Mr. Smith?"

Andy suspected, but then decided to play dumb. "Beats me," he said. "Last I saw him he was running down the hall. It's only dumb luck Joe saw me."

"Yeah," Joe agreed. "I could have just stomped you like Tommy stomped that other bug."

Tommy looked a little worried. "Hell, I didn't look closely at that bug," he confessed. "What if..."

Andy had found his clothes in Mr. Smith's bathroom. Once he dressed, he advised that maybe they should all get out of Mr. Smith's house. "I don't want to get the blame for anything," he said.

They agreed, although Tommy did sneak back one time to looks for anything tiny. He didn't find anything.
11212211221122222211212121.title: Dumb luck

choices: Andy's brother arrives with help to deliver the TV
Call an exterminator to deal with the bug problem
11212211221122222211212122.content:
An expression of distaste covered Tommy's face as he glared down at the slippery little bug at his feet.

Twice had the teen missed stomping the bug under his sneaker. "Third time's the charm" Tommy thought to himself, shifting his weight in preparation to stomp the stunned insect flat once and for all.

A sudden movement caught Tommy's notice on the nearby wall. A thumb-sized roach was skittering an arms length up the wall, obviously frightened by the teenager's presence.

"A roach? Seriously?" He thought aloud. "Mr. Smith is going to blame me if he finds his house infested!" Forgetting the smaller, less intrusive bug, Tommy swept the fleeing roach from the wall, grumbling with disgust when his hand came into contact with the filthy insect.

He didn't want to be blamed for a possible infestation by his neighbor, especially a cockroach problem. The squirming creature landed on it's back with a light thud near his right foot, desperately struggling to regain it's footing and escape.

--------------

Pulling himself up, the little man almost fell backwards as his head spun. Tiny Bryan felt major shell shock after having been almost stomped by a sneaker that rivaled any cruise ship he had ever seen.

"I have to get away... Andy..." He thought, still trying to pull himself up, and squinting over where he shoved the reckless teen.

"A ROACH?" Came Tommy's thunderous voice from above. His vision wavered as Bryan looked up, the enormous form of his helpful teen-aged neighbor looming directly above. The young titan was no longer glowering downwards, but now focused in a different direction. With an impressive motion, Tommy's massive arm swept a wiggling black shape from its perch high on the wall.

A hard thump sounded as a building-sized creature landed a few dozen feet away. Unsteadily pulling himself upright, the tiny scientist gasped in surprise at the monstrous cockroach. Laying on it's back, and violently struggling to right itself, the horrendous creature hissed and thrashed about.

Bryan realized his sudden fortune. Tommy was more interested in this threatening roach, which gave him a chance to flee. A quick glance upwards confirmed his hopes, seeing the disgusted expression on the gigantic youth's face. The little man burst into a sprint towards the nearby baseboard where the stunned Andy watched. A sizable crack was visible to Andy's left, a crack that looked large enough to shelter both their minuscule forms. He ran right past the scuffed rubber sole of Tommy's left sneaker, easily three stories in height alone to the bug-sized scientist.

An earth shattering crash from behind caused Bryan to stumble just as he reached the baseboard, falling into Andy.

"Dude, Mr. Smith! We need to get out of here!" Andy stated the obvious, his voice cracking with fear. The almost unnoticeable crack in the decorative wood was a comfortable 6 feet tall, and many feet wide. Stuffing the terrified Andy in first, Bryan shuffled safely inside, and they both watched Tommy's huge sneaker lift, revealing the cockroaches smashed remains, partly stuck to the teen's shoe sole.

This was all unbelievable to Andy, who never thought he would be in the position of an insect.

"DAMN, WHERE DID THE OTHER BUG GO?" An annoyed Tommy roared from above. The massive footwear landed heavily as the giant teen shifted around, searching for the tiny "bug". Bryan held his breath despite himself when a gigantic sneaker landed with a crash just outside his refuge, Andy just gaped in awe from behind. He felt an inherent desire to try and gain Tommy's attention, but held himself, knowing all too well the likely outcome.

------------

Bringing his foot down on the gross cockroach with a satisfying crunch, Tommy suddenly remembered the original insect.

"Damn. Where did the other bug go?" He frowned, shifting his large feet around in search of it. No sign of the smaller, more insignificant pest was to be seen as he gazed around the hall, unaware of the small opening in the moulding near his feet.

Shrugging, Tommy decided to...
11212211221122222211212122.title: Another bug appears

choices: Andy meets the boot sole (death)
Andy survives
112122112211222222112121221.content:
Tommy walked to the back door after hearing the sound of a truck pull up. Joe followed behind, and interjected "Where the hell did Andy go? His bro isn't gonna want to drop off a TV without him here" Tommy shrugged, obviously frustrated. He should of never invited his friends to Mr. Smith's home.

A white delivery truck was parked in the driveway, one that Tommy recognized. Two guys exited, both in their twenties and clothed in dark blue slacks and work shirts with name tags.

"Hey, Tommy, what's up?" Dan greeted casually. His smile faded slightly as he looked around for his younger brother. "Where is Andy?"

"Andy skipped out, we can't find him." Joe stated with an air of annoyance. Tommy grunted in agreement, crossing his arms. "I hope the TV is the same type." Tommy said looking over as Dan's co-worker opened the back of the truck.

Dan frowned now. "I grabbed the closest thing we had. I need to talk to Andy first before I just drop it off." He glanced around again as if Andy would burst forth from one of the bushes.

"The asshole just up and left after helping to break the TV, I can't be responsible for buying a new one myself." Tommy almost pleaded. He couldn't believe that the one time Mr. Smith entrusted the care of his home to him that something like this would happen. He couldn't explain this blatant lack of responsibility to Mr. Smith.

The older guy sighed, and scratched his short hair thoughtfully. "Alright, dude. Andy owes me big for this... Where do you want the TV?" He followed Tommy inside, leaving Joe to inspect the television.

-----

As this went on, the tiny duo crept from their cramped hiding place. Bryan decided they needed to get somewhere other than the hall, and the living room was closest. He lef the frightened Andy, having to urge the kid on.

They had only barely entered the living room when huge footsteps began rattling the floor. Tommy entered with a strange giant dressed in dark slacks and scuffed work boots.

"Watch out!" Bryan yelled a warning as Tommy's mammoth sneaker landed nearby. Andy dove out of the way just in time as the second sneaker landed thunderously, separating the two bug-sized men. Bryan pulled himself up quickly, becoming quite used to these close encounters. "Andy! Where are you!?"

"Help me! DAN! Down here!" His eyes widened when he heard and saw a shouting Andy running towards the gigantic boots.

-----

Tommy stood still, completely unaware of the ordeal that his huge feet caused his missing friend and Mr. Smith. As he talked to Dan, he had almost forgotten about the bug problem that had eluded him earlier.

"Shit, this TV is different than the one Andy told me about." Dan muttered, shifting his large boots around. "This guy is gonna noticed it is different."

Tommy sighed loudly, how could he explain this to Mr. Smith? A bug infestation, then this? He would never get another job from Mr. Smith again at this rate.

"Let's just bring it in..." Tommy stated flatly.

As Dan stepped away from the fallen TV, he lifted a boot over an unseen speck on the floor.
112122112211222222112121221.title: Bad move

choices: Dan and his co-worker enter with the new TV
Bryan thinks of a plan
1121221122112222221121212211.content:
With a dull clomp, Dan stepped away from the fallen television. He gave it a cursory glance and sighed.

"You gonna need help getting this mess out?"

Tommy halted at the doorway that led into Mr. Smith's foyer with a surprised look. He turned back and gave Andy's older brother an enigmatic grin.

"Totally, it's gonna be a pain to throw that crap away. I'd really appreciate any-..."

Dan stretched his arms behind his head and gave another sigh, but finished with a tired nod to his brother's friend. "Yeah. Don't worry about it - Me and Larry will haul it out for you. No problem... I'll let that smartass pay it back later" He finished with a cocky grin.

Tommy didn't hesitate throwing his errant friend under the bus and nodded thankfully in response. Andy's older sibling had always been a bit of douchebag, as well as a shady individual in the past. When Tommy was younger, he was afraid of him; taller and more aggressive than Andy - which is saying something. Dan had an entire arm coated in a tattoo of skulls and flames, so Tommy and his friends assumed Dan was some kind of criminal.

All that aside, Tommy figured this act of awesome kindness abdicated him.

Stepping towards the front door, Dan flashed a slight smirk. "Plus, we can get some decent scrap value for it at the dump."

-----

Andy was a gifted athlete at school. Partaking in both junior high basketball and the track team with decent results. Yet, for all his physical prowess, this test pushed his limits.

"You dumb shit-for-brains! Dan!!!" His normally confident voice cracked with strain and fear. "Down here! Look fucking down!"

His older brother, nearly 5 years his senior, towered high and completely dominated his shrunken brother's entire vista.

"SHIT, THIS IS DIFFERENT THAN THE ONE ANDY TOLD ME ABOUT."

Slowing his pace dramatically, Andy reacted to the now deeper and explosive voice that belonged to his gigantic brother. His thunderous words seemed out of sync, slowed down to resemble the speech of a clumsy giant from some cartoon. Yet there was no mistake - this was his older brother and his only hope.

Andy spouted another volley of frustrated pleas. His brother had been a menace his entire life; teasing and bullying him, never willing to admit out-loud that they had each other's backs. Deep down, Andy knew Dan cared for him. More than once, his big brother had beaten up kids that bullied Andy in school. Only after to declare that he was the only one allowed to beat the crap out of him - which he then demonstrated.

"Daaaaaaaaaaaaaan! Heelp meee you fucking idiot!" Andy cried at his oblivious brother.

The ground shuddered violently, sending Andy to his knees. He looked up to see Dan's humongous work boots shifting with monumentous result. They were beaten to hell: the black leather scuffed with mud and dirt. The toe of the right boot had worn away slightly, showing off a dull layer of steel. This mountain of worn leather raised suddenly, rotated and slammed down again.

"You giant prick! Fuck you!"

Dan merely continued his seemingly cosmic conversation, unfazed and unconcerned with the world at his feet. He never even glanced down. Andy stared at his colossal form, realizing just how humongous Dan had become. Only then did he finally began to feel something else towards his older - now mega-sized - brother. This feeling was fear. Not from his predicament or past encounters with his best friend, but now from the sheer size and oblivious power displayed by his impossibly gigantic brother.

Andy was both terrified and incredulous. His brother was completely in another plane of existence; too fucking huge to care about something as small as Andy.

Yet, he looked like he always did. Dressed in the dark blue uniform his work dictated: T-shirt embezzled with the company logo. Loose fitting, dark blue cargo slacks displayed a variety of tools stuffed into the various pockets; pens, a wrench, some papers, an open pack of cigarettes, and other paraphernalia he used on a daily basis. The slacks seemed to drape endlessly before ending with Dan's black work boots. He bought them a year ago, Andy remembered because the jackass had been leaving them in the hall outside his room more often that not.

"...THIS GUY IS GONNA NOTICE THE DIFFERENCE."

The booming statement shook Andy from his paralyzed state; but too late. Dan finished with his inspection of the broken television and prepared to move.

Shifting position, Dan's enormous work boots lifted and crashed down - one crunching a piece of the trashed TV. Then the nearest boot raised from the ground and soared over many hundreds of feet with ease to loom over Andy's position.

Andy pissed himself and began a scattered aria of screams. The tiny frightened teenager stood a mere speck in the shadow cast by the titanic boot, hopeless to escape.

"Daaaaaaaaaaan! NOOO!!! IT'S MEEEE! YOUR BROTHER!"

His cries were instantly lost against the hard, heavy-lugged sole. Andy had glimpsed it before, never caring much to take any notes. A boot is a boot, after all.

Now, it had taken on a completely different light. The sole was worn heavily, yet still retained enough tread to wedge pebbles and clumps of dirt. The yellow logo "CAT" was visible through huge deposits of crusted mud and paint, while the words "OIL RESISTANT" were almost completely covered by a dried gum wrapper. Blades of grass and the smeared remains of a mushroom were picked up from crossing Mr. Smith's front yard. All from a day's work for Dan, who would impatiently scrape the tread on the welcome mat when he got home.

Andy just wailed. His teenaged mind had handled far beyond capacity, leaving him in a state of petrified shock. He only found enough to shout one last time.

"WHYYYY!"

Only a mere second after Dan proceeded to step, he brought his boot down with a dull, hefty *boom* before continuing his tremendous passage.

---

"Noooo! Nooooooo! You have to stop!"

Bryan fell over a minute cleft in the hardwood, hitting his chin painfully against the floor. He wasted not a moment. Andy had been shrunken by Bryan's own negligence, and he would be damned if...

*BOOM*

Before Bryan had even righted himself, the humongous boot landed and rattled the surrounding area with slight vibrations.

The minuscule scientist stared with an expression of utter horror at the behemoth work boot that belonged to Andy's older brother. It sat like a battleship of black leather, planted firmly where hysterical Andy had just been.

"Oh... shit..." Was all the shocked man could produce.

"No. Oh God, fucking no!"

*BOOM*

The other boot lifted and slammed down as Dan shifted his tremendous form to face the broken TV. Bryan gazed up at him, trying to view his face. The titan complied, turning it slightly to reveal a bored, tired, and annoyed expression.

"...NEED HELP GETTING THIS MESS OUT?" The dangerously clueless guy thundered.

Just business as usual, Bryan thought incredulously. This oblivious behemoth just stomped his little brother from existence and he was none the wiser. Dan raised his thick arms over his head, brushing his short brown hair in the process. Vehicle sized globes of sweat were shaken into free-fall by the action, plummeting to the floor with dramatic splashes.

Dan and Tommy were so far removed from the teeny man's macro world. Andy merely shared the fate that many other minuscule lifeforms met on a daily basis. Even if Andy's giant brother had noticed his tiny attempts, they would have been perceived as nothing more than the skittering movements of some insignificant bug.

It seemed hopeless, more so than ever, to contact these gargantuan titans.

Bryan jolted when he heard Tommy respond, his teenaged voice slightly less impressive than the older brother's but powerful nonetheless. The tiny man failed to pick up more than a few words from their impressive speech.

His feeling of disgust and pity seemed to eat away at his resolve. He shook his head and clenched his fists before shouting.

"I need to get help!" He *would* be rescued. Despite his guilt, Bryan refused to share Andy's fate.

Perhaps, if Bryan could be rescued, he could find tiny Andy alive! It wouldn't be the first time a step proved non-lethal. If not... Bryan would be forced to keep the secret in order to protect Dan from the knowledge.

Then the behemoth in question spoke once more. "...NO PROBLEM.... I'LL LET THAT SMARTASS PAY IT BACK LATER."

Bug-sized Mr. Smith trembled at the words. He gazed up at the titanic worker, thinking right now he needed protection *from* Dan.

Without any inkling of his actions or the irony of his words, Dan happened to spare a glance at the floor. His gaze was brief and failed to spot the tiny home owner. Bryan had no chance to take advantage of this rare look before the huge man followed Tommy out with heavy, lumbering steps.

Bryan slunk to the ground. This had started as a nightmare for him: almost ending up stomped by his helpful neighbour and his careless friends. Now, an innocent teenager had joined his nightmare and more than likely gotten himself killed. Bryan felt traumatized. Why did this have to happen to him?

At the very least, he was safe for now. Andy's terrifying mega-sized brother had left, taking his huge boots with him, and Tommy and Joe would hopefully give him a chance to plan for rescue.
1121221122112222221121212211.title: Andy's BIG Brother

choices: The exterminator arrives
Bryan and Andy look for Tommy and Joe
112122112211222222112121222.content:
"I don't have time for this!" Tommy groaned, scanning the hallway one last time for the bug. "Stupid bugs! Mr. Smith is gonna think I let them infest his house..."

Scratching his hair thoughtfully, Tommy debated what to do. He had planned to enjoy using his neighbour's home, inviting friends over, watching some television on his flat-screen, and ordering pizza. So far all his plans had resulted in disaster.

Joe came sauntering in from the kitchen, hearing Tommy's distressed groans.

"You could just spray some Raid around or something," Joe offered. "It was only a couple bugs, right?"

The two teenagers tromped back into the kitchen. Joe idly opened the upper cabinets, obviously bored. Tommy hastily thrust open the cabinet doors under the sink. It held next to nothing, save for a couple bottles of air freshener and dish soap. Slamming the doors, he sighed,

"What the hell am I gonna do now?"

Joe stifled a yawn, leaning against the kitchen island. He shrugged in response and glanced around the pristine kitchen. Mr. Smith's telephone was mounted against the wall, along with a board pinned with dozens of phone numbers. One of these numbers stood out to the annoyed teenager. He shifted over to it, squinting at the homeowners swooping writing. "Dude! Right here, Mr. Whats-his-name has an exterminator's number here." Joe said, tapping the number in question.

Tommy's ears pricked up, almost stumbling over a stool as he approached Joe. "Oh, shit! Thank God!" He snatched the posted number from the wall. It was nothing short of gold in the teenager's hand: an answer to his unsaid prayers.

A female voice answered when Tommy dialed the number, offering the extermination company's name.

"Hello, yes, yes. I'm calling about an infestation of bugs here at my house." Tommy figured he should pretend ownership to the home, not wanting to explain his situation. It only then struck Tommy about paying for the service. As luck would have it, the secretary quelled his fears.

"Bryan Smith? Yes, we have you scheduled for next week. The usual date." She continued."Do you need us to make an emergency visit? We just had a cancellation."

Still feigning to be his neighbour, Tommy grinned at Joe with a knowing smile. "There is a serious infestation brewing, please send somebody over immediately!"

Tommy sighed, hung the phone up and slumped into a stool next to Joe. His worries melted away. Mr. Smith's home would be rid of pests before anything serious began, and at not cost or effort on Tommy's part. All the effort Tommy put into keeping Mr. Smith's home free of pests, Tommy felt quite satisfied. Shifting on his stool, Joe didn't share the satisfaction. He yawned and grumbled about being bored.

"Let's get out of here before they get here, man. I don't think they'll buy you being your neighbour in person."

Joe wasn't wrong about that possibility. "Yeah, let's go grab something to eat and check back in a few hours."

They grabbed their stuff and left the house, unlocked. Joe wondered aloud about Andy's whereabouts while Tommy glanced back at the house, unaware that both Andy and Mr. Smith remained inside.
112122112211222222112121222.title: Calling the exterminator

choices: Diego begins spraying immediately
Diego decides to inspect the house first
1121221122112222221121212221.content:
"Fuck me! My best friend just tried to stomp me like a freaking bug!"

Andy looked absolutely livid. His eyes still shone wide with fear, yet now that the immediate danger had passed, Bryan noted some of the teenager's cocky demeanor returning.

Thinking it best to calm the kid, Bryan prepared to speak.

"What the hell were those two lug-heads thinking!" Andy angrily interrupted. "How could they not see it was me!" Hitting his fist against the rough wall, he turned to Bryan with a scowl. "Or, for that matter, you!"

Bryan frowned at the hopelessly hot-headed youth. When they first met, he had explained the facts of shrunken life to Andy. Who had himself keenly declared Bryan Smith as a "bug" and spurred his giant friends on a wild witch-hunt to stomp him. He wanted nothing more than to feel sorry for the kid, but his chiding attitude made that difficult.

"Listen..." The weary scientist began.

"You can't just fucking run out and expect them to see you. To them, you are nothing more than a tiny speck now - like me." Andy tensed at that, but remained silent as Bryan continued. "If we want to get rescued, we need an intelligent plan. No running out or screaming like an idiot."

Bryan returned the glare Andy was giving him. The only sound was Andy's teeth grinding together and Bryan's exhausted breathing.

"Okay?" He questioned with as little annoyance as possible.

Andy grunted, crossed him arms, but relented. "Dammit... Okay! You happy now?"

With a curt nod, Bryan exited the safety of their hide-away, glanced both ways, and beckoned Andy to follow.

---

Diego shifted his truck into gear and pulled the old vehicle to a stop. He had been heading over to another client's home when a call from the company's secretary stopped him. They had cancelled.

"Emergency visit, huh?" Diego said as he stepped out and went to grab his tools. The secretary's call didn't give him much else to go on, not even what "emergency" he should expect.

Between himself and the other guys he worked with, they all agreed that this client, Bryan Smith, was a bit... odd. Diego was always used to the homeowner being there to greet him and give him some basic info. Mr. Smith was never home whenever Diego, or his co-workers arrived. Except for one time, when Diego nearly knocked the guy over as he opened the kitchen door like he always did.

He apologized to the guy - but only received a meek response before the flustered man rushed past him and drove off.

Probably just anti-social or something, Diego figured.

Cap covering his head, chemical tank on his back, Diego whistled as he strode towards the back door.

---

The two shrunken males only just reached the towering portal that led into the kitchen. Crossing the hallway was nothing short of an Olympian feat - made all the more difficult by Andy's complaints and Bryan's exhaustion.

"...then what? Once we catch up to them, what do we do then?" Andy persisted.

"We'll figure something out, I am sure. With the two of us combined, we can't fail."

Andy opened his mouth, shut it with a frown, then opened it again. "I don't even hear them. Shouldn't the ground be shaking or something from their clumsy feet?"

Struggling to keep himself moving was already enough. Now to listen to this idle twaddle was proving too much. Bryan prepared to verbally tear the teenager's head off when the thought struck him.

"You're right," Bryan agreed with an air of caution. "We should be hearing some sort of disturbance..."

Right then, as if to reassure the two bug-sized men that they weren't alone, a thunderous knocking boomed from the kitchen. They transition from hardwood to kitchen tile, both alarmed and confused. The tremendous pounding repeated once again, this time followed with a loud barrage of noise. Both of them felt the previously still air change suddenly. Moments later, a gusting wall of wind blasted them with unforgiving force.

"Ouch! What the hell was that?" Bryan squeaked. He had been blown backwards, weaker and more frail than Andy who had withstood the gale. "Oh no, did they leave!?"

Andy didn't respond. He only stood there, seemingly frozen as he stared off into the distant vista of the kitchen. Afraid that the sound was Tommy and Joe leaving, Bryan joined him, gasping at the sight.

The back door closed with a tumultuous boom, sending light vibrations through the tiled floor. Standing before it was a huge man in grey uniform, wearing a baseball cap that cast a foreboding shadow over his face. He stood like a looming monument, his dark form stark against the white door and walls and his large dusty boots planted firmly on the ground.

Bryan heard Andy question the identity of the titan. His voice was scared once more, imploring for guidance but sounding muffled to the tiny man who only had eyes for the looming intruder. Gruffly snorting, the giant raised an impressive arm to his face and idly wiped the sleeve of his uniform against his nostrils. Such a mundane, impolite gesture took on an air of other worldly wonder.

"Damn! Mr. Smith, snap out of it! Who the hell is that?"

He didn't know. This huge stranger wasn't anyone Bryan was acquainted with. For all he could surmise, this man was some kind of criminal. Bryan squinted at the distant, shaded face. The giant seemed to be idly scanning the room, his features were young; friendly even - yet strong and swarthy. His appearance sent a tingle through Bryan's body. Then it clicked.

"He's an exterminator!" The memory of the brief encounter rushed back to him.

"What?!? Why the hell is he here?"

If the obvious had not yet dawned, the huge man interjected and dispensed all doubts by rolling his thick shoulders to set down a hefty metal tank on the floor. It collided against the tiles with a dull crash, sending another quake to rattle the shrunken onlookers. Standing out against the chrome tank was a sticker. Red with a yellow font, "TOXIC CHEMICALS".

The young titan crouched his mountainous bulk over the tremendous container, gripping a shiny turnstile with large gloved hands and turning it many times. He then produced a long, snaking tube that ended with a nozzle and connected it to the side of the tank.

"He's gonna freaking spray us like bugs! We need to stop him! He has to see us!" Andy screamed and began running towards the colossal tradesman without a second thought.

Bryan grabbed at the sprinting teenager, trying to halt his hysterical flight. "No, you damned fool! WAIT!" Just like before he chased after Andy. The athletic teen well out-paced the tired scientist in both height and stamina. Grout in between each tile proved sizable - with collections of dirt and chalky grit. Andy left Bryan tripping over a muddy piece of grass tracked in only hours before from his own shoes. He ignored the older man's pleas and sprinted onto the next stretch of tile.

Meanwhile, the humongous exterminator rose back to his full height. His gaze idly swept the tile floor before him. Neither Bryan, Andy, or their minuscule chase stood out to the colossal man, whose only thought was his task.
1121221122112222221121212221.title: Big Trouble

choices: Climb onto Tommy's foot
Climb the chair
1121221122112222221122.content:
For most people, the fact that a group of teenagers had demolished an expensive television and made a general nuisance of themselves would have been the bad news of the day.

For professor Bryan Smith, Tommy and his out-of-control friends were only part of his mounting problems since he had voluntarily, but perhaps unwisely, shrunk himself to the size of a bug.

Even now, as he remained in hiding in the dubious refuge provided by the space between the floor and the bottom of his own towering television/entertainment stand, peace of mind eluded the shrunken man, whose own scientific breakthrough had reduced him to the size of a grain of rice.

In his most disturbing encounter with the giants, the tiny man had been almost stomped flat beneath the sole of one of the titanic sneakers worn by the enormous teenager named Andy.

It was that extremely close call that had forced the tiny man to take shelter in the shadowy recess under the massive TV stand, the largest piece of furniture in his own colossal living room.

If he had thought that would be enough to discourage the boys, he hadn't contemplated the deep and abiding distaste teenager Andy held for bugs and other pests.

One way or another, Andy meant to have one less filthy, disgusting bug on the loose in the world. That determination had led to the attempt at moving the television, which had resulted in the accident that left the expensive, state-of-the-art set less than worthless.

Fearing every loud sound and sudden vibration, his body showing the visible evidence of his ordeal, muscles tired and aching, the shrunken man cowered in the dark space.

As much as he didn't want Tommy on the hook for the damaged set, that wasn't at the top of the tiny man's priorities.

Right now, he needed Tommy's help in order to regain his normal size.With each new hurdle, the tiny scientist began to realize that his hope of ever escaping his shrunken nightmare continued to recede farther and farther.

Hoping that Tommy would play a fateful role in his immediate future, he decided he should make one more attempt to contact his enormous teenaged neighbor.

Despite his unruly and deplorably irresponsible friends, the miniaturized scientist retained his faith in Tommy, the neighborhood teen who had performed odd jobs for him for years.

The unfortunate scientist's own arrogance and some simple twists of fate had made Tommy the most important person in this bizarre drama. Unfortunately, the teenager was blissfully unaware of the struggles of his tiny neighbor and the part he had, so far, played indirectly in them.

The unlucky scientist had given Tommy a simple job, which was to mail a package for him. What Tommy hadn't known was that the plan called for Mr. Smith, a brilliant research scientist, to mail himself to his nephew at college in California.

As much as he regretted his actions, as much as he now wished he had done things differently, the shrunken man could not go back and choose again.

His scheme had gone terribly wrong, of course, and now he huddled in terror in his own home, terrified and humiliated at every turn by four teenaged titans who, at every turn, seemed out to destroy him.

Although his earlier attempts at contacting Tommy had ended in failure, the tiny man could not simply give up. Even as his attempts became more desperate and more dangerous, he kept railing against fate.

For a long time, there had been no quakes caused by the footsteps of titans. He had not heard any loud, thunderous voices.

Curious, and resolved to try again, the tiny man breathed a sigh of relief and walked toward the light. He exited the dark space beneath the TV stand and tried to scan the living room, which looked bigger and stranger than some alien fantasy city.

His eyes fastened on a titanic form. "Tommy!"

The little man scurried over the floorboards, racing toward the building-sized recliner on the other side of the living room. His enormous teenaged neighbor's impressive body was sprawled in the chair.

He continued to run, screaming out Tommy's name from time to time, only for the colossal surroundings to swallow up his feeble voice.

The other titans had disappeared. He knew they were probably somewhere in the house, and they could return at any moment.

"I've got to reach Tommy," he told himself.

His path across the floor was unimpeded this time until he saw the huge obstacle that loomed from the flat floorboards. As he drew closer, he recognized the object as one of Tommy's sneakers. Several yards away rested its equally huge mate.

Tommy had taken off his shoes to relax in Mr. Smith's comfortable recliner. His friends had gotten on his nerves, and now he just wanted to take it easy and try to think of some sort of excuse he could offer to Mr. Smith about everything that had gone down.

The shrunken man stared in mesmerized astonishment at the size of Tommy's discarded footwear.

But, his goal was the teenager, not his sneakers. Besides, as he got closer, he also smelled the intense odor.

"Phew! His feet reek!" The tiny man exclaimed.

Detouring around the sneaker, the bug-sized man ran toward the recliner. Tommy's socked feet were on the floor. He kept running, closing the gap, until he was standing right next to the titanic teen's cotton-covered toes.

"Tommy!" The tiny man screamed as loudly as he could. "Please! Just look for me! Down here, at your feet!"

He simply could not attract the giant's attention that way. What could he do?
1121221122112222221122.title: His Only Hope

choices: Tiny Bryan falls
Tiny Bryan holds on
11212211221122222211221.content:
Suspense and adventure on an unprecedented scale had motivated Bryan Smith to undertake his impulsive scheme.

Now, after some twists of fate that had not gone his way, not to mention sheer bad luck, the shrunken man found himself to the monumental feet belonging to his next-door, teenaged neighbor, Tommy.

The expanse of cotton fabric covering those huge feet didn't smell much better than the huge sneakers the giant had casually dropped onto the floor.

The teen's careless and terrifying friends had almost hastened the bug-sized scientist's demise on several occasions since their intrusion into his home.

All the time he was seeking a way to contact his colossal savior, the tiny man had to be constantly on his guard for one of the other menacing titans.

Daring himself to move as close as possible to the enormous socked foot, the tiny man stood in the shadow of the huge foot. When he gazed upward, he could see nothing but the sole of the worn sock, which looked quite dingy from repeated and frequent wear.

"Tommy!" The shrunken man shouted as loudly as his miniature stature permitted. "It's me! Down here, at your foot!"

When that failed to stir any response at all from the giant, the unfortunate scientist proceeded reluctantly to Plan B.

"I've got to climb his foot," he said aloud. "Climb higher, and hope I can get him to notice me."

He had to hope the giant would notice and recognize him as well. So far, every time he had attracted attention, the giants had quickly misidentified him as a bug, with almost lethal consequences.

When he grabbed fistfuls of the cotton sock in his tiny hands, the little man pulled himself up. After an exhausting climb, he reached the teenager's ankle. At that point, it dawned on him what a monumental task he had chosen for himself.

-------

While Tommy rested in the recliner in Mr. Smith's living room, his three friends had stepped outside to await the delivery of a television that they hoped they could switch for the one they had accidentally broken when moving things around in their pursuit of a "bug" that had taken refuge beneath Mr. Smith's entertainment center.

Eventually, a van pulled into Mr. Smith's driveway and two guys in their twenties stepped out.

"Someone order a TV?"

Andy greeted his older brother. "About time you got here."

Dan flashed his kid brother a grin. "Where do you want it?"

"Follow me," Andy said.

Dan and his partner, Larry, struggled with the television, wrestling it out of the van and carrying it inside the house while Andy held open the back door.

-------

Meanwhile, the shrunken scientist had climbed to the top of Tommy's sock, and now reached a wall of flesh.

He touched the bare skin of Tommy's massive shin. The flesh was hard and warm to his touch.

By clinging to the wiry leg hairs, he was able to continue his upward climb. He began to feel like he might have made a wise decision.

At the same time, Tommy felt an itch and was about to scratch it when his friends burst back into the house with two other guys hauling a huge television.

"We got it," Andy announced to him.

Tommy stood, looking in dismay. "That doesn't look anything like Mr. Smith's TV!"

When he detected movement, the tiny man tried to wrap his hands around one of the giant's thick leg hairs.

"I've got to hang on," he cried out loud. He knew that if he fell now, he would be completely exposed on the floor with multiple giants stomping around the room.

Even as he gripped at the rope-like leg hair, he felt his grasp slipping.
11212211221122222211221.title: Daring Ascent

choices: Tiny Mr. Smith tries to resume his climb
Tiny Mr. Smith falls off into the jungle of his own yard
112122112211222222112212.content:
As tiny Mr. Smith gripped at one of the wiry leg hairs on Tommy's gigantic leg, he saw one of the teenager's mammoth fingers coming right toward him. He almost let go of his grasp on the hair, but he breathed a sigh of relief when the titan scratched absently a few inches above the shrunken man's location.

He felt as puny and insignificant as a flea as he tried to retain his grip on the thick dark hair. That's the status that his lack of foresight had reduced him to. He was a flea-sized man crawling up the gigantic leg of his titanic teenaged neighbor, hoping desperately that he might make contact with the titan and arrange his salvation from the ever-growing nightmare.

Then, to make matters worse, Tommy started moving. The tiny man screamed and tried his best not to let go and plunge to the floor.

Tommy argued loudly about the television that Andy's brother had delivered.

Andy's brother surveyed the wreckage of the other set. "It's even better than that piece of junk," he told Tommy.

"But Mr. Smith is going to know that's not his television!" Tommy shouted.

He turned in exasperation from the living room, deciding he needed some fresh air outside the house. He didn't stop until he walked down the front steps and across Mr. Smith's front yard.
112122112211222222112212.title: Worse and Worse

choices: ...top of Tommy's other socked foot
...a bare patch of earth and sand
1121221122112222221122121.content:
Even as Tommy made an unexpected trip to the front lawn, tiny Mr. Smith struggled to continue his upward momentum.

Unfortunately, an exasperated Tommy didn't get far in his trip outside before he stepped on a pebble. No problem if he had put on his sneakers, but that hurt when he was still wearing only his socks.

"Oww! Damn!" Tommy exclaimed, balancing on one foot and trying to see what he had stepped on.

As a result of the titanic teen's wildly unpredictable lurching, his tiny unseen passenger found that his desperate grasp on one of Tommy's leg hairs was slipping through his hands.

"Tommy!" The tiny man screamed. "What are you doing?"

His cries went unheard, and he felt his hands slipping inexorably along the length of the cord-like hair. The shrunken scientist tried to throw out a hand to retain his grip, but his attempt coincided with the giant teenager's decision to head back into Mr. Smith's house.

As he lost his grasp, the bug-sized man fell, screaming, only to land with a thud on...
1121221122112222221122121.title: Losing his Grip

choices: The arrival of the giants is bad news for Mr. Smith
Mr. Smith falls off the edge of the concrete step
11212211221122222211221211.content:
His plunge ended with a soft thud, his bug-sized body sprawled atop the wide cotton surface of Tommy's socked left foot.

Although his head was swimming from the impact, he knew he didn't have long before his gigantic teenaged neighbor would move again.

He tried to grab at the cotton beneath his puny body, clinging to as much of the fabric as he could manage to collect between his fists.

That's all the tiny man had time to do before Tommy continued his walk back toward Mr. Smith's front door.

The world seemed to fly past at extreme velocity for the tiny man, who watched his surrounding blur each time Tommy lifted his foot and took a step.

"Please, stop," he was reduced to begging. "Tommy! Help!"

Suddenly, Tommy did stop.

But the shrunken man's relief proved fleeting. His titanic neighbor had paused only to open the door.

As Tommy opened the door to re-enter the house, the motion caught his tiny foot passenger unready. The forward momentum hurled the tiny man off the socked foot, and left him screaming as he dropped several inches to the unforgiving cement.

He barely had time to register the severity of his situation before Tommy stepped into the house and slammed the door closed behind him.

The sudden misfortune left the shrunken scientist dazed and more than a little bruised. Nothing broken, he was able to ascertain, but he didn't know how much more of these sudden impacts his tiny, reduced body could withstand.

Inside the tiny man's home, Tommy saw that his friends had placed the new television on Mr. Smith's entertainment stand.

With his arms folded across his chest, Tommy declared, "That's not going to fool him."

Andy's brother, Dan, frowned. "That's his problem."

As Dan removed a cigarette from a pack, Tommy snapped, "No smoking in Mr. Smith's house."

Dan rolled his eyes. "All right! I'll go outside if that will make your precious Mr. Smith happier."

"Wait," Andy said. "I'll come with you."

The two brothers made their way across the room toward the front door, where on the other side a tiny, unsuspecting man waited for them.
11212211221122222211221211.title: Stranded on his own doorstep

112122112211222222112212111.content:
Once tiny Mr. Smith managed to get onto his feet, he moved weakly toward his front door. To his dismay, there wasn't even enough space between the floor and the bottom of the door, which was farther sealed by a wide plastic strip to insulate the home and keep out unwanted pests.

He wasn't going to get back inside through the front door unless Tommy returned for him. Dejected, he realized that his huge teenaged neighbor didn't even have a clue about the terrible predicament his careless actions had left the shrunken scientist.

The bug-sized man scanned the gigantic surroundings of his own front step and the lawn, which stretched forth like miles of untamed jungle.

With a shudder, he realized the jungle probably came with an assortment of predatory insects, all ready to make a meal of a tiny human who had unwittingly dropped far, far down the food chain.

"I have to wait here for Tommy," he said aloud. "If Tommy comes, I can get back inside the house and...."

He trailed off. The tiny man had no more ideas. He had tried in vain to contact Tommy, but he was too damn small.

He didn't have to wait long. The door opened unexpectedly, disgorging two of the titans from inside Mr. Smith's living room.

Neither of the giants was the one speck-sized Mr. Smith hoped to see. By the time he overcame his shock, he also missed his opportunity. The giants closed the door behind them.

Dan and Andy stood on the porch step, oblivious to anything tiny and insignificant at their feet.

"Your buddy Tommy sure is uptight," Dan remarked.

Andy laughed. "Well, he's not usually like that."

Dan grunted and struck a match, lighting up his cigarette. He waved the match, dousing the flame, and dropped the still smoking stick onto the concrete surface beneath his feet.

Back inside the house, Joe tried to convince Tommy that everything would work out. "It may not be the same TV, but it's a good one." Joe said. "Mr. Smith will understand. Accidents happen."

"I am sure Mr. Smith knows all about accidents," Tommy muttered. "Well, at least I didn't let Andy's stupid brother smoke inside Mr. Smith's house. He would really hate that."

Mr. Smith screamed and dodged as the smoldering match fell from the sky, missing him by mere inches. The discarded match was so close to his puny body that the acrid smoke choked him and caused his eyes to water.

He stumbled blindly, trying to get away from the noxious smoke released by the match.

The whole time, the two giants talked, oblivious to the discomfort their casual actions had inflicted on the tiny, unnoticed homeowner.

Dan puffed on the cigarette, and reminded his brother that, because he had delivered the television as promised, he owed him a favor.

"Whatever, man," Andy agreed.

"This guy's house is pretty sweet," Dan said. "So, what's the deal? Your buddy Tommy house-sitting?"

"Something like that," Andy said.

The cigarette burned steadily, and from time to time, Dan tapped away ashes.

His latest disposal of the ash poured down a fiery storm of ash on the tiny man, who had dared to gaze skyward for a look at the faces of the two mighty gods. Instead of making another desperate attempt to get noticed, he was forced to flee the vicinity of the scorching ashes.

Winded, the tiny man panted, trying to come up with his next move. Then, that too, was snatched away from him. His fate came down to a casual action on the part of an unknowing and uncaring titan.

His cigarette spent, Dan dropped it onto the porch step. Once again, a smoldering object fell from the sky, almost landing on top of the tiny man.

If the match had smelled bad, the smoldering cigarette butt was even worse. The smoke wafted around the tiny man, who staggered to escape.

"Well, see you around, bro," Dan said, raising his scuffed boot to finish off the discarded cigarette.

He brought the boot down squarely on top of the smoldering butt, while at the same time trapping the shrunken scientist in the oncoming shadow. There wasn't time for any reaction as the giant moved the sole of his boot on the rough concrete, grinding the cigarette and the tiny man into the unyielding surface.

The door opened as he lifted his boot. Tommy ushered his other friends out of Mr. Smith's home.

The whiff of cigarette smoke lingering in the air made him feel right at least about one decision he had made.

Mr. Smith would surely be glad that Tommy had demanded that Dan take his smoking habit outside to the front step.
112122112211222222112212111.title: No smoking inside

choices: as Dan flicked his cigarette toward him
as Andy noticed a tiny bug near the porch
112122112211222222112212112.content:
With Tommy remaining steadfast in his refusal to let Dan smoke in Mr. Smith's home, Dan and his brother, Andy, stepped out the front door onto the concrete porch where they surprised a tiny, unsuspecting man.

"Guys!" The shrunken scientist screamed at the two youths. "A little help, please!"

As with every other attempt, tiny Mr. Smith's desperate shouting went unheard by the giants.

Instead, they advanced toward the edge of the porch, crowding the bug-sized man closer to the sheer drop.

"Stop!" Mr. Smith shouted as he tried to evade Dan's sneakers.

"WHAT'S UP WITH YOUR FRIEND?" Dan asked his brother as he lit up a cigarette.

"TOMMY'S UPTIGHT," Andy remarked. "MR. SMITH'S ALWAYS PAYING HIM WAY TOO MUCH TO DO STUPID STUFF FOR HIM. HE DOESN'T WANT TO MESS THAT UP."

Dan began smoking his cigarette as he nodded.

Until that point, Andy had remained a safe distance. That changed as the brothers shifted position, and tiny Mr. Smith saw Andy's shoe coming toward him.

At the last second, he chose to take a wild leap rather than risk being crushed beneath the teenager's massive sneaker.

Landing on a patch of sand and pebbles, the tiny man scrambled to his feet. His concrete porch loomed like a sheer cliff almost a hundred feet up. He had to get back inside his house and get Tommy's attention before something bad happened.

He looked up and was ready to shout again at the titans when he saw Dan start to flick his cigarette into the yard.

The tiny man ran...
112122112211222222112212112.title: Dropping off the edge

choices: Tommy spies an interesting struggle near his foot
Dragged beneath his sand
11212211221122222211221212.content:
The larval form of myrmeleontidae, with a spade-shaped head held on a thick neck lower than the rest of its bloated body, ranked as one of the most fearsome predators in Mr. Smith's yard.

It wasn't a creature that the research scientist would likely have noticed on a day-to-day basis, unless he had happened to notice one of the steep pits constructed in loose earth and sand.

The bug-sized man happened to land with a jarring thud on the rim of the pit. The impact knocked him breathless, which left him powerless to do much more than gaze upward at Tommy's majestic body that loomed overhead like some titan of myth.

Oblivious to the concealed peril at the bottom of the funnel-shaped pit, the tiny man got to his feet once he managed to start breathing again. As he did so, his movement dislodged some boulder-sized grains of sand that crashed deeper into the pit.

At the same time, Tommy took a careless step that brought his left sneaker dangerously close to the bare patch of ground. The little man was so convinced that the sneaker was coming down on him that he screamed and threw his arms over his head.

Instead, the sneaker missed, but the footfall's impact sent a strong quake through the loose soil. The tremor tipped the balance, and the speck of a man lost his footing, tumbling into the pit.

He slid along the concave slope, managing to check his descent halfway toward the base of the pit. He scrambled and tried to climb out, but loose grains of sand, pebbles and even a few boulders (from his reduced perspective, at least) kept dislodging with his every move.

Then, to his horror, two large jaws burst from the grainy sand gathered at the base of the pit. The monster thrashed with its jaws, hoping to seize the tiny prey that had caused the disturbance.

Shrunken Mr. Smith screamed at the sight of the monstrosity. The long, jagged pincer-jaws raked the air just below his feet, prompting another scream and another futile attempt to scramble out of the pit.

He saw Tommy's mammoth form still looming over him and screamed for help.

"Tommy, hear me!" The tiny man shouted. "Please, get me out of here."

The monster, thwarted in its ambush, began to more fully emerge from its burrow in the bottom of the funnel-shaped pit, revealing more of its terrifying form.

The larval insect's body was encased in a shell, looking like some lumbering, armored tortoise except for the rows of sharp spikes that lined the edge of the armor. It pushed itself forward and up by the use of six powerful limbs.

The more the creature pushed above the surface of the ground, the more the unstable walls of the pit gave way. The tiny man scrambled on hands and knees, but felt himself sliding back with the rest of the debris loosened by the avalanche.

Most terrifying were the set of powerful pincer-jaws, which were almost as long as the rest of the insectoid body.

The creature was only about twice the shrunken man's length, not counting the wicked jaws, but it was powerfully built, almost like a living tank.

The tiny man felt more than ever like a bug as he felt himself slipping, falling deeper into the pit.
11212211221122222211221212.title: Myrmeleontidae

choices: Push the bug to its demise
Save the tiny bug
112122112211222222112212121.content:
As the monster waiting at the bottom of the pit sensed the vibrations caused by its intended prey's struggle to climb out of the trap, it used its powerful body to thrash against the walls of the pit.

The movement caused more of the loose sand and pebbles to come loose. The increasing avalanche slid to the deep bottom of the ingenious trap.

Mr. Smith, recognizing the monstrous predator's intentions, fought to keep himself from being torn away from the wall by the cascade of sand. If he lost his grip now, the creature's fearsome pincer-jaws would grab him and drag him to a certain doom.

From above, Tommy happened to glance down, his attention attracted by a faint movement, and noticed the struggle of a tiny bug on the edge of the pit.

"Oh, cool," the teenager said aloud. "Ant-lions!"

He remembered studying about the larval form of myrmeleontidae back in elementary school, although the teacher had referred to the immature insect by the less intimidating common name of "ant lion."

Dropping to his knee, the teenager took a closer look at the intriguing life-or-death struggle taking place at his feet.

When the teenager's knee slammed into the ground, the impact sent out a seismic tremor that almost tossed an unprepared Mr. Smith to the bottom of the pit.

The huge tremor didn't fling him to his doom, and it also served to intimidate the hungry predator. It ceased trying to bring its prey closer, wisely afraid to move if an even larger predator was close at hand.

Grateful for the reprieve, the tiny man began screaming for Tommy's help.

"Down here," he shouted. "It's me! Help!"

Of course, even so close to the scene, Tommy failed to notice the shrunken scientist's desperate pleas. To his eyes, he saw the tiny bug struggling to avoid falling deeper into the pit.

He decided to...
112122112211222222112212121.title: The Eternal Struggle

1121221122112222221122121211.content:
Tommy frowned as he looked down at the ant lion. It had stopped moving. He didn't understand what had been for him a simple kneeling motion had been a shattering tremor to the tiny bug.

"Aw come on! Don't stop!" he whined. Looking down he could see the tiny bug was slowly working its way up.the slope.

Below Mr. Smith huffs as he struggles up the slope, taking advantage of the reprieve from the ant lion. He glances up to see Tommy's massive eyes staring right at him, his expression unfathomable.

Tommy smiles at the two bugs. "I'm not trying to take your meal!" Tommy laughs and reaches down.

Mr. Smith looks up again as Tommy's voice booms above him. He isn't paying attention and misses the words though. He sees Tommy's hand reaching down, undoubtedly to help. "Yes!" he shouts happily as he nears the top edge of the pit.

Without even considering the tiny bugs' life Tommy gently taps his index fingernail against it sending it sliding back down.

Tommy's finger keeps going and the pink wall of his fingernail slams into tiny Mr. Smith.

"Augh!" he shouts as pain shoots through his body. "No!" he cries out as he tumbles back down into the pit. He glares up at the smiling Tommy as he falls down, devastated that the boy he trusted carelessly flicked him to his death.

"To-" he is cut off as the massive larvae grips him tightly and quickly pulls him underground before the larger creature can take its meal.

Tommy watches the ant-lion grasp the bug and disappear beneath the sand quickly.

"Cool" he breathes as he rises to his full height. He then stomps off to continue with his day.
1121221122112222221122121211.title: A little push

choices: Another giant exits the house, endangering tiny Bryan
Bryan decides to follow Tommy, leaving his property
1121221122112222221122121212.content:
"Tommy! Help me!" Sputtered the tiny scientist, face planting once again into the shifting sands of the pit. "Please!" He managed to shriek as he slid down the soft sand again.

The ant lion remained dormant, despite it being aware of the struggles of the helpless prey. Bryan desperately clawed the sand, trying to climb out of the deadly sand pit, his tiny fingers sinking fruitlessly into the sand causing him to slide downwards.

Spitting out the dry sand, Bryan suddenly noticed a huge shadow loom overhead.

-----------

Looking down at the insignificant bug trying to escape the clever ant lion's trap, Tommy frowned slightly.

The ant lion had ceased pulling the little bug to its doom, and refused to show itself. "Must of decided to wait for better prey than this tiny ant" Thought the disappointed teen, unaware that his own casual actions caused such violent seismic activity as to frighten the fearsome ant lion into hiding. Despite himself, Tommy felt a pang of pity for the incredibly small insect that was valiantly struggling to escape the pit.

"Here you go little guy" He said shoving his large index finger behind the ant, pushing it roughly back onto flat ground and burying the ant lion's pit accidentally. The tiny pale ant seemed to wiggle around, as if trying to tell him something, which of course Tommy thought was ridiculous.

"Don't you go into the house now, or I will have to deal with you personally!" He joked, almost to himself. Rising back up to his full stature, the young man decided to take a short walk, having become bored with the insignificant bug.

-------------

"HERE YOU GO LITTLE GUY." Roared Tommy's explosive voice from above. The shrunken man screamed in terror as a street-sized digit crashed into him from behind, throwing him forward with intense force. Bryan struggled to stand up, brushing off sand he felt numerous scratches and bruises caused by the gigantic Tommy's finger.

Looking up, the dry sand causing his little eyes to hurt, he noticed the huge teenager's expression still showed no recognition, only a bemused look of pity. "Tommy! Look closer, please! Why can't you just see!?" Bryan squealed as he excitedly jumped and waved his arms. Tommy's face showed no signs of change, and the tiny man watched as the huge lips moved.

"DON'T YOU GO INTO THE HOUSE, OR I WILL HAVE TO DEAL WITH YOU PERSONALLY!" Came the thunderous, booming voice. The bug-sized scientist covered his ears, glaring up at the frustratingly oblivious Tommy.

He couldn't believe it, Tommy was kneeling down, looking right at him, yet he still didn't realize he was anything other than a little ant. Bryan's heart sank, feeling once again his hopeless situation. A loud rumble caught his attention as the impossibly huge Tommy rose from his crouched position, his massive sneakers crunching the sandy ground as the shifted. The tiny genius craned his head back, his eyes watering from the dry sand and his own emotions.

"No!" The tiny man cried as Tommy's massive sneaker landed with an explosive thud right next to him, missing his little form by only a few meters. Tommy wasn't even looking where he stepped, having almost forgotten the rather boring ant at his feet. The titanic sneaker lifted off the ground, leaving a noticeable tread impression that easily spanned many football fields in its wake.

The little speck of a man watched as his oblivious saviour stomped away to resume his day.
1121221122112222221122121212.title: Tommy the Oblivious Saviour

112122112211222222112212122.content:
Once grown out of its larval stage, the "ant lion," or Myrmeleontidae, is a mild-mannered, totally inoffensive insect with delicate-looking wings and a long, cylindrical body.

The larvae, however, give this predator its name. If anything, when considered at its own scale, the ant lion is a more terrifying and determined predator than a lion or tiger.

As tiny Mr. Smith tried to scramble out of the sandy pit, he slipped back, which permitted the mostly submerged creature to use its wicked jaws to grab his left shoe.

The predator began to pull back its powerful body below the surface again, pulling its intended prey with it.

At this point of the struggle, a distracted teenager noticed the flurry of sand and grit being kicked up in the inch-deep pit.

Always curious, Tommy got down on one knee and watched the fascinating tableau as the ant lion dragged its prey beneath the sand.

Trying to free himself, the tiny man gazed skyward and locked eyes with Tommy.

"Yes!" He yelled jubilantly. "Tommy, help..."

With another fierce jerk, the ant lion interrupted the tiny man's cries.

As Tommy watched, a strange little insect disappeared beneath the sand, pulled down by the unseen terror.

As a kid, he had played with "doodle-bugs," even deliberately knocking ants into their deep pits so he could watch the resulting life-or-death struggle.

"Cool," he breathed out.

As the struggle continued beneath the sand, the unseen monster kicked up a few more grains of grit before the exhausted prey succumbed.

The teenager looked around for another ant to drop into the pit. Not seeing any, he got to his feet and headed back to Mr. Smith's home.

"Bet Mr. Smith would have been interested in seeing that," the teenager said. "Since he's such a science geek and all."

Itty-bitty Mr. Smith listened to the thunderous voices of the giant teens as they discussed ways of dealing with any bug they found hiding beneath the huge oaken television stand.

He heard titanic grunts and groans as the behemoths strained their enormous muscles to wrestle with the heavy piece of furniture beneath which the shrunken scientist had taken refuge.

The bug-sized man knew his time was running out when he spied a huge dust bunny. The blob of dust and fuzz looked as big as a boulder, and gave Mr. Smith a more pleasant alternative than the option of having the four giant teenagers find and stomp him like some pathetic insect.

He raced toward the dust bunny, throwing himself under its concealment just as the guys moved the building-sized television stand, admitting some harsh artificial light into what had been a dark, shadowy cavern.

The little man prayed that the clump of dust concealed him from the sharp eyes of the teenaged titans.

"Well, Andy, where's your damn bug?" Joe asked.

"Yeah, I don't see any sign of bugs," chimed in Andy's buddy, Steve.

"I knew this was a waste of time," Tommy declared in a loud voice full of irritation.

Mr. Smith felt his heart race as he listened to the giants. He wished he could rush out from cover and scream loudly enough for Tommy to notice him. But, based on a string of earlier failures in such attempts, he remained motionless, hoping they would go away and leave him alone.

"That bug has to be here!" Andy insisted.

"You can see it isn't," Tommy said. "But look at all that dust and crap. Might as well take the vacuum cleaner to all that before we move the television stand back into place."

Beneath the heavy piece of furniture, the tiny man, once the owner of the house as well as all the furnishings being manhandled by the teenaged titans, cowered in the shadows as he heard his fate discussed so contemptuously by those same giants.

With the colossal television stand out of the way, the three teenaged titans surrounded him, three pairs of cruise ship-sized sneakers closing off all hope of escape.

Tommy sighed in relief when he was finally able to lock Mr. Smith's door after driving his friends from his neighbor's home.

Terrified at their swift advance, the tiny man faced two possible options. He could try to run as fast as he could to avoid the path of their enormous shoes, or duck inside the discarded soda can and hope to ride out the approaching storm.

11212211221122222212211122.content:
The tiny man kept his mind occupied by spinning possibilities of eventual rescue, all featuring reunions with Tommy, the next-door teenager who, albeit without realizing what he was doing, had cast off the tiny man into a raging flood that had removed him from the security of safety of civilization.

By keeping himself deep in thought, he didn't have time to worry about the possible perils of gigantic wildlife, such as spiders, snakes and lizards.

Uneasily, he wondered what sort of prey dragonflies might attack.

As the buzzing of the dragonfly's wings grew more distant, the shrunken scientist took a moment to gaze in awe at the enormous trees that formed an impossibly distant canopy.

Beneath that green roof, he had his view blocked of the sun and sky, other than the stray beams of dappled sunlight that reached the woodland floor. He made his way carefully over the accumulated debris of dropped acorns, fallen leaves, conifer needles and the garbage discarded by thoughtless people.

The ground was littered by enormous examples of empty beer bottles, soft drink cans and fast-food bags. Although the evidence spoke of a heavily trafficked area, he saw no sign of giants.

In a sense, the absence of giant strangers came as a relief to him. He stopped to rest in the meager shade offered by a colossal bottle with its label peeling.

The bottle looked bigger than a building to the bug-sized man. Touching the curved glass, he made his way to the open neck of the smooth bottle. He resisted the urge to crawl into the huge bottle to focus on more immediate concerns.

If only he could determine where the flood had transported him, he could formulate a plan for finding Tommy.

He never got the chance.

Three huge teenagers crashed through some small saplings that reached as high as their waists. As the alarmed little man stared at the intruders, he realized each of them looked even more enormous, more powerful, more muscular than Tommy and any of his friends.

He didn't realize he was looking at three members of the high school football team, including their star quarterback, Justin.

They wore jeans, sports jerseys and stylish sneakers. Tiny Mr. Smith gaped when he saw the trio of titans stomping along the edge of the stream.

In their presence, what had been a river that had completelty overwhelmed the shrunken man dwindled to look more like a evaporated to a feeble stream.

Quarterback Justin, who sported an impressively toned body and short cut blond hair, jumped the stream, his huge sneakers squishing in the mud on the other side of the stream.

Now, even that small barrier of water didn't separate the tiny man from the colossal jocks.

One of Justin's buddies, the biggest of the impossibly big behemoths, followed his friend. His body looked more like a lumbering mountain to the bug-sized scientist.

The tiny man listened in terror at the way their huge shoes squished in the mud. He saw they carried empty glass jars and one of them held a long-handled mesh net.

The three giants continued to stomp through the woods, but they complained non-stop.

"This is freakin' boring," Justin said. "Making us collect a bunch of puny bugs for extra credit. I'd like to take that pathetic science teacher and squish him like some bug."

His friend grunted, but said, "We're just lucky Mr. Mendez is willing to give us some extra credit. If we flunk his class, it's goodbye to the football team."
