choices: Fall to the carpet below
Still stuck when the car stops
11212222121122.content:
Bryan sprinted faster than he thought possible, dodging dark pebbles scattering the rough asphalt. The ground around him darkened! Unable to resist he looked back. A dark shoe sole, that could dwarf a city, loomed above. Its tread was packed with pebbles from the ground, and other filthy crushed bits and bugs.

"Noooooo! he wailed, attempting to push himself harder. Ahead he could see Tommy, his face unconcerned as he looked at the very giant who's foot was crashing down.

---

"Dude, just a quick game?" Tommy asked again, facing Jeff now. Jeff, his sneakers crunching on the rough asphalt, reached down and picked up his hat. As his foot hit the ground, an unnoticed speck disappeared underneath. Jeff shook his head with a grunt.

"Nah, we gotta go... But some other time for sure." he said. With that he followed Mark towards the street, leaving Tommy and Joe at the court.

A disappointed Tommy turned to Joe, "Well, I guess I should mail the box.". Joe shrugged "Whatever dude."

Little did any of the young men realize the precious cargo was no longer in the package.

---

Jeff sauntered through the grass. At one point he felt his foot contact something on the ground. A glance downwards revealed he had accidentally leveled an ant hill. He didn't stop moving, flicking his eyes forward with an unconcerned grunt.

He drops into a small Honda Civic, as Mark starts the car. It comes rumbling to life and they pull away from the curb.

---

Bryan coughs again. He couldn't he was still alive. The gargantuan shoe had slammed down. Bryan had expected that to be it. However he found himself trapped within the tread. He had screamed with each jarring step. He now found himself staring at worn and filthy carpet. The shoe rested at an angle, allowing light to illuminate his space.

The entire space seemed to be vibrating for some reason. Around him, chunks of dirt occasionally shook loose and rained down onto the carpet below.

Bryan could feel his own bindings loosen slightly, and began to struggle.
11212222121122.title: Cargo missing, but not missed

choices: Shrinking Time!
Unexpected Phone Call
1122.content:
Bryan's mind remained abuzz from anticipation of his impulsive scheme to mail himself to his nephew.

He imagined he could command some newfound respect from young Zach once he discovered his uncle's amazing scientific breakthrough.

Bryan knew, however, that at least part of Zach's resentment had some basis in reality. His research into the shrinking formula had consumed him for the past few months. Zach, who really looked up to Bryan, probably felt neglected.

Bryan chuckled. "Well, he'll be looking at his Uncle B. in a whole new light when I arrive at his dorm via the U.S. Postal Service," the scientist said.

Bryan decided to get some rest. According to his plan, tomorrow would be a big day.

He stripped down to his boxers and then crawled beneath the covers of his bed.

Sleep proved elusive, however, since he found he could not get get thoughts of shrinking out of his mind. After a long period of tossing and turning, he finally managed to slip into a rather fitful sleep.

••••••

Bryan heard loud, muffled voices and suddenly intense light blinded him.

"WHAT IS IT, ZACH?"

"DON'T KNOW!" Zach answered his roommate. "FUCKIN' BOX LOOKS EMPTY."

Bryan yelled as loudly as he could. "Wait! I'm in here!" He tried to shield his unprepared eyes from the bright light.

Suddenly, his world lurched and he felt himself falling.

Zach and his roommate looked down as a pale speck dropped onto Zach's desktop.

"WHAT THE—"

"I THINK YOUR UNCLE SENT YOU A FUCKIN' BUG, MAN!"

"IT'S JUST LIKE HIM!" Zach said in a thunderous tone of disgust.

Bryan's vision began to clear in time for him to gaze up at the two colossal young men. "Zach! Look closer! It's me...your Uncle B."

"WELL, THIS IS WHAT I THINK OF HIS DAMN BUG." Zach extended a single finger and lowered his fingertip toward the tiny bug.

"Nooh! Wait! Don't!" Bryan screamed as the massive fingertip descended toward him.

••••••

Bryan awoke with a start. Within seconds details from the dream began to fade, but he still felt shaken.

"Just a dream," he muttered. It wasn't enough to persuade him to change his plan.

Bryan pulled on a robe and went to his kitchen. He needed some coffee to face the day.
1122.title: Planning to Impress Zach

choices: Bryan shrinks
Bryan shrinks
11221.content:
Bryan awoke the next morning feeling refreshed and eager to start what promised to be a very big day— in more ways than one.

He made his way to the kitchen for a cup of coffee. He saw his pre-labeled package on the table. Bryan picked up the box in one hand. He could hardly believe that, in about seven hours, he would make himself small enough to fit inside the package in preparation for being shipped to his nephew.

Bryan placed the box aside and started some coffee. Soon, the aroma of coffee filled the kitchen. After pouring himself a cup, the scientist took a seat at his table. He spooned some sugar from a bowl and sweetened his coffee. A few grains of sugar fell off the spoon and landed on the tabletop.

After a few sips of the sweetened cup of joe, Bryan sighed and looked at the box.

Bryan's mind raced ahead to thoughts about his nephew opening the box and finding him. Bryan tried to imagine what Zack would look like to him.

His earlier experiments with shrinking had given him an appreciation for the sheer enormous scale of his surroundings, but he had never yet encountered another human being from his drastically reduced perspective.

A small, dark form crawling across the tabletop drew him out of his daydreams.

"Damn ants!" Bryan muttered. He reached for a napkin and used it to reduce the tiny pest to a smear. After wiping up the spilled grains of sugar, which had attracted the tiny ant in the first place, Bryan stood and tossed the napkin into a trash can next to his kitchen counter.

Bryan looked down at the package and saw something that gave him pause. The ant had arrived with companions. He watched one of the tiny creatures crawl across the address label on the package.

With a shiver, Bryan realized that, once he put his plan in action, he would be no bigger than the ant. And, with one careless movement, his nephew would be capable of obliterating Bryan.

For the first time, Bryan paused in his headlong rush to continue with the plan. Still, he reasoned, there should be a way he could give Zack the surprise of a lifetime without putting himself at risk for any undue harm.

His ringing phone startled Bryan. His voice sounded shaky. "Hi, uh, hello," Bryan said.

"Hey, Uncle Bry!" Zack's voice greeted him with enthusiasm.

"Zack!" Bryan felt as if the phone call must be a twist of fate. "I'm really glad to hear from you."

"Thanks," Zack said. "I felt bad after our last talk. I didn't mean to act like a jerk."

"No," Bryan said. "Don't worry about it."

"Thanks. You're the greatest."

"Uh, Zack," Bryan began, "I am still sending you that package..."

"You don't have to do that," Zack said. "You've done enough for me."

"No, this is something I really want to do," Bryan said. "But I need to tell you a few things."

"Sure."

"Well, when the package arrives, treat it carefully."

"Is it fragile?" Zack inquired.

"Somewhat," Bryan answered. "It's very important that you open it carefully and take a close look at the contents."

"Sure," Zack said, intrigued by his uncle's precise instructions.

"A very close look, do you understand?" Bryan asked.

"Yeah, I'll be careful. I wouldn't want to break my present, Uncle B."

"Good," Bryan said. "All I want to add is that I think you're in for a big surprise."

Zack laughed. "Can't wait, Uncle B."

"Well, I can't wait to see you," Bryan said.

"Maybe for the holidays, right?"

"Or even sooner," Bryan said.

"I don't think I can manage to get away before then," Zack said. "And I know how busy you are at the lab."

"You never know," Bryan said, his enthusiasm for his scheme completely restored.

"Well, I can't wait to see what this big surprise is," Zack said. "Talk to you later."

"Yeah. Good bye, Zack."

Bryan made his way back to the kitchen table. He saw that a couple of other ants had joined their companion.

He took another napkin in hand, but this time he brushed the ants gently off the table instead of squishing them.

"Consider that your second chance, guys," Bryan said aloud. "I'm going on a trip, so that gives you time to vacate the premises before I return. If you're still here when I get back, all bets are off."

He moved to the sink and rinsed out his empty coffee mug.

Bryan looked at his watch. He now had time to take a shower and get ready for his big shrink.

He could hardly wait!
11221.title: Words of Advice

choices: Tommy notices the pesky ants
Bryan ducks inside the box
112211.content:
Before taking his shower, Bryan made one last check of his preparations. Staring down at the tiny box, soon to serve as his transportation for a trip to California, he felt the electricity of excitement begin to build in his mind.

He didn't bother to get dressed after his shower. After using a towel to thoroughly dry his body, he wrapped his towel around his waist and walked barefoot into his kitchen.

Bryan took the vial of shrinking formula in his hand. He watched, mesmerized, as he sloshed the pale blue liquid within the glass tube.

He upended the vial and swallowed the contents in a single gulp. The formula remained virtually tasteless except for a faint metallic aftertaste.

Bryan removed his towel and tossed it onto the kitchen counter. He then moved quickly to use a chair to step onto his kitchen table. Although he had undergone the astonishing process on several other occasions, he still marveled as his surroundings appeared to expand rapidly in all directions.

In less than two minutes the brilliant research scientist shrunk from six feet tall to a mere quarter of an inch.

As on past occasions, his body felt somewhat numb for a few seconds after the shrinkage ceased.

After he re-asserted control over his body, Bryan took in his surroundings with the same sense of wonder he had experienced the first time he used the formula to reduce himself.

Bryan stared across the vast expanse of the kitchen table. The shipping package now resembled some large building.

He began his trek toward the box, eager to dress in the clothes he had shrunk in preparation for this moment.

As he approached the box, however, Bryan suffered a rude shock when he saw a bizarre sight. Two lines of ants, each individual ant measuring a full four feet in length, streamed toward and away from the box.

Bryan halted and stared at dozens of the large insects. Each six-legged insect stood at shoulder height to the shrunken man.

"What the hell?" Bryan said.

He moved with a measure of caution closer to the lines of ants.

As he got closer, he could clearly see antennae twitch on the hideous heads of the segmented insects.

In addition, he saw that some of the ants held items in their mandibles. A second look identified the items as crumbs of food.

"They're stealing my supplies!" Bryan yelled in anger. The little man rushed forward, nimbly stepping between two ants rushing away from the box with crumbs of food held in their jaws.

Bryan watched as ants crawled in and out of the small entrance he had cut into the side of the box.

Bryan looked around and saw that the ants appeared even more numerous. He saw dozens of the insects.

Bryan heard a strange grating noise and turned to see an ant heading toward him with its fearsome mandibles clicking. Bryan gasped when he saw this ant looked larger and more sturdy than the worker ants milling around the box.

He prepared to run, but two smaller ants blocked the oncoming ant's path. Bryan used the diversion to slip past the ants and reach the entrance into the box.

Bryan started to make his way inside the box when he met an ant making its exit. The tiny man recoiled and let the ant make its way past him.

At that moment, the kitchen door opened. Bryan, startled by the unexpected noise, looked up and watched as Tommy entered, right on time, to pick up the package for mailing.

Bryan's nerves nearly failed him. Nothing could have prepared him for how huge Tommy now looked to him. The teenager looked like a fearsome behemoth.
112211.title: Unexpected Little Problem

choices: Tommy continues zapping ants
Tommy notices a strange ant
1122111.content:
"Kewl!" Tommy exclaimed as he looked down and saw dozens of tiny insects scurrying on Mr. Smith's kitchen table. "Ants!"

Bryan, still in the shadow of the box, gazed up at Tommy's titanic form, more than a little awed at the huge teenager. He didn't stop to wonder why Tommy sounded so excited about the discovery of a few ants.

"Well, let's take care of this!" Tommy said, lowering his hand.

In one swift swoop, Tommy scooped the box off the kitchen table, leaving Bryan in shock. "No!" The tiny man screamed. "Tommy! Wait!"

Tommy shoved the little box into a pocket.

As Bryan watched, the huge teenager fished in another pocket until his hand withdrew a round glass disc attached to a long silver handle.

A beam of sunlight shone through Bryan's kitchen window at Tommy's back, perfect for focusing high intensity beams through the mammoth magnifying glass.

Holding the magnifying glass over the tabletop, Tommy narrowed the beam of light and moved the super-charged shaft of energy toward the nearest ant.

The tiny creature writhed and tried to escape, but Tommy followed its every move with relentless efficiency until the insect sizzled and popped.

Tommy had enjoyed this particular game since he had been a kid. He moved his laser toward another ant.

Tiny Bryan had to shield his eyes from the intense beam of light. He watched horrified as the beam fell onto another ant. He heard the crackling as the ant burned to a quick crisp under the highly focused beam of sunlight.

After Tommy felled a third ant, Bryan realized the teenager meant to obliterate every ant in sight. Unfortunately, Bryan realized, he wouldn't look all that different from the tiny ants.

"Tommy!" Bryan shouted. "Stop!"

Bryan looked around for any possibly hiding place, but found himself completely exposed.

Then, glancing upward, he saw the beam of light moving across the tabletop toward him. Far above, holding the magnifying glass in a steady hand, Tommy smiled at his trek of carnage.
1122111.title: Death Ray

choices: ...Zap this last ant!
...get a better look at this weird bug
11221111.content:
Tommy unleashed a wave of carnage and destruction across Mr. Smith's kitchen table as he used his handheld magnifying glass to focus a particularly powerful beam of light, using the tightly focused laser to scorch ant after ant.

Most of the tiny ants didn't have a clue of their impending doom until their bodies sizzled, crackled and popped from the intensity of the beam of light. As living ants became scarce, the teenager noticed a weird ant that looked paler than the others. Intrigued, he began to pursue the tiny ant, which fled ahead of the path of the unstoppable beam of light across the polished, smooth surface of the table.

He had toyed for almost a full minute with the strange, pale little ant, noticing how the tiny creature seemed to anticipate the oncoming beam and try to evade it.

He was almost to tired of the game when his friend, Joe, opened the back door and strolled into Mr. Smith's kitchen.

"Whatcha doing, dude?" Joe asked.

"Zapping ants," Tommy said and chuckled. "It's fun!"

"I've been calling and texting you, dude," Joe complained. "Don't you ever check your phone?"

"I'm nearly finished," Tommy said.

When the second giant entered the kitchen, Mr. Smith took advantage of the brief reprieve. He had almost exhausted himself trying to avoid Tommy's deliberate attempts to incinerate him. There was no place to hide and, if he stopped and tried to communicate, the destructive laser beam would burn him to ash before he ever got close enough to get Tommy's attention.

"Well, I've been looking all over for you," Joe complained as he watched Tommy take up the pursuit again of a pathetic little ant.

"Dude, there's something weird about this bug," Tommy remarked. He slowly directed the beam of light toward the speck-sized ant, only to watch it veer away from the beam. "See what I mean?"

"This is freakin' boring, dude," Joe said.

"Hold on, man," Tommy said. "I just want to..."
11221111.title: Zap, crackle and POP!

choices: Cloudy weather suddenly cuts off the sun
ZAP!
112211111.content:
Research scientist Bryan Smith, now a mere quarter of an inch tall, stood on his kitchen tabletop as a pillar of fire and light moved steadily across the vast plain.

He tried to look past the fiery column for any hint of his next-door neighbor, but the light burned his eyes. He did make out the god-like hand wielding the mammoth magnifying glass that focused mere sunbeams into infernal death rays.

As the lethal beam approached, he weaved to the right, attempting to run as fast as possible for a being reduced to the size of a small ant.

To his horror, he saw the fiery beam of light change course, adjusting to follow his every attempt at evasion.

Suddenly, the back door opened and the tiny man looked away from the beam to follow the entrance of another mega-sized teenager.

----

"WHATCHA DOING, DUDE?"

Tommy lowered the magnifying glass when he saw his best friend, Joe.

"ZAPPING ANTS," Tommy said, He chuckled when he looked down and saw that the weird pale ant was no longer moving. "IT'S FUN!" Tommy added for Joe's benefit.

Joe, however, complained in a loud voice about texts and phone calls unanswered. "DON'T YOU EVER CHECK YOUR PHONE?"

"I'M NEARLY FINISHED," Tommy answered.

The speck-sized man listened to the conversation between the two titans as he struggled to catch his breath, regain his strength and formulate a plan.

He didn't trust Tommy's buddy, but at least Joe wasn't chasing him with a death ray trying to burn him to a crisp.

Then, to his horror, Tommy raised the magnifying glass again, maneuvering to catch the sunlight at the best angle to produce a perfect zapping beam of energy.

Joe complained some more and watched with a frown as his friend resumed his chase of a pathetic little ant across the surface of the table.

As the tiny man ran for his life, he heard Tommy's voice directing Joe's attention toward him.

"DUDE, THERE'S SOMETHING WEIRD ABOUT THIS BUG," Tommy said. Yet again, he gradually directed the beam of light toward the little ant, only to watch it veer away from the beam. "SEE WHAT I MEAN?"

Joe yawned and remarked that he was bored. When he looked down at the table, he saw only a tiny, pale bug, much too small and insignificant to retain his interest.

At the same time, the tiny scientist took one more opportunity to communicate his true identity to his giant neighbor. "Yes, look closer," Mr. Smith screamed and waved his arms over his head. "Tommy, it's me! It's Mr. Smith, not a bug. Help me!"

"HOLD ON, MAN," Tommy said. "I JUST WANT TO ZAP THIS LAST ANT."

The little man shrieked and ran as fast as he could across the vast plateau of the kitchen table.

"BETTER BE CAREFUL, OR YOU'LL BURN A HOLE IN YOUR NEIGHBOR'S TABLE," Joe said.

Tommy scoffed and continued to follow the tiny bug with the incendiary beam right to the edge of the table.

As he ran, the shrunken man saw that he was coming toward the edge of the tabletop, which represented an unimaginable abyss for the tiny man.

Taking a leap off the edge wasn't an option. He was sure he couldn't survive the plunge to the distant floor. He stopped and turned to face his gigantic neighbor.

Tommy noticed only that the tiny pale bug had halted its flight. He chuckled and said, "LOOKS LIKE THE END OF THE LINE."
112211111.title: The chase is on

choices: Joe tells Tommy to swat the bug
Joe suggests they play with the bug
1122111111.content:
It took immense willpower, which he didn't realize he possessed, to stand rooted in his tracks and face the oncoming wrath represented by his teenaged neighbor and the fiery magnifying glass of death.

He tried to find some trace of the friendly, eager young man he knew so well. Instead, his nerve began to fail when he saw Tommy's features twisted in disgust, his lips turned in an arrogant sneer and his eyes alive as he anticipated the imminent demise of something as lowly and utterly insignificant as a mere ant.

The speck-sized man took a deep breath and started to scream for the giant's attention when Tommy spoke first.

"LOOKS LIKE THE END OF THE LINE," the titanic teenager pronounced, capping the statement with a sinister chuckle.

The little man's eyes darted wildly, looking for cover or any other means of escape. He fastened his gaze instead on Tommy's bored, indifferent friend.

"Joe!" The little man screamed and waved. "I'm not a bug."

Tommy advanced the scorching stream of light across the tabletop.

"God, no!" Mr. Smith cried, his nerve failing him at last. "Tommy, please," he begged before he fled toward the edge of the table.

Suddenly, the beam of hot energy fizzled, faded and finally vanished.

"WHAT THE..." Tommy remarked in surprise.

He shook the magnifying glass, as if it was something as simply as a dead battery. Then, he noticed, that sunshine was no longer pouring through the kitchen window to power his incinerator.

"IF YOU WANT THAT BUG DEAD, THERE ARE EASIER WAYS," Joe remarked.

Hearing how his reprieve was so mercilessly short-lived, the tiny man flung himself on his knees. "Tommy! Joe! Stop! Look at me! I am not a bug!"
1122111111.title: When skies are gray...

choices: Jump and fall to the floor
Tommy's swat is faster than the bug
11221111111.content:
After enduring the relentless pursuit the teenagers had inflicted on him with the gigantic lens of the magnifying glass, tiny Mr. Smith felt the world was being terribly unfair when he heard Joe tell Tommy there were lots of easy ways to get rid of a bug.

Hoping they'd recognize a gesture of pleading, he got on his knees, shouted their names and begged them to recognize him.

Tommy placed the magnifying glass on the tabletop. "Not as fun as zapping them one at a time," he said with obvious disappointment.

"Bugs must be stupid," Joe said. "After you chased it all that time, it isn't even trying to get away from you."

Tommy squinted at the speck-sized creature and chuckled. "So dumb it deserves to die," he said.

"No!" The little man leapt to his feet. He needed to get away from the giants.

"Here's what you need," Joe said and reached for something hanging from a hook on the wall near Mr. Smith's fridge.

Gazing from the vast surface of the table, the shrunken scientist watched as Joe handed Tommy the cheap yellow and black plastic flyswatter that he'd purchased at a dollar store to deal with the occasional household pest that wandered into his home.

He kept running, but he didn't appear to cover much ground. Of more immediate concern, he was approaching the edge of the table, but if he turned back, he would place himself in easy reach of the two teenaged titans.

A glance back over his shoulder saw the flyswatter held aloft in Tommy's enormous hand.

"Damn! He's going to try to swat me!" The scientist screamed and ran toward the edge. Flinging himself into open space would give him a one in a million shot at survival. Getting swatted by the massive yellow and black construction of cheap plastic would spell an immediate "game over" to his misadventure.
11221111111.title: Swat the Bug

choices: Joe puts him on floor and removes his shoes and socks
Joe drops him into a nearby coffee mug
11221111112.content:
The tiny scientist, no bigger than an ant, heard Tommy's enormous friend with horrifying clarity.

"EASIER WAY TO GET RID OF THAT LITTLE PEST," Joe remarked.

He stared up at his enormous neighbor and the teenager's best friend, knowing his life depended on his communicating his true identity to them.

On his knees before the two titans, he begged for their mercy. "Tommy! Joe!" The tiny scientist screamed the names of the two colossal titans. "It's me! I am not an ant!"

Tempted to shrug off Joe's suggestion and find something more interesting to do, Tommy still felt a spark of curiosity. "YEAH?"

Joe smiled and his massive hand descended toward the table. With nowhere to run, the tiny man found himself pinched between two massive fingertips.

He tried to move, to breathe, even to scream... He was literally being crushed between the titan's fingertips. The indignity stung at his elevated intellect. How could he end up squished like a mere bug between some teenager's fingertips?

"WHAT YOU GOT IN MIND?" Tommy asked.

"MIGHT AS WELL HAVE SOME FUN WITH THE PUNY PEST," Joe answered.
11221111112.title: All fun and games

choices: Bug in training
Oops!
112211111121.content:
The tiny man watched as Joe scooted a chair from the table and sat in it. His instinct told him to run, but he knew he could not possibly run fast enough to escape the two enormous teens.

"PULL UP A CHAIR AND WATCH," Joe instructed.

Tommy seated himself just as Joe lifted a bare foot and hovered it over the little man.

The bug-sized scientist watched the bare foot rise a few inches off the floor and move to cover him. The enormous foot blocked his view of the titans.

Slowly, without applying too much weight, Joe lowered the sole of his bare foot onto the tiles. He caught the speck of a man beneath the arch of his foot, halfway between the heel and his toes.

"WHAT YOU DOING MAN?"

"IT'S FUN. I'VE DONE THIS SINCE I WAS A KID." Joe explained as he rolled his foot back and forth.

"WON'T THAT JUST CRUSH THE ANT?" Tommy asked.

"NOT IF I'M CAREFUL," Joe said. He felt a tiny form, no bigger than a grain of sand, provide a hint of resistance between his foot and the floor.

Tommy grinned and began removing his shoes. "I WANNA GIVE IT A GO!"

Joe lifted his foot and saw the tiny bug sprawled on the floor. "BE MY GUEST."

Tiny Mr. Smith had been certain the giant meant to stomp him, but Joe had merely trapped him. Then, the cruise ship-sized foot began to roll him back and forth. He had produced unheard screams, begging them to spare him.

When the foot lifted, he imagined he had been heard. Instead, when he weakly turned over on his back and looked up, he saw Tommy removing his socks.

"No!" The little man screamed. "Tommy, it's me."

His neighbor's foot hovered over him for a moment and then began to move closer.

"Tommy! Please, stop!"

Once again, he found himself trapped against a teenager's bare foot. The pressure felt greater, owing to Tommy's inexperience with playing with bugs beneath his bare feet.

"CAREFUL," his friend advised. "IT'S EASY TO ACCIDENTALLY SMUSH THEM."

"YEAH," Tommy said as he began to slowly roll his foot forward.

"YOU FEEL IT?" Joe asked.

"YEAH, I THINK I DO!" Tommy exclaimed. Indeed, he felt the pinpoint of friction where the tiny body prevented his foot from meeting with the unyielding floor.

"NOW, ROLL YOUR FOOT BACK, GENTLY," Joe said.

Tommy followed the instructions, a wide grin on his face.

"ISN'T IT COOL, MAN?" Joe asked. "I COULD PLAY WITH THESE TEENY BUGS ALL DAY LONG!"

Tommy continued to roll the puny ant beneath his bare foot, discovering why Joe found this activity such a thrill. He held absolute control over the tiny creature. The application of the slightest pressure could smear it beneath his foot.

It became a game, the challenge being to see how long he could roll the unfortunate bug beneath his foot without accidentally bring too much force to bear.

He laughed. "Too bad you can't teach bugs tricks," he joked. "We could teach it to worship our feet."
112211111121.title: Joe's Game

1122111111212.content:
The tiny man found his latest humiliation thoroughly ego-crushing. Not only had his next-door neighbor mistaken him for an ant, but had kept him trapped beneath his huge, smelly foot for the past 10 minutes, rolling him over the smooth floor tiles.

Thoroughly coated in the foot sweat from his time under the bare soles of the two titanic teenagers, the teeny man found himself on his back as Tommy kept him securely imprisoned.

Gasping for breath, and only inhaling more of the rank stench from Tommy's sweaty foot, the shrunken scientist tried not to speculate on how much pressure his tiny body could endure without suffering dire consequences.

He suspected that his ordeal had already sent him close to the upper limits of his endurance. "Please, Tommy!" He shouted in a hoarse voice. "Please, lift your foot."

Suddenly, the pressure eased back. The foot, bigger than many an ocean-going vessel, swung out of the way to permit Tommy to stare down at the speck of a bug.

"Well, it survived," he said. "Well, more or less."

The shrunken man tried to pull enough oxygen into his lungs to revitalize his exhausted body.

"So, did you like that, you pathetic little bug?" Tommy spoke down to him as if he expected an insect to understand his words.

Joe laughed. "I half expect it to plead with you for mercy, man."

Tommy wiggled his toes, and the little man's eyes widened as each of the massive appendages flexed. "That what you want, little bug? Mercy?"

"God, please," The tiny man said through clenched teeth. "Tommy, just look closer."

He felt his strength returning, although with frustrating slowness. He rolled over onto his side, but still could not make his legs work to raise him onto his feet.

"It would be cool if you could teach it to worship at your feet," Joe admitted, referring back to Tommy's earlier comment.

"Yeah, but it's far too stupid and puny to ever do anything worth keeping it around," Tommy said. "Might as well put it out of its misery."

"No!" The little man cried. "Not that."

Joe shrugged. "Whatever, man."

Tommy yawned. "Well, we can always find another ant," he said as he moved his foot back into position just as the tiny man got back onto his feet.

The titan's foot slammed back into him, forcing him again onto his back. As the foot pressed harder, the hard-won air in his lungs was again squeezed out. The pressure grew, preventing anything but the screaming in the tiny man's head.

"So?" Joe asked. "Over yet?"

Tommy smirked. "Nope."

He rolled his foot, again enjoying the friction from the tiny point of resistance.

"Now you're just being mean," Joe laughed in admiration of his friend's actions.

"Yeah," Tommy agreed. He did have other things to do.

He increased the pressure, but he wasn't quite expecting the sudden instant when the resistance simply vanished.

"Oops!" Tommy said.

Joe laughed. "Did you?"

Tommy broke into a wide grin. "Bug's gone, dude!" Mildly disappointed, he lifted his foot and tilted it for a look at the surprisingly small red dot.

"What now?" Tommy asked nonchalantly.

"Dunno," Joe answered.

Both boys looked bored. "Let's go play some videogames," Joe finally suggested.

Tommy agreed, but deep down wished he had kept the little bug around a little longer. He really had enjoyed the feeling it gave him to control the fate of something so puny and powerless.
1122111111212.title: Oops! Moment

1122111112.content:
The teenager was far removed from the tiny bug's world. Now, with the arrival of his friend distracting him, he just wanted to end the game.

He had no way of knowing the paralyzing fear his statement injected into the tiny man.

The few words continued to echo in the shrunken scientist's brain. "LOOKS LIKE THE END OF THE LINE!"

Frozen in place, he lifted his eyes to gaze beyond the massive magnifying glass held in the giant's mighty hand. He tried to make contact with the eyes in the huge face that he had known for so many years. "Tommy, please," he begged. "You can't kill me!"

He watched as the other titan moved around the room. Joe, his attention never quite focused on one thing at a time, nosed around in Mr. Smith's fridge.

When Tommy began to advance a fiery beam toward him again, the shrunken man did his best to run in a diagonal path across the wide corner of the kitchen table. The merciless titan, of course, proved quicker and cut off his path with a mere flick of his wrist, aiming the blazing beam of focused sunlight and driving it toward the stupid bug.

"Oh no!" The speck of a man screamed when Tommy anticipated his path. The rapidly advancing light blazed, forcing him to cover his eyes.

Joe, can of soda in hand, returned tableside to watch. He saw Tommy direct the red-hot beam of light squarely onto the teeny bug.

Mr. Smith produced a scream of anguish before he vaporized from the heat.

"YOU HEAR THAT?" Joe asked. "SOUNDED LIKE THAT LITTLE BUG SCREAMED."

Tommy snickered. "GUESS IT REGRETS CROSSING MY PATH."

Joe laughed in agreement and Tommy scanned the top of the kitchen table for any additional ants. Except for the blackened speck of ash, he didn't find any.
1122111112.title: ZAP!

choices: Exhaled and blew the charred bug off the table
Flicked the bug off the table
112211112.content:
Almost out of breath, his endurance near its limits, the tiny scientist rejoiced when he heard Tommny's comments.

"Yes, yes," shouted the bug-sized man. "Look closer!"

Suddenly, Tommy directed the beam of focused light toward him again. Shocked, the speck-sized man called forth enough of his energy reserves for one last evasion.

"I am freakin' bored, dude," Joe complained. When he looked down, he saw only a itty-bitty creature beneath his notice and barely worth the effort it would take to squish.

Tommy urged patience on his friend. "I just want to get a closer look at it."

"Fry the bastard already!" Joe demanded in exasperation.

Tommy hesitated. On the tabletop, the tiny man looked up at his ginormous neighbor. "No! Don't listen to him!" The tiny man screamed as he tried to make his muscles move. "Please, it's me! Mr. Smith!"

"It's just a freakin' bug!" Joe reiterated loudly.

When Tommy moved the massive magnifying glass, the little man saw the wide glass lens begin to focus the sunshine, building up a fiercely focused ray of death that glided across the tabletop toward him.

"No!" He ran, somehow able to move his legs, only to find himself engulfed in the scorching light.

Blinded, he felt his body sizzle. "Tommy! Stop!"

The shrunken scientist stumbled out of the tightly focused beam, falling on hands and knees, smelling a scorched scent.

He felt an intensity of pain, but played his last card, hoping if he remained motionless, Tommy would figure he had succeeded.

"Happy now?" Joe said.

Tommy lowered the magnifying glass, squinted to see if the toasted bug was still kicking. The speck of a man realized that he had to remain motionless even through the torture. He didn't even want to see how he had fared from the instant spent inside the column of fiery light. His hair still smoked where the beam had burned it almost to his scalp.

"I don't know," Tommy said. "Something still looks weird about it."

Joe grunted in disgust and...
112211112.title: Burned

choices: Not so lucky
Left alone
1122111121.content:
Tommy remained determined to get a closer look at the odd bug, despite his friend's growing impatience.

Joe grunted loudly in irritation. "You're crazy, man!"

The giant teenager bent closer, staring at the charred little bug. A gleam in his eyes, he sucked a defiant blast of air into his lungs.

Tiny Mr. Smith heard the rush of air being drawn into Joe's lungs, but he forced himself to remain absolutely still. If the titans thought he was still alive, they would surely finish him off.

"Wait!" Tommy shouted as he realized Joe's intent.

Ignoring his buddy, Joe exhaled forcefully. The gust of wind smashed into the nearly incinerated bug and blew the tiny creature over the edge of the table.

Joe, looking quite pleased with himself, looked at Tommy. "Now, can we bail from this place?"

Tommy thought of looking for the tiny bug, and did scan the floor near the table.

"Enough already," Joe complained.

Tommy sighed. "All right. I guess it was just a bug."

"Yeah, that's right," Joe said. "What else would it be?"

The two teenaged behemoths failed to notice the tiny, scorched form that had fallen painfully to the distant floor, and now hoped desperately to avoid their destructive feet long enough for them to make their exit.
1122111121.title: Blown Away

11221111211.content:
Against his expectations, the shrunken scientist survived the terrifying plunge to the distant kitchen tiles. He marveled at his good fortune until he realized that the “lucky break” represented merely more evidence of his transformed nature.

He thought of all the times he had observed tiny bugs and ants tumble from tables and counters, seemingly immune from any lethal consequences. Their salvation rested in their extremely tiny size and mass, however… a trait the former scientist now shared with them.

His most immediate need upon impact was to pull air into his lungs. The breath had been literally smashed out of his body after his inevitable contact with the floor. As he remained motionless, fighting for air, he pushed aside the pain of his burns.

He could, given enough time, recover from the burns. He idly wondered if the damage inflicted by his gigantic neighbor’s magnifying glass might leave scars.

He would gladly put the nightmare behind him, if only he could succeed in attracting Tommy’s attention without the terrifying possibility the teenager might mistake him for a real bug.

A fresh wave of pain blurred his vision, making him question why he had ever been so foolish to shrink down to such a small size, making himself totally powerless in a world populated by awesome giants that could destroy him in the blink of an eye and not even know it.

-----

Tommy took a few steps toward the table, making a cursory search for the strange little bug that his buddy had so inconveniently blown off the tabletop. Although his eyes fell on the very tile where the tiny man rested, the colossal teenager failed to notice the minuscule form.

“ALL RIGHT,” Tommy admitted to Joe. “IT MUST HAVE JUST BEEN A BUG.”

Joe snorted loudly. “WHAT ELSE COULD IT HAVE BEEN?”

In impatience, Joe began unconsciously tapping the toe of one of his sneaker on the tiles. “ARE WE FINISHED HERE?”

-----

Now breathing almost normally, the tiny man groaned painfully as he realized the imperative need to move out of range of the enormous shoes worn by Tommy and Joe. The two teenaged behemoths remained utterly unaware of the scorched “bug” desperately attempting to avoid their destructive feet. The tapping of the one giant's shoe on the tiles sent powerful vibrations and loudly distracted the little man's thoughts.

He watched as one of Tommy’s huge shoes sailed over him as the teenager moved toward the back door. “YEAH, LET’S GO.”

Energized at seeing his only hope depart, the bug-sized man scurried over the enormous kitchen tile. “Wait! Don’t go! Don’t leave me here!”

Tommy turned and saw Joe staring at the floor. His friend had detected a tiny form sprinting over the flat tile.

Joe, thinking fast and not wanting to alert his curious friend, lifted his Airwalk a few inches off the floor and maneuvered it over the ugly, burned bug.

“I’M RIGHT BEHIND YOU,” Joe said, letting his shoe drop on top of the location where he had seen the scurrying bug.

The sudden action took the tiny man by surprise. So intent on reaching Tommy, he had let himself forget about the presence of the second giant.

The Airwalk looked immense as it hovered only inches over him, blotting out most of the light in the room.
“No!” The tiny man screamed as the shoe dropped.

------

Joe could have ignored the bug and spared its life, but he didn’t want Tommy to see it and delay their departure because of his insistence that the “bug” looked strange.

Strange or not, it was just another bug, and Joe knew a thing or two about how to deal with bugs. In the yard, he did stop to scrape the bottom of his shoe against the edge of the sidewalk. Then he followed his friend back to his house.
11221111211.title: Dealing with bugs

choices: to smack against Tommy's shirt
To land on the floor between their feet
1122111122.content:
Holding himself perfectly still as the two titanic teenagers loomed over the kitchen table took every shred of willpower in the shrunken scientist's reserves.

The smell of burned hair and scorched skin increased his nausea. He wanted more than anything to crawl away and hide before the enormous teenagers inflicted another indignity or injury upon hide.

"THERE'S NOTHING WEIRD ABOUT IT," Joe snorted in disgust. He pulled back his finger and aimed at the scorched little form. He flipped the finger across the pad of his thumb, focused squarely on the motionless form.

Tiny Bryan, still intent on getting the giants to ignore him, opened his eyes just in time to see the onrushing finger. He didn't have time to move a muscle, not even the time to scream.

The giant flicked him casually, totally unaware of the inherent power his action delivered to the bug-sized man.

He was propelled into the air, hurtling through the enormous void of his gigantic kitchen.

The path from Joe's casual flick caused him...
1122111122.title: Flicked Off

choices: Bryan evades the gargantuan jab
Bryan is struck and falls backwards
11221112.content: Tommy smiled with childish amusement, moving the beam of light all around the sleek, black countertop. Suddenly, however, he came across something weird. Unlike all of the ants, this one wasn't black and didn't seem to crawl, but walk upright! "Totally cool," Tommy said. He reached out with a mammoth sized fingertip and prodded it.
11221112.title: Noticed

112211121.content:
Shrunken Bryan saw the approach of the massive fingertip, and quickly evaded curious Tommy's gargantuan jab by running to the right.

"OH, WELL," Tommy reacted to the tiny bug's evasive tactics. "IF YOU WOULD RATHER PLAY WITH MR. SUNBEAM..."

Tommy laughed as he once again began moving the giant magnifying glass, directing a fierce beam of light across the sleek, black countertop, closing the gap with the elusive and strange little ant.

Tiny Bryan realized he had made a huge blunder. Tommy had detected something strange enough to make him question his identification of his neighbor as a mere ant.

And, instead of embracing this chance for salvation, the shrunken man had fled like a fool!

The quarter-inch-tall man stopped and turned to face his titanic teenaged neighbor.

"Tommy!" Bryan screamed as loudly as possible.

His eyes strained to see past the dazzling pillar of intense, focused light bearing down on him.

As the teenager brought the tightly focused beam directly onto the weird bug, he waited expectantly for the inevitable result.

As for the tiny man, blinded by the light, he felt the sizzling of the air around him as the beam began to make his skin fry.

There was a very brief shriek that went unheard, followed by the usual sizzling pop as another little ant turned to a burnt crisp.

Shifting the magnifying glass to dissipate the beam of light and simply study the magnified view of the speck of blackened cinders, Tommy wondered again about the strange little bug.

"I'm sure there's more where it came from," he decided before shoving the lethal magnifying glass into his pocket.
112211121.title: Evasion but no escape

choices: Tommy as rescuer
Tommy as god
112211122.content:
Bryan felt like he had been struck by a tractor trailer truck when Tommy's blunt fingertip crashed into his meager body. The impact knocked the tiny man flat on his back and tossed him a good distance across the table's flat surface.

"WHAT THE—" Tommy muttered, his words a dull roar to the tiny man. He lowered the huge magnifying glass over the tiny sprawled figure for a better look.

The bug-sized man grew tired of beating his tiny fists futilely against the curved wall of glass.

His neighbor now looked like some colossal mountain of flesh, skin and muscle. Tommy placed the small glass container into one of the cupholders located between the seats of his car.

He smiled down at the imprisoned shrunken man, meaning to make him feel better about the situation.

Mr. Smith gazed through the distorting glass walls, which made Tommy's eyes look even larger.

"Tommy! Please, listen to me!" Unfortunately, due to the thick glass, the squeaks of protest from the speck of a man no longer reached his gigantic neighbor's ears.

From time to time, he looked up and could see the upper half of Tommy's body behind the steering wheel. Even from this limited perspective, Tommy still looked gigantic and all-powerful.

They didn't ride far. Tommy pulled the car into a space in the lot in front of the post office.

He looked down again at his tiny passenger. Every time he saw the tiny man, he felt strange. The situation, so unreal, produced a mix of feelings. Some protective and others... Well, the giant teenager didn't dwell too long on those fleeting thoughts of how huge he must appear to his neighbor.

The tiny man who was the object of Tommy's attention stared up, trying to determine what was happening.

"DON'T WORRY, MR. SMITH," Tommy said. "I JUST HAVE TO DROP YOUR PACKAGE IN THE MAIL, AND THEN WE'LL GET HOME AND FIGURE OUT SOMETHING TO DO WITH YOU."

The bug-sized man panicked, but his reaction was already too late. Without so much as another glance, Tommy left the car, slamming the door behind him.

Trapped like a bug in the glass container, the shrunken scientist realized how horribly his plan had gone astray. Without the antidote contained inside the package, he had no means of growing back to his normal size!

For the foreseeable future, he was trapped, reduced to the size of a lowly insect and utterly dependent on the whims of a humongous teenager. His brain went into overdrive with possible escapes from his nightmare.

If his nephew opened the package...

The tiny man rejected the avenue of deliverance. Even if Zack opened the package, he would never notice a tiny glass vial 20 times smaller than a grain of sand.

If he sent Tommy on a mission to EDL Labs to secure more of the antidote...

Impossible, the bug-sized scientist decided. The lab had far too much security in place for a mere teenager to circumvent.

"Oh my god," the speck of a man said aloud. "I'm stuck the size of a bug!"

About that time, Tommy returned to the car. After he slid behind the wheel, Tommy took time to reassure his itty-bitty neighbor.

"DON'T WORRY, MR. SMITH. THE PACKAGE IS ON ITS WAY!"

The little man felt his world falling apart. "What have I done?" Mr. Smith cried.

Tommy, oblivious to how his actions had just caused enormous consequences, smiled again as he stared into the glass jar at his puny neighbor.

"I CAN'T WAIT TO GET HOME," Tommy said...

"AND I AM SURE YOU WANT OUT OF THAT JAR," he added quickly.

1122111221121111.content:
In the last hour, tiny Mr. Smith had narrowly escaped being incinerated, crushed and frozen.

Now, the scientist, who had shrunk himself to the size of a grain of rice, found himself airborne thanks to a hurricane force gust of wind admitted into Tommy's home when the titanic teenager and his friend departed.

Then, as the force of the wind dissipated as the teens closed the doors behind them, the tiny man began plunging toward the distant floor.

He screamed as the kitchen tiles rushed to meet him. Because of his small size, he didn't fall at a lethal speed, but impact with the floor was something he would rather have avoided.

For a few moments, he could only lie sprawled on the floor, slowly regaining his strength. By the time he got onto his feet, he began to realize how Tommy's moment of carelessness had landed him in a gigantic world of hurt.

His fall had traded the bizarre landscape of the immense kitchen counter for the alien plain represented by dozens of massive kitchen tiles. At the center of the room, an impossible kitchen table looked like a surreal flat-topped mountain supported by four massive columns.

"Oh my god," the bug-sized man exclaimed, only for his desperate voice to be swallowed by the immense stillness of the room.

He had been completely helpless to prevent their departure, and now he realized his dilemma had increased exponentially. If Tommy and his friend returned, they would not realize that he was stranded on the floor.

The little man recalled how gargantuan an effort he had expended to make contact with Tommy in the first place.

He had been so sure that he was close to getting back to normal size when Tommy had noticed him. What was wrong with the kid? He didn't even seem to fathom how perilous the world could be for a man shrunken to the size of an insect.

Tommy, the kid next door that had been like a nephew to Mr. Smith for more than ten years, had rescued the shrunken scientist, but thanks to some careless decisions and an inability to truly appreciate the peril of his neighbor's situation, the teenager had promptly lost the tiny man.

The green tendrils flowing from the stadium-sized ceramic planter on the kitchen counter provided a ready-made network of cables perfect for climbing.

"I guess that makes Tommy the giant," he thought to himself.

Mr. Smith stopped and examined the strange filament anchored to the green branch. He followed it across the gulf to where it joined a criss-cross arrangement of other cables.

He studied the assembly of cords for a moment before he recognized the pattern.

"Oh no," the tiny man cried out. He looked around nervously, but seeing nothing he exhaled slowly.

If he had continued his climb, he could have easily stumbled into the silken trap. Although he didn't see any sign of a lurking spider, the jungle of green foliage suddenly looked more shadowy and sinister.

"I can't give up," the tiny man said aloud. Reaching the relative security of the lofty countertop at least got him into closer proximity with his titanic neighbor.

He saw that, by taking a detour to some other nearby branches, he could bypass the maze of silken cords.
